editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: ‚ùß The thre bokes of Cronicles, whyche Iohn Carion (a man ≈øyngularly well ≈øene in the Mathematycall ≈øciences) Gathered wyth great diligence of the be≈øte Authours that haue written in Hebrue, Greke or Latine. ‚úö

Whervnto is added an Appendix, conteynyng all ≈øuch notable thynges as be mentyoned in Cronicles to haue chaunced in ≈øundry partes of the worlde from the yeare of Chri≈øt. 1532. To thys pre≈øent yeare of. 1550.
Gathered by Iohn Funcke of Nurenborough.

div.head: ‚Ä¢ o the mo≈øte excellente Prince, Edwarde the ≈øyxte, by the grace of God, Kyng of England, Fraunce and Irelande, Defendour of the fayth, and in earth, immediatly vnder God, ≈øupreme head of the church of Englande and Irelande: your graces humble and obey≈øaunt ≈øubiect Gwalter Lynne wy≈øheth aboundance of all grace and Godlynes wyth a long and pro≈øperous raygne.
div.p: COn≈øyderyng that the knowledge of thynges pa≈øt (mo≈øt excellent prince) is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øarye for ≈øuch as woulde pa≈ø≈øe ouer the tyme to come in a decent and Godly order, and that the greate≈øt nombre of youre Maie≈øties people doo not vnder≈øtande other languages, then theyr naturall tounge:
I haue thought it my duetye (beynge one that ≈øpendeth all hys tyme in the ≈øettynge forth of bokes in the Engly≈øhe tounge) emonge≈øt all other to ≈øet forth thys ≈øhorte Cronicle.

Wherein is briefly declared all that is nedefull to be knowen, concernyng thynges done in tymes
pa≈ø≈øed. The learned haue „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the latyne tounge, and therfore my laboure maye ≈øeme the le≈ø≈øe profytable vnto them. But yet yf my knowledge would haue ≈øerued me to haue tran≈ølated it as eloqueÃÑtly as it is written in latyne: I doubt not but the learned al≈øo myghte haue founde ≈øome ≈øwetnes in my laboures. And not wyth≈øtandynge my rudenes (mo≈øt excellent Prynce) I tru≈øt your maie≈øtie wyll (after your accu≈øtomed clemencye) accept my good wyll, whyche thynge I do not doubte ≈øhall encourage all faythfull engly≈øhe men to embrace my laboures and gather the fruytes of the ≈øame. To pray≈øe the worcke which being ≈øet forth to be reade of all men wyll pray≈øe it ≈øelf, were but a labour halfe lo≈øte, for ≈øuch a thing nedeth no pray≈øe, but is ≈øo manife≈øtly good that all men that reade it ≈øhalbe forced to pray≈øe it. Other pray≈øe therfore I wyll not geue it, but that it is a worcke worthy the name of ≈øo excellent a prynce as your maye≈øtye is, and therfore worthy to be embraced of all your faythfull ≈øubiectes. Whyche thynge I mo≈øt hartely wy≈øhe to come to pa≈ø≈øe to the glorye of God, your Maie≈øtyes honour, and the profyte of all your faythfull ≈øubiectes. Sobeit.

closer.signed: Your Graces humble ≈øubiect and dayly Orator Gwalter Lynne‚ñ™

div.head:
The „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚Ä¢ eadynge hy≈øtoryes.
div.p: ALthough the readyng of Hy≈øtoryes be profytable to euery man in generall, for many cau≈øes as we hereafter ≈øhall declare: yet doth it chyefely belonge to kyngesHi≈øtories are bokes of kynges and prynces. and great men. And hy≈øtoryes maye worthely be called theyr bokes, becau≈øe that the knoweledge of them is profytable and nece≈ø≈øary for all them, whyche are ordeyned to rule a commune welth. For not onely the Heythen hy≈øtoryes do make euery where much mentyon of prynces, but al≈øo the hy≈øtoryes of holy ≈øcrypture.

For be≈øyde that, the holy ≈øcryptures do makeHi≈øtoryes of holy ≈øcrypture. mentyon of the wyll of God and of hys worde, and al≈øo of Chri≈øtes ≈øpyrytuall kyngdome, they teache al≈øo of polityke admini≈øtration, and ≈øet forth manye notable examples, whych are nece≈ø≈øary to be knowen in the gouernaunce of a commune weale, and by the whych, the myndes of Prynces may be ≈øturred and inflamed to the endeuour of ryght pryncely vertues.

The hy≈øtoryes of the Heythen, declare of theHi≈øtoryes of the Heythen. of≈øprynge and begynnynge of great realmes, and for what cau≈øes alteracyons and great chaunges do befall in realmes: be≈øides that, they do conteine al≈øo preceptes of vocatyens and powres, by the whych commune weales be ≈øtably≈øhed and pre≈øerued. And for thys cau≈øe chefely are hy≈øtoryes worthy to be called the bokes of great prynces and lordes.

Seinge now, that it is nece≈ø≈øary that euery man had nede of two maner of powers, namely, the politike or external, and be≈øide this by the faith and drede toward God, the examples of ether of them are propoundid and ≈øet before vs in the hi≈øtories. And that we maye fir≈øt ≈øpeake of ciuil powres, Princes, and all ≈øuche as are ≈øet to gouerne greate thynges, mu≈øt fyr≈øte and chefelye con≈øidre and beholde tho≈øeWhat mu≈øte be marked in the exaÃÑmples of princes. examples and hi≈øtories, by the which they maye be admoni≈øhed howe they al≈øo maye faithfully behaue them≈øelues in gouerning a coÃÑmune weale. In this mu≈øt they ≈øet befor them the examples of good princes and kinges, and mu≈øt learne of them by what meanes & wyth what vocacions chefely they haue v≈øed in gouernynge or rulinge empyres, that they haue had re≈øpect to nothinge ≈øaue only to the commune profyt, that they haue only con≈øidered and exerci≈øed iu≈øtice and equite, that they haue puni≈øhed greueou≈øly ≈øinne, that they haue not warred for euery cau≈øe, but that they haue oft kept peace by the polytyque forberynge of iniuryes. Al≈øo in theyr defence, they were of a doughtye and ≈øtronge courage, they haue v≈øed great gentylne≈ø≈øe and loyalte towarde the goode and peaceable. Fynallye they haue endeuoured to enuyrone their realmes wyth ≈øtronge fortre≈ø≈øes and greate powre, be≈øyedes the anauncemente of Godlyne≈ø≈øe and goode maners.

In the examples of tirauntes mu≈øt they marke ye What is to marked in ye examples of tirauntes. contrarye, namelye, that theyr endes were full of mi≈øerye, and by rea≈øon of theyr crueltye, per ‚Ä¢ y ‚Ä¢ yous: and ≈øoo there happened deadly alterations in
the commune weale. Of thys wy≈øe is it euident that Pharao pery≈øhed by rea≈øon of tyranny, and for lyke cau≈øe were the Romane kynges dryuen out. Oftymes al≈øo haue Princes vndone them≈øelues ech other by rea≈øon of pryde, enuy or hatred, the whych ≈øomtyme grew of a thynge of no value. Lyke as Pompeius had no cau≈øe to oppre≈ø≈øe Iulius Ce≈øar, ≈øaue only enuy. The lawes of ye Graccyans amonge the Romanes do beare wytne≈ø≈øe, that newe alteracyon or chaunge, doeth oft geue occa≈øyon of cruell warres. Nother hath the Turky≈øh empyre hys of≈øprynge by any other occa≈øyon, ≈øaue by here≈øy and di≈ø≈øentyon of learnynge and doctryne of the fayth. Daungerous con≈øpyracyons cau≈øe oft tymes that kyngdomes are ouerthrowen, the whyche wytne≈ø≈øeth the example of the Athenians, whyche lo≈øte theyr gouernaunce and goodes by rea≈øon of ≈øuch leagues as they had made. To ob≈øerue and marke ≈øuch thynges in readyng of hy≈øtoryes, doth greatly auayle them that beare rule, that thereby they maye learne to beware in theyr gouernaunce, le≈øt any ≈øuche lyke do befall: For ≈øuch ca≈øes do dayly befall. Yea though the per≈øons do ≈øomtyme chaunge in coÃÑmune welthes, neuerthele≈ø≈øe ≈øo much as is concernynge the equalytye of mattiers, the worlde is and alwayes abydeth lyke to hym≈øelfe.

Wherfore Thucydydes (whych was excellentThe ≈øay ≈øayeng of Then cidides coÃÑcerning hi≈øtories both in knowledge of Martyall affayres, and had him≈øelfe endured a great & contynuall warre, the which he him ≈øelfe wrote, wyth dyuers other thinges) ≈øaid mo≈øt truely: Hi≈øtories is a trea≈øure which
neuer ought to be layde out of our handes: that w ‚Ä¢ beinge holpen by the ≈øame, may the more commody ou≈øly in treat of the affaires that for the moo≈øt part in the commune welth. So noble a trea≈øure verely are hi≈øtories, by ye which that they that haue gouernaunce of the commune welche, are aduerty≈øed of ≈øundry publyke matters.

Be≈øydes the≈øe al≈øo are ther founde in hi≈øtoryesHow hy≈øtoryes do profy ‚Ä¢ e prynate „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . ≈øuch examples, which do profet euery priuate per≈øon ≈øeuerally, ≈øuch as the≈øe be: The magi≈øtrate mu≈øt be obeyed. They, which rebelled again≈øt the higher powers, were neuer vnpuni≈øhed, as Ab≈øalon, Catilma, Brutus, Ca≈ø≈øius and ≈øuch like that were therfore puni≈øhed. Of faithfulne≈ø≈øe of frendes, as Ionathas, which ≈øaued the life of Dauid. Of the puni≈øhment for aduoutry and ≈øuche like wicked dedes, as it appeareth by ye example of Dauid. What nedeth many wordes euen as in al ≈øciences are ≈øet forth examples to be folowed: ≈øo are in hi≈øtories ≈øet forth & painted examples of al kind of vertues. Yee and in examples and thinges coÃÑmitted is more euidently ≈øene the worthine≈ø≈øe of vertues, yea & al≈øo of what vnclenne≈ø≈øe and di≈øhone≈øty vices are, than in preceptes or doctrinees: Becau≈øe that examples being ≈øet before vs as images, do not only teache openly, but do al≈øo admoni≈øh, ≈øturre, and inflame the myndes yt are hone≈øtly brought vp, that they maye be kindled toward vertues and hone≈øty with a certain ple≈øur and loue. For who could be ≈øo cruel of minde, which ≈øhulde not be moued, yf he did reade ≈øome excellent and laudable dede, or an example of vengeaunces.

I haue brefely ≈øhewed, how the examples of politike
vertues and ciuill cau≈øes mu≈øt be ob≈øerued inA Chri≈øtenman mu≈øte ≈øearche the commaundementes of ≈øayth and feare out of hy≈øtoryes. readynge of hi≈øtories: Nowe doth it pertayne to a Chri≈øtenman, to whome godlyne≈ø≈øe appertayneth that he maye knowe that out of hi≈øtoryes are to be gathered in≈øtructyons of fayth and feare of God. For the≈øe are the chefe≈øte vertues of Godlye men, that are allowed before God. And thoughe the hy≈øtoryes of the Gentyls do not teache vs that God careth for vs, or that God worketh wyth vs: a godlye harte neuerthele≈ø≈øe ≈øhall marke thys, namelye, how commune welthes are kept and pre≈øerued in the worlde from heauen, and that it is the workinge and dede of God, to reuenge violence and wronge, and that God doth oftentimes di≈øtribute hys excellente vertues amonge the Heythen. For princes can not kepe their kingdomes again≈øt Satan, without the ≈øingular benefite of god, & the aide or a≈ø≈øi≈øtauÃÑce of great vertues. And of this wi≈øe ≈øhal the mind of a godly man think by him≈øelf, that ≈øuch notable actes & puni≈øhmentes are the worck of god and ≈øhal by them learne to fear God, that is to ≈øaye, that tiraunces are greueou≈øly puni≈øhed, according to that ≈øentence: he that taketh the ≈øword, (that is, he that taketh vpon hym the authoryte of vengeaunce, without a commauÃÑdement,) the ≈øame ≈øhal peri≈øh with y‚Ä¢ ≈øword. Contrary wi≈øe maie be ≈øene al≈øo that good princes are kept and pre≈øerued of God: & the ≈øame haue the heithen perceued al≈øo, ye princes do re≈øt vpon the aid of the goddes. For Homer the poet ≈øayeth, that God holdeth for the hys ≈øhyide in battail, to defend princes. He faineth al≈øo that euerye prince is in ≈øauegard by the defence of his god,
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
as it appeareth that the godde≈ø≈øe Pallas was wyth Achilles in battayll. &c.

Althe≈øe thinges are moo≈øt clerely expre≈ø≈øed in y‚Ä¢ hi≈øtories of the holy ≈øcripture, as in Abraham, Dauid, Ezechias and other kinges, whome God hath defended. And their examples are prepounded to euery prince, yt they may be a≈ø≈øured that god doth of likewi≈øe defeÃÑde the good. For the hi≈øtories of holyThe di≈øtreÃÑce of holy and proph ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ hi≈øtories. men and Heithen men do differ in that, that in y‚Ä¢ hi≈øtories of holy men are ≈øet forth and declared the witne≈ø≈øes of Gods workes, the which al≈øo do not only treat of politike matters, but do chefely ≈øhadowe and declare vnto vs Gods kingdome, that God geueth his worde, that frely and of mercye he will ≈øaue: the which thing the hi≈øtories of the Gentiles can not ≈øpeake of.

Therfore ought euery Chri≈øten man chefely to know the holy ≈øcripture, that out of them they mayWhat holy hi≈øtories do teache. learne the doctrine and confirmation of faith. Fir≈øt how al thinges are created of God, how ≈øinne dyd beginne, that Chri≈øte hath ≈øet vp his kingdomes again≈øt ≈øinne, that he hath geueÃÑ his word, that Chri≈øte was promi≈øed, and that he is come to abandon ≈øinne and to ≈øaue vs. Item how God, whan he had geuen his word, hath alway pre≈øerued and maintened Chri≈øtes kingdome, and that Chri≈øtes kingdome, that is the true beleuing, haue alway ben coÃÑ uer≈øaunt vnder the cro≈ø≈øe ≈øence the beginninge of y‚Ä¢ worlde, and yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe are ≈øaued, that Satan with the greate≈øt power of the world hath a≈ø≈øaulted the word of God. Item that God hath woÃÑ derfully alway kept his promi≈øe, aboue the vnder≈øtandynge
and thought of mens wit or wi≈øedome. Item that God hath ≈øet before vs bothe the examples of his dredefull vengeaunce, and al≈øo of grace or fauour. Of this wi≈øe haue king Dauid and other gotten remi≈ø≈øion and forgeuene≈ø≈øe of ≈øinnes, that by theyr examples we may be comforted, and beleue that God wil forgeue. Nether is y‚Ä¢ to be omitted, that God hath geuen vs al maner of prophecyes of exterior kingdomes, to ≈øtabli≈øh our mindes, that of the accompli≈øhment of their chaunce, we myghte haue wytne≈ø≈øe, that our word is come of God, and that none other faith ≈øaueours is true. Item that we ≈øhuld be warned whan Chri≈øte mu≈øte come, and whan the ende of the worlde is to be loked for. IteÃÑ for ≈øo muche as we knowe that all thynges ≈øpoken of in the prophetes are come to pa≈ø≈øe, that we may beleue, that tho≈øe ≈øhall happen al≈øo, the which holye ≈øcripture ≈øayeth ≈øhall befal.

Moreouer to vnder≈øtande prophecyes arighte, it is greatlye nece≈ø≈øary to knowe the order of kingdomes, the nombre of the yeares, and many other thynges, whyche in readynge of Heathen hy≈øtoryes do offer them ≈øelues: the knowledge whereof is chefelye nece≈ø≈øarye for Chry≈øten men, that they may the better vnder≈øtande the propheties, and haue the better iudgment of them.

Of all thys truely maye euery man iudge, how muche profyte is taken oute of the readynge of hy≈øtoryes, and the greate profyte or frute that commyth of them ought dylygently to ≈øteare and driue euery man to knowe them.

div.head: After what order hy≈øtoryes mu≈øt be comprehended and red.
div.p: HE that wyll reade hy≈øtoryes to profyt, the ≈øame mu≈øt comprehende all the tymes ≈øence the foundacyon of the worlde into a certayne order. For there were ≈øome that diuyded the worlde therfore in ≈øeuen ages, and haue rekened them diuer≈øly: but tho≈øe, where they endeuour to ≈øett an order, they do nothynge but ≈øett all thynges wythout order. As for me, I wyll folow the renowmed ≈øayenge of Ely the prophet, whych hath excellently dyuyded the worldeEly hath dyuyded the wo ‚Ä¢ lde into „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ages. into thre ages wyth the whyche he ≈øheweth the greate≈øt chaunges of the worlde: al≈øo what tyme it behoued Chri≈øt to come, and how longe thys ≈øtate of the world ought to la≈øt, and thus it is.

div.head: The ≈øayenge of Helias hou≈øe.
div.p: THe worlde ≈øhall ≈øtande ≈øyxe thou≈øand yeres and after ≈øhall it falle.
Two thou≈øande yeares wythout the Lawe.
Two thou≈øande yeares in the lawe.
Two thou≈øande yeares the tyme of Chri≈øt.
And yf the≈øe yeares be not accomply≈øhed, oure ≈øynnes ≈øhall be the cau≈øe, whyche are greate and many.

That is to ≈øaye, the worlde ≈øhall ≈øtande two M. yeres without any pre≈øcript admyni≈øtration, & certayn lawe of the word of God: but whan the≈øe be gone, there ≈øhalbe geuen the circumcy≈øyon and
lawe: be≈øydes thys ≈øhall a certayne polytique lawe and ≈øeruice of God be in≈øtitute out of Gods worde, and thys ≈øtate ≈øhall la≈øte two thou≈øande yeares. After thys ≈øhall Chri≈øt folowe, and the tyme of the go≈øpell ≈øhall lykewy≈øe ≈øtande aboute two thou≈øande yeares: but here ≈øhall ≈øome yeares want. For God ≈øhall wyth the hay≈øte of hys commynge preuent it, that the yeres of this age ≈øhal not be accompli≈øhed, the whiche Chri≈øte hym≈øelfe in the, xxiiii. chapiter of. S. Matthewe, ≈øayeth: Wythoute tho≈øe dayes had ben ≈øhortened, all fle≈øhe ≈øhulde not be ≈øaued.

We ≈øhall in wrytynge of the hy≈øtorye v≈øe thys order,The fyr≈øt age. and diuide the boke in thre partes, whereof the fyr≈øt ≈øhal comprehende tho≈øe thinges, which are chaunced betwene the tymes of Adam and Abraham. For tho≈øe are the fyr≈øte thou≈øande yeares: Of the≈øe is not much written, but ≈øuche thynges as are moo≈øt worthy of memory, and of the≈øe times, there is no certainte, but of that which is found wrytten in the Byble.

The nexte age of two thou≈øand yeares, ≈øhalbeThe ≈øecond age. counted from Abraham, vntill Chri≈øtis commyng: all though concerninge to the full numbre of the yeares, the tyme is not accomply≈øhed. For as we haue ≈øayde before, God maketh hay≈øt to the latter day. As for thys age, is the propre and bery age of the worlde, in the which the moo≈øt myghtye kyngdomes and monarchies haue ≈øucceded ech other by a certayn order: nether hath the worlde euer ≈øo declared hys force and myght, as in this age. Wherfore we ≈øhall deuide thys tyme in foure monarchyes. For it ≈øemeth, that God wolde the worlde to be
maintened by a certaine gouernaunce in hys place, that a certen means of ≈øhame and hone≈øty might be con≈øeruid, and the wicked mighte be puni≈øhed, and for that cau≈øe hath he in≈øtitute Monarchies. Such Monarchies are kingdomes, where the chefe andWhat Monarchyes ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , and of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ hat pup≈ø
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . vpper power of al thinges pertaineth to one alone for the con≈øeruation of commune peace and ryght. Such a monarchy was of ≈øo great pui≈ø≈øaunce, that the exterior of foren kinges, could not with≈øtande or oppre≈ø≈øe it. And by a certain ordinary ≈øucce≈ø≈øionThere ‚Ä¢ e only ‚Ä¢ oure Monarchyes. were only four ≈øuch monarchies. The fyr≈øt was of the A≈ø≈øirians, y‚Ä¢ ≈øecond of the Per≈øians, after them the Grekes, at the la≈øt y‚Ä¢ Romanes. And to the honor of ≈øuch an empire or ≈øuperiorite, hath God exaltedThe honor of the Em
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ re remay
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ h by the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ s. y‚Ä¢ Germanes before other nations in the≈øe latter times. For though the Roman empire be ≈øome deal mini≈øhed now a daies:) for as it was prophecyed before it was y‚Ä¢ plea≈øure of god that y‚Ä¢ monarchies ≈øhuld finally decay) neuerthele≈ø≈øe the maie≈øty remaineth by the Romane empire, nether is ther any king, but he hath a re≈øpect towardes yt kingdome. Moreouer though we haue not alway alyke mighty Emperoures, neuerthele≈ø≈øe God prouidinge ≈øo, there happeneth ≈øomtime an Emperour of ≈øuch power, yt the maie≈øty of the empire may be con≈øerued: and that to hold vp the religion and concorde of al natyons. The Germane princes, and chefely the electors ought to e≈øtime grearly this their honour, that they haue ≈øuch high autoritye coÃÑmitted them of God, to pre≈øerue religyon, iu≈øtice and commune peace. For verely, it is of great force that thys monarchy be pre≈øerued, thoug it be not ≈øo very great. Therfore ought y‚Ä¢ princes to beware, le≈øt ther ry≈øe
any ≈øedes of ≈øedition & di≈øcord among them, which might geue occa≈øion to cau≈øe this empire to decay. For whan this empire, wyich is the head of al good gouernaunce or admini≈øtratioÃÑ in the worlde now aThe empyre mu≈øt be ≈øaued and kept by all meanes. daies, ≈øhuld be diuided, pulled a≈øunder or wai≈øted, it could not be but that ther ≈øhuld folowe a perturbation of al degrees in euery part of Chri≈øtendom: the which is gretly to be doubted, without God do preuent ≈øuch mi≈øery with his la≈øt coÃÑming. For holy ≈øcripture doth coÃÑforte vs, & teach openly, that after yt this Germaine empire ≈øhal decay & faile, yt latter day ≈øhal ≈øtraight waye folowe. This is ≈øufficient to be ≈øpoken of monarchies, le≈øt any man be ignoraunt that al hi≈øtories, and al thinges done in the world, mu≈øt be referred to the≈øe monarchies. And be≈øides that y‚Ä¢ ob≈øeruing of the order doth ayde y‚Ä¢ memory it doth al≈øo not a litle helpe thervnto, yt one may ≈øe how & for what cau≈øes kingdomes are chaunged: wherby is to be learned how al tho≈øe things are to be e≈øchued, which coÃÑmunely bring chauÃÑges of kingdomes. The la≈øt age froÃÑ y‚Ä¢ natiuite of Chri≈øt vntyll the worldes ende, doth like wi≈øe contayne two M.The thyrd age. yeres, although we haue ≈øaid before, that the yeres of this age ≈øhulde not be whole, that the two thou≈øand yeres may be complete. This ≈øeÃÑtence of Elias truely conteineth many notable doctrines, & is chefely to be con≈øidered therfore, becau≈øe that from the natiuite of Chri≈øte, it ≈øpeaketh al≈øo of that tyme, in the whiche the ende of al thinges is to be loked for, and therefore haue‚ñ™ I ≈øett it in the begynnynge of the boke, that it myghte be commytted to euery mans hearing. But howe that the Rhomane
monarchye dyd begynne after the incarna ‚Ä¢ yon of Chri≈øt, and how the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion came to the Germanes, al≈øo how the Mahomety≈øh or Turky≈øh empire beganne, and howe the Popy≈øhne≈ø≈øe hath gotten encrea≈øe offoren power, all the≈øe thynges ≈øhall we ≈øhewe in thys thyrde parte. But thys al≈øo is chefely to be noted with diligence in readyng of hi≈øtories,The kyngdome of the worlde and Chri≈øtes Kyngdome‚ñ™ that God hath in≈øtitute two maner of kyngdomes: the one a worldly kingdome the other a kyngdome of Chri≈øt: and therefore it is nece≈ø≈øary to marke here‚ñ™ howe that the churche hath begonne euen from the begynnynge of the worlde, and by whatt maner God hath alwayes kept her. Therfore that godly myndes maye haue a confyrmation of theyr fayth, we ≈øhall note by the ≈øtate the tyme of eche of the kingdomes, where and by whome the kyngdome of Chri≈øt was, and what ≈øtate it was in than: the knowledge of whiche thinge, bringeth no ≈ømall profite to godlye readers.
Adam is ≈øett in a Parady≈øe of plea≈øure, to whome is forbyden the tree of lyfe. Gene≈øis. ij.
Adam and Heua are deceyued by the ≈øuttelty of the ≈øerpent. Thence comthe tran≈øgre≈ø≈øyon of the commaundement, and Synne.

div.head: The fir≈øte boke of the Cronicles, whych conteyneth the fyr≈øte two thou≈øande yeares, From Adam vntyll Abrahams tyme.
div.p: HOly ≈øcrypture doeth teache vs,Adam and Heua. that God created heauen and earth, after that man, Adam and Heua, and ≈øat them in parady≈øe, that is, that they beynge ≈øet oute of daunger of death and ≈øynne, mighte lyue in the earth happely: but when they forgat the commaundement of God geuen, they fell into the daunger of ≈øynne and death. But fora≈ømuch as all this is clearly written in the holy Bible, out of the whiche they oughte to be learned, it is invaine to ≈øpeake thereof here: it is ≈øufficient onelye to aduerti≈øh the reader, that the worlde ≈øtandeth by the≈øe beginninges, and that Adam and Heua are created of God, whyche are the of≈øpringe of all mankinde.

Moreouer, about the very time of creation, dydThe in≈øtitution of ciuill power and of all lawes. God in≈øtitute the ciuyll adminy≈øtratyon, when he gaue Adam power ouer all tho≈øe thynges, that are in the earth and ≈øea, that he ≈øhoulde v≈øe them, and ≈øhould ≈øett a good order in all tho≈øe thinges that are exteriour. That commaundemente of God is the ≈øpringe and beginninge of all lawes, and what≈øoeuer ciuile ordinaunces there are, are begonne of it, the whiche are approued and alowed of God, by rea≈øon of this commaundemente geuen to Adam.
The churche hath her begynnynge here al≈øo: ForThe beginninge of the churche. the commaundemente, wherein they ≈øhoulde exercy≈øe theyr fayeth, and feare before God, was here geuen: but whan they began to ≈øynne, hath God di≈øclo≈øed the power of Sathan, and again≈øt it hath promy≈øed the Go≈øpell or glad tydynge of the womans ≈øede, that is of Chri≈øte, that Chri≈øte ≈øhoulde come, and way≈øt Sathans kyngdome, and ≈øhoulde delyuer vs from ≈øynne and death into liberte.

Thys was the fyr≈øt preachinge of the Go≈øpell, whiche beganne the churche and Chri≈øtus kyngdome.The fyr≈øte preaching of the Go≈øpell. For in the churche mu≈øte not onely be preached the commaundementes of good workes, but al≈øo the forgeuene≈ø≈øe of ≈øynnes by Chri≈øt: for thereby onelye are we reconciled to God, and endure agayn≈øt death and all maner of temtation, whan by fayth we take the promy≈øe of forgeuene≈ø≈øe of ≈øynnes: And of thys wy≈øe toke Adam and Heua con≈øolacion out of the word that Chri≈øte was promy≈øed, and of the≈øe two per≈øons is the churche fyr≈øte begonnne. Be≈øyde thys was it nece≈ø≈øary al≈øo, theyThe begynnyng of temporall afflic
‚Ä¢ ions. ≈øhould ≈øuffer temporall afflictions: for they were dryuen out of parady≈øe: that is, they were ≈øubiecte to death, and all maner of other my≈øeries, and ≈øo lyued theyr dayes in laboure and trauayl in that lande, which the Iewes po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed afterwarde. For it is written, that they were created by the cytye Dama≈øcus.

div.head: Of Cain and Abel.
div.p: SCrypture ≈øayth that Adam and Heua broughte forth children, and that Cain ≈ølewe hys brother Abel. And here begynneth the per≈øecution of the ≈øayntes of the wicked men, and is and example very dredefull. For thys man≈ølaughter happened for none other cau≈øe,Per≈øecution for the true gods ≈øeruice than for y‚Ä¢ ≈øeruice of god, the which, whan it is done purely, Sathan can not abyde it: for the whyche cau≈øe he ≈øturreth Cain to ≈ølaye his brother, that the worde of God and ≈øyncere doctrine maye be quenched. And this dede ≈øheweth howe vehement is the ire of Sathan and rage: al≈øo what mannes fraylne≈ø≈øe and blindne≈ø≈øe is. There are by the waye rehear≈øed in this hi≈øtory weyghty and graue preachinges of the iudgement of Chri≈øt to come, of the dredefull vengeaunce for ≈øheddinge of bloude, the whiche to rehear≈øe here, were to longe.

Cain after that he fled hys fathers ≈øight, he beganThe cytye Enoch. to buylde the citye called Enoch. Hys chyldren inuented all maner of handycraftes and ≈øciences. Finally for the man≈ølaughter was he puni≈øhed, for he dyed a lyke kynde of death.

div.head: Of Seth.
div.p:
AFter this was Seth boren to Adam. thys man beynge famous and renomed for his endeuour of hone≈øt and godlyne≈ø≈øe enforced after Abel to auaunce and augment Gods kyngdome. Of this Seth were afterward engendred holy fathers, and the remnaunt of
thys kynred remayned: But the po≈øterytie of Cain was whole drowned in the floude. Io≈øephus wytne≈ø≈øethAdam and Seth finders of ≈øciences. that Adam and Seth made two tables, the one of bra≈ø≈øe, the other of ≈øtone, and that in them wer grauen the worde of God and prophe≈øyes, by the whiche the worde of God was kepte. He wryteth moreouer, that they diuided the yeare into twelue monethes, and that they ob≈øerued fyr≈øte the cour≈øe of ≈øtarres and taught it. For it had not bene po≈ø≈øible, that the minde of man coulde haue attayned to the ≈øearching of ≈øo high and wounderfull things, without God had opened them the knowledge of them. Wherfore to Adam and Seth we mu≈øt a≈øcribe the word of god, the figures of the letters and the greate≈øt ≈øciences. Ther are al≈øo many witne≈ø≈øes among the Grekes, that the writinge and all ≈øciences are come of the Iewes aunceters. For Herodotus writeth in his fyfte boke, that the Grekes haue receaued theyr ≈øciences and letters of the Phenices.

The age of Adam was nyne hundreth and thirty yeares, and reached vntill the time of Noes father: but he dieth hundreth and. 26. yeares before Noe was borne. But in this tyme is written to be happened nothinge worthy of rehear≈øall, vntyll Noes tyme, ≈øaue only genealogy: that in the meane whyle we maye know ≈øurelye, of whom it behoued Chri≈øt to be borne. But neuerthele≈ø≈øe by the waye maketh ≈øcripture mention of the death of Enoch,Enoch is an ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ mple of euerla≈øtyng lyfe. that he be taken vp by God: the whiche dede God hath ≈øett before the worldes eyen, that it mighte know and beleue that there is immortalitie after thys lyfe, and that God ≈øhall iudge, and ≈øaue the
good truely, but puni≈øh the wycked.

div.head: Of the Floud.
div.p:
THE ≈øcripture maketh mention that the worlde was puni≈øhed of God, and ioyneth therto the occa≈øions thereof, namely that it begann to peier: and amonge the chefe≈øt of the euels are named the de≈øpi≈øynge of God, aduoutry and tyranny, in the which is v≈øed all maner of wylfulne≈ø≈øe and wantonne≈ø≈øe. For of this wy≈øe ≈øaieth the text: The childeren of holy men beganne to becomeGene. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ tyrauntes vpon earth, by the which is ≈øignified, that whan Gods worde was de≈øpi≈øed and hys wor≈øhyp, they liued vnmaneredly and an vnbrydeled lyfe, they oppre≈ø≈øed the weake and poore, accordinge to their plea≈øure, and v≈øed wylfulne≈ø≈øe of rulinge as they would. For cau≈øe of the≈øe thinges did God threaten the worlde wyth the floude: and before the ≈øame ≈øhould come, he wylled Noe to preach it an hundreth yeare before, that ≈øome beynge conuerted, mighte be ≈øaued.

Whan Noe was ≈øixe hundreth yeare olde, came the floude, and accordinge to Goddes commaundement, went he into the arcke with his wyfe and his thre ≈øonnes Sem, Cham and Iaphet, taking with them their wiues, and was ≈øaued. The re≈øidue of men and bea≈øtes hath the floude taken awaye and de≈øtroied. And are from the creation of the world, vntyll the tyme of the floude, thou≈øand, ≈øixe hundreth and ≈øixe and fiftye yeares.

div.head: Of the tyme after the Floude.
div.p:
WHan Noe had now ben aboue an half yeare in the arcke, and that the floud myny≈øhed, the arcke re≈øted vpon the hyghe≈øthyl of Armenia: and after the yeres ende, whan the earth beganne to drye, Noe was commaunded of God to leaue the arcke, wherein he had now ben a whole yeare. Than dyd God ordeine as it were a new worlde agayne. For fyr≈øt he gaue hys worde, by the which he promy≈øed not to drowne the world agayne, and in token of certayntye, he gaue the Raynebowe, which ≈øhulde admony≈øh vs of the promy≈øe made: and of thys wy≈øe hath he ≈øet before vs tokens of beneuolence and mercy, to exercy≈øe the fayth: He hath al≈øo than permitted the lybertye to
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ e of fle≈øh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øt „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ed cate fle≈øh, the which the holy fathers before the floude dyd neuer v≈øe. Be≈øyde thys gaue God a new commaundement of outwarde admini≈øtration, and commaunded more playnly that man≈øleyers ≈øhoulde lykewy≈øe be putt to death, by tho≈øe,The example of vengeaunce. that be lawfullye permittted, that is by the officers. Of thys wy≈øe than is a new ≈øtate of the worlde ordeyned agayn.

All the≈øe thynges haue I brefely recyted, ≈øpecially that euery man may call to minde, and waye by hym≈øelfe, how great Gods wrath is for ≈øynne. For God would cau≈øe the worlde to be more ware by this example, becau≈øe he wyliudge and auenge: it is al≈øo ≈øhewed that God ≈øhall once iudge the whole worlde, for he will not that ≈øynne be vnreuenged
or vnpuni≈øhed. Some haue written, that ≈øeynge the worlde hath fyr≈øt be drowned with waters, it maye be gathered by naturall rea≈øons, that it ≈øhall after thys be con≈øumed wyth fyre. Yea and this is worthy to be marked, that they whiche belong to god, are kept of him, though they be few, abiect and de≈øpi≈øed.

This is al≈øo to be noted in thys place, that the ciuyll power is ordeined, and puni≈øhment for man≈ølaughter. For that is nerehande the heade of all ciuill exerci≈øe of iu≈øtice, after the which all other ca≈øes and tre≈øpaces ought to be iudged.

div.head: Of the Tower of Babel.
div.p: AFter the floude whan mankynd was now encrea≈øed, the Tower of Babel, and the citie of Babilon was begon to be buylded by the Chaldees, that they might begyn a kyngdome ther, and ≈øubdue to them other nations or people. But thys enterpry≈øe hath God ouerthrowen: For whan they all v≈øed before one language, it befell that after the commune ≈øpeche was chaunged,The proprietye of ≈øpeches. they ≈øpake one one maner of language, another another, ≈øo that they vnder≈øtode not eche other. Wherfore there was a diui≈øion of ≈øpeches, and the worke it ≈øelfe was left vnperfect. The po≈øterite of Noe than was ≈øtrowed here and ther in the world, the which the fygure folowynge ≈øhall declare.

Sem the elde≈øt ≈øonne of Noe, of who≈øe kynredSem. is Chri≈øte, hath wyth hys childeren po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed
that parte of Siria, whiche is towarde the Ea≈øte. For of Aram hys ≈øonne, came the Syrians: of A≈ø≈øur, came the A≈ø≈øyrians: of Arphaxat, came the Chaldeis: of Elam are the Per≈øyans ≈øpronge.Cham.

Cham the ≈øeconde ≈øonne of Noe, hath optayned that countrye, whyche goeth towarde the South. Of Canaan, are come the Chananeis: of Mizraim, came the Egyptyans: of Chus, came the Ethiopians: of Saba, came the Arabians.Iaphet.

Iaphet the longe≈øt ≈øonne of Noe went to the North and We≈øt, and this is the father of vs all, and therefore his name founde by the Poetes, whych haue called him Iapetus. Of his ≈øonne Iauan or Iaon are the Grekes, whiche are called Iones:Iones are ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ fyr≈øte „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ s. for they be the fir≈øt Grekes. And the voice Ianan or Iaon, is no doute the ≈øame, whom the Latines do call Ianus.Wherfore Ianus hath „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ lages.

They v≈øed to paynte him with a double vy≈øage, before and behinde, becau≈øe that of hym be ≈øprouge both the nations, the Grekes and the Latines: and as oft they would begynne any thinge, they wor≈øhipped him wyth a ≈øpngulare honour, by the whyche they wytne≈ø≈øed that they countedThe Macedones. Iaon their father. Iaons ≈øonne was Cethim, of whome are called the Macedones, and thys confyrmeth the fyr≈øte boke of the Machabees, and the worde Machetim ≈øygnifyeth in Hebrue of Cethim, of the whiche is ≈øpronge the worde Macedo. For Stephanus the expounder of Greke wordes, wryteth that the auncient dyd ≈øaye Macetis.

Iaon had manye chyldren, Eli≈øa and Dodanim, of the whiche haue their beginninge the AeolesAeoles. or Hellas and the Dodoneies: all the≈øe are the fir≈øt of the Grekes. Of Tar≈øis Iaons ≈øonne, is Thar≈øus in Cilicia called.

Iaphet had other chylderen al≈øo, Gomer, Magog, Tyras and Me≈øech. Of Gomer are the Cunerij or Cimbry as witne≈ø≈øeth Eu≈øebius. Of A≈øcanes Gomers ≈øonne came the Tui≈øcones, that is, the Germanes. Of Magog are ≈øpronge theThe Germanes. Scythe, and of them are begonne the Turkes. Of Thyras come the Thraces. I haue brefelye ≈øhewed what part of the worlde eche of Noes chylderen hath po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, the which doeth greately auayle better to vnder≈øtande many hy≈øtoryes.

div.head: Of the fyr≈øt Monarchye.
div.p:
THat it maye be vnder≈øtande how the worke of God mu≈øte be knowen and honored in tho≈øe thynges that the magi≈øtrate or ≈øuperiorite doeth: we haue aduerty≈øed before in the preface, that God willed to entertayne the world by foure Monarchies, to the intent that policye, iu≈øtice and correction mighte be entertayned amonge men: for this cau≈øe are many thyngesThe foure Monarchies are propo≈øed to Daniel. Dan. ij. ≈øpoken here and there of the≈øe Monarchies in holy ≈øcripture God hath propo≈øed them to Daniel two maner of waye: Fir≈øt vnder the figure of a greate man, who≈øe heade was golden, the bre≈øt of ≈øyluer, the belly of copper, the legges of yron, the fete partely
of earth, partly al≈øo of yron. And le≈øt we ≈øhould not know, that then finally ≈øhal y‚Ä¢ end of the world be, there is added, how that the ≈øtone Chri≈øt doeth breake his fete, that the man hym≈øelf do fall, and ≈øo do the world cea≈øe.

Daniel hym ≈øelf hath expounded this vi≈øion of the foure monarchies. For he ≈øaieth that the head doth ≈øignifie the fir≈øt kyngdome, that is, the Monarchie of the A≈ø≈øyrians. The bre≈øt of ≈øiluer, ≈øygnifieth the kyngdome of the Per≈øians. The belly of copper, ≈øignifyeth the kyngdome of the Grekes. The legges of yron ≈øignifyeth the kyngdome of the Romanes. The fete of yron and earth, ≈øignifyeth the ≈øtate of the Empire of Rome at this tyme, namely that now a dayes is much le≈ø≈øe and weaker, than it was wont to be.

The foure bea≈øtes ≈øhewed vnto Daniel do al≈øo pretende the≈øe foure kyngdomes. The Lyone≈ø≈øe, ≈øygnifyeth the force of the A≈ø≈øyrians. The Beere ≈øygnifieth the Per≈øian empyre. The Leoparde ≈øignifieth Alexander. By the fourth bea≈øt are the Romanes ≈øignifyed. And there is added that be≈øyde the Romaine empyre there ≈øhall ry≈øe an other empyre full of cruelne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øuche one that ≈øhall make a new lawe agayn≈øt Gods worde: And that is the Mahometi≈øh and Turky≈øh empyre now a dayes. God wyll haue vs ≈øo truely warned, that as we knowe the hi≈øtories of al the worlde, we ≈øhould con≈øyder that the tyme of fini≈øhyng be not farre of, and that of this wi≈øe we ≈øhould haue wherewith to confirme our faith.

In the Bible it is manife≈øt, that the fyr≈øt kingdome beganne by Nemrod amonge the Babylonians, and the ≈øcripture calleth him a valyaunt hunter before God, that is, a mighty prynce, which wyth force ≈øubdued men to obeye. And he isNemroth Gods hunter. called a hunter before the Lorde, as Gods hunter: whereby it is ≈øignifyed, that the ciuill power is ordeyned of God, as a vengeaunce, and that ≈øhe be a mini≈øter of God. Wherfore the fyr≈øt Monarchye beganne by the Chaldeis, as wytne≈ø≈øeth al≈øo Xenophon, and the ≈øucce≈ø≈øors of Cham raygned fyr≈øt, of the whyche dyd Nemroth y≈ø≈øue. For though Noe had cur≈øed hys ≈øonne Cham, yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe dyd God in the meane whyle by a wonderfull de≈øtiny differ the vengeaunce and promi≈øe. Howbeit the kyngdome remayned not by the po≈øteryte of Nembroth. For there ro≈øe a newe kyngdome by the A≈ø≈øirians thorough A≈ø≈øur, by whome al≈øo the citye Niniue was buylded. Oute of Niniue went the A≈ø≈øyryans, and ≈øubdued the cytye of Babylon, the whyche Diodorus Siculus doeth wryte: and by thys occa≈øyon is the Monarchye tran≈ølated from the Chaldeis to the A≈ø≈øyrians.

Strabo and other dyd make mention of the cityeNiniue. Niniue, that it lyeth in A≈ø≈øyria: whereby it may ea≈øely be gathered, that Niniue and Babilon haue ben two ≈øeuerall cityes, not one of dyuer≈øe names. Many kynges are there rehcar≈øed in thys Monarchye: Howbeit ≈øeyng ther is nothing notably written of their dedes, it maketh no greate matter to
rehear≈øe their names onely: onely this behoueth it the reader to remembre, that this Monarchye beganne neare hande before the ende of the fyr≈øte two thou≈øande yeares, whiche were accompli≈øhed before that tyme, whan Abraham was fyftye yeare olde.

Hetherto haue wee treated of the fyr≈øte age of the worlde, in the which may be ≈øene of the creation of the worlde, of the churche, and ciuyll admini≈øtration ordeined of God, be≈øyde that of other wonderfull dedes ≈øhewed in the world by god. ButThe churche from Noe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ AbrahaÃÑm the churche, came from Noe the patriarche, vntyll Abraham, whiche was eyght and fyftye yeare olde, whan Noe dyed. In the meane whyle whan this Monarchye beganne, vngodlyne≈ø≈øe and idolatry beganne to ry≈øe here and there in Babylon, and the true worde of God was in the meane tyme quenched.

div.head: ≈øeconde boke of the Cronicles, of the foure Monarchies, the whiche lykewy≈øe comprehendeth two thou≈øand yeares.
div.p: FOra≈ømuche it is before all thynges nece≈ø≈øary and profytable in hi≈øtories, to con≈øider the times and order of thinges that are happened: I willed to parte this Cronicle in mo≈øt greate and certaine nombers, whiche maye ea≈øely be perceaued and kepte in memorye, in the whiche neuerthele≈ø≈øe mighte be comprehended the mo≈øt and principall chaunges of the worlde. After than that we haue fini≈øhed the fir≈øt age, we ≈øhall vndertake to ≈øpeake of the two thou≈øande yeares folowynge, in the whiche al≈øo appeared the greate≈øt power of the worlde, and the mo≈øt greate≈øt monarchies haue folowed in order.

div.head: Of the fyr≈øt Monarchye of the A≈ø≈øyrians. Ninus kyng of the A≈ø≈øyryans.
div.p:
WE haue admoni≈øhed afore that the Chaldeis haue raigned fir≈øt by the Babylonians, but they remayned not longe in the empyre, but that the A≈ø≈øirians the neighboures of the Chalde is obtained the kingedome and they beginne the hi≈øtory of kyng Ninus: which beynge become mo≈øte puy≈ø≈øaunt in the Ea≈øte at theZoroa≈øtres fynder of witchcrafte‚ñ™ la≈øt al≈øo had warre wyth Zoroa≈øtres kynge of the Bactrians. It is ≈øayde that thys Soroa≈øtres fand
fyr≈øt wytchcraft, and to haue taughte the cour≈øe of heauen, and the ≈øtarres wyth great diligence. As the warre was fyny≈øhed that Ninus had wyth Soroa≈øtres, he dyed, leauynge hys heyre a yonge ≈øonne.

div.head: Of quene Semiramis.
div.p: SEmiramis the mother of the chylde, ruled her ≈øelfe after the kynges decea≈øe. For the feared in ≈øo newe a kyngdome, and where they were not all yet of their fre wyll ≈øubdued, that for the chyldes youth, the people mighte haue ≈øpeded to rebellion, and le≈øt ≈øhe ≈øhoulde be de≈øpy≈øed, by rea≈øon of woman kynde: wherfore ≈øhe v≈øed mans garment, and fayned her to be the kynges chyld. She was doughtyeSemiramis v≈øed mans garment. and excellent in princely affayres, and augmented the borders of the dominion wyth vanqui≈øhynge countries, and makynge fortre≈ø≈øes. She raygned happely and with great pray≈øe xlij. yeres. She fortifyed Babilon with co≈øtly buyldynges, dyches and walles enuyroned about it. Whan the mother was deade, Ninias the ≈øonne raygned wyth good quietne≈ø≈øe: and of this wy≈øe was the ≈øuperiorite of the worlde and Monarchye by the A≈ø≈øyrians a great ≈øea≈øon, But, fora≈ømuche as there is not much written of the kynges folowyng, I will pa≈ø≈øe ouer the rehear≈øall of their names, becau≈øe the good reader can not well kepe them in mynde. Who≈øo wyll knowe them, may ≈øeke them by manye other wryters.

Neuerthele≈ø≈øe it is no doute, but that manys and ≈øundry chaunges are befallen in this Monarchye, the which maye ea≈øely be gathered out of the Bible, which wytne≈ø≈øeth, that the A≈ø≈øyrians po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Babylon, longe before the tyme of Cyrus, howbeit they were two kyngdomes: the one of the Niniuites, the other of the Babylonians. But for what cau≈øes or whan the≈øe mutations were, that is vtterly vnknowen. Herodotus wryteth that the A≈ø≈øyrians kept this Monarchy fyue hundreth yeares, and that after that longe tyme there was no certayne or fyrme kyngdome, but that the Medes v≈øed a proper kyngdome, and likewy≈øe the Chaldees by the Babylonians, and the A≈ø≈øyrians had their kyngdome at Niniue, and amonge the kynges had nowe the one ouerhande, nowe the other. Finally the Medes beynge become myghty, drewe the vpper Monarchy to them, takynge al≈øo the citye Babilon. The≈øe thinges ≈øeme moo≈øt lyke≈øt, to the whiche agre tho≈øe that are written of Sardanapalus, not only by Meta≈øthenes, but al≈øo Bion, of whom Agathias maketh mention.

div.head: Of Sardanapalus.
div.p:
WE mu≈øt ≈øpeake a lytle of Sardanapalus, how he was depryued of his kingdome, & that afterward the kingdomes were diuided. Whan God wyll puny≈øhe the worlde, he geueth it lecherous prynces. By the hi≈øtoriesA lecherous prynce. it is manife≈øt, that Sardanapalus nothinge
regardyng the gouernaunce of the kyngdom, ga ‚Ä¢
Sardanapalus wantonne≈ø≈øe. hym ≈øelfe only to plea≈øures, in ≈øo much al≈øo, that ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ v≈øed to paynte and coloure him ≈øelfe, to make h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ beawty, and to clothe him with womens garment. It is ≈øaid that he ≈øat in the middes of di≈øhone≈øt women, and v≈øed all maner of vnclenne≈ø≈øe. How ≈øhuld not ≈øuch an empyre haue had a pyteful ende? Whan nowe the Medes & Babilonians were fallen from hym and rebell, and that he had lo≈øte the battayll again≈øt hys enemies, neither coulde no where merchandes be more ≈øalfe, he ≈øet ye ca≈øtell at Babylon inThe death of Sardanapalus fyre, and burnt him ≈øelfe in it. Howbeit (as wryteth Duris) he ≈øent afore his thre ≈øonnes to Niniue: and hereby it commeth, that after the decea≈øe of Sardanapalus, the kyngdomes are diuided. Bolochus reigned at Babilon, whiche fell from Sardanapalus with Arbace. Arbaces kepte the kingdome of the Medes. The po≈øteryte of the A≈ø≈øirians dured a certaine ≈øpace of yeares by them of Niniue. Many yeares haue the≈øe thre kyngdomes foughte and ≈øtryuen for the Monarchye.

div.head: Of Egypte.
div.p:
WE haue ≈øuffycyentlye ≈øpoken of thys fyr≈øt Monarchye, but howe many yeares there be, vntyll the tyme of the ≈øecond monarchye, ≈øhall we note hereafter. At thys tyme mu≈øt wee ≈øhewe brefely a few thynges of other kyngdomes, whych are come vp be≈øyde this monarchy. For theThe kyngdome of the Egyptians. very large empyre of Egypt was in his floure, that whiche was gouerned by the po≈øteryte of Cham:
which was gouerned by the po≈øterite of Cham: but as concernyng his power, it was le≈ø≈øe then the monarchye: as now a dayes the kyngdome of Fraunce is myghty in dede, but yet it is le≈ø≈øe then the Empyre, concernynge ther power, or the dignite of his maie≈øtie.

div.head: Of Abraham and the ≈øpyrituall kyngdom.
div.p:
LE≈øt we be ignorant in what ≈øtate the word of God and the church was, we mu≈øt al≈øo ≈øpeake of the ≈øpirituall kyngdome. AbrahamAbraham was in Ninus tyme. was in the time of kyng Ninus. For when he was old about fifty yeares, the fir≈øt twoo thou≈øande yeares had an ende, and the kyngdome of the A≈ø≈øyrians was already begonne. And that more is, whan now the true wor≈øhyp of God and his worde began to come out of v≈øe in the kyngdome of Babylon, There weÃÑt out of Chaldea into Me≈øopotamia,Thare. with his two ≈øonnes Abraham and Loth, le≈øt he al≈øo myght bee ≈øtayned with the wickednes of the ≈øuper≈øtition that the Chaldees v≈øed. This idolatryVr of the Chald. es. doth the ≈øcripture cal Vt Chaldeorum that is, the Chalde fyre. For when in the ≈øacrifice of the true Godly (the fyre fallyng downe from heauen) kyndled the oblacions: the wicked folowyng their examples, kyndled a fyre, and ≈øo ≈øet vp a newe Gods ≈øeruice, that with ≈øuche a worke, they might ≈øerue God, without the expre≈ø≈øed worde of God, & without the knowledge of the promy≈øe of Chri≈øt to come. Hereafter al≈øo in the hi≈øtories is the ≈øame fyre called Orima≈øda,
that is, holyfyre, the whiche kynges cau≈øed al≈øo to be caried before them vpon a hor≈øe. The fir≈øt occa≈øioÃÑ The fir≈øt occa≈øion of ydolatry. of ydolatry among men began by this fyre, before Images were v≈øed. But le≈øt y‚Ä¢ worde of god ≈øhould vtterly be quenched, God renewed afre≈øhe the promy≈øe of Chri≈øte, and added a new ceremony too the worde, the which as a token, ≈øhould kepe the remeÃÑ braunce of the worde in mens myndes. For true doctrine is lightely put out of mens mindes, without it bee beaten into the peoples myndes by outward tokens and ceremonies. To that was Abraham cho≈øen of God, the whiche when he was olde thre ≈øcore and fyften yeares, he was commaunded of God to go into Chalde, leauyng Me≈øopotamia, where a new promi≈øe was made hym, that the ≈øede of Abraham ≈øhould po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the lande of Canaan, &The true wiÃÑg of the promi≈øe made to Abraham. ≈øhould beare rule in it: and al≈øo that the ≈øede of Abraham, namely Chri≈øt ≈øhould come, by the whiche God woulde ble≈ø≈øe all nacions, that is, that GOD would be appea≈øed by that ≈øede and takyng awaye the power of ≈øynne and death, geue lyfe euerla≈øting To this promy≈øe hath God added circumci≈øion, theCircumci≈øioÃÑ is the token of promi≈øe. whiche ≈øhould be a ≈øygne of promi≈ø≈øion, and a prouocation to beleue. And therfore remayned alway afterward in the churche or congregacion the worde and ≈øpirituall kyngdome of Chri≈øt among a certain people, that is, in Abrahams po≈øterite, amonge the whiche it was nece≈ø≈øary to haue bene alway ≈øome, whiche were true beleuers and Godly. As for the whole hi≈øtory of Abraham, is fully written in the holy Bible. In this place ≈øuffi≈øeth it to ≈øhewe in what tyme Abraham hath bene, and what chaunges
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ gion are happened in the meane ≈øea≈øon. But the promy≈øe was other whyles repeted to Abraham. As for the circumci≈øion was geuen hymWhen the circuÃÑci≈øion was geuen. when he was foure ≈øcore yeare olde and nyne, thee yeare from the creation of the world two thou≈øand and ≈øeuen and fourty, ≈øome count it to our Iubile two thou≈øande and fifty.

Abraham had of Agar his handmayden a ≈øomeAgar. I≈ømael. called I≈ømael: the ≈øame began to growe in ≈øtrength and pui≈øaunce by the Arabians, and the Agareny in Arabia beare the name of this Agar, of whome we ≈øhall ≈øpeake afterwarde.

div.head: Of the de≈øtruction of Sodome.
div.p: THE foure ≈øcore and nyntenth yeare of Abrahams age hath GOD for thee abhominable euyll dedes, horrible and vncomly lecheryes, de≈øtroied fyue cities: Sodome and Gomorre, and the other cities lyeng therby, burnyng them with fyre from heauen. The place where the cityes were is become a great mara≈ø≈øe, who≈øe length and bredth conteyneth the ≈øpace of certain miles: euen yet at this time as though it were ful of pitche doth burne with coÃÑtinual ≈ømoke and vapor for a token of Gods indignacion & vengeaunce for ≈øo greate ≈øynnes. This happened the thre hundreth and four≈øcore & eleuenth yere after the floude, after that Noe was deade the fourtieth and one. Of thys wy≈øe hath God other whyles wytne≈ø≈øed to the worlde, that he wyll bee auenged and iudge ≈øynners.

div.head: Of I≈øaac.
div.p: AFter this was a ≈øonne borne to Abraham, of his wyfe Sa ‚Ä¢ a, called I≈øaac,I≈øaac a fygure of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øt. of who≈øe ≈øede is Chri≈øt. For he dyd beare hys fygure, whan God commaunded that he ≈øhould be offered of hys father: wherby is ≈øignifyed, that Chri≈øt ≈øhould bee a ≈øacrifice, with the whiche ≈øhould ≈øynne and death be di≈øamilled. And by this example it is ≈øignifyed agayne, that God wyl forgeue ≈øynnes, ray≈øe the dead, and geue euerla≈øtyng lyfe to the beleuyng.

I≈øaac had two ≈øonnes Iacob and E≈øau. Of E≈øauIacob E≈øau. The Edo
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ fore „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ was called Edom „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ was called I≈ørael haue the Edomites in Arabia their begynnyng: for E≈øau was called Edom, that is, reddi≈øh, becau≈øe he ≈øolde his brother y‚Ä¢ ryght of y‚Ä¢ fyr≈øt borne, the which God hath ble≈ø≈øed, for a me≈ø≈øe of potage y‚Ä¢ was ≈øomwhat reed, de≈øpy≈øynge the ble≈ø≈øyng of God and his benefyte for loue of hys belly. But Iacob was ≈øurnamed I≈ørael, that is, prince of God, of whom the people I≈ørael haue their of ≈øprynge. But for al thee≈øe thynges mu≈øt the Bible be loked.

div.head: Of Io≈øeph Iacobs ≈øonne.
div.p:
BEcau≈øe Io≈øeph is reher≈øed amoÃÑg the chiefe and moo≈øt wy≈øe≈øt gouernours, we do worthely here make mencion of hym. For he taught the Egyptians both the religion and ciuyll maners: and aboue all is it worthy to bee marked, that the man whiche was endued with holyne≈ø≈øe &Io≈øeph a man ≈øage and holy. the holy gho≈øt, had ≈øet vp a very hard and rigorous maner of rulyng, and that where the whole kyngdome
of Egypte was large and wyde, he ioyned them together as members of one body: ≈øo that we may learne thereby, that rygour is mo≈øt nedeful to entertayn the people in there office or duety, & alowed of God. For the common people is commonly de≈øtroied by lybertie. But for becau≈øe he came into Egypte by the con≈øpiration of his brethren, that he was ≈øolde of them, and al≈øo what chaunce he had in Egypte, of all this is there fully wrytten in the Bible. For by thys wonderfull occa≈øion God wylled hym to come into Egypt, that in the ≈øame kyngdom al≈øo myght be taught the true wor≈øhyp of God and that the promy≈øe of Chri≈øtes commyng myght bee made manife≈øt. For God would euer haue his word preached euen in the greate≈øt kyngdomes: al≈øo that by this occa≈øion God might fede Iacob and his po≈øterite in the tyme of derth.

div.head: Of Mo≈øes, and of the puny≈øhment of the tyraunt Pharao.
div.p:
ALthough God had promy≈øed to the po≈øteriteThe cau≈øe of affliction. of Abraham the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the lande of Canaan, yet hath he differred the promy≈øe a long ≈øea≈øon, that through the word they myght haue in the meane while wherewith to exercy≈øe their faith: ye he ≈øuffred them before to be ≈øore puni≈øhed in Egypte. For as ≈øaith the booke of Gene≈øis, Iacob and his chyldren fled into Egypte in the tyme of derth, where they dwelled a longe ≈øea≈øon, the which we ≈øhal note hereafter. But when Pharao ouercharged the people without mea≈øure and remi≈ø≈øion, and v≈øed tyranny, in≈øom uche that he comaunded al≈øo to ≈øley in contynently all the mankynde
that were borne: God ≈øent Mo≈øes, to leade the people of I≈ørael out of Egypte, the whiche after many wonders, brought the people to the redd ≈øee. Pharao folowed them wyth great force, tru≈øtynge to optayne hys mynde that he myght ≈ø ‚Ä¢ aye them: for ther was no place to e≈øcape, ≈øeynge of the one ≈øyde they were clo≈øed in wyth hylles, of the other ≈øyde wyth the ≈øee, and Pharao the tyrauÃÑte laye vponAn example of grace and goodnes. them behynde. But here declared God, that whan extreme nece≈ø≈øite lieth vpon them that be hys, he is nere by them, and heareth them. For the water went back, and gaue the people waye a great ≈øpace, that they myght pa≈ø≈øe wythout any daunger: but the tyraunt folowed into the ≈øea vnhappely, which was drowned wyth the water that returned into hys fyr≈øt cour≈øe, and wyth hym the choy≈øe of the people of Egipt. Here theÃÑ hath God ≈øett forth againAn example of vengeauÃÑce a new example to the worlde, that he wil iudge and be reuenged of wycked tyrauntes, and all that de≈øpy≈øe godlyne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: What time the ten commaundementes were geuen.
div.p:
THe fyftyeth daye after that the chylderenWhen y‚Ä¢ law was geuen. of I≈ørael were gone out of Egypt, whan they iournyed through thee de≈øert by mount Suiai, were the ten commaundementes geuen, wyth incredible magnificence and maie≈øtye, namely wyth a voice out of heauen full of feare and drede. Thys worke of God is ≈øuch, as none higher dyd euer happen to men at any tyme in the worlde. For the
doctrine of the ten coÃÑmaundementes conteygneth the ≈øuÃÑme of the godly wy≈øedome, and in a brefene≈ø≈øe doth comprehende all maner of lawes and con≈øtitutions that can be any wher. Therfore is it nedefull to know the tyme in the whiche ≈øuche a wayghtye lawe was geuen of God, namely the yeare from the creation of the worlde two thou≈øande, foure hundreth and foure and fyfty. Seuen hundreth, foure ≈øcore and eyghtene after the floude.

S. Paull ≈øayeth, that the lawe was geuen afterThe time froÃÑ the promy≈øe made to Abraham, vntill y‚Ä¢ goyng out of Egipt. that the promy≈øe was made, foure hundreth and thyrtye yeares. For the ≈øame is the nombre of the yeres ≈øence the tyme, whan Abraham beynge olde thre ≈øcore and fyftene yeare receaued the promy≈øe vntyll that tyme whan I≈ørael was brought out of Egypte by Mo≈øes. And the≈øam that is redde in the xii. chapiter of Exodus that I≈ørael dwelt in Egypt foure hundreth and thyrty yeares, the ≈øame maye not be rekened from the tyme that Iacob weÃÑt into Egypt, ≈øeynge Io≈øeph was than in his floure. And that thys was not the nombre after Iacob only, maye ea≈øely be gathered here by, that Caath went wyth Iacob. And he begat a ≈øonne A ‚Ä¢ ram, who≈øe ≈øonne was Mo≈øes. Now can it not be that betwene Caath and Mo≈øes haue ben foure hundreth yeares. Wherfore the foure hundreth and thyrty yeares, whereof ther is redde in Exodus, are to be couÃÑ ted from that tyme, wheÃÑ Abraham came fyr≈øt from Me≈øopotamia into Canaan, and was afterwarde conuer≈øant hym≈øelfe in Egypte. And that the mynde of S. Paul may the better be vnder≈øtaÃÑd, I ≈øhall gather the noÃÑber of y‚Ä¢ yeares ≈øoÃÑwhat more dilgeÃÑtly
There are fyue and twenty yeares vntyl the byrth of I≈øaac, from the tyme that Abraham came fyr≈øt in to the lande of Canaan, what tyme he hym≈øelf was thre ≈øcore and fyftene yeare olde.
I≈øaac begat Iacob when he was thre ≈øcore yeare olde.
The foure ≈øcore and tenth yeare of Iacob was Io≈øeph borne.
Io≈øeph lyued an hundreth and ten yeares.
After Io≈øeph vntyll Mo≈øes was borne are thre ≈øcore and fyue yeares. And this nombre of the yeares doth Philo note al≈øo.

Mo≈øes was foure ≈øcore yeare old when he ledde the people out of Egypt. If the≈øe yeres be numbred together, they mount to the nombre of foure hundreth and thyrty. So muche tyme was there ≈øence that the promy≈øe was fir≈øte made to Abraham, vntyll that tyme that I≈øraell came out of Egypte, and after that was the lawe geuen. Now hath God geuen this I≈øraelity≈øh people a certayn policy and a ≈øeuerall kyngdome, in the whiche can nothyng bee requyred, that pertayneth to Gods ≈øeruice, to the pre≈øthode, al≈øo to the ciuyll iu≈øtice: that finally there myght be a certayn people, whiche ≈øhould haue the worde of God, and of the whiche Chri≈øt ≈øhoulde fynally be borne. By this people than hath alwaye bene the churche, Gods kyngdome and hystrue word, vntil that chri≈øt had ≈øuffered: the which mu≈øt be marked, ≈øo that no man bee ignoraunt that ≈øhe churche hath alway bene, and that God hath ≈øence the begynnyng of the worlde reueled his worde, and to haue kept it alway with vs.

div.head: Of the princes or rulers of I≈øraell.
div.p: FRom the departyng out of Egypte vntyll the begynnyng of Sauls kyngdome were thre hundreth thre ≈øcore and nyne, yeres the which the texte of the ≈øyxt chapiter of y‚Ä¢ third boke of kynges doth declare. Now had this people after Mo≈øes decea≈øeÃÑ princes, whiche partely were created by the aucthorite of wy≈øe men, partely were by a ≈øingular callynge ray≈øed vp of God, by the whiche are notable thynges done: and of this wy≈øe declared God, that he is faithfully with them that be his, and to defend them, though they ≈øeme ≈øomtyme to be to≈ø≈øed with the waues of peryls. The≈øe princes by an Hebrue co≈øtume werePrinces we ‚Ä¢ called Iudges. called Iudges. Howbeit for ≈øomuche as their hi≈øtories be written in the Bible, we ≈øhall only rehear≈øe their names, that the order of thee Cronicles, and cour≈øe of the yeares maye the better be ob≈øerued.

After the≈øe gouerned y‚Ä¢ people the≈øe hygh prie≈øtes:
