div.head: The Kynges of I≈ørael.
div.p:
THe iudges of the people of I≈ørael wer not ≈øuccedyng by enheritaunce: therefore was not the gouernaunce among that people firme or certayne, ≈øaue only with the hygh prie≈øtes: but God ordeined ≈øomtyme wy≈øe princes amonge theÃÑ in ≈øteade of a garni≈øon, & tho≈øe ray≈øed God now here now there. But the people euell coÃÑtented with this incertaintie of gouernaunce, required of Samuel the hygh prie≈øt too haue a certayne kyng, the whiche might gouerne the kyngdom. Samuel willyng to do nothyng ra≈øhly, a≈øked coun≈øayl of God. god ≈øhewed that he was very wroth with that wilfulne≈ø≈øe of the people demaundyng a newe kyng & commaunding ye people to bee greuou≈øly puny≈øhed therfore. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe God dyd in the meane ≈øea≈øonThe in≈øtitution of kyngdomes and kyn ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ e of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . graunt to the makyng of the kyng and in≈øtitutyng and continuance of a kyngdome. The power of the kyngdom, and admini≈øtration of it, is confirmed here with wordes of no ≈ømall importaunce: the whiche mu≈øt chefely be con≈øydered.

Moreouer it is to bee marked, that God is not
dy≈øplea≈øed becau≈øe he doth my≈øpray≈øe the gouernaunce of a kyng (for he doth manife≈øtly coÃÑfirme it) but hee is di≈øplea≈øed with thee peoples de≈øyre of newfangline≈ø≈øe in chaunging that commune welth,The chaungynges and renewynges of kyngdoÃÑs di≈øplea≈øeth God. which he him ≈øelfe had in≈øtituted. For God will not ≈øuffre the chaunge of the kyngdomes, whiche are ordeined by hym. Al≈øo are we admoni≈øhed by thys example, that we e≈øchue any mutacion at all. In this hi≈øtorie are there many other notable commaundementes, the whiche for ≈øhortne≈ø≈øe, I mu≈øtThe confirmacion of ciuyll gouernaunce. ouerpa≈ø≈øe. This one thyng wyll I only reher≈øe, that the ciuill gouernaunce, the aucthorite of princes and kynges is here coÃÑfirmed of God, when he ≈øpeaketh of the ryght and duetie of a kyng.
Saul reigned fourty yere, and was de≈øtroied forSaul. his vngodlyne≈ø≈øe, & all his kynred was de≈øtroted.

Dauid reigned forty yeare, and God puni≈øhedDauid. hym for aduoutry committed, and by ≈øedition was he dryuen out of hys kyngdom by his owne ≈øonne Ab≈øalon: But God re≈øtored him into the kyngdom, and puny≈øhed the ≈øedition greuou≈øly. Ab≈øalon died a ≈øtraunge death.
Salomon was forty yeres kynge, but after hisSalmon. decea≈øe, was the kyngdom deuided in ≈øundery partes for the aduoutry of Dauid.

div.head: Of the Kynges of Iuda, of Salomons linage and kynred.
div.p:
ROboam kynge raygned ≈øeuenten yeres.Roboam. And when hee woulde not obey thee Coun≈øayll of the elders, in miny≈øhynge the charges and exactions of the kyngdome, he cau≈øed wyth hys rygorou≈øne≈ø≈øe, that a
chaunge of the kyngdome is ca≈øued. For he ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ owedThe occa≈øioÃÑ of the kyngdome of Samaria. the coun≈øaill of younge men, nother wolde relea≈øe ought according to right. Wherfore deciuered from him the moo≈øt part of the kyngdom, and dyd begynne a new kyngdome in Samaria, the whiche was the occa≈øion of many greate battayls on both partes. As for the po≈øteritie of Dauid, retained the kyngdome in Iuda, and the tribe of Beniamin, folowed that kyng.
Abia reigned thre yeare, and in battayll vanqui≈øhedAbia. the kyng of the ten tribes in I≈ørael.

A≈øa reigned fourtene yeare. The ≈øame obtainedA≈øa toke away the wicked Gods „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . great prai≈øe, becau≈øe he rooted out the wicked wor≈øhyp of God, which was in≈øtitute again≈øt the worde of God: in ≈øo muche, that he fauoured not his owne mother in this behalfe: for ≈øhe al≈øo folowed a ≈øundery wor≈øhip of God. For this cau≈øe gaue him God good fortune agayn≈øt the Arabians, the whiche he vanqui≈øhed in battayll. At the la≈øt was he puni≈øhed al≈øo of God, for a certayn con≈øpiration that he had made, leauyng the tru≈øt in God.

div.head: The mydde or half part of the worldes age.
div.p: ABout the twelft yere of this kyng A≈øaes raigne, are accomply≈øhed there thou≈øand yeares of the worlde, that is, the mydde or half part of all the worldes age, accordyng to Elias ≈øaynge, the whiche we haue noted in the beginnyng of the boke. Henceforeward may be marked, that in coÃÑtinently after happened moo≈øt greate≈øt and ≈øodayn chaunges in all kyngdomes, that there dyd ary≈øe battayles and man ≈ølaughter, for the la≈øt tyme of the worlde dyd drawe on.

Thys is al≈øo to be noted, that the publike wellThe Iewes are elder. the Iewes are elder than of the Grekes and Romanes: wherby it maye ea≈øely be gathered, that all other nacions haue their ≈øpring of the Iewes auncetry, and that the elde≈øt doctrine, yea euen Gods word hath ben by the Iewes fathers or auncetres.

Io≈øaphat raygned fyue and twenty yeares:Io≈øaphat a defender of the religion. he is alowed for hys endeuour of religion, and that he hath exerci≈øed all kinglye duetyes wyth great diligence. And for that cau≈øe dyd god‚ñ™ geue hym excellent victories. Elias the prophet was in his tyme, which was taken vp quieke into heauen: & ≈øoElyas was in the mydle age of the worlde. ray≈øeth God a prophet, euen in the myddes of the worldes age, no le≈ø≈øe of famous doctrine then miracles, that the word and promi≈øe of Chri≈øt might be ≈øometyme renewed. The re≈øt than of the thre M. yeares of the worlde, began vnder thys Elias. After Elias, ≈øucceded Eli≈øeus the prophet. As for the≈øe two prophetes, how they haue reproued theEli≈øeus. wycked ≈øeruice of God, and what miracles they haue done, is ≈øufficiently treated in the Bible.

Ioram reigned eight yeares: he commaundedIoram a ≈øetter vp of new Idolatry. to kyll his brethren euen the elde≈øt, & was a beginner of a new Idolatry, wherfore he was al≈øo worthely puni≈øhed of God: he dyed vanqui≈øhed of the Phili≈øtenes. the which caryed away his wiues and chylderen, ≈øaue Ocho≈øias, which was the yonge≈øt.

Ocho≈øias raigned only one yeare, and accordyngeOcho≈øyas. as his father dyd, he permitted the fal≈øe ≈øeruice of God to be ≈øet vp, wherfore he was ≈ølayne. But whan his mother Athalia ≈øaw that her ≈øonneAthalia. was dead, ≈øhe cau≈øed to be ≈ølayn all them that were
a lyue of the kynges bloud, & of this wy≈øe was the kyngdome tran≈ølated from Salomons po≈øterite: that hereby we maye learne how rygorou≈øly GodExample of ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ geaunce. doth puni≈øh ≈øynne. Before all thinges mu≈øt princes con≈øider and marke this, that God doeth rout out the kynred of great princes becau≈øe of wickednes.

Athalia the mother of Ocho≈øias kept the kyngdome with violence, and v≈øed ≈øeueÃÑ yeares great tyranny. At the la≈øt ≈øhe was worthely puni≈øhed, when through the commaundement of the high prie≈øt ≈øhe was ≈ølayn.

div.head: Of Nathan and his po≈øteritie.
div.p: IN the reher≈øall of y‚Ä¢ fathers, of the which Chri≈øt is borne, hath Luke the euangeli≈øt e≈øt out Salomon. For Salomons po≈øte rite was de≈øtroied: neuertheles Dauids po≈øteritie ≈øucceded in the kyngdome, accordyng toNathan Dauids ≈øonne. the promi≈øe of God. Dauid had al≈øo a ≈øonne NathaÃÑ of whom Luke maketh meÃÑcion. Of his kynred wer the≈øe kynges of Iuda folowyng, namely.

Ioas reigned fourty yeres: the ≈øame was of notableIoas. Ioiada. godline≈ø≈øe, ≈øo long as Ioiada y‚Ä¢ high prie≈øt liued, whom he obeyed: afterward fell he to vngodline≈ø≈øe and Idolatry, and cau≈øed zachary the prophete theZacharias the prophete. ≈øonne of Ioiada to bee ≈ølayne before the temple, of whom Chri≈øt doth al≈øo make mencion in the .xxiij. chapiter of Mathew. Wherfore God willed to puny≈øh hym by the Syrians, and finally was he ≈ølayn by his owne ≈øeruauntes.

Ama≈øias was kyng nyne and twenty yeares:Ama≈øias ‚Ä¢ u≈øi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ godline≈ø≈øe. this al≈øo was conuer≈øant in Godlyne≈ø≈øe at the fyr≈øte, and herkened to the prophetes: whereby he
dyd luckely vanquy≈øhe thorough God the Id ‚Ä¢
means. But heyng after become haut and pre≈øumptuous, he made war of pure wilfulne≈ø≈øe and with out con≈øtraynt, in the whiche he was taken and fynally dyed.

Ozias raygned twoo and fyfty yeares, the ≈øameOzias which al≈øo is called Azarias. was al≈øo called Azarias. The ≈øame was at the fyr≈øt al≈øo Godly, and ouercame the Phili≈øthines. Afterwarde whan he woulde hym≈øelfe offre in the temple agayn≈øt the ordinaunce of God, he was ≈øtrykenOzias. Amos. Micheas. Ionas. with lepro≈øy. In his tyme lyued O≈øeas, Amos and Micheas, whiche prophecied agayn≈øte either kynges of Samaria and Iuda. Ionas was ‚Ä¢ l≈øo at this tyme, whiche was ≈øent to preache to the kynge of the A≈ø≈øirians.
Ioatham reygned lykewy≈øe ≈øyxten yeares: the≈øameIoatham. was Godly, & fought luckely again≈øt Ammon.

Achas reygned lykewy≈øe ≈øyxten yeares: hee ≈øetAchas. vp fal≈øe wor≈øhipping of god & of ouer great ≈øuper≈øtition and peruer≈øe opinion of godline≈ø≈øe, he buylded euery where throughout al the lande chappels and altars: wherfore God ≈øuffered hym and all his royalme to be greuou≈øly puny≈øhed and ≈øpoyled.

Ezechias reigned nyne and twenty yeares: HewasEzechias ‚Ä¢ godly kyng. a Godly kynge, he re≈øtored Gods wor≈øhyp, auoidyng Idolatry, he gaue the prie≈øtes their tenthes agayne. And becau≈øe the≈øe are true feates of good princes, therfore hath God geuen hym noble victories. For when the kynge of the A≈ø≈øyrians be≈øyeged Hieru≈øaleÃÑ he called vpon God for aide, & the citie was deliuered of the ≈øyege, by the angel ≈ølaingE≈øaye. the enemies. E≈øaye the prophete was in the time of
this kynge in great wor≈øhyp, by whome the kynge was in≈øtructed in ≈øuche thinges as pertayne to the feare of God. But in the ≈øyxte yeare of Ezechias,The way≈øtynge of Samaria. gat the king of the A≈ø≈øyrians the citye of Samaria, and led awaye the ten tribes of I≈ørael in bondage. The moo≈øt parte of thys were the people of God, that were fallen from Iuda, and had ≈øet vp a propre
‚Ä¢ he wa≈øting of Samaria. kyngdome. But whan the kynges of Samaria were afrayed le≈øt the people ≈øhoulde fall agayne to the kyngdome of Iuda, the which was ordeined of God, yf they ≈øhuld ≈øomtyme re≈øorte to Hieru≈øalem fea≈øtly, to do theyr ≈øacrifyce, and to heare the word of God, accordinge to the ordinaunce of the lawe: they ≈øet vp a certayne peculiar or propre Gods ≈øeruice, a propre doctrine, and a ≈øacrifice agayn≈øt Gods worde: and ≈øo haue they abu≈øed all thinges again≈øt the worde of God vnder pretence of Gods name, to entertayne the priuate power of their kyngdome.

Agayn≈øte this wor≈øhip of God are ≈øometyme ≈øent prophetes, to the ≈øauegarde and con≈øeruation of many: in the meane ≈øea≈øon haue the mighty with alThe „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ a w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d wor≈øhip „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ th not „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øhed. The example of the feare of God. ≈øtubbernes kept their fal≈øe gods ≈øeruice. Wherfore, God hath greuou≈øly puni≈øhed the≈øe kinges wyth warres and vproures, neither la≈øted the raigne of this empyre longe by any kyndred, in ≈øo much al≈øo, that at the la≈øt God ≈øuffred the kynges and people to be led away. Duely oughte this example make vs afrayde, that we learne to feare God: For if god ≈øpared not the po≈øterite of Abraham, vnto the which happened ≈øo manife≈øt promi≈øes and ≈øo great, but hath ≈øodenlye ouerthrowen theyr kingedome,
and ca≈øt them out: who is ≈øo ≈øure minded, which can beleue that we ≈øhall e≈øcape fre? But in myne opinioÃÑ Samaria i ‚Ä¢ a figure of the church of the Ea≈øt. that part of Samaria‚ñ™ ≈øemeth to beare the figure of the churche of the Ea≈øt and of the Grekes: for lyke as I≈ørael caried away by the A≈ø≈øyrians into Samaria, came neuer agayne: euen ≈øo al≈øo the churche or congregacion of the Ea≈øt is vtterly de≈øtroied by the Saracens and Turkes. And as it happened to the tribe of Iuda afterwarde: I feare me le≈øt it chaunce lykewy≈øe al≈øo to the We≈øt parte. It is to be feared truely that God ≈øhal handle vs more rygorou≈øly, becau≈øe of the greatne≈ø≈øe of our my≈ødedes. Houbeit God woulde in the meane ≈øea≈øon ble≈ø≈øe the ≈øede of Abraham before all natioÃÑs. Wherfore ought the godly reader con≈øider this example by hym≈øelfe, and pray God, that he wyll cha≈øten vs with mercy, and not to ca≈øt vs vtterly away. This kyngdom dured only two hundreth and foure and fourty yeares. That tyme verely was very ≈øhorte, ≈øpecially ≈øeyng thys people had ≈øoo excellent promi≈øes, euen of outwarde goodes al≈øo, and in the meane ≈øea≈øon had they warre al≈øo and vproures. So litle doth God ≈øuffre the wicked ≈øeruice of God vnpuni≈øhed. The wa≈øtyng of the kyngdom of Samaria was done the thre thou≈øande, two hundreth and fourtieth yere after the creation of the world. Mana≈ø≈øe the ≈øonne of Ezechias ≈øucceded his fatherMana≈ø≈øe a wicked kyng in the kyngdom of Iuda, and reigned fyue and fifty yeres. The ≈øame re≈øtored the fal≈øe Gods ≈øeruice, & for fal≈øe zele of godline≈ø≈øe, he burned in ≈øacrifice his own childreÃÑ. He per≈øecuted the prophetes. E≈øay y‚Ä¢ The death of E≈øaye. mo≈øt holy prophet hath he cau≈øed to be cut a≈øunder
with a ≈øawe and ≈ølayne: at the la≈øt was he taken o ‚Ä¢ his enemies and caryed awaye. Howbeit whan he knowledged his tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe, and called hartyly vpon the Lorde, he was taken frely to mercye, and GodMana≈ø≈øe an example of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ pe ‚Ä¢ te ‚Ä¢ s. hath ≈øet him for an example to ≈øynners, that they doute not, but that God ≈øhall haue mercy, and a≈ø≈øwage hys wrath & vengeaunce, if they turne from their wyckedne≈ø≈øe. Amon raigned two yeare: heAmon. was a wycked kynge, wherefore he dyed with the ≈øwearde of hys ≈øeruauntes.

Io≈øias raigned thyrty & one yere: he toke awayIo≈øias. the wicked wor≈øhip of God. He ouerthrew the chappels and Idols: he coÃÑmaunded to burne the bones of fal≈øe prophetes. In his tyme were the bokes ofThe bokes of Mo≈øes ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ founde. Mo≈øes found again, which had many yeres be lo≈øt. That truely is a notable example, that wickedne≈ø≈øe & mens traditions doth grow ≈øo excedingly & preuayle, that holy ≈øcripture is ≈øo greatly de≈øpy≈øed, y‚Ä¢ euen the very bokes be lo≈øt. But God ≈øo prouiding & for ≈øeynge, ≈øhe is neuerthele≈ø≈øe at the la≈øt re≈øtored and brought to lyght. This hi≈øtory no doute dothThe figure of pure doctryne before the worldes „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ de‚ñ™ ≈øhewe the figure of the la≈øt times in the church, to y‚Ä¢ which the true and ≈øincere knowledge of the word ≈øhalbe opened, euen before the ende of the worlde. But though Io≈øias was a verye godly kynge, yet wanted not he finally his errour. For whan he had now liued in good peace a great whyle, & had done many noble actes, beyng waxen hardy, he thought he might haue no mi≈øfortune by rea≈øon of his godlyne≈ø≈øe. Wherfore he warred vpon the kyng of the Egiptians, the whiche neuerthele≈ø≈øe demaunded condicions of peace. But becau≈øe he toke that warr by tru≈øt of mans power, he dyed of a gre ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ wounde
that he had gotten in y‚Ä¢ battayll. Ioachas raignedIoachas. thre monethes: and was caried awaye into Egipt.

Ioakim raigned two yeares. In his time inuadedIoakim. Nabuchodono≈øor. Daniel Nabuchodono≈øor kyng of Babylon all Iewry, who≈øe tributary he became: many men were led away, among the which was al≈øo Dauiel yet yonge. Afterward whan Ioakim kepte not the bonde or treaty, Nabuchodono≈øor came againe, and takyng Ioakim, cau≈øed him to be ≈ølayne at Hieru≈øalem, & his body to be ca≈øt amongs y‚Ä¢ other dead carca≈øes, without the citie, according to y‚Ä¢ prophe≈øye of Ieremy which prophe≈øyed that he ≈øhuld be buried as an a≈ø≈øe. Ioachim or Ieconias was kyng thre monethes:Ioachim ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Ieconias Nabuchodono≈øor about this tyme beynge come agayn, be≈øeged the city: Ieconias yelded him ≈øelfe frely through the coun≈øel of Ieremy the prophet, vnto whom God had reueled, that Hieru≈øaleÃÑ ≈øhuld be de≈øtroyed, & the people caried away: howbeit he ≈øhuld not wholy be de≈øtroied, but y‚Ä¢ he ≈øhulde once come agayn, & Hieru≈øalem ≈øhuld be buylded agayn. Ieconias was kept in BabiloÃÑ by god, becau≈øe he had obeied y‚Ä¢ voice of the prophet, the which we ≈øhall note hereafter. The be≈øt of the people were led in captiuite at Babilon with‚ñ™ Ieconias, and al≈øo all the moo≈øt co≈øtlye ve≈ø≈øels and ornamentes that were in the temple at Hieru≈øalem. SedechiasSedechias. raygned eleuen yeres: he fell from the kyng of Babilon, whome he wolde not geue tribute: for which cau≈øe Nabuchodono≈øor came again & be≈øieged the citie. And though Ieremy coun≈øeled hym, that he ≈øhuld yelde him ≈øelf, (for it were ≈øo fore≈øeen of god, y‚Ä¢ the people‚ñ™ ≈øhuld be led away, and Iuda puny≈øhed)
ye ‚Ä¢ would not he obey, ‚Ä¢ oldened and tru≈øtynge too Gods promy≈øe, that the people of Iuda ≈øhould not peri≈øhe. This did Sedechias boa≈øte, and the hygh prie≈øts did interpretate the promy≈øe of God peruerfly. For God could neuerthele≈ø≈øe ≈øaue his people, though he dyd ≈øuffre them to bee caried awaye and to be puni≈øhed a certain ≈øpace. And thus was Ieremias prophecy de≈øpy≈øed, ≈øpecially becau≈øe it was ≈øo long differed, nother did it ≈øo come to pa≈ø≈øe. Be≈øide this had the king of Babylon bene now thre times in Iewry, & yet had not profited in be≈øieging the citie of Hieru≈øaleÃÑ. Moreouer it was now y‚Ä¢ eleuenth yeare, in the which many were fled out of the cytie, the toune yet ≈øaued. The≈øe thinges were the cau≈øe, that after maÃÑs iudgement they ≈øtifly tru≈øted, that nothyng le≈ø≈øe ≈øhoulde be, then that general de≈øtruction, which Ieremy had prophecied. Al≈øo wasAn example of greate huÃÑ ger. the citie euery where fortified with fortre≈ø≈øes, again≈øt the power of the enemies. But Nabuchodono≈øor de≈øtroyed them wyth hunger for whan he be≈øyeged the citie a yeare and an halfe, it is ≈øaied that there was ≈øuche hunger, that many did eate theirAn example of mens ≈øtony hertes. owne children. So ≈øtony hart ‚Ä¢ ed is mans nature in her purpo≈øe that where ≈øhe was coÃÑ≈øtrained with ≈øo great nece≈ø≈øitie, yet refu≈øeth ≈øhe to come and take ≈øuccoure and con≈øolacion of God. For if they had yelded them≈øelues after the prophetes coun≈øayll, though the bany≈øhement had bene harde to them, yet myght they haue had peace at the lea≈øt wayeThe death of Sedechias. with the aliens. Finally when Sedechias toke the flyght, he was taken, & after that ≈øawe he his chyldren ≈ølayne in his pre≈øence: but his iyes were put
out, the citie of Ieru≈øalem was de≈øtroied, the temple that God cau≈øed to be buylded, was burnt, the be≈øt of the people of the Iewes, was caried awaye to Babylon into bondage, this example ought earne≈øtly admony≈øhe vs, that God wyl not ≈øpare other kyngdomes and princes, but that he wyll greueou≈øly puny≈øhe ≈øynne, ≈øeynge he hath v≈øed ≈øo greate rigour agayn≈øt this kyngdome, the whiche he hym ≈øelfe dyd ≈øet vp, for the ≈øcripture witne≈ø≈øeth that God hath puny≈øhed Iuda, with innumerable kyndes of puni≈øhmentes for his ≈øynnes: and added thoo≈øe ≈øynnes whiche were the chefe≈øt ≈øynnes, namely, de≈øpy≈øyng of Gods worde, the wicked wor≈øhyp of God, tyranny agayn≈øt the true preachers of Gods worde and prophetes.
The de≈øtruction of the citye happened the threThe de≈øtruction of Ieru≈øalem. thou≈øand thre hundreth and thre ≈øcore and therten yeare ≈øence the creation of the worlde.
The yeares From Dauid vntyll this ≈øpoylynge of the citie Ieru≈øalem are fiue hundreth and ≈øixten.

Hytherto remayned the kyngly name by the po≈øteritie of Dauid, amonge≈øt the whiche were many notable and renowmed kynges, as the lyke in none other kyngdome. For that kyngdome of Iuda had God ≈øpecially created, and gouerned it: but becau≈øe they were not without ≈øynne, therfore were theyThe kyngdome of Iuda. puny≈øhed of God, and the kyngdome was chaunged. For the kyngdome of Iuda was kept in captiuite in Babylon thre ≈øcore and ten yeares: howbeit in the meane ≈øea≈øon dyd God declare hym≈øelfe ≈øo, that it myght bee perceaued that hee cared for hys people and churche, and that he neuer would for≈øake
her. For he ≈øent notable prophetes, as Daniel amonge≈øt the Babilonians, whiche conuerted al≈øoNabuchodono≈øor was conuerted of Daniel. Nabuchodono≈øor ye kyng. For whan he was puny≈øhed by Gods iudgement for his vngodlyne≈ø≈øe, and was become madde & woodde, ≈øo that he differred nothinge from a bea≈øt, Daniel prayed God for him, and he was re≈øtored: afterward comminge to hys ryght mynde agayn from hys wyckedne≈ø≈øe, he renounced hys Idolatry, and as he was taughte of Daniell, he toke vpon him Gods true ≈øeruice.

After Nabuchodono≈øor, raygned his ≈øonne Euilmerodach.Euilmerodach The ≈øame commaunded to entreate Iechonias the kyng hone≈øtlye, and accordinge to hys kyngly dignitye, the which by the coÃÑmaundemente of Ieremy the prophete, yeldynge him ≈øelfe frely, went al≈øo in exyle. And after this wi≈øe dyd god fortunate this kyng, which beleued the wordes of the prophete: though he was in daunger for a ≈øea≈øon. Of this wy≈øe verelye was Dauids kynred ≈øaued from de≈øtruction by God, through gods prouidence the which we ≈øhall declare at large hereafter.

After Euilmer odach ≈øucceded Baltha≈øar in theBaltha≈øar kingdome. The ≈øame was a de≈øpi≈øer of godline≈ø≈øe & Gods word, he re≈øtored of a new the old & abrogate Idolatry of the Chaldeis: he v≈øed the ve≈ø≈øels that were caried from the temple of Ieru≈øaleÃÑ at his bankettes: he mocked the God of the Iewes, and for a reproche, he cau≈øed to be ≈øonge, that the God of the Chaldeis was a true God, & greater than the God of the Iewes. But what happened. The≈øe bla≈øphemousBla≈øphemyes are not vnpuni≈øhed. voices brought the de≈øtruccion of the whole kyngdome. For ther was clerely ≈øene a hande that
wrote vpon the wall, that Baltha≈øar ≈øhould pery≈øh with all his kingdome. The ≈øame happened the very ≈øame night: for the Medes and Per≈øians fell ≈øodenly vpon the Babylonians, and gat the kyngedome, and killed the kynge Baltha≈øar. This example witne≈ø≈øeth al≈øo that the bla≈øphemies agayn≈øte God, remayne not vnreuenged.

Now hath the tyme of the fir≈øt monarchy an ende,The ende of the fyr≈øt monarchye. vntyllthe Per≈øes and kynge Cirus. Betwene the byrth of Abraham and kyng Cirus are a thou≈øand, foure hundreth and four ≈øcor and fyften yeares, in the which was y‚Ä¢ monarchy fir≈øt by the Chaldeis, after that by the A≈ø≈øyrians. But whan it beganne to be alienated, now preuailed the A≈ø≈øyrians than the Babilonians, vntill the Medes and Per≈øes dyd growe, and finally gat Cyrus Babylon, recouering the Monarchy and makyng all one.

It is chefely to be con≈øydered, that the whole kingdome of the Iewes is coÃÑprehended vnder the tyme of this fyr≈øt monarchy: where by it is euidentThe Iewes are mo≈øt auncient. that the Iewes are mo≈øt auncient people, and that only their hi≈øtories are certayn and true of the fir≈øt kyngdomes of the worlde.

div.head: Of the Grekes.
div.p:
WE ≈øhall now note brefely the ≈øtate of the Grekes, in the tymes of the fyr≈øt Monarchye: where by it ≈øhalbe ea≈øelyThe hi≈øtoryes of the Iewes are elder than of the Grekes. gathered, that the hi≈øtories of the Iewes are much more auncient, than the Grekes: for all their hi≈øtories are written after the fyr≈øt Monarchy. Nether can the
Grekes rehear≈øe any thyng certayue or of longer ≈øpace, than that theyr Olympiades do ≈øhewe. But the Olympiades began the eyght & thertyth yere of kynge O≈øias. And if that be diligently rekened,Whan the Olympyades „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
it ≈øhall appeare to be about two hundreth yeare before the monarchye of the Peries. But becau≈øe of vnlearned readers I ≈øhall leaue the Olympiades, and ≈øhewe brefely what hath happened by the Grekes in the tyme of the fyr≈øte monarchye.

The country of Grece had no certayne kyng,The country „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . as other nacions, but there were in it partly many prynces, partly al≈øo mighty cityes, & ≈øundry greate chaunges happened with the princes. For the cityes encrea≈øyng in puy≈ø≈øaunce, coulde not well ≈øuffre Princes, as we haue ≈øene in Italy in oure dayes, and as I ≈øhall afterward ≈øet ≈øome examples, which are profytable to know, and haue true wytne≈ø≈øe of hy≈øtoryes. For there are fewe hi≈øtoryes withe the Grekes before the battayl of Troye.

div.head: Of the battayl of Troye.
div.p:
THE battayll of Troie happened before the tyme of Dauid, the whiche maye be proued by the wytne≈ø≈øe of Virgil. For he ≈øayeth that the kyngdome of Alban, dured thre hundreth yeares. Of thys wy≈øe ≈øayeth he of that kingdome of Alban. Thre hundreth yeares wholy, ≈øhall be the raygne vndoutedly. Before the ende of thys raygne beganne Rome to be buylded, the which we ≈øhall declare afterward. And if ye reken backward the nomber of the yeres, ye ≈øhal find that from the tyme of the buylding of Rome, vntyl the begynnynge of Salo mons kyngdome, are thre
C. and thre yeares. And it is euident that the battaill of Troie was not long before. Some hi≈øtory wryters do differ here, whiche ≈øaye that thys battayl was of more antique, but I coulde proue the contrary by many argumentes, the whiche I doo now pa≈ø≈øe ouer, becau≈øe of brefene≈ø≈øe. For≈øoth thys one thyng is worthy to be marked, that the occa≈øyon of the Troian battayll is ≈øpronge of adultery.The occa≈øpon of the battayl of Troie was aduoutry. For Paris the ≈øonne of the Troian kyng, led away Helena the wyfe of Menelaus prince of Grece, the hefe of the Grekes and the cytezens takyng this „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ di≈øplea≈øure, making a con≈øpiracy, went to Troie, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ nd be≈øyegyng it ten whole yeares, at the la≈øt they „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ anne the ca≈øtel Ilium and the cytye Troye, and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ayeng kyng Priamus, the kyngdome of Troye „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ as wholy quenceed. From Troye ≈øayled EneasEneas.
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to Italy, in ye which he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed that part, which „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ as called Latium. He beganne here a new kingdome,Latium. A≈øcanius whiche al≈øo was called. Iulus. and buylded for hys ≈øonne A≈øcanius, whych was al≈øo called Iulus the citye Alba, in the which „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ he po≈øteryte of Eneas raigned, vntyll the tyme „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ hat Rome was buylded. In the battayll of Troie „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ere many doughty and renoumed princes, who≈øe „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ames maye be ≈øought other wayes. Out of The≈ø
‚Ä¢ aliaAchilles. Hector. was there Achilles, of whom Hector the mo≈øt „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ aliaunt capitaine of the Troianes was ≈ølayne: „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ nd Achilles him ≈øelfe at the la≈øt was ≈ølayne al≈øo by „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ yle. For the Troianes had maryed to hym a doughter of Priamus, and as he ≈øatt knelinge in hys prayer before the altare in the temple, he was ≈øtrycken through wyth a dart of Parys by a decepte.

div.head: Of the battayl of Thebe.
div.p: NOt long before the battayll of Troie, ther was another of Thebe much more cruel.The occa≈øyon of the battaill of Thebes. For ≈øeynge the kyngdome of Thebe was fallen of right by inheritaunce to the two brethren Ethrocles and Polinices, they agreed together vpon this condition, that they ≈øhuld raigne euery one a yere one after y‚Ä¢ other. Howbeit whan Ethrocles had receaued the kingdome, he woulde raigne continually contrary to the appointement.Ethrocles. Polynices. Wherfore hys brother Polynices beyng con≈øtrayned, fled to Adra≈øtus king of the Argies, the which as he had geuen him in mariage his doughter, heAdra≈øtus. woulde ≈øet him into the kingdome againe by force, but Adra≈øtus was ≈ølayne before Thebe with other princes. Ethrocles and Polinices brethren, meting together by chaunce in battayll were ≈ølayne wyth woundinge eche other. The di≈øcorde of the bretheren was the cau≈øe of thys great and dolefull ≈ølaughter of the brethren. Nother was the warre yet fyny≈øhed: for other princes be≈øeged the cytye agayne afterward with a mighty power, and gettinge it, dyd at the la≈øt ouerthrowe it.

div.head: Of Hercules.
div.p:
ALytle before thys tyme, that is, ≈øhortey before Saul was made kynge by the Iewes, lyued Hercules in Grece, whichHercules of Tyrinthus. before other princes is chiefely pray≈øed for hys noble vertues. His elders were Amphytryo and Alcmena boren of the cytye Tyrinthus, whych lyeth not farre from Argis. But AmphytrioTyrynthus
fled to Thebe, becau≈øe that in a di≈øcorde betwene hys brother and hym, he ≈ølewe hym: and for thys cau≈øe fortuned Hercules to be borne at Thebe, and here he ≈øhewed the fyr≈øt profe of his power.Minya. For whan they of Minya a toune in The≈ø≈øalia, (which at that tyme were of renoumed puy≈ø≈øance, and raygned in the cytye Orchomenus,) a≈ø≈øaulted the towne of Thebe, Hercules defended it, driuing the enemies of from it, and toke the citye Orchomenus,Orchonemenus. the dominion whereof began than to fayle. This citye was mo≈øt ryche, who≈øe greate pray≈øes are in Homers worckes, for her plentyfulne≈ø≈øe. This victory gat Hercules fir≈øt a great name, in ≈øo much that afterwarde other prynces of Grece cameThe dedes of Hercules. frely to him: therfore was he euery where a maker of peace, he ayded princes and cities, he reuenged and cha≈øty≈øed vnryghteous dedes, and again≈øt them that he had holpen, v≈øed he great mekene≈ø≈øe, nother layed anye charge vpon them, that they were not able to beare. The≈øe are the thynges for the whiche he de≈øerued ≈øo greate pray≈øe, as none other prynce the lyke. Afterwarde toke he hys yourneye into A≈øia, where he ouercame kyng Laomedon, and ≈ølewe hym: but in thys vyctory, v≈øed he a very kyngly moderacion of mynde. For he ≈øaued the kyngdome, nother woulde de≈øtroye it, but gaue the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof to Priamus, as to the true heyre. And becau≈øe he re≈øtored the kingdome to Priamus, it is ea≈øye to ge≈ø≈øe what tyme Hercules lyued. Be≈øyde thys he made the ≈øea in Italy and Spaine ≈øafe from robbers, and for
this cau≈øe, cau≈øed he to be ray≈øed two rockes in the vtter coa≈øtes of Spayne and Aphrica, which ≈øhuld alwaye beare wytne≈ø≈øe of this dede. For at thysHercules pillers. time yet are they called Hercules pyllers. Charles the fyfte, the mo≈øt victorious or mo≈øt valiant Emperour, hath the≈øe at this tyme as a peculiar badge, namely that he may be knowen to be ≈øent to vs of God, to the intent that in thys troublous ≈øtate of the worlde, he maye be in whole Europa as an Hercules, to re≈øtore agayne wyth hys prowe≈ø≈øe and ≈øtronge victorious hande, peace and in≈øtyce.

Hether to haue we ≈øpoken of the notable thynges that are happened in Grece in the tyme of the fyr≈øt monarchye. But I ≈øhall neuerthele≈ø≈øe adde a few thynges be≈øyde the≈øe: For in reading of hy≈øtoryes mu≈øt ≈øpeciallye be con≈øydered, what ≈øtate the kyngdomes were of, what religions, what maner of lawes, Fynally what ≈øciences they had, wherein they flory≈øhed. Whan the ≈øonnes of Noe dyed, the
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ after „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
true vnder≈øtanding of Gods worde pery≈øhed al≈øo in Grece: though in the meane whyle they retayned of thepr fathers the maner of ceremonies, and ≈øentences of godlyne≈ø≈øe, yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe was the vngodlyne≈ø≈øe encrea≈øed, and otherwyles was one or other Idolatry ≈øet vp. For enery one ymagyned for him ≈øelfe an order to wor≈øhyp God, accordynge as hys con≈øtraint and nece≈ø≈øite compelled hym. For it is ≈øpoken of a Poet: The fyr≈øt feare that came to men mortall. Cau≈øed gods that be immortall. That is mo≈øt euidente and true in fayninge of the wicked ≈øeruice of God. For noman is ≈øo cruel of nature, whyche beynge in nece≈ø≈øyte, that doeth
not ≈øeke God: and for ≈øo muche as he knoweth not that God mu≈øt be ≈øought by faith only in Chri≈øt, he falleth to ≈øome outwarde worke, and faineth ≈øome new maner of wor≈øhippyng God. Of this commethThe occa≈øioÃÑ of all maner of vngodlyne≈ø≈øe. the fountayne and ≈øprynge of all the vngodlyne≈ø≈øes nere hande that are in the worlde. Nether nedeth any man ≈øuppo≈øe, that men erred ≈øo greatly, that they thought Images and contrefaitures to bee God: for they knewe ryght well, that they were wood and ≈øtone, but they were of this opinion, that this worke and this ≈øeruice plea≈øed God, and that he would be wor≈øhipped of this maner: where as yet God wil not be wor≈øhypped by vnfaythfulne≈ø≈øe without onely Chri≈øte by what maner of worke or fa≈øhion ≈øoeuer it be. And ≈øo could thei neuer be ≈øure, whether God were fauourable to them: for no man can ≈øurely per≈øuade hym≈øelfe the ≈øame, without the manife≈øt promy≈øe of God, and without Chri≈øt. TheThe head of Idolatry. heade then of all Idolatry is to tru≈øte in a peculiar and in a forged wor≈øhyp of God, excogitated of hys awne hed and in the meane ≈øea≈øon neuerthele≈ø≈øe, to doubte in tribulations whether God will be fauourable. This doute I ≈øaye is the principall parte of Idolatry. And the vngodly, whiche neuerthele≈ø≈øe e≈øtemeth hym ≈øelf good and wi≈øe, doth in this point much differ from the tren chri≈øtian & godly. SuchHow muche an vngodly doth differ from a chri≈øtian. an vngodly man hath goodly vertues & very ≈øhynyng workes: but his hart doubteth whether God be fauourable to him. As for a godly man and true Chri≈øtian, may wel be le≈ø≈øe then he, coÃÑcerning other vertues: but in his hart he is ≈øurely per≈øuaded that he is in the fauour of God, according to ye promi≈øes for
„Äà2 pages missing„Äâ ≈øitting in a chere vpoÃÑ the denne, prophecied of thinges to come, out of the whiche denne, in the meane whyle came ≈ømoke & bla≈øt of windes. Of this wi≈øe is it ≈øayd to haue bene happened at Delphis. After that the≈øe prophecies were ≈øuppo≈øed to be written of the prie≈øtes, as vndouted ≈øouth ≈øaynges: and becau≈øe they were doutfully written, they might bee taken diuer≈øly. The≈øe were deceates of the deuel, wherewith he begiled the worlde.

div.head: Of Homerus and He≈øiodus.
div.p:
BY the Grekes only were fir≈øt the be≈øt learnedWith the Grekes were p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ fir≈øte of renow ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e. poetes, whiche were partly mu≈øicians partly prie≈øtes: ≈øome of them al≈øo were w „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øene in phi≈øyck and a≈øtronomy. The≈øe compry≈øed their wy≈ødome and learnyng with ver≈øes ≈øhort ≈øentences. But among them, who≈øe workes are yet manyfe≈øt, were Homerus and He≈øiodus theWhat tyme „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ erus ly
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . chiefe. Ca≈ø≈øius writteth that Homerus liued after the battaill of Troie thre hundreth and thre ≈øcor „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ yeres, and before the fondacion of Rome euen there about whyche maye bee gathered to haue bene about that tyme, when Io≈øaphat reigned in Iewry His dwellyng was at Smyrna, whiche lieth in the forth part of A≈øia, where the moo≈øt auncient of the Grekes dwelled, whiche were called Iones and Acolidas. And all though Homerus was not myghtye in gouernaunce of the common wealth, it ≈øemeth yet that he v≈øed the coÃÑpany of the greate≈øt princes of all Greke. For he de≈øcribed of the be≈øt m „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
ner the kynred and of≈øpringe nearehande of a „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
princes: and his bokes are euen a myrour of all ciuyl occupation and princely vertues. For he hath payntedHomers bokes are a myrour of all ciuyl and princely vertues. and ≈øet forth all thynges, that can befall in gouerning a commune welth. Be≈øydes this al≈øo what is the duety of princes and great men in there coun≈øels gathered together, and in other afferes what≈øoeuer they be: he hath ≈øet them forth ≈øo conningly, that he ≈øemeth to be mo≈øt exercy≈øed in parliamentes, and diui≈øing of mo≈øt weyghty matters apperteining to kingdomes. Moreouer the ≈øage wryters dyd neuer pray≈øe ≈øo highly no poetes writing, as the poetry of Homer, the whiche Alexander the great would neuer ≈øuffre to be out of his handes, becau≈øe he might haue, wherout he might be admoni≈øhed and taught of the duety and vertues of an excellent kynge.

He≈øiodus (as wytne≈ø≈øeth Porphirius) lyueth anHe≈øiodus a pre≈øt at Helicon. hundreth yeare after Homer. He was a neighbure or prie≈øt of the mount Helicon, where was a greate and a famous temple. His writinges are for the mo≈øt parte ≈øermones of good maners. For they are ≈øhort ≈øentences, compri≈øinge the pyth of all kynd of vertues: but they treate nothinge of Chri≈øte. For thys heauenly doctryne was hydden to the Gentyls. Thys poetes writinges, conteyne al≈øo as it were a iu≈øt and perpetuall Kalendar, ordeyned afterHe≈øiodus bokes. the cour≈øe of the Sonne, and the ob≈øeruation of tho≈øe ≈øtarres, whiche ≈øhewe the difference of the yeare. Thys boke is worthy to be learned by rote of yonge chyldren, and it ≈øemeth that wy≈øe men of Grece, haue in tymes pa≈øt apprehend theyr chyldreÃÑ here to knowe the≈øe noble ≈øciences. But the poet
He≈øiodus, a man of notable learnynge and temperaunce at the ende dyed wretchedly by ≈øome of hys frendes, whych dyd euyl recompence hym for hys good dedes.

div.head: Of the buildinge of the citye Rome.
div.p:
PRoca Kynge of Alba had two ≈øonnes
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . „Äà‚óä„Äâ . Numitor and Amulius. Nowe had the father determined to geue the kyngdom to hys ≈øonne Numitor, becau≈øe he was the elder: but Amulius that was the yonger, droue hym out, and v≈øurped to hym the kyngdome. And le≈øt he myght feare any dauÃÑger by the y≈ø≈øue of Numitor, he ≈øtew hys ≈øonne Agi≈øtus by fraude, & hys brothers doughter‚ñ™ Rhea Syluia, bounde he wyth
„Äà‚óä„Äâ Syluia. a vowe of perpetual cha≈øtitye in the company of the virgins Ue≈øtales. But ≈øhe beynge made greatwith chylde, brought forth two twynnes, whych afterwarde were called Romulus and Remus. But whan Amulius knew of thys dede, he cau≈øed the mother to be kept in pry≈øon, and the chyldren to be trowen into the floude of Tyber, to drowne them. Whan the chyldren were now ≈øet at the brinke of ye water, by chaunce came a wolfe≈ø≈øe out of the nexte mountaynes, which gaue theÃÑ ≈øoucke, vntil they were founde of the Kynges ≈øhepherde, who bringinge them home, toke them hys wyfe to noury≈øhe.

Wherfore whan they were waxen greate, and herde of the pretended murther in theyre youth, of Amulius, and that the Kyngdome was taken from theyr vncle Numitor by force, they determyned to auenge the tyranny, and by occa≈øion ≈ølew kynge
Amulius, re≈øtorynge theyr vncle Numitor into his Kyngdome. Of thys wy≈øe doth God not ≈øuffreAn example of vengeaÃÑce. vnrighteou≈øne≈ø≈øe to be vnpuni≈øhed. Romulus and Remus brethren, buylded afterwarde a citye in hat place, where they were founde and layde.

Whan ≈øtryfe was ry≈øen amonge the brethren, for ≈øoThe ≈øtryfe of Romulus and Remus for ye realme. much as they were equal in age & ≈øtrength, whiche of them ≈øhulde raygne: they agreed that the Gods ≈øhould iudge it, ≈øo that who≈øe ≈øhulde haue the greater flyght or voyces of byrdes, the ≈øame ≈øhulde beare rule.

To Remus therefore dyd fyr≈øt flye ≈øyxe great rauens, afterwarde flew twelue for Romulus. Now whan Remus demaunded the Kyngdome by rea≈øon of the fyr≈øt flyght, ther ro≈øe agayne debate betwene the brethren. It is a wonder, how fearcely mens myndes beto≈ø≈øed wyth couetou≈øenes to beare rule, nother can it lightely≈øuffer and be quiet But what nedeth many wordes? At the la≈øt ray≈øe a commotion, Remus was ≈ølayne, and Romolus raygned alone, of whome al≈øo hath Rome the name By this appeareth that ye citye of Rome, was buylded by the po≈øteritye of Eneas. For Syluia the mother of Romulus, had hyr ≈øprynge of Eneas. But for as muche as Romulus Father was vnknowen, they fayneth that the god Mars was he, becau≈øe of a more hone≈øter cloke or pretence of the ‚Ä¢ aute. But how Romolus dyd ordeyne hys kyngdom, & what warres he made, doth Titus liuius wryte. I wyll only ≈øhewe brefely the ordre of the tymes, and what notable chaunges of realmes are happened in the meane whyle that euery man maye knowe,
what is chefely to be marked in readynge of all hy≈øtoryes: nother ≈øhall we al≈øo pa≈ø≈øcouer the≈øe wonders, that are happened by ≈øome heauenly prouideÃÑ ce, that we may ≈øe that vnryghteou≈ønes is puny≈øhed of God, and for what cau≈øes coÃÑmune wealthes and Kyngdomes are chaunged.

Pomponius Atticus and ≈øome other, whych reken the nomber of yeares moo≈øte dyligently, doethWhan Rome was ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y ‚Ä¢ deth. affirme that the citye of Rome was begonne to be buyldeth, in the begynnynge of the thyrde yeare of the ≈øyxte Olympias: that is, the tenth yeare of Ioathan Kynge of Iuda, but after the creation of the worlde, the thre thou≈øand, two hundreth, and one.

Rome was before Chri≈øtes byrth, ≈øeuen hundreth and nyne & tweÃÑtyyeare. I wyl al≈øo adde, that Varro wryteth, the twelue great rauens, to ≈øygnifye the tyme and la≈øtyng of the citye, namely a thou≈øande and two hundreth yeare. For euery great ra
‚Ä¢ en ≈øhulde ≈øygnifye a Seculum, that is a hundret yeare: and this is no euyll interpretacion. For from the begynnynge of the cityes buyldynge, vntyll the tyme of Honorius and Archadius, whan it was de≈øtroyed of the Gotes, was a thou≈øand and thre hundreth yeares.
The kynges raygned at Rome two hundreth and foure and forty yeares, as wytne≈ø≈øeth Liuius.
Eu≈øebius addeth al≈øo two yeares.

div.p: Alha the citye, and puny≈øhed theyr gouernoure which was a true breaker wyth dew puny≈øhment.
He gaue anotable example to men therin, how traytours ought to be puny≈øhed.

For he cau≈øed hym to be bounde and ≈øtretchedThe death of Metius Suffecius. out betwene two wagons, and with hor≈ø≈øes dryuen ≈øundery wayes, to be pulled in≈øunder, and toren to peces. The kyngdome of Alba cea≈øyd here, and this happened alytle before that tyme, whan Mana≈ø≈øes raygned in Iewry.

Whan Alba was ouerthrowen, the po≈øteritye of the Troyans, chefely of Iulius the ≈øonne of Eneas, write to Rome, leauynge Alba the whych after warde became myghty by the Romanes, toke all the monarchy alone, in the tyme of Iulius Ce≈øar.

Therfore was it well prophecyed of Homerus, concernynge Eneas, that hys po≈øteritye ≈øhould haue dominion euerla≈øtingly: and that is no doubte to be vnder≈øtande of the Romane dominion: for theyr monarchy is the la≈øt. But we ≈øhall ≈øpeake more larger of the≈øe thynges hereafter after Tullus Ho≈øtylius ≈øucceded in the kyngdome and raygned.

div.p: In his tyme began the monarchy of the Per≈øians and for becau≈øe I myght be brefe, therfore wylled I al≈øo to comprehende here the kynges of Rome, becau≈øe they for the mo≈øte parte all reygned beforeWhan the monarchy of of the Per≈øians, began. the monarchy of the Per≈øes: durynge the whiche few thynges worthy of remembraunce are befallen by the Romanes, vndoutedly who≈øe puy≈ø≈øaunce was not great before that tyme.

Tarquinius Superbus raygned xxv. yeares
was dryuen out of the kyngdom, for the abhominacion of his ≈øonne Sextus Tarquinius, the whichTarquinius Superbus. did by violence mi≈øv≈øe the mo≈øte hone≈øte wyfe Lucrece, whiche moued with ≈øhamfa≈øtnes of ≈øuch wickednes pearced her≈øelf with a ≈øwearde, eueÃÑ through the hart. Her kyn≈øfolke moued with the wickednesLucrecia. of the dede, droue out the kynge. This example doth al≈øo witne≈ø≈øe, for what cau≈øes God doth ≈øuffre kyngdomes to be changed, and tyranny to beAn example of vengeauÃÑce puni≈øhed. This is ynough ≈øpoken of the beginnyng of the foundacion of the citie, and whence happened the fir≈øt chaunge of the common wealth.

div.head: ¬∂ Of the ≈øecond Monarchye.
div.p:
WHen the Iewes had bene thre ≈øcore and ten yeares in exile by the Babylonians, as we haue ≈øayde before, the kyng of BabylonBaltha≈øar kyng of Babylon. Baltha≈øar was puny≈øhed of God‚ñ™ becau≈øe he bla≈øphemed the God of I≈ørael, and v≈øed the ve≈ø≈øels that were ordeined for the tempels v≈øe, in his bankettes. For the Medes and Per≈øes were fallen into his kyngdome, and toke the citie of Babylon, with the kyngdomes of Chaldee and A≈ø≈øyrya. Worthely therfore is this to bee called the ≈øeconde monarchye: For the greate≈øt kyngdomes of the worlde, began now to growe together, too the
whiche all A≈øianearehande was ioyned afterward by the Per≈øians. Here ought y‚Ä¢ godly mynd before all thynges to con≈øyder the≈øe noble benefytes and workes of God, whiche brought agayne all thee worlde in one certayn body and a lawfull empyre, that iu≈øtice and hone≈øtie myght be mainteined. For it were nece≈ø≈øary, that all ciuilitie and good lawes ≈øhould pery≈øhe amonge men, without God cho≈øe and ordeined ≈øomtyme myghty monarchyes, and puy≈ø≈øaunt princes, the whiche might defende them, and if they were decayed, to re≈øtore them agayne.

This monarchy of the Per≈øians was knowento the Grekes, and for the mo≈øte parte are happened in this monarchies tyme, what≈øoeuer notable andThe hi≈øtories of the Grekes begynne at thee Per≈øians. greate fetes are done in Grece. And thereby commeth that the Grekes begyn their hi≈øtories at the Per≈øians, the whiche it ≈øemeth to haue litle knowledge, what hath bene done in other kyngdomes, before the Per≈øians tymes.

As for the order of the yeres in hi≈øtories, I mu≈øt here aduerty≈øe the reader, that I haue hetherto borowed the rekenyng of the yeares out of holy ≈øcriptures, the whiche ≈øhewe by order the counte of the yeares, euen from the creation of the worlde, untyll the≈øe ≈øeuenty yeares, in the which the Iewes were kept in the Babylonicall banny≈øhment. Moreouer, in the holy Bibels are conteyned certayne Cronicles of the yeares, vntyl the tyme of the Per≈øes: but after that is thee order of the yeres not ≈øo wel kept, ≈øaue that Daniel ≈øaith, that there are four hundreth and ≈øeuenty yeares, from that tyme that it was
graunted to the Iewes to repare the citye Ieru≈øalem vntyll Chri≈øt was borne. And of ≈øo ea≈øy a thynge, ≈øome men maketh a great que≈øtion, of countinge the≈øe yeares a ryght, in the which we ≈øhall ≈øhewe to be no difficultye. For Daniel hath very well expre≈ø≈øed and marked the tyme of Chri≈øtes coÃÑminge.

div.head: The begynnynge of the Monarchye of the Per≈øians.
div.p:
BUt that the nombers do agre wyth the ≈øeuenty yeares afore≈øayde, we ≈øhal reken in the Monarchy of the per≈øyans a hundreth nynety and one yeare. Although the Grekes do reken the nomber of the≈øe yeares greater in the Monarchy of the per≈øes. Howbeyt thys is come thereby, that the Grekes, haue not begonne fyr≈øt to reken whan the≈øe ≈øeuenty yeares were expyred, but that about a twenty yeares before. And of this wy≈øe mu≈øt the rekenynge of PhiloThe rekeninge of the Gre
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Philo. and other Grecians be made equal. For the Iewes begynne in the yere of Cyrus, after that he had wonne the cytie Babylon. But the Grekes reken tho≈øe yeares wythal al≈øo, the which he had reygned before: but they are not to be referred to the yeares en≈øuynge. Moreouer that the matter maye the better be vnder≈øtande, accordynge to the order of Philo, we ≈øhall fyr≈øt rehearce the high prie≈øtes, after that, ≈øhall we al≈øo adioyne the Per≈øian kynges, as the Grekes do reken them.

But he that vnder≈øtandeth Cyrus kyngdome to beginne after the conquerynge of Babylon, the≈øame maye ea≈øely laye together the nomber of the
Grekes with the≈øe. CxCi. yeares.

div.p:
The order of the tymes doth for the moo≈øte parte allowe this nombre. For as the hi≈øtorye wryters haue lyued at ≈øundery tymes: euen ≈øo hath euery one made mencion of hys kynge, that raygned atHerodotus Theu≈øidides hys tyme: euen as Herodotus maketh mencion of xerxes, Theucydides of Artaxerxes with the longe hande: after the≈øe made Xenophon mencion ofXenophon.
Darius the ba≈øtarde and his yonger ≈øonne Cyrus, he wrote al≈øo of Artaxerxes Mnemon: Xenophon went a warrefare al≈øo, in tho≈øe warres, that were v≈øed at the≈øe tymes. Therfore the late wryters do greatly erre of the Iewes, they be very dull a≈ø≈øes, which ≈øet but four Per≈øian kinges, le≈øing more theÃÑ an hundreth yeares in this euident counting of the worldes yeares: of the whiche do ≈øpryng more greueous errours.

In Daniel and E≈ødras is mencion made of the Per≈øian kynges, but they varye in ≈øome names from the Grekes. As for me, (that all thynges may be knowen more manyfe≈øtly) I wyll brefely ≈øhewe what my mynde is. Meta≈øthenes is of ≈øome reiected,Meta≈øthenes becau≈øe he nameth ≈øome Per≈øian kynges other wy≈øe, then the Grekes. But for ≈øo muche as E≈ødras and Philo do not di≈øceuer from hym, I do not reiect tho≈øe kynges, whiche Meta≈øthenes reher≈øeth. For it is no doubt, but that E≈ødras was perfecte of the kyngdome and ≈øtate of the Per≈øians, forE≈ødras was ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gh ‚Ä¢ in the Per≈øian matt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s. ≈øo muche as it is euident that hee was one of the chefe of the realme and of the kynges coun≈øayll. Meta≈øthenes doth ≈øet in this order the Per≈øian kynges, and the≈øe be the fyr≈øte wherein they vary: but Philo and E≈ødras kepe the ≈øame order.

div.p: This variaunce after my mynde may ea≈øely bee iudged. Of the fyr≈øt Darius, whiche reigned with Cytus, haue the Grekes no certainte (for ≈øo much as ≈øaieth Daniel,) he neuer reigned, and therefore was his name all together vnknowen, to men of ≈øtraunge nacions. And Daniel hath ≈øeparated this Darius from Cyrus. For he ≈øayeth that Darius of Media was Cyrus of Per≈øia. Now do the Grekes reken only the Per≈øian kynges, nother do they myngle with them the Medians affeirs, who≈øe kyngdome was already tran≈ølated too the Per≈øians: therfore do the Greke wryters di≈ø≈øent nothyng from the holy ≈øcriptvres, though they leaue out Darius, ≈øeynge they counte onely the Per≈øian kynges. Io≈øephus wryteth that this Darius were Cyaxares, the ≈øonne of A≈øtyages, of whome Xenophen wryteth, the whyche I wyll not ≈øtryue wythall.

The ≈øeconde Artaxerxes A≈ø≈øuerus, is DariusArtaxerxes, A≈ø≈øuerus. Hy≈øta≈øpis ≈øonne, and Camby≈øes is pa≈ø≈øed ouer, becau≈øe hee reigned hys father yet lyuynge, or not long after his fathers death. For the Per≈øians had this cu≈øtome, that whan ye kyng went forth on war, they ordeined another before, which ≈øhuld ≈øupplie ye Camby≈øes. kings rowme being ab≈øeÃÑt. And by this occa≈øioÃÑ was Camby≈øes ordeined kyng & gouernour of y‚Ä¢ realme
of Cyrus hys father, whan he made warre agayn≈øt the Scythyans, wyth the which he hadde warre ≈øyxe yeares: and for this ≈øea≈øon dyd Cambi≈øes raigne, whome the Grekes ≈øaye to haue raygned ≈øeuenyeare, the which mu≈øt be vnder≈øtande of that time wherein, the father was yetlyuing. And the hi≈øtoryes of A≈ø≈øuerus do wytne≈ø≈øe that he was Darius becau≈øe Philo wryteth that the≈øe kyngdomes be recouered of hym agayne by warre, whiche were fallen back and rebelled, whan Cyrus had foughten wyth the Scythes hauing no goodlucke.

The thyrde was called Darius ArtaxerxesWherfore Darius Artaxerxes was called with the long hande. wyth the longe hande: the ≈øame do the Grekes ≈øimply call Artaxerxes wyth the longe hande: and he had the name thereof, that hys ryght hande was longer than the left, whome Meta≈øthenes calleth Darius, E≈ødras doth call hym Darius and Artaxerxes indifferently: for they v≈øed the≈øe names none otherwy≈øe, than oure Emperours v≈øe the names of Ce≈øar and Augu≈øtus, But that Artaxerxes doth ≈øtrayght waye folow Darius in order, that is happened for thys cau≈øe, that Xerxes forthwyth in the begynnynge of hys raygne wente in to Grece and that in the meane ≈øpace Artaxerxes ruled the kyngdom in the Ea≈øt. And becau≈øe Xerxes remayned not at hande in the Ea≈øt, therfore do not the Iewes make mention of hym, but holde Artaxerxes, for the kynge, ≈øeynge he beynge made gouernour of the kyngdome ruleth ≈øo longe as Xerxes was from home. After thys is ther no varyaunce more, and of thys wy≈øe maye the hy≈øtoryes of the
Byble and Grekes be made very well to agre. The di≈øagreynge of the yeres ry≈øeth therof y‚Ä¢ ≈øome Kynges gouerned the other yet lyuinge: and ther by is it come, that ≈øome other haue gathered the yeares otherwy≈øe.

div.head: Of Cyrus.Cyrus.
div.p:
CYrus the fyr≈øt Prince of the Monarch of the par≈øiansis rekened one amonge the moo≈øt doughtye≈øt Kynges & lordes of the worlde. For be≈øyde the manyfold excellent and very princely vertues, had God geueÃÑ and endued hym wyth ≈øundery luck and fortune in rulynge, and very excellent vyctoryes of hys enemies: yea he fortuned to be taught and in≈øtruct al≈øo by Daniel the prophet in godlynes and in the trew wor≈øhyp of God as holy ≈øcriptures do wytne≈ø≈øe, Such kynde of Princes, beinge ≈øo garny≈øhed wythHow great men ought to be folowed. the vertues of God, ought we to honoure, as noble gyftes of God, by the whych God wyll helpe the worlde, retayne men in theyr vocacion, haue mode≈øtye kept and peace, finally to haue lawes ordeyned. And ≈øeynge it is ≈øo, it is a very vngodlyne≈ø≈øe ether to de≈øpi≈øe or to ≈øet nought by ≈øuche Princes, as the commune ≈øort of people do. But this Cyrus is worthtely to be counted among ≈øuch mini≈øters of God and very excellent Princes of the worlde. Nother can the noblene≈ø≈øe of kynred be requyred in hym. For it ≈øo plea≈øyd God, that the worthyne≈ø≈øe of gouernaunce be kept and maynteyned and by men auanced wyth moo≈øt hyghe vertues, and renowme of theyr auncerters. And for ≈øo much as God
hath preferred with ≈øo high honors, therfore ought they lykewy≈øe to be honored of vs, as a mo≈øt excelleÃÑt gyfte, of God.
The father of Cyrus was a prince, or a gouernourThe father of Cyrus. of Per≈øia, borne of the of≈øprynge of Sem: his mother was borne of the kynges blude of Medes.
And Herodotus wryteth, that A≈øtyages kynge of the Medes ≈øawe in a dreame, out of hys doughtersA≈øtyag ‚Ä¢ s „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . wombe to grow a vyne, who≈øe ≈øprynge ≈øhould ouer ≈øhadowe whole A≈øia.

Of this was the coniecture taken, that a moo≈øt myghty prince ≈øhoulde be borne of her. Therefore whan Cyrus the chylde was now borne, A≈øtyages feared, le≈øt his kyngdome ≈øhould be remoued from the Medes, to the Per≈øians. For the which cau≈øe he commaundeth his v≈øher Harpagus, to put forth the chyld to be ≈ølayne. But whan Harpagus bu≈øied to ≈ølayne it, he was ≈øaued by a wonderfull de≈øtiny: So vayne are mens enterpry≈øes and ≈øtudyes to hynder Gods coun≈øels. The chyide was taken to the ≈øhepeherde to beare it vpon a hyll, that thete it myght dye for honger: the ≈øhepeherde was al≈øo coÃÑ maunded not to leaue the chyld, vntil it were dead, and to ≈øhewe this ≈øame to Harpagus, that he might certifye the kynge the truth of the thinges, and to ≈øe the chylde buryed accordynge to the dignitie. But what dyd happen? At the ≈øame tyme by chaunce, whan the ≈øhepeherde bryngeth this chylde: into his hou≈øe, his wyfe was delyuered of a deade chylde: the which whan ≈øhe herde of her hu≈øbande that thys chyld ≈øhoulde be layed abrode to peri≈øhe, whome be≈øyde the comlyne≈ø≈øe of bewty, ≈øhe perceaued
to declare ≈øome kyngly ≈øtrength and courage, and al≈øo becau≈øe it was borne of the kynges bloude: ≈øhe coun≈øeleth and prayeth her hu≈øbande to laye hyr deade chylde in his ≈øteade, and to take it her for to brynge vp for hers. She admony ≈øheth hym al≈øo to committe no murther with the kynges chylde, chefely ≈øeinge no daunger can befall or happen to the realine by this chylde, for a≈ømuche as it ≈øhalbe brought vp and taken for the ≈øhepeherdes chylde.
The ≈øhepeherde foloweth his wyues coun≈øell he ≈øende worde to Harpagus that the chylde is dead.

Who ≈øendeth ≈øome to ≈øee wheter it were ≈øo, and cau≈øeth the chylde to be buryed: and all this is ≈øheweth the kyng for a trueth. In the meane whyle is Cyrus brought vp by the ≈øhepeherde: and as he grew vp by proce≈ø≈øe, forth wyth appeareth in him kynggly towardne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe of wyt.
Moreouer amonge the chyldren (as the chyldreÃÑ co≈øtume is) he ordeyned a kyngdome, and hym that offended, dyd puny≈øh greueou≈øly.
But it happened by this chaunce, that whan he had beaten a gentlemans chylde very rygorou≈øly for a tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion, he was accu≈øed to the chyldes elders, the which made complaynt to the kynge.

The kynge callynge and demaundynge of the chylde, he maruayleth at his great graue con≈øtancye and the wy≈ødome in an≈øwerynge, than to the chyldes age. Beynge ≈øtreght waye a≈øtonyed in hys mynde, he aduy≈øed hym of the tyme, wherein hys doughter was delyueted, and as he had ≈øearched out all the circum≈øtances of hys age the tyme and the bryngynge vp he knewe that it was his co≈øyn,
his daughters ≈øonne, the which in tyme pa≈øt he had commaunded to be de≈øtroyed. Knowynge hym he kept hym in hys court a certayn ≈øpace: and whan A≈øtyages dyd now dout no more of hym, by rea≈øon of hys ≈øyngular towardne≈ø≈øe & hone≈øty, the whych dyd ≈øhyne in the chylde, he ≈øent hym into Per≈øia to hys elders. Howbeit the kynge was in the meane whyle greatly wroth wyth Harpagus, for the deceate, becau≈øe he dyd not accomply≈øhe the kynges commaundement, in ≈ølayeng at that tyme the chylde. He commaundeth Harpagus yonge≈øt ≈øonne to be brought to the court: the which whaÃÑ HarpagusThe notable crueltye of A≈øtyages had done, the kynge commaunded to ≈ølaye him and ≈øeethe him and to ≈øet it before Harpagus for to eate wythout hys knowledge: but whan he had now eaten ynough, A≈øtyages commaunded to brynge the heade, fete and handes of the chylde that were hewen of, and ≈øhewe them to Harpagus, that he myghte ≈øe that he had eaten the fle≈øhe of hys owne chylde.

As harpagus ≈øawe the heade, he knew the kynges dede, & al≈øo whence the occa≈øion came: but all grefe ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, he wor≈øhpped the kynge accordynge to hys wonted reuerence and drede, thynkyng in the meane ≈øea≈øon to be once greatly reuenged of thys tyranny of the Kynge. But Harpagus euer after cea≈øed not to ≈øtere vp the chefe of Media & the mo≈øtThe dede of Harpagus ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ pu ‚Ä¢ t A≈øt ‚Ä¢ yes tyranny. puy≈ø≈øant nobles to fal to the Per≈øes, and to make Cyrus Kynge: he ≈øheweth it to Cyrus al≈øo, and exhorteth him to inuade the kyngdome, nother ≈øuffre the tyranny, that the Kynge hath v≈øed agayn≈øt other of them to be vnreuenged.

And that the enterpry≈øe be ≈øecrete, he hydeth a lettre in the belly of a holow hare, and taketh him to a tru≈øtye me≈ø≈øenger to bringe it into Per≈øia to Cyrus, and ≈øendeth no worde els by the me≈ø≈øenger, but that kynge Cyrus him ≈øelfe doo flee the hare. Cyrus fyndynge the letter, and knowynge Harpagus coun≈øell, maketh continently ready an hoo≈øt, and goeth agayn≈øt the Medes. A≈øtyages on the other ≈øyde commaundeth hys army to with≈øtande the enemy, of the which he maketh Harpagus chefe captayne: but whan the felde ≈øhulde be fouten, he yelded both hym ≈øelf and hys army wyllyngly to Cyrus. Wherfore A≈øtyages hauyng lo≈øt the kyngdome of Media, was vanquy≈øhed. Howbeit Cyrus ≈øaued and kept hym, and cau≈øed hym to be intreated accordynge to hys royall dignitie. Thys alteration happened in the kyngdome of the Medes, by rea≈øon of the kynges tyranny, for the which al≈øo the whole empyre was tran≈ølated to the Per≈øes.

After thys warred the mo≈øt ryche Cre≈øus vpon Cyrus in the fore parte of A≈øia, whome CyrusCre≈øus king o ‚Ä¢ A≈øia‚ñ™ metyng wyth an hoo≈øt, ouercame, and toke in the whole kyngdome, and wynnynge the moo≈øt ≈øtronge≈øt citye Sardis, toke Cre≈øus pry≈øoner. But whan by the kynges commaundement, Cre≈øus ≈øhulde be burned, and was nowe vpon the pyle of wood, he cryed wyth verye pytefull waylynge: O Solon, Solon. Cyrus woundred at this noy≈øe, and cau≈øed to demaunde for what cau≈øe he dyd ≈øo crye nowe and than, wyth ≈øo greate doulfulnes. Than he ≈øyghynge from the dep ‚Ä¢ ≈øt of hys harte, ≈øayde: Solon was in tymes pa≈øt a moo≈øt wy≈øe man
among y‚Ä¢ Athenians, whom I dyd ≈øomtyme greatly wor≈øhyp, whan he was with me, and I ≈øhewed him all my power and trea≈øures, and finally a≈øked him, whether any mi≈øfortune myght euer happen to me, that were ≈øo well fortified with ryches and power, again≈øt all chaunces of fortune, and again≈øt the power of my enemies? But SoloÃÑ an≈øwered toThe graue ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ighty „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚ñ™ that with a rebuke: That noman is ≈øo happyin this lyfe, which before his death can be called happye of euery ≈øyde: nether is anye man ≈øo mighty or puy≈ø≈øaunt, whom an vnhappy chaunce can not make feble and ouerthrowe. But that as than he beynge ≈øafe by rea≈øon of pro≈øperitye, he ≈øayde he de≈øpy≈øed tho≈øe wordes, nother coulde he drede this notable fall, the which he had now proued: and becau≈øe that now fir≈øt he vnder≈øtode Solons ≈øayenge, therfore dyd he now name him before his death, and that he wy≈øhed al men to remembre in pro≈øperity aduer≈øytyes, which may befall, le≈øt they become proude for the pre≈øente felicitie, to enterpri≈øe or vndertake oughte, that by chaunce myghte bringe mi≈øchief to them. Whan Cyrus heard this, he was moued
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ trample o ‚Ä¢ pitye. with pitye toward Cre≈øus, ≈øayenge: That hereafter he woulde not entreate Cre≈øus ≈øo cruellye, which had intymes pa≈øt be a moo≈øt myghty kynge: for he knew that he was a man al≈øo, and to hym al≈øo it myght befall, to haue nede of an other mans helpe and mercye. After thys commaunded he Cre≈øus to be brought to him, and had him in greate reuerence, as a great prince, and v≈øed hys coun≈øel in gouernaunce.

Cyrus demaunded of hym al≈øo, by what cau≈øe he had taken this warre, whether he were moued, by the an≈øwer of Apollo, whome he had a≈øked coun≈øell before? To this an≈øwered Cre≈øus, ≈øayenge: That Apollo coun≈øelled him right well with the≈øe wordes, Knowe thy ≈øelfe, and all thyng ≈øhall pro≈øpete. He dyd not refu≈øe thys coun≈øell of Apollo. For whan his hoo≈øt had gotten the wor≈øthande in aydinge the A≈ø≈øyrians, he had purpo≈øed thenceforth to lyue in re≈øt and peace, chefely for ≈øo muche as he ≈øawe Cre≈øus to haue ≈øuch pro≈øperitie and power in bringinge all thinges to pa≈ø≈øe. But whan he was pray≈øed of the cityes that laye rounde aboute, and of his great princes for his power and conning of warrfaringe, he was agayne deceaued by pryde and vaine glory of him ≈øelfe, and was ≈øo by the other princes made capitaine of the warre agayn≈øt Cyrus. And that by the≈øe prai≈øes he was brought, to take the an≈øwer of Apollo otherwy≈øe, and that he thought he was ≈øuche a one in dede, as he was prai≈øed, namely, that he was no le≈ø≈øe in power, than king Cyrus, and by the≈øe meanes had he taken the warres in hande. But hetherto is ynough ≈øpoken of Cre≈øus. Hereof maye notable examples be taken,Example that princes do oft, warre con≈øtrayned by no nece≈ø≈øytye. What is to be con≈øydered in kyng Cyrus. that princes be oft brought to warre by no con≈øtraynt of nece≈ø≈øytie, and to theyr greate hynderaunce, by the coun≈øell and flattery of them, which can fal≈øely per≈øuade and extolle with vaine pray≈øes theyr power and vertues.

In king Cirus is chefely to be con≈øidered, that in ≈øo great pro≈øperities of all thynges, he v≈øed great
moderation of minde, and that in ≈øo great violence of victories, he ≈øwaged tyranny wyth mekene≈ø≈øe.

Cyrus than toke in all the kyngdomes from Per≈øia, vntyll the fyr≈øte borders of Ionia: from thence beynge returned, he be≈øieged the cytye Babylon, which ≈øemed moo≈øt ≈øtronge≈øt again≈øt all forceHow Cyrus ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ BabyloÃÑ. Euphrates. of mans power. But Cyrus wanne her, and that by this meanes: The floude Euphrates runneth through the citye by ≈øome ryuers: dyggynge thorough hys caucyes, he ledde the cour≈øe of the water another waye, and as the floud was dryed, men myght ≈øafely go into the toune on foote. Be≈øyde that had he hys e≈øpyals, whych ≈øhewed what tyme the Babylonians were at re≈øte, and ≈øo broughte he hys army into the cytye in the ≈øtyll of the nyghte, whan they douted nothyng le≈ø≈øe.

But what nedeth here to pray≈øe and auaunce much the pro≈øperytie of Cyrus? ≈øeynge it maye ea≈øely be thought and con≈øydered, that it is Goddes worke, and not of mans wy≈øedome or power, that ≈øo many and ≈øo ≈øtronge tounes and kynges be ≈øubiect to hys kyngdome, vnto whome it ≈øemeth no mans power nearehande myght wyth≈øtande. For tho≈øe hygh monarchies are ordeined & con≈øerued by an heauenly power, for to pre≈øerue the ≈øtate of a coÃÑmune wealth, agayn≈øt the will of Satan. Moreouer after that Babylon was wonne, than began that kyngdom of the Per≈øes fyr≈øt to be called a monarchy: For the heade citye or ≈øee of the monarchy,Babylon is the h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ de citye of the monarchye. was Babylon, and the kyngdomes of Chalde, A≈ø≈øyria, Medes and Per≈øians be now brought vnder one empyre. The moo≈øt parte of A≈øia was ioyned
thereto al≈øo, and other great countries, which border vpon the≈øe kyngdomes. Cyrus gouerned the≈øe kyngdomes with great pray≈øe, in≈øomuch that no princes pray≈øes, wherof hi≈øtoryes do make mencyon, can be compared wyth his commendacions and ‚Ä¢ uauncementes.

I ≈øuppo≈øe that thys monarchy began after that Babylon was wonne in the thre ≈øcore and tenth yeare after that the Iewes were ledde into captyuyte in Babilon. But ≈øence the creation of y‚Ä¢ world, the yere of thre thou≈øand, foure hundreth and thre and forty, and before Chri≈øtus byrth the fyue hundreth and one yeare. Whereby it maye ea≈øely be gathered, that tho≈øe hi≈øtories of the Grekes that begynne at Cyrus, be not very olde.

div.head: Of the Iewes delyuered out of the Babylonycall captiuite.
div.p:
HEtherto haue we ≈øpoken of the ≈øtate of the commune wealth and empyre of tho≈øe tymes: nowe re≈øteth it that we ≈øpeake al≈øo of the ≈øpyritual kingdome of God, and of the churche. After that Cyrus had ≈øubdued the Babylonians, he ≈øet the Iewes free and at libertye out of all his kyngdomes, and re≈øtored them into the kyngdome of Iewry. This exampleHow muche God careth for his churche or congregatioÃÑ. wytne≈ø≈øeth howe muche God doeth care for the church or congregacion of the godly, and howe lytle he doth forget them. For that the church myght be relea≈øed from the ≈øeruice & bondage, it was nece≈ø≈øary that Babilon the citye ≈øhuld be taken and pery≈øhe
„Äà2 pages missing„Äâ For a prince mu≈øt not be a cowarde, to repre≈ø≈øe the force of his enemies. Herodotus wryteth al≈øo that ≈øome do ≈øuppo≈øe otherwi≈øe of Cyrus death: and XenophonWhat Xenophon writeth of Cyrus. writeth that he dyed in his bedde, and that before his death, he exhorteth his childeren to the feare of God, to vnitie and loue to eche other, and that with a greate relation and manye wordes he admoni≈øhed them to remembre that mens ≈øoules dye not with the bodies, but that they remayne immortall, and that the godlye after thys lyfe enioye
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
an euerla≈øtinge re≈øte wyth God: and that contrary wy≈øe the wicked ≈øhalbe greueou≈øly puni≈øhed. And to this is it ≈øaied that he ≈øhoulde haue added a ≈øub≈øtanciall euidence of mans rea≈øon, concerning euyll doers, the which in this lyfe haue a great inwarde drede in their minde, for the con≈øcience of theyr wicked dedes: and that therby may be gathered that the ≈øoule hath a certayne beynge: and that ≈øeynge this feare is beaten in by God, it is euidente that God will be reuenged of all thynge that is vniu≈øtly committed. Hetherto is ther ynough ≈øaide of thys moo≈øt holy kinge Cyrus.

div.head: In what tyme the Philo≈øophers were fyr≈øt in Grece.
div.p:
BEfore haue we ≈øhewed that by the Grekes were the Poetes fyr≈øt in high reputation, by rea≈øon of ther learning: afterwardes inThe Philo≈øophers were ‚Ä¢ p ‚Ä¢ ≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Cyrus tyme. The Philo≈øophers of Ionia and Italy. Cyrus tyme began another kynd of learned men, whiche were called Philo≈øophers, & of them were two ≈øectes at one time: for ≈øome were philo≈øophers of Ionia, & ≈øome were called philo≈øophers of Italy.
The philo≈øophers Ionici were in Ionia, they v≈øed greate diligence in naturall thinges, and ≈øearchinge out the cour≈øe of ≈øtarres. The beginner ofThales begynner of philo≈øophers i ‚Ä¢ Grece. them was Thales, which diuided fir≈øt for the Grekes the yere in thre hundreth and thre ≈øcore daies. For though they had before twelue monethes, yet were they con≈øtrayned to brynge the mouynge of the ≈øonne to the cour≈øe of the mone. Thales did al≈øo ≈øhew fir≈øt of the Eclyp≈øe in Grece, and found the poynte whan the daye and nyghte are equall, the which was no ≈ømall conning. He had learned the≈øe thinges of the Egiptians, with whom God had kept this ≈øcience. The≈øe Thales taught al≈øo that the ≈øoules are ymmortall: and he is the fyr≈øte and true begynner of the philo≈øophers of Grece.

The other parte of the philo≈øophers, whychePythagoras begynner of philo≈øophers of Italy. are called the Italians, began by Pythagoras: for the ≈øame lyued al≈øo aboute the tyme of Cyrus, in that vttermo≈øt part of Italy, which bendeth to Sicilia, and was ≈øometyme Grece. In the tyme of Pythagoras raigned at Rome Seruius Tullius: his ≈øcole was not occupied in Phi≈øick and A≈øtronomy, as the other, but in Arithmetick, Geometry & Mu≈øick. Pythagoras liued a very ≈øolytary lyfe wyth his di≈øciples, and v≈øed ≈øundry ceremonies, & taught many inconuenient thinges of the ≈øoules nature, that mens ≈øoules remoue into bea≈øtes to be puny≈øhed. The Pythagorians taughte their doctrines priuatly amonge them≈øelues: and it was commaunded amonges them that noman ≈øhoulde publi≈øhe them, le≈øt by rea≈øon of a doctryne not accu≈øtomed, the commune ≈øort of men mighte be ≈øturred ether
to di≈øcorde, or to a de≈øpi≈øynge of good maners. But ≈øuch kynde of phylo≈øophers dured not longe: nother is it now nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øpeake more of the begynnyng of philo≈øophers. I would onely ≈øhewe i ‚Ä¢ here, le≈øt any man might be ignoraunt, what tyme the connyng of ≈øciences began and encrea≈øed: wee ≈øhall hereafter in hys due place ≈øpeake of them, whych haue before all other garny≈øhed and had in reuerence Philo≈øophye, whereof there is not ≈øo great nomber. For very few are ther that be worthy to be called wyth ≈øo excellent a name Phylo≈øopher, and therfore ≈øhall we not rehear≈øe ≈øo many of them.

div.head: Of Solon.
div.p: THough wee ≈øtudye to be brefe here, yet wyll not I pa≈ø≈øeouer Solon vnrehear≈øed:Solon „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ and beg „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of the Romane lawes Thales and Solon at one „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . for of hym hath the ciuyll lawe of the Romanes, whych is yet in v≈øe his oryginall begynnynge. Thys Solon lyued about thys tyme, and was very familyar wyth Thales. But whan at Athenes were ≈øpronge great debates, becau≈øe that the greate≈øt of the citye, had made bonde men of theyr creditours, that were not able to pay them, euen of pryuate wylfulne≈ø≈øe, the whole citye of Athenes dyd agree to Solon, that he ≈øhoulde take order and correcte thys wyllynglye of the greate≈øtmen, and the other mi≈øv≈øes of the commune wealth. Solon toke thys wyllynglye vpon hym, and ≈øet forth manye excellente con≈øtitutions and lawes, the whych are yet manyfe≈øt.

Now was Draco the law geuer by the Athenians, before, Solons lawes were not ordered with anye mercye at all, for he ordeyned that all tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions and tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes ≈øhoulde be puni≈øhed wyth the ≈øwearde: and for thys cau≈øe ≈øayde one, that Dracons lawes were wrytten wyth bloude, andDracons lawes. not wyth y ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ k. So hard and cruell con≈øtitucions were in the worlde at the begynnynge. But nothyng can be durable, that is to extreme, and is not mitigate with the temperaunce of mercy or iu≈øtice. As for Solon made a difference in the≈øe thynges or degrees, and ordeined that ≈øome ≈øynnes ≈øhoulde accordynge to rea≈øon be puny≈øhed greueou≈øly, and other more mercyfullye ordeined al≈øo of geuinge trybute, of weyghtes, and of the ≈øea≈øoÃÑs of the whole yeare. And ≈øpecially is this lawe pray≈øed, in theSolons law concernynge vagabondes whiche he ordeined, that euery man ≈øhould certyfy the higher officers once in the yeare how great his ≈øub≈øtaunce were, and of what maner crafte he were, where with he gat hys lyuynge: and if there were any ydle fellow or vagabounde, too dryue the ≈øame out of the cytie.

div.head: Of Camby≈øes.
div.p:
CAmby≈øes began to raygne whan hys father Cyrus went to warre agayn≈øt theCamby≈øes‚ñ™ Scythians. He ioyned the kyngdome of the Egiptians, to his fathers domynion. But he was greatly vnlyke his father in vertues. Whan Prexa≈øpes one of hys chefe coun≈øelersPrexa≈øpes. had admony≈øhed hym ≈øomewhat boldelye, and ≈øayde that the Per≈øes dyd alow hym greatly,
but that the ≈øame my≈ølyked them, that he was geuen to dronkenne≈ø≈øe. He cau≈øed the Peeres of hys realme to be called together, and demaunded whether he might worthely be blamed in any thynge. But they an≈øwered, No, but that he al≈øo ≈øurmounted hys father Cyrus in vertue: for by hys actiuene≈ø≈øe was Egypte al≈øo ioyned to his kyngdome. But Cre≈øus (to whom Cyrus had chefely commended his ≈øonne Camby≈øes to be taughte & norturedThe „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . in hone≈øty) ≈øayd the coÃÑtrary: CaÃÑby≈øes (quod he) can not yet be compared to hys father Cyrus, for he hath not left ≈øuch a ≈øonne of his begettinge, as Cirus hath left Camby≈øes. This delectable ≈øayenge plea≈øed Cambi≈øes at that tyme. But as the coun≈øel departed, whan none of the princes had blamed ought in him, he commaunded Prexa≈øpes to be called to him, and bad him bringe his yonge≈øt ≈øonne to him: For he woulde declare howe ≈øobre he myghte ≈øeme to be, euen whan he were droncken. For he woulde ≈øhute wyth a bowe at his chylde, whan he was droncken, and if he coulde hyt his harte with the darte, than he might thynke that in drinkynge he were not be≈øyde the capacite of his rea≈øon: but if not‚ñ™ than he might worthely be ≈øayde to be geuen to dronkenne≈ø≈øe.

But what nedeth many wordes? Whan Camby≈øesThe „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of Camby≈øes. had well dronken, he ≈øhott at the chylde as at a marke, and as the darte was pearced thoroughe, he cau≈øed it to be rypt vp, and ≈øhewed to hys father Prexa≈øpes, that the harte was ≈øhot thorough a ryght, ≈øayenge, that thereby he might haue euydence, that he was not dronken.
So barbarous, cruel and tyrannicall maners bringeth dronkenne≈ø≈øe into mens mindes, though theyDronkenne≈ø≈øe bryngeth in mo≈øt wycked maners. be well taught before: euen as no doute was that kynge Camby≈øes was from hys youth brought vp in moo≈øt hone≈øt nourture. And though a dronken man can hytt a right in ≈øhoutinge, yet in the meane whyle can he not v≈øe the ryght coun≈øels of rea≈øon, and wanteth tho≈øe vertues, whiche communely ≈øteare men to mode≈øtye and auancement of glory. Such lyke examples ought to be ≈øhewed to yonge men, whiche ≈øometyme be enclyned and geuen to dronkenne≈ø≈øe: for what ende folowed of the≈øe, ≈øhall we ≈øhewe ≈øhortely hereafter. He ≈ølew al≈øo hys own brother Smerdis, whome he cau≈øed priuely to be put to death, le≈øt he ≈øhuld raygne at any tyme. He maryed al≈øo hys owne ≈øy≈øter, where neuerthele≈ø≈øe nature doth abhorre ≈øuch kynde of maryage.

It fortuned vpon a tyme, that whan kynge Camby≈øes ≈øat at borde wyth the quene, at y‚Ä¢ meale tyme, ≈øet he a lyons whelpe and a ≈øtrong dogge together to make a game: and whan the lyon had the ouerhande by rea≈øon of hys fearcene≈ø≈øe & ≈øtrength,The faythfulne≈ø≈øe of dogges. another dogge of no le≈ø≈øe fearcene≈ø≈øe brake wyth great ≈øtrength the bandes y‚Ä¢ he was bounde withal, and holpe his brother the dogge, and ≈øo was the lyon ouercome. The kyng had great delyte at that game, becau≈øe of the faythfulne≈ø≈øe of the dogges. But the quene moued wyth the ≈øame dede, began to wepe very bytterly, and whan the kynge toke that ≈øorowfully, and a≈øked the cau≈øe of her weping, ≈øhe an≈øwered: To my brother happened nothynge le≈ø≈øe, than ≈øuch faythfulne≈ø≈øe, as I haue ≈øene in the≈øe
dogges helping eche other. The kyng taking thisThe cruelne≈ø≈øe of Camb ‚Ä¢ ≈øes toward ‚Ä¢ is ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øter the „Äà‚óä„Äâ . an≈øwere wrothfully, cau≈øed her ≈øtrayght waye t ‚Ä¢ be had out of hys ≈øyght, and ‚Ä¢ lew her. But ≈øuch co ‚Ä¢
dicions can not longe pro≈øper. For God ≈øayeth in the ≈øcryptures: The bloud thyr≈øty and deceatfull ≈øhall not lyue oute halfe theyr dayes vpon earth. Wherfore God ≈øtroke hym not longe after wyth a greueous and heauy vengeaunce. For as he ≈øhould come out of Egypte into Per≈øia, as he ≈øat vpon his hor≈ø≈øe, hys ‚Ä¢ wearde fell out of hys ≈øheeth, and wounded hym ≈øo ≈øore in the one ≈øyde, that he dyed. This example ≈øheweth, that God ≈øuffreth tyrauntes not
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . very longe. For he lyued not much more than one yeare after Cyrus, nother left he anye heyre after hym: and of thys wy≈øe is he cleane deade. It is truely a pyteous thynge and greatly to be bewayled, that in ≈øo lytle a ≈øpace the kingdome of the Per≈øes is taken from the po≈øteritie of Cyrus. The rule of the empyre remayned neuerthele≈ø≈øe wyth Cyrus bloude. For Darius had wedded Cyrus doughter the whyche neuerthele≈ø≈øe was al≈øo of Cyrus bloud.

div.head: Of the puni≈øhment of a wicked iudge.
div.p: NO prince is of ≈øo de≈øperate hope, which doth not at any tyme ≈øome laudable or hone≈øt thynge. For God doeth garni≈øhe the offyce of a gouernour or high officer, and maketh that other whyles notable and nece≈ø≈øary thynges are done nece≈ø≈øarely, for the con≈øeruation of publyke admini≈øtration.

Camby≈øes is alowed in all hi≈øtoryes for thys one ‚Ä¢ ede, for the which he is worthy to be pray≈øed. HeSi ‚Ä¢ amnes a wicked iudge. had a gouernour in the fore part of A≈øia, called Si
‚Ä¢ amnes: he heard ≈øaye that this iudge iudged vniu
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ly, beynge corrupt wyth gyftes of mony: Wherefore he cau≈øed him to be ≈ølayne, and the ≈økynne ‚Ä¢ lain o ‚Ä¢ from his body commaunded he to be fa≈øtened vpon the iudges ≈øeate, and ordeined in ≈øteade of the deade iudge his ≈øo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e called Ota ‚Ä¢ es, and ≈øat hymOta ‚Ä¢ es. in the ≈øeate ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ diciall vpon this maner and condition, that by the beholdyng of his fathers ≈økynne he ≈øhuld beware, le≈øt he ≈øhould be puni≈øhed lykewy≈øe. This example warneth tho≈øe that are in authorytye, to remembre that God will not ≈øuffre wyckedne≈ø≈øe to be vnreuenged.

div.head: Of Darius Kyng of the Per≈øians.
div.p: WHan Camby≈øes was gone into Egypte, the Magi rebelled agayn≈øt him at Su≈øa,An example of a notable inte ‚Ä¢ p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ aÃÑce. Who were called Magi and one of the Magies toke the name of a kyng vpon him by gyle. Magi are called y‚Ä¢ wy≈øe men & prie≈øtes of tho≈øe contryes. But whan Camby≈øes made him now ready to returne into the kyngdome, that he might puni≈øh worthely tho≈øe ≈øeditious Magies, euen in his yourney by a mi≈øchaunce (as we haue ≈øayd before) he dyed. A ‚Ä¢ ter the death of Cambi≈øes the Magies beyng ≈øla ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e, y‚Ä¢ Peers of the realme toke the kingdome to them: ≈øelues after that poyntyng a day of a≈ø≈øembly, they came to treate of re≈øtoringe one into the kingedome Per≈øy for a certayn order.

The peers or Princes were ≈øeuen in nomber,
as in the Germ ‚Ä¢ ne empyre are ≈øeuen Electors: tho≈øe doutle≈ø≈øe were cho≈øen and poynted by greate wy≈øedome and coun≈øell, as the hyghe≈øt coun≈øellers of the wh ‚Ä¢ le empyre of Per≈øia. Whan now the≈øe ≈øeuen prynces were come together, to deui≈øe for the commune health of the realme, there ro≈øe controuer≈øy in deui≈øynge, and of thre thynges ≈øpecially.

One Othan ‚Ä¢ s coun≈øelled to cho≈øe no more kynges,

The ≈øeconde Megaby≈øus refu≈øynge that coun≈øell ≈øayde, that ≈øuch lybertye ≈øhoulde be wor≈ø≈øe than tyranny: for the princes and cityes, yf they want a Lorde, can not but mi≈øv≈øe that libertye to priuate wylfulne≈ø≈øe. But le≈øt anye ≈øuche do happen, it were good not to choy≈øe one onely kynge, but to orde ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e ≈øome princes, by whome ≈øhoulde alwaye remayne the full power of a kynge.

The thyrd called Darius refelling the ≈øentence of ether of them, coun≈øelled one kyng to be cho≈øen: for though in thys poynt, as in all other thynges of men myght befall great and many inconueniences, yet is no royalme or dominion more ≈øurer than
