it is mo≈øt euident, there can no fayrer or more profytabler thynge be founde, tha ‚Ä¢ a Monarchye, namelye, whych goeth nexte to a godly kingdome. Moreouer it can not be that concorde can be kepte longe amonge fre princes, or yf ≈øome princes be cho≈øen to gouerne ≈øome myghtye realme in ≈øteade of a kyng: and that for the diuer≈øytye of moo≈øt weighty cau≈øes, whych myght ≈øome tyme befall in ≈øo large a dominion, in the whiche the princes coulde not allwaye agree together. Be≈øydes thys that there ≈øhoulde not want amonge≈øt the princes the endeuour of ≈øouerayntye and gouernaunce aboue the other, ouer the which he ≈øhoulde procure to rule, as ouer ≈øubiectes or inferiors. The≈øe were the cau≈øes which Darius alleged: vnto whom agreed the other foure princes, and ordeyned to choy≈øe a kyng after the co≈øtum ‚Ä¢ ble maner.

But le≈øt any debate myght ary≈øe amonge the princes of the royalme they determyned to committe the lot of the kynges eleccion to God. They agreed that the princes ≈øhoulde come together very early on hor≈øes into a certayn place, and who≈øe hor≈ø≈øe ≈øhuld neye fyr≈øt, the ≈øame ≈øhould be kyng. Darius beynge come home, ≈øhewed thys cou ‚Ä¢ ≈øell to the controller of hys court, whych ≈øayde he would ea≈øely brynge it to pa≈ø≈øe. For before the euenyng of the appointed daye he dyd lead Darius hor≈ø≈øe and a mare into the place appoynted, and there letteth he go the hor≈ø≈øe to the mare‚ñ™ that in the mornynge the hor≈ø≈øe comminge to the place, myghte neye for the mare beyng ab≈øent.

And as the princes came together in the appointed
a place at y‚Ä¢ ≈øet houre, Darius hor≈ø≈øe neyen fyr≈øt: & le≈øt they might dout whether it were Gods will that Darius ≈øhould be their kinge, ≈øodenly at y‚Ä¢ ≈øame very tyme whan the hor≈ø≈øe neyed, was ther a lightening in an open and cleare ayer with thonderinge. Forthwith the other princes lyghtynge from their hor≈øes, dyd to Darius dew reuerence.Darius is made kyng of Per≈øia. And by this occa≈øion was Darius ≈øet vp in the hygh dignitie of the Per≈øian empyre, the which he gouerned after that with great prai≈øe. He re≈øtored with great power the countries that were rebelled whan Cyrus dyed in Scythia, to the empyre. Babilon the citie al≈øo, refu≈øynge now the dominion of the Per≈øes, he recouered after longe≈øiege, and that by this meanes:

One zopyrus the ≈øonne of Megaby≈øus, one ofThe notable ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ thfulne≈ø≈øe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Zopyrus „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Darius. the ≈øeuen lordes or princes, cau≈øed willinglye hys no≈øe, eares and lyppes to be cutt of, maketh the kinge priuy of his coun≈øell, and falleth to the Babilonians as one that were fled: he complayneth of the kinges cruelne≈ø≈øe, whiche cau≈øed him to be of this wy≈øe di≈ømayde and toren, becau≈øe he gaue him coun≈øell to for≈øake the cytie: nother fayned he hym≈øelfe otherwy≈øe, than to be the kynges enemy, and that he were fled to the Babilonians for cau≈øe of coun≈øel taking. The Babilonians did frely receaue him, and as he was made capitaine of them, he ≈ølew ≈øome of Darius ≈øouldiours: for ≈øo was he agreed with Darius, that therby he might at the fir≈øt augment the confidence of the Babilonians in him. Afterward ye Babilonians tru≈øted him with the whole army, the which he betrayed to Darius: and made
al≈øo that he recouered the whole citye, the whiche he had nowe be≈øieged ≈øyxe monethes and a whole yeare. As for Darius gaue hygh thankes to thys zopyrus for hys faithfulne≈ø≈øe, for he ≈øet hym afterwarde before all the princes of his kyngdome. And as a pomgranate was geuen hym, he ≈øayde: HeA graue ≈øayenge of Darius. woulde wy≈øh him no better thinge in this lyfe. than that if he might get ≈øo many zopyries, as there are graines in this apple. For therby would he ≈øignifie that a kynge can haue no worthier trea≈øure, nor no ≈øtronger fortre≈ø≈øes, than faythful frendes and coun≈øellers.

div.head: Of Darius Warres in Grece.
div.p: THE Per≈øians a≈ø≈øayed to drawe byEmpyres haue theyr boundes. claime to them the kingdomes of Macedony and Grece, becau≈øe they bordered vpon Per≈øia. But becau≈øe God hath prefixed euerye royalme as it were certayne boundes, the whyche it can not pa≈ø≈øe: therfore coulde the Per≈øian kinges ≈øubdue nor make ≈øubiectes to theyr empyre, nother the Macedonians nor the Grekes. Wherfore happened about that tyme in Grece many and greate chaunces: the which as they are many, euen ≈øo to rehear≈øe them all ordely, were to longe: but I ≈øhall rehear≈øe them all ordely, were to longe: but I ≈øhall rehear≈øe ≈øome of them, howbeit none ≈øaue the very be≈øt, and that brefely.
The Per≈øians ≈øendinge Amba≈ø≈øadours toAmyntas kyng of Macedony. Amyntas kynge of Macedouy, de≈øyred that he woulde yelde hym≈øelfe to them.

Amintas being afrayd becau≈øe of the Per≈øians, power, graunted willingly to do their reque≈øt in a maner pro≈øtrate, & treated me≈ø≈øengers very courteou≈øly. And whan a royall banket was ordeined for y‚Ä¢ Amba≈ø≈øadours after their wil, they de≈øired to haue brought to them noble women and ladyes, for to garny≈øhe the banket. Amyntas which dur≈øt denye them nothynge, commaunded to brynge them.

Whan the Per≈øians were now droncken, they dalyed wyth the gentle women vncourteou≈øly, in≈øomuch that theyr vnmanerelyne≈ø≈øe yrked and di≈øple≈øed kyng Amyntas, and his ≈øonne Alexander theAlexander „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Amyntas. yonge king: and by rea≈øon of the ≈øhamefulne≈ø≈øe and reuerence of age, de≈øyred Alexander his father the kynge Amintas, that departing out of the company, he would go to bed, & he wold remayne with the ge≈øtes. As the father went now away, Alexander faynyng myrth, he ≈øuffred the Per≈øians to daly and playe more frelier wyth the women: at the la≈øt he prayed them all to ry≈øe, and ≈øuffre the ladyes to go a lytle apart, for they ≈øhould ≈øtrayght way
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of Alexander returne better trymmed. The nobles of the Per≈øians ≈øuffred that wyllingly. In the meane ≈øea≈øon cau≈øed Alexander the fayre≈øt yongmen apparelled wyth womens garmentes to returne into the banket, and hyde ≈øweardes vnder theyr garmentes, wherewyth in daylienge they ≈øhould ≈ølaye the Per≈øes, the which was done. For the Per≈øyans were kylled of euery one of the≈øe yonge men, and thus was theyr vn≈øhamefulne≈ø≈øe greueou≈ølye puni≈øhed. This Alexander is rehear≈øed amonge the greate grauntfathers of Alexander. After this rebelled the Grekes al≈øo, which were vnder Darius in the
forepart of A≈øia, and taking the citye Sardis, burnedSardis. it, and to this dyd the Athenians ayde them.The ≈øutteltye of Hi≈øtieus in makinge an vproure. For one Hi≈øtieus a noble prince ≈øente a ≈øeruaunt to their captayne, and le≈øt the matter ≈øhould be di≈øclo≈øed, polyng his ≈øeruauntes heade, he prynted vpon hys heade letters conteynynge this ≈øentence, that they ≈øhould di≈øceuer and rebell to the kynge: afterward as the heare was growen agayne, he ≈øent no letters, but this ≈øeruaunt to the capitaine wyth this me≈ø≈øage only, that he ≈øhould klyppe of his heare, and loke vpon his heade: the whiche whan the capitaine had done, ≈øtraight waye fell he from Darius. But thys traytour was kylled, and Hi≈øtieus was hanged, and the commotion beynge ≈øwaged wyth the≈øe remedies, went no farther.

This and other lyke gaue Darius occa≈øion toHow great ≈øettinge forth to warre vpoÃÑ Grece Darius made. gather a great hoo≈øt, namely a hundreth thou≈øand footemen, and ten thou≈øand hor≈øemen, and to ≈øende them into Grece to be reuenged of the Athenians for the ≈øedition and vproure. They pytched their tentes two myle from Athenes. Whan nowe ≈øome coun≈øeled not to wyth≈øtande the enemies, but yf they be≈øieged the citye, to defende it manly, onely Miltiades coun≈øellinge the contrary, ≈øhewed that the ≈øyege ≈øhould be heauy and verye intolerable for the communalty: but with a ≈øodayn inua≈øyon myght the enemyes be lyghtely vanquy≈øhed. TheyThe coun≈øell of Miltiades. folowed Miltiades coun≈øell, whom al≈øo they made captayne of the warre: the Athenians made an army agayn≈øt the enemies of ten thou≈øande, nother had they any ≈øuccour≈øe out of the other cyties, ≈øaue of one thou≈øand men that the city Platea had madePlatea.
out. And wyth thys ≈ømall army, was that greate and cho≈øen company of the Per≈øyans di≈øcomfytedThe re ‚Ä¢ ow
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ d victory ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Miltiades and layed doun: and thys battayll de≈øerued a very great pray≈øe, for it deliuered all Grece from a great and incredible feare, where wyth ≈øhe was no le≈ø≈øe taken at that tyme, than yf at oure tyme the turke ≈øhulde inuade Germany.

We mu≈øt not ouerpa≈ø≈øe here, what recompen≈øe the Athenians haue made finallye to Miltiades, and how they haue requyted hym, for thys good dede. For be≈øyde this victory, had he done other great actes for the commune welth. Wyth chyualry had he added other cities and yles, wherewyth he augmented the empire and dominion of the Athenians. But becau≈øe greate vertues can not want the enuy and detractions of euell men, it was procured by the people and broughte to pa≈ø≈øe,

that M ‚Ä¢ ltiades was ca≈øt into the commun pre≈øon, vntyll he payed to the communalty thre hundreth thou≈øande crownes. But whan he was not able to paye that ≈øumme, and beganne nowe to be ≈øycke of the longe pre≈øonment and ≈øtenche, his ≈øonne Cymon
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øonne ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ M ‚Ä¢ ltiades went into pre≈øon to delyuer the father: at the la≈øt whan the father was deade, a very ryche city≈øin maryed Myltiades doughter, and di≈øbur≈øynge out the ≈øumme of money, he delyuered Cymon out of pre≈øon. Can not good men be duely rewarded of the communaltye on thys wy≈øe?

div.head: Of Kyng Xerxes.
div.p:
DArius had two ≈øonnes: the elder was begotten ear he had the kingdome offred, but the yonger called Xerxes was in y ‚Ä¢
Xerxes.
tyme of the kyngdome of hys mother Ato≈ø≈øa that was Cyrus doughter. The ≈øame by rea≈øon he was of both parentes of the kynges bloude‚ñ™ he ≈øucceded his father beyng dead in the royalm, that the kingdome myght remayne by the y≈ø≈øue of Cyrus. The elder brother ≈øuffred this wyth a great mode≈øty of mynde, ≈øtryuynge in no manere wyth his brother Xerxes. As now the hoo≈øt of y‚Ä¢ Per≈øians was ouer throwen in Grece, Darius a≈ø≈øembled a new army, but in thys appoyntynge dyed he. Wherfore Xerxes ≈øtraight before hys raygne accompli≈øhed the preparation that hys father had begonne, and entred into Grece with a moo≈øt puy≈ø≈øaunt army, in≈øomuch that ≈øome haue writteÃÑ, that neuer was ≈øo great anHow great Xerxes army was agayn≈øt the Grekes. army a≈ø≈øembled before at one tyme, as was kynge Xerxes armie. Iu≈øtine ≈øayeth, that of his own kingdomes were ≈øeuen hundreth thou≈øand men in armoure, and of the other that were confederat with hym, thre hundreth thou≈øand men. Though it ≈øemeth not wel to be beleued, that ther haue ben ≈øuch a multitude, yet beare hi≈øtories wytne≈ø≈øe ynough, and al≈øo ≈øunderye battails that were had at that tyme, that Xerxes hoo≈øt was very great. And now at this pre≈øent time do we proue ≈øufficiently, wyth howe great an hoo≈øt, howbeit lyght armoure, the Turkes and other nations of the Ea≈øte do make theyr warre.

Daniel al≈øo wytne≈ø≈øeth, that a kynge ≈øhall come oute of Per≈øia again≈øte the Grekes wyth a very great hoo≈øt of ≈øouldiours. It is red al≈øo, that whan thys great multitude was now gathered in one felde, Xerxes weping, ≈øayd with an h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y
harte. The cau≈øe of mans life is very mi≈øerable: for of ≈øo many thou≈øand men, can not one lyue ouerThe graue ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ yenge of Xerxes. a hundreth yeare. It is al≈øo ≈øayde that whan Xerxes nowe ouerlayed the ≈øtrayghtes of the ≈øee wyth brydges, as there ro≈øe a tempe≈øte, he commaunded to beate the ≈øee.
To thys belongeth it al≈øo, that it is not vnworthely ≈øayd, that in goynge forth, hys hoo≈øte dryed vp floudes wyth drynkynge.

Wonders were al≈øo ≈øene, the which admoni≈øhed
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . the kyng to de≈øy≈øt of his enterpry≈øe, becau≈øe of the my≈øhappe to come. For a ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ brought forth an hare in the hoo≈øt, where by was ≈øignifyed flyght. Ther appeared al≈øo a comet, called Ceratias, the which is bowed lyke a horne. Ther was al≈øo an Eclip≈øe of the ≈øonne. And as hy≈øtoryes make mencion, ≈øuche ≈øignes are not ≈øene wythoute ≈øome vnhappyne≈ø≈øe or hurt, namely by the which God threateneth hys wrath: and therfore oughte they not to be de≈øpy≈øed, but rather a pryck or ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ynge for vs that we do feare God: for here maye be ≈øene what alteracions of commune welthes and all e≈øtates of the worlde are en≈øued.

Xerxes wolde fyr≈øte ≈øet vpon the Grekes wyth
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the Grekes is „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . battayll by lande. As for Grece is clo≈øed rounde about, and ther is no entry into it ≈øaue by ≈øee, or by ≈øome ≈øtrayghtes of the mountaynes, wher certayn thou≈øands of the Grekes were ≈øet to kepe the enemyes from entrynge in, of the whyche the greate≈øt parte fled contynently as the Per≈øes would entre: only foure hundreth Lacedemonians abode whichThe of the Lacedemonians. v≈øed greate force to re≈øi≈øt the enemies: and though
they were farre le≈ø≈øe in nombre and weaker, than that they could dryue back ≈øo great force of the enemies, yet declared they ≈øuch ≈øtrength in fyghtynge, that they ≈ølew about twenty thou≈øande of the Per≈øes.

For beynge ayded wyth the oportunite of the ≈øtrayghtne≈ø≈øe of the mountaynes, they were ≈øafe of the inua≈øion and oppre≈ø≈øion of the multitude of the enemies, nother coulde they be enuyrouned by waytes layenge. In the ≈økyrmi≈ø≈øe dyed Xerxes two bretheren, but on the other ≈øyde died the foure hundreth Lacedemonyans, wyth theyr kynge Leonides. The acte is greatly pray≈øed by rea≈øon of the courage and ≈øtrength to defende the country, becau≈øe that they beynge ≈øo fewe in nombre, were not afrayed to ≈øet them ≈øelues agayn≈øte ≈øo great a multitude: and though they had not the victory, yet was the power of the enemies greately abated with thys ‚Ä¢ yght, and theyr hardene≈ø≈øe myny≈øhed.

Whan the Per≈øes had the victory in thys battayll, wounder it is, how greatly all Grece was afrayed, and in that parte of Grece did ≈øome cities yelde them ≈øelues frely to Xerxes. At Athenes al≈øo one Cyr≈øylus, or as ≈øayeth Herodotus, LycidasCyr≈øylus. coun≈øelled, that the Athenians al≈øo ≈øhoulde geue them≈øelues vnder Xerxes power: for in no maner are they able to wyth≈øtande ≈øo myghty an enemy. Themi≈øtocles contrary wy≈øe coun≈øeled to defendeThemi≈øtocles a defender of the liberty of the countrye. the lyberty of the contrary. For if the Per≈øes fortune to haue dominion in Grece, all hone≈øty of maners ≈øhall be in daunger, all lawe, all good vertues
≈øhall pery≈øhe. The Per≈øes ≈øhall v≈øe all wyllfulne≈ø≈øe agayn≈øt their wyues and chylderen, as it were euidente they haue done agayn≈øt them, whiche were now ≈øubiect to them: therfore were it more hone≈øte to dye in the libertye, than willinglye to admitte ≈øuch lordes.

Thys coun≈øell of Themi≈øtocles was accepted of euerye man wyth a commune con≈øent, that they ≈øhoulde defende them≈øelues manlye agayn≈øt the enemies. The Athenians beynge wroth wyth Cyr≈øylus for hys wycked coun≈øell, commaunded
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚ñ™ to ≈øtone hym: and the women lykewy≈øe ≈øtoned hys wyfe, becau≈øe her hu≈øband had put forth ≈øuch coun≈øell, the whyche if they had folowed, they ≈øhoulde haue broughte all theyr chylderen to di≈øhone≈øty.

Thys dede is pray≈øed for the vertue, and is worthy of remembraunce, that they woulde rather dye for the lybertye of the contry, than they ≈øhoulde yelde them≈øelues to a ≈øtraunge nacyon, to ouerthrowe the ≈øtate of theyr citye and all policye and hone≈øty.

As the Athenians a≈øked coun≈øell at the aun≈øwere
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚ñ™ of Apollo at Delphas, it was aun≈øwered them: that they ≈øhould haue victory with walles of wood: the whiche Themi≈øtocles expounded of the defence of ≈øhyppes, and he exhorted that leauynge the citye, they ≈øhould lead their wiues and children into the ≈øhyppes: for their citie ≈øhould at length not be able to wyth≈øtande the power and ≈øo great multitude of the Per≈øians, be≈øyde that al≈øo be not the Per≈øes very well appointed by ≈øee.

Thys coun≈øell was alowed, and the re≈øidue
of the cities haue folowed it. Sparta and Corinthus, the whiche with a furny≈øhed nauye helde by force the ≈øtraightes of the ≈øea, by the yle Salamina, le≈øt they mighte be compa≈ø≈øed by the multitude of the ≈øhyppes that Xerxes had.

Whan Xerxes hearde that the Grekes had made a nauy, and vnder≈øtode that greate daunger ≈øhoulde come to hym, yf the Grekes v≈øed the ≈øea frely, and as they had oportunitie, ≈øhould falle into the kyngdome: it was coun≈øelled Xerxes, that contrarywi≈øe he ≈øhoulde combre the Grekes wyth warre vpon the ≈øea. The ≈øame was done. But as the Grekes had the victory, the moo≈øte part of the Per≈øes was di≈øcomfyted, and many ≈øhyppes were drouned.

This victory re≈øtored a courage to all Grece, and made Xerxes feble. The kynge him ≈øelfe was not in the battaill, but remaininge with a fewe ≈øhyppes vpon the coa≈øt, he dyd onelye beholde it. All the Grecians rendred the renoume of the battaill to Themi≈øtocles onelye, becau≈øe that the victory beynge gotten by his coun≈øell, all Grece was ≈øaued.

Amonge the re≈øte of the traynes, whyche Themi≈øtocles v≈øed in thys warre, I thoughte toThemi≈øtocles ≈øuttyll deuy≈øe. rehear≈øe thys one ≈øuttyll deuy≈øe. Whan Xerxes was aba≈øhed after the battayll, he thought the kynge mighte ea≈øelye be broughte thereto, that leauinge Grece, he ≈øhoulde returne for alltogether into Per≈øia wyth the re≈øte of hys armye.

Therfore faynynge hym ≈øelfe humbly pro≈øtrate‚ñ™ as wyllinge to procure fauoure by the kynge, he
cau≈øed to ≈øhew hym by the me≈ø≈øenger, that the Grekes deui≈øed to breake the bridge, the whyche he had cau≈øed to be layde before vpon the ≈øea: Wherefore to haue hym ≈øtrayght waye oute of Grece, before the occa≈øyon of flyenge were taken him, wythout he woulde ca≈øt him ≈øelfe in great daunger. As he hearde thys tydynge, he made him ≈øtrayghte waye readye to flye. But whan in flyenge he fande the bridge broken by the tempe≈øte, he pa≈ø≈øed ouer wyth a lytle boate, euen wyth vtter daunger of his lyfe, becau≈øe the ≈øea was troubled wyth the vehemency of the floudes. Of thys wy≈øe dyd God turne the fortune of the dice, and puny≈øhed the
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ mple „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚ñ™ pryde. Great princes haue here an example ≈øett before them, whereby they mu≈øt learne not to tru≈øte in their puy≈ø≈øaunce, but that in the feare of God and tru≈øt to God mu≈øt great thynges be taken in hande. That he had thys ≈øhamefull ende, for becau≈øe this expedicion made euery man ama≈øed, and al≈øo for becau≈øe Xerxes dyd brynge on to Grece ≈øuch a great multitude and power none otherwi≈øe than in oure tyme the Turke was con≈øtrayned to for≈øake the city of Vienne with great ≈øhame, which came into Germany with an hoo≈øt of two hundreth thou≈øande men.

Howbeit Xerxes departynge out of Grece, left Mardonius the capytayne there wyth thre
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ni
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚ñ™ thou≈øande ≈øouldyours: and that for thys cau≈øe, becau≈øe the kynge per≈øuaded by Mardonius coun≈øell wente into Grece, agayn≈øte the mynde and wyll of the other Lordes.

And becau≈øe it happened not as Mardonius promy≈øed, therefore dredinge le≈øt beynge returned home he might lo≈øe hys heade, becau≈øe of the mi≈øchaunce of the warre, he de≈øyred that he might be left in Grece wyth that army, to a≈ø≈øaye all fortunes of warre, yf by chaunce he coulde make feble the affayres of the Grekes. Xerxes than ≈øuffred that, and betoke hym to hys fortune.

Fyr≈øt beganne Mardonius frendely to entreate the Grekes, that hauing layde before them tolerable condicions of peace, they woulde willingly yeld them≈øelues. But the Grekes beynge become more couragious, by rea≈øon of the victory, refu≈øed vtterly all dominion of the Per≈øes, and denyenge the leage, a≈øked that he ≈øhoulde defende hym ≈øelfe with force and fyghtynge hande. Than toke Mardonius and burnt the citye of Athenes, and wente thorough vntyll Thebe: for they of Thebe were fallen to the Per≈øes. The Athenians and Lacedemonians makyng than agayn a fre≈øh army by land of an hundreth thou≈øand men, met at ≈øundry times with Mardonius in battayll: at the la≈øte Mardonius con≈øtrayned for faut of vytayls, made an ende. AlexanderAlexander. kyng of Macedony was wyth the Per≈øes, of whom we made mencion before: the ≈øame ≈øhewed the Grekes before the euenynge, that they ≈øhould make them ready in armes on the next day, for Mardonius was determined to pyche hys la≈øt felde, and that was ≈øo done, but the Per≈øes beyng ouercome, lo≈øt the felde, Mardonius beyng ≈ølayne al≈øo, whiche thynge the other coun≈øellers of kyng
Xerxes tolde him before the warre began. But this was the ende of ≈øo great a ≈øettyng forth to warre: and whan this warre was ended, the cities of Grece began too encreace in power and enlargynge of their dominion ≈øubduyng many yles of the Per≈øes, whiche they adioyned to their dominion. Moreouer the Grekes beyng become puy≈ø≈øauÃÑt, waxed al≈øo haut and pre≈øumtuous, and for de≈øyre of dominion, they procured al≈øo inwarde ≈øedicion & warre with in them≈øelues: and beyng ouercome with mutuall damages that eche had done to the other, they were con≈øtrayned fynally to yeld them≈øelues to ≈øtraunge princes, quenchynge and de≈øtroyeng all the e≈øtate of their common wealth and the vertues, whereby they flory≈øhed before. But of this ≈øhall we treate a lytle hereafter.

It is nece≈ø≈øarye to knowe Themi≈øtocles exampleThemi≈øto
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ rded for „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . before any thyng, the whiche for ≈øo muche as he was the man, by who≈øe proui≈ø≈øe and coun≈øail whole Grece was ≈øaued, for the whiche thynge al≈øo hys pray≈øes are auaunced, more then of any valeaunt captaine, whiche Grece had: yet was he euel rewarded of his cite≈øens: for they droue him out of y‚Ä¢ citie. This thanke geueth the commoÃÑ people for the mo≈øt worthye vertues: yea the deuell hym≈øelfe blyndeth men, that they do not acknowledge ≈øo hygh gyftes of God. Wherfore it behoueth the be≈øt and excelle ‚Ä¢ t men to haue pacience before all thynges: for it can not bee, but they mu≈øt haue grefes and all vnthankfulne≈ø≈øe in that ≈øtate of lyfe. After that fledThemi≈øtocles fl ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ th too Artaxerxes. Themi≈øtocles to Artaxerxes, by whome he was had in greate honor, in all thynges equall to the
princes and peeres of his royalme. It is wrytten al≈øo, that Artaxerxes ≈øhould haue ≈øayde: he coulde wy≈øhe his enemies no more euyll, but that they blinded with ≈øuch madne≈ø≈øe, dyd put awaye wy≈øe men from them.

div.head: Of Artaxerxes with the longe hande.
div.p: AS Xerxes was deade, raigned his ≈øonneLoÃÑgimanus‚ñ™ that is with the loÃÑg hand. Artaxerxes: who≈øe right hande was longer than the left, whereof he gat the ≈øurrname, wyth the long hand. Thys kynge is chefely pray≈øed for his ≈øyngular wy≈øedome and gentlene≈ø≈øe of maners and endeuour of peace. Therefore do I rehear≈øe his hi≈øtorye here nomore at length, that wee maye finallye returne to the Iewy≈øh hy≈øtories, le≈øt we be ignoraunce what ≈øtate was in the church and ≈øpyrytuall kyngdome.

div.head: Of Zorobabel the Iewy≈øh capitayne.
div.p:
WE haue ≈øhewed before that in the Bible is one of the Per≈øian kynges called A≈ø≈øuerus: but the ≈øame wasA≈ø≈øuerus. Darius Hi≈øta≈øpis, and as I ≈øuppo≈øe, thys Darius is A≈ø≈øuerus, which hadHe≈øter. quene He≈øter. Herodotus doth al≈øo make mencion of Arti≈øtona, the whiche Darius had be≈øyde queneArti≈øtona‚ñ™ Ato≈ø≈øa. Ato≈ø≈øa, and ≈øayeth that the ≈øame Arti≈øtona was very well beloued of Darius: and it appeareth that thys ≈øame was He≈øter. Philo writeth al≈øo that the hi≈øtory of Iudith happened in the tyme of this Darius: and that Arphaxad, whereof the hi≈øtory of Iudith maketh mention, was captayn of y‚Ä¢ A≈ø≈øyrians,
after that they were now fallen from Cyrus, wh ‚Ä¢ was ouercome of the Scythyes. I do not di≈øalow thys meanynge of Philo: but verely as I do ≈øuppo≈øe, the hi≈øtory of Iudith was now already fulfilled, before that Iuda was led into bondage: and al≈øo before the Per≈øians monarchy.

For Arbaces kynge of the Medes was beforeArbaces. the monarchy of the Per≈øes: and Ninius was de≈øtroyed in the tyme of the Per≈øians kyngdome: and whan the Per≈øes had the monarchy, nether Ninius, nor the Medes had theyr kynge. Howbeit I graunt here euery man to defende hys meanynge.

After Darius Hi≈øta≈øpis ≈øetteth Philo Artaxerxes wyth the longe hande, pa≈ø≈øynge ouer king Xerxes, but doutle≈ø≈øe for none other cau≈øe, ≈øaue as is ≈øhewed before namely, than whaÃÑ Xerxes was gone into Grece, Darius wyth the long hand gouerned the royalme in the Ea≈øt in the meane ≈øea≈øon. And this is that Darius with the longe hande, whiche
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ is, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ long hand. gaue the Iewes leaue the ≈øeconde tyme to buylde agayne the temple. For though Cyrus had permitted the Iewes to returne to Ieru≈øalem, for to tyll theyr lande, and to re≈øtore the kingdome & the wor≈øhip of God: neuerthele≈ø≈øe in the meane ≈øea≈øon after Cyrus death‚ñ™ were they letted by the borderers, y‚Ä¢ the building could not goo forewarde, vntill the ≈øeconde yere of Artaxerxes with the long hand, whoÃÑ Philo calleth Darius with the longe hande. The≈øame commaunded in the ≈øecond yeare of his king
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ by a commune proclamation & commaundement, that Ieru ‚Ä¢ al ‚Ä¢ & the temple ≈øhuld be repared.
This was the occa≈øion, by the whiche the Iewy≈øh natioÃÑs was re≈øtored to his libertie, in≈øtituted again the gouernaunce of the royalme, with the Gods ≈øeruice, and builded agayne the temple and cities. And though Iuda had not hetherto his kynges, yet had they princes of Dauids po≈øterite, vntil that tyme, that the Machabees began to reigne. Fir≈øte reigned zorobabel, who≈øe po≈øteritie what fortune they had, and how finally the whole kyngdome is tran≈ølated from Dauids po≈øteritie, ≈øhall we ≈øhewe hereafter. For ≈øo was it prophecied afore by the prophetes, that Chri≈øte ≈øhould be borne about thatChri≈øtes coÃÑ myng. tyme of Dauids bloude, that foren princes ≈øhoulde v≈øurpe to them the kyngdome of the Iewes, that was now already alienated.

div.head: The rekenynge of the ≈øeuenty wekes out of Daniel.
div.p: IT was ≈øhewed Daniel by heauenly reuelacion of Chri≈øtus commynge, and howe long the Iewy≈øh people ≈øhould la≈øt. Ther is a notable wytne≈ø≈øe in this prophecy, to confirme the certaynte of our faith again≈øt the Iewes, whiche ≈øtriue and contende that Chri≈øt is not yet come, and wayte yet for another Me≈ø≈øias.

Verely the rekenyng of the tyme appointed by Daniel, is ea≈øy, and ≈øpecially it is plea≈øaunt to know thereby, that Chri≈øte was ≈øurely come about that tyme, the whiche Daniel hath pre≈øcribed. For though other do count diuer≈øly, yet if ye go not froÃÑ the order of the hi≈øtories, there ≈øhall bee found no great di≈ø≈øention, wherfore ye could doubt. For the diligent rekening of the tyme, is requi≈øite to repete
out of Ptolome the≈øe Eclip≈øes, that are happened, and to gather out of them ordely euery yeare: but that were not one mans laboure. And diligently ought By≈øhops to occupie them in the≈øe thynges, with doyng co≈øtes, that the vnder≈øtandynge of ≈øo notable prophecies, myght bee clerely had in the churche. I truely wyll gather here out of the be≈øt hi≈øtories the nombre of the yeares, and endeuoure to make the rekenyng there of very playne.

Daniel ≈øayeth: Seuenty wekes are concludedThe place in Daniel of the ≈øeuenty wekes. vpon this people, and ≈øpecially accordynge to the commaundement of buyldyng agayne Ieru≈øalem, ≈øhalbe ≈øyxty and nyne wekes, vntill Chri≈øtes kyngdome, and than ≈øhall Chri≈øt be put to death.

Fyr≈øt mu≈øt it be knowen what that the wekes do yearly ≈øignifye, ≈øo that euery weke make ≈øeuen yeares, the whiche maye ea≈øely be proued. Wherefore the ≈øeuenty wekes make foure hundreth and nynety yeares.

Secondly ≈øayeth Daniel: Chri≈øte ≈øhalbe put to death after thre ≈øcore and nyne wekes: but ≈øo that he teache the half weke, and afterward bee put to death. The tyme and office of Chri≈øt is notable expre≈ø≈øed of this maner.

Thyrdly mu≈øt the nyne and ≈øeuenty wekes bee rekened from the ≈øeconde yeare of Darius Longimanus, that is, wyth the long hande: For then dyd God ≈øende Zachary and Aggeus the prophetes, that they ≈øhoulde comforte and certaynely a≈ø≈øure the people of repairyng Ieru≈øalem hereafter without any hynderaunce. And of this worde, that is, of this reuelacion are the aungels wordes to be vnder≈øtande:
Becau≈øe then was made the ≈øure promy≈øe to the people, of the furtheraunce of the temples repayryng.

Be≈øyde that commaunded Longimanus that ≈øelf ≈øame yeare by an open commaundement, that ‚Ä¢ he Iewes ≈øhoulde not be hyndered of their purpo
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d worke of buyldynge the citie and temple, as it was done before. But all this is to be red in the bodies of Eldras.

And ≈øurely to this ≈øame delaye of tyme in repairyng of the temple had ≈øaint Ihon re≈øpect in the ≈øeconde chapter of his go≈øpell, where the Iewes ≈øaid, that in buyldyng of the temple, were ≈øpent ≈øyx and fourty yeares: for that is the nombre of the yeares, from the ≈øeconde yeare of Cyrus, vntyll the ≈øyxte yeare of Longimanus, wherein the worke of the temple was accomply≈øhed.

But now is it gathered out of the booke of the Machabees, and out of Io≈øephus, that from the begynnyng of Alexander, after the death of the la≈øt Darius vntyll Chri≈øte was borne, to be thre hundreth and ten yeares.
From Chri≈øtes byrth vntyll hys baptyme thyrty yeares.
Summa, from the begynnynge of Alexander vntyll the baptyme of Chri≈øte, thre hundreth and fourty yeares.

To the≈øe put the tyme from the ≈øeconde yeare of Longimanus, vntyll Alexander after the death of the la≈øte Darius, and as Meta≈øthenes counteth there ≈øhall be a hundreth and fyue and fourty yeares.
Summa, from the ≈øecond yere of Longimanus vntill, the bapti≈øme of Chri≈øte are foure hundreth, foure ≈øcore and fyue yeare.

And therfore thre ≈øcore and nyne yearly wekes make euen foure hundreth and foure ≈øcore and two wekes. Whereby it is manife≈øt, that when Chri≈øte was bapty≈øed, were fulfylled three ≈øcore and nyne yearly wekes, and in the weke folowynge taught Chri≈øt, & in the ≈øame half weke was he put to death: For Chri≈øte was put to death the fourth yeare after that he was bapti≈øed. Wherfore when this weke that foloweth is added to the thre ≈øcore and nine, there ≈øhalbe ≈øeuenty wekes: and this is the maner to count the tyme appoynted by Daniel. For after Chri≈øtes death are the Iewes nomore Gods people, and their temple was afterward an abominacion, the whiche Daniel witne≈ø≈øed playnly.

Be≈øyde this are other notable doctrines, and con≈øolacions of troubled coÃÑ≈øciences in this prophecy, of Chri≈øtes office and kyngdome, that he came to preache forgeuene≈ø≈øe of ≈øynnes: but to expounde all this maketh to no purpo≈øe here, nother is it here taken in hande.

I haue truely ≈øought out with ≈øo great diligeÃÑte as I could, the maner of countyng the ≈øeuenty wekes of Daniel: nother do I fynde that it can greatly varye, if ye wyll folowe the fourme of hi≈øtories. For though ye wyll not folowe Meta≈øthenes, yet doth the rekenyng of the Grekes agre very well here with. For after the countyng of the Grekes are betwene the death of Alexander, and the beginnyng of Augu≈øtus twoo hundreth and foure ≈øcore
yeares, the whiche I can proue with very ≈øtronge rea≈øons. If ye do now take the yeares of the Per≈øians, after thee ≈øeconde yeare of Longimanus by the Grekes, ye ≈øhall fynde the ≈øame al≈øo.
After Alexander vntyll Chri≈øtes byrth, are thre hundreth and two and twenty yeares.
After Chri≈øtes birth vntyl hys bapty≈øme thyrty yeares.
Put therto the nomber of the Per≈øians from the ≈øecond yeare of Longimanus an hundreth and two and thyrty yeares after the Grekes.
Summa of this is foure hundreth, foure ≈øcore and foure yeares.

So perfectly do the hy≈øtories of the Grekes agre with the tyme that is founde in Io≈øephus and Philo, that ye maye openly perceaue, the tyme of Chri≈øtes commynge to be mo≈øte fyttly appoynted by Daniel. And truely I doubte not, but wy≈øe and learned men will alowe and te≈øtifye, that both the≈øe rekenynges that we haue ≈øet here, maye bee very well proued by wytne≈ø≈øes of hy≈øtoryes. And without it were to longe, I coulde brynge yet other more rekenynges, whyche ≈øhoulde agre with the≈øe al≈øo: So that it is no doubte, but that Daniel hath mo≈øte ryghtely hytt thee tyme of Chri≈øtes commynge. It hath al≈øo no ≈ømall pyth of con≈øolacion or comfort, (though the maner of the tyme do not agre ≈øo iu≈øtly with euery minute,) that we may be certyfyed, that the tyme prophecyed of Daniel be longe ≈øence pa≈øt. Wherfore are the Iewes in manife≈øt erroure, whiche can by no rea≈øons proue, that the ≈øame tyme is not yet pa≈øt, though they wyll vnder≈øtande
the wekes of dayes or yeares. But her of is ynough.

But I fynde by the Grekes the tyme after Alexanders

This nomber doth not ≈øo greatly di≈øagre wyth the other aboue reher≈øed, and can ea≈øely be made to gre of learned men.

div.head: Of E≈ødras.
div.p: A Certayne ≈øpace after the coÃÑmaundement publy≈øhed dyd kynge Artaxerxes let E≈ødras the ≈øcribe returne to Ieru≈øalem. And duely not without a cau≈øe ought meÃÑ tion to be made of this man in the hi≈øtories: for theE≈ødras gathered together the bookes of the Bible. bookes of the holy ≈øcripture, that were now ≈øcattered and ≈øtrowed, dyd he gather agayne and ≈øet in order. For this worke was worthy to be the duety of a true by≈øhop. Becau≈øe that without holy ≈øcripture, cannot be maynteined the true religion and wor≈øhyp of God.

In the tyme of this Artarerxes Longimanus began the great warre of Peloponne≈øus, whicheThe warre of Peloponne≈øus. the Grekes had amonge them≈øelues, in the whiche the citie of Athens at the la≈øt was vtterly de≈øtroyed. This warre la≈øted neare hande vntyl the ende of the Per≈øian monarchy: and therfore I wyl fir≈øt brefely reher≈øe in their order the Per≈øian kyng. s. ≈øuche as are yet behynde.

div.head: Of Darius the ba≈øtarde.
div.p: DArius the ba≈øtarde reigned after Longimanus, and of truth he was not the ≈øonne of LoÃÑgimanus, but had his ≈øi≈øter to wife and was his brother in lawe. He had two ≈øonnes, At taxerxes whom they cal Mnemon, and Cyrus the yonger. Artaxerxes ≈øucceded his fatherArtaxerxes Mnemon, Cyrus. in the empire. Cyrus was made mo≈øt pui≈ø≈øaunt in Ionia.

div.head: Of Artaxerxes Mnemon.
div.p: AS Darius was deade, Cyrus began to take fal≈øly to hym the kyngdome: for be≈øyde that he ruled in a mo≈øt pui≈ø≈øaunt duchy, he was apte al≈øo for all manner of thing, and delited chefely in warre, and therfore armed he hym≈øelf with great power again≈øt his brother.The warre of Cyrus agai≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ brother. Be≈øide this had his mother more affection to hym, than to his brother, whiche had a mode≈øt and gentle mother wit. But God did not pro≈øper this wicked enterpri≈øe of Cyrus: for in a battaill, where he tought again≈øt his brother, was he ≈ølaine. Artaxerxes declared hym≈øelfe not without courage in this battaill: for he was greueou≈øly wonded of Cyrus, and lept vpon another hor≈øe, that he ≈øhoulde knowe, that the victory came to hym afterwarde by God only.

div.head: Of Ochus.
div.p:
OChus the ≈øonne of Artaxerxes was mo≈øte gredy of mans bloud: for be≈øide the great tyranny that he v≈øed, he ≈ølew al≈øo his own brothern. He buylded the citie Sidon, and brought Egypt againe to the Per≈øian monarchy:
but they kept the loyalte of their yeldyng not very longe. At the la≈øt was he ≈ølayn of one of his gouernours.

div.head: Of Ar≈øames.
div.p: AR≈øames was the ≈øoÃÑne of Ochus: the ≈øame was made kyng being yet yonge, by the capitain of the ho≈øt, which flew his father Ochus. But when Ar≈øames began now to wax great, the capitain of the hoo≈øt fearyng, by rea≈øon of the wycked dede that he had done, he ≈ølew by a di≈øceat this Ar≈øames al≈øo. Afterward makyng a league with Codomanus prince of Armenia, he toke to hym the kyngdome al≈øo, and called hym, Darius. Thus was the kynred of the noble princeCyrus kynred was queÃÑ ≈øhed. Cyrus quen≈øhed, and the kyngdome of the Per≈øians beyng tran≈ølated from Cyrus po≈øterite, came to a foren prince. Nether is that onely to be lamented, that ≈øuche power and honour, and ≈øo hygh gyftes of God, were deleyed and put out of remembraunce within ≈øo few yeares: but muche rather, that Cyrus folowers beyng ≈øtrayght waye vnlyke hym, dyd declare their father to haue no maner of vertue, the whiche appeareth in Ochus, who≈øe feates of tyranny gaue occa≈øion that the whole kynred of Cyrus was aboly≈øhed.

div.head: Of the la≈øt Darius.
div.p:
The ≈øame was ≈øtraunge from Cyrus but heDarius the la≈øt. was made prince of Armenia by kyng Ochus for his noble actes of chyuairy, for the whiche actes al≈øo he was cho≈øen kyng by them, that had ≈ølayne Ar≈øames, left he ≈øhould be
reuenged of Ochus, that had done hym good. ButAn example of vnkyndne≈ø≈øe. being blynded by this occa≈øion, and with the hope of the kyngdome that was offered hym, he forgat all the benefites, that he had receaued of Ochus, and hauyng the kyngdome, he called hym≈øelfe Darius, that nothyng ≈øhould be wanting to the royall dignitie. But he was greuou≈øly puni≈øhed for his vnkynone≈ø≈øe and di≈øloyaltie. For when he was vanquy≈øhed of Alexander, lo≈øynge all his landes and kyngdome, he lo≈øt al≈øo his lyfe & the whole monarchie of Per≈øia. But we ≈øhall treate more largely hereof in the begynning of the third monarchie, and when we ≈øhall ≈øpeake of Alexander.

div.head: The Warres of the cities of Grece.
div.p:
WE haue touched before how the Grekes waxed welthy and pre≈øumptuous when the Per≈øes were driuen out of their landes: for pride and pre≈øumption do commonly folow after great pro≈øperitie. Wherfore duryng this monarchie, they had great and durable warres among them≈øelues, by the whiche whole Grece went finally to naught: in≈øomuche, that after ward it was open for euery man to breake in. And al≈øo for the mo≈øt hone≈øt gouernauÃÑce & lawes, which they v≈øed in their coÃÑmon welth, ≈øucceded filthine≈ø≈øe and mo≈øt corrup maner of behaueour. And whome would it not greatly pitie to reade, that ≈øo many & great commodities or yuels, and ≈øo durable and wickedMo≈øt great warres ray≈øed very lyght cau≈øes. warres are ray≈øed of ≈øo lyght cau≈øes. They be examples herely not onely to be wondered at, but al≈øo mo≈øt worthye≈øt to be marked, for they may admony≈øhe
men, that they take no warre in hand lightely and for euery lyght cau≈øe, but only con≈øtrayned by great nece≈ø≈øitie: ≈øeing the warre rai≈øed amonge the Grekes for a ≈ømall occa≈øion, could be in no maner nor meanes be ≈øwaged and layed downe, tyll finally ≈øtraunge people fallyng into Grece, oppre≈ø≈øed both partes.

It is not my mynde here to de≈øcribe this whole warre: for Theucidides, Xenophon, and afterward other haue written therof whole bokes. But I wil reher≈øe one thyng among all other, namely what fall the citie of Athens hath had in this warre, and what mi≈øery ≈øhe hath ≈øuffered, when ≈øhe was taken in. And agayne how ≈øhe was at the la≈øt re≈øtored againe by the vertues, moderation and pacience of ≈øome good men. For as hautne≈ø≈øe, hardine≈ø≈øe & pre≈øumption brought the ≈øtate of the citie in decay, euen ≈øo dyd pacience and mekene≈ø≈øe of maners re≈øtore the ≈øame agayne.

The begynnyng of the warre was aforen cau≈øe,The occa≈øioÃÑs of the ware of Peloponne≈øuswere light and how loÃÑg they la≈øted. the whiche the Athenians myght ea≈øely haue e≈øthued. For the Corinthians were enemies to the citie Corcyra, the which required ayde of the Athenians: and optained it the ea≈øier, becau≈øe that the Athenians, which were already ≈øtrong on the ≈øee, hoped that through the league and confederation of theÃÑ of Corcyra, which had al≈øo great pui≈ø≈øauÃÑce vpon the ≈øee, they ≈øhould become lordes of whole Grece. On the other ≈øyde y‚Ä¢ CorinthiaÃÑs required a≈ø≈øi≈øtauÃÑce of the Lacedemonians, and of this wy≈øe was Grece diuided. The Lacedemonians did ioyne them ≈øelfs with the Per≈øes, of whome they were a≈ø≈øi≈øted with
mony and victuals: howbeit the Per≈øes v≈øed in the meane ≈øea≈øon di≈øloyalte or fal≈øhode, le≈øt the LacedemoniaÃÑs ≈øhould become to mighty. And this warre dured (as ≈øayth Xenophon) eight & twenty yere, froÃÑ the tyme of Longimanus, vntil Axtarerxes Mnemon, and many cities pery≈øhed my≈øerably in thys warre. Al≈øo may be ≈øene a wonderfull alteration of fortune in the examples of this warre. For when Alcibiades was captayne of the Athenians, were the Lacedemonians greately put to the wor≈øe and ≈ølayn, and that in the foure and fyue and twentieth yeare: ≈øo that they de≈øpayred euer to come to their former abilitie. Howbeit ≈øhortely after, in the nexteAlcibiades. yere was the worlde turned. For when Alcibiades was driuen out of the citie, though the en ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e of ≈øome malepart or euel men, were the Athenians ≈ølayen ofLy≈øander. Ly≈øander by the citie Egos of Potanus, where had happened a ≈øtraunge wonder in the begynnyngeA woÃÑder ≈øene in the tyme of the GreciaÃÑs warre. of this warre. For in the ayre was ≈øene a great fyre the ≈øpace of thre ≈øcore and fyftene dayes. Afterward fell a great ≈øtone from aboue into the cicie. After this battaill was the citie of Athens enuironed with a heuy ≈øyege. Many died of hunger. Being demauÃÑded to yelde them, vpoÃÑ this coÃÑdicionThe ob≈øtma
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and malepartne≈ø≈øe of yt Athenians in time of warre confirmed al≈øo with a deare. that they ≈øhould breake downe the towres & fortre≈ø≈øes of the citie: they refu≈øed malepartly the coÃÑdictoÃÑs of peace, & remained by their purpo≈øe: geuing al≈øo a common commaundement, that who ≈øo ≈øhould couÃÑ ≈øaill to make a league of agremeÃÑt with the enemies, ≈øhold be put to death. As lately is happened with y‚Ä¢ Florentines about .ii. yeres pa≈øt. But after fyue monethes were the Athenians coÃÑ≈øtrained with huÃÑger
to ≈øende Amba≈ø≈øadours into the hoo≈øtes tentes too demaunde peace. Wherevpon when they had taken deliberacion in the coun≈øaill of thoos that had con
‚Ä¢ ederated them≈øelues the Corinthians and Thebanes did con≈øtantly coun≈øail, that the citie of Athens ≈øhould be ouerthrowen euen out from the foundacion, and that of all their dominion ≈øhould be made commune pa≈øtures. But the Lacedemonians reproued that, ≈øuppo≈øyng to be not hone≈øt to quenche and ca≈øt it away at once of ≈øuche wy≈øe and to forgett the remembraunce of ≈øuche benefites, wherewyth this citie had holpen whole Greke again≈øt the Medes and Per≈øes. Moreouer could not al≈øo ≈øo excellent a ≈øtate of this citie be ouerthroweÃÑ, without the incredible hurte of all the Grecians. For they ≈øayd: that Grece ≈øeyeth with two eyes, whereof the oneSparta and Athens are two eyes of Grece. was Sparta, the other Athenes: Wherfore hede mu≈øt be taken, le≈øt Grece haue but one eye. Wherevpon it was concluded finally that Athenes beyng ≈øaued, onely the towres and walles ≈øhoulde bee ca≈øt downe, and a certaine gouernaunce ≈øhould bee pre≈øcribed the Athemans, after the whiche they ≈øhould lyue, and ≈øo ≈øhould peace be made on both parties.The yeldyng of the Athenians. The Athenians yelded them≈øelues frely vpon the≈øe condicions, and the walles were ca≈øt downe with great triumphe: for with min≈øtrel≈øy dyd they dauÃÑ≈øe al≈øo. Part of their nauy was brent, and part caried they with them. This happened about the ≈øeuen & twentyeth yeare when this warre had la≈øted. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe were the Lacedemonians alrayd of one Alcibiades, whiche was ≈øled to the Per≈øes when he was driuen out of Athenes. Wherfore the Lacedemonians
required of the Per≈øes, that they wouldAlcibiades Ayeng to the Per≈øes is ≈ølayn. The Per≈øes are an example of di≈ølopal ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . ≈ølayn Alcibiades, whiche the Per≈øes did by a trap though the Per≈øes had receaued Alcibiades according to the office of ho≈øpitalitie, and that he had put all his tru≈øt in the faith of the Per≈øes. But it chauÃÑ ≈øeth ≈øo with men, that were fortune doth incline her ≈øelf, that waye doth mans fauour loue al≈øo. Therefore ought he chefely to be ware, euen of the vnfaith fulne≈ø≈øe offrendes, whiche is out of pro≈øperitie, and he whom men do enuie and yrke, for hatred of hys vertues. This Alcibiades was hyghly furni≈øhedAlcibiades ‚Ä¢ as ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ oble in ‚Ä¢ ea ‚Ä¢ es of war but re≈øtle≈ø≈øe & ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ . with feates of warre or chiualry, but of an vnquiet minde, & he was cau≈øe of the breche of the peace that was many yeares before concluded betwene the Lacedemonians and Athenians: He had v≈øed in all Grece ≈øo many wyles and ≈øo ≈øundry craftes, that it was euen commonly ≈øayde: If there had happened to be borne two Alcibiades in Grece, it mu≈øt nedes haue gone wholy to naught. Howbeit ≈øuche endeuoure can not pro≈øper, therfore died Alcibiades fynally of this ≈øorte. And though the warres of the cities were now ≈øyny≈øhed, yet began now fyr≈øt the de≈øtruccion of men at Athenes. For ≈øeyng the citie of Athens was full of rebellions, there were ordeyned of the Lacedemonians thirty men, whom they
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ yrauÃÑ
„Äà‚óä„Äâ were ordeyned at Athens. called Tiranny, to whom was committed aucthoritie, that they ≈øhould puni≈øhe the ≈øedicious rebelles without law or iudgement: and le≈øt any man ≈øhould with≈øtande this aucthoritie with any ≈øedicion, they layed a great garni≈øon of ≈øouldiours in the ca≈øtell.
Of the re≈øtoryng of Athens after the de≈øtruction of it.

THe Lacedemonians v≈øed this ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe, to puni≈øh the common commotions, and hygh nece≈ø≈øitie con≈øtrayned them to do that. The thirty men v≈øed their aucthorite at the fir≈øt again≈øt no man, ≈øaue the ≈øedicious: afterward did the olde hatred of ≈øome of them bru≈øte out again≈øt ye be≈øt of the citie, but good men did they put to death: ≈øemblable examples of ye like we haueTheramenes is put to death. knowen in oure dayes. And whan this di≈øplea≈øed one of them, named Theramenes, a doughty man and iu≈øt, they ≈ølew him al≈øo, to cau≈øe other to be afrayed: and that more is, thei parted the goodes of theÃÑ that were put to death, among their compainions. The be≈øt of the cite≈øens fled to Thebe and Argos, where for pitie of ≈øo vnworthy my≈øery, the were receaued, euen agayn≈øt the commaundement of the Lacedemonians, whiche was that no man ≈øhoulde receaue the Athenians that fled or were bany≈øhed. Amonge the≈øe banny≈øhed men was one that was doughty and valiaunt in the common wealth, called Thra≈øybulus: the ≈øame ioynynge with hym theThra≈øibulus re≈øidue of the banny≈øhed men, and a preuy ayde or ≈øub≈øydy of them of Thebe, taketh in the ca≈øtell by Athens, and afterwarde goyng to Athens, and pychyng a felde, vanqui≈øheth the thyrty Tyrannos‚ñ™ and recouereth the citie. The cite≈øens that were fled were re≈øtored by this Thra≈øybulus: and as coÃÑ cernyng gouernaunce of policy, iudgementes and lawes, the ≈øtate of the whole common wealth was chaunged, after the olde cu≈øtome. Thra≈øybulus de≈øeruedThe pray≈øe of Thra≈øibulus. chefely a greate pray≈øe for his moderation of the mynde, that after ≈øo notable a victory,
wherein he had al≈øo taken many of the enemies pri≈øouers, he woulde rather ≈øpare them, then by good ryght to ≈ølaye them. And when he con≈øidered that there ≈øhould be no ende of puttyng to death, yf thee goodes of the cite≈øens that were taken away ≈øhould be re≈øtored to euery man agayne or to the true heyres, namely, that were already come to the third or
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ orget ‚Ä¢ ulne≈ø≈øe of i ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ uries is ordeined. fourth po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor: he bande them euery one with ≈øuch a bande amonge them≈øelues, that no man ≈øhoulde thenceforth remembre any vengeaunce or iniury done, but that euery man ≈øhould kepe that he had, & kepyng the common peace, euery man to be content with his portion or lot. By this meanes and moderation was a quietne≈ø≈øe ≈øet in the common wealth. And this is a noble example, that with beneuoleÃÑceA notable exaÃÑple to main
‚Ä¢ ame v „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ e. and forgenyng is procured a more durable concord in ≈øuche cinyll commotion, then that euery man wyl go forth with rigour and force.

Afterward were the Lacedemonians become proude and haut al≈øo with this lucky chaunce: For they would dryue Per≈øes out of A≈øia, whiche had
‚Ä¢ odon capitayn of the Per≈øes. ≈øuccoured them. But the Per≈øes for that tyme made Codon capitaine of their hoo≈øt, whiche was fled from Athens in the ciuill commotion: of hym were the Lacedemonians di≈øcomfyted. The Lacedemonians takyng greueou≈øly their mi≈øfortune, layde al the fault vpon them of Thebe, becau≈øe they had entertained the banny≈øhed Athenians: wherfore theyThe LacedemoniaÃÑs ‚Ä¢ ight with ye Thebanes, and a
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ di ‚Ä¢ con ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed fell into their contryes of the whiche ro≈øe a new occa≈øion of warre, in the whiche the Lacedemonians beyng ouercome, were wholy vndone, & the Thebane power encrea≈øed.

Whan this warre was fini≈øhed, the ThebanesThe Thebanes de≈øtroye the PhociaÃÑs. toke another warre again≈øte the Phocians, the whiche were wholye aboly≈øhed, and the re≈øidue were banni≈øhed. Finally dyd Philippe kyng of MacedonyPhilippe de≈øtroyed the Thebanes. di≈øcomfite and tame them of Thebe. And thus were fyr≈øt Athens, after that Sparta, finally Thebe de≈øtroyed, and al that power of the Grekes came to naught. Howbeit whan the Athenians and Thebanes dyd not kepe the conditions and appointementes of peace made with kinge Philippe, he was coÃÑ≈øtrained to inuade for to take in al Grece.

This is ynough ≈øpoken in brefe maner of the dolefull warres of Grece, the whiche were an hundreth and thyrtye yeares after Xerxes, durynge which ≈øpace was lytel peace. The≈øe warres are at large written by Thucidides and Xenophon, and ≈øome other. We haue thought it therfore ≈øufficient, yf we had opened and declared the example of the Athenians, y‚Ä¢ which is the principal in that hi≈øtory.

div.head: Of the Philo≈øophers.
div.p:
IN the meane tyme that thys befell, dyd learnynge al≈øo flory≈øh. Hippocrates theHippocrates Phi≈øicion lyued from the tyme of Longimanus, vntill Ochus, an hundreth and foure yeares. And be≈øyde that all Grece had hym in greate e≈øtimacion, he was al≈øo muche made of by the kinges of Macedony, by the which al≈øo he ≈øpent great part of his lyfe. Soranus wryteth that HippocratesSoranus wrote the life of Hippocrates. was ≈øent for by kynge Perdicas, becau≈øe many iudged that the kynge was fallen into a con≈øumption, and was for≈øaken of other Phi≈øitions.
But whan Hippocrates was come, he perceaued that the kynge was not ≈øycke for feblene≈ø≈øe of bodely ≈øtrength, but that he pined for loue and inwarde ≈øorowe. For he loued out of mea≈øure the handemayden of his father, & as oft as he ≈øawe her, chaunged both the mynde and colour in the kynge. Of thysPerdicas was healed of Hippocrates. wy≈øe perceaued Hyppocrates the cau≈øe of the ≈øyckne≈ø≈øe, and gaue remedy to dryue it awaye. Be≈øyde this, whan the pe≈øtilence raigned, he cau≈øed a great‚òû woode to be ≈øett on fyre agayn≈øte the infect ayer, whence the infection of the ayer came: and of thys wy≈øe kept he the whole contry The≈ø≈øalia ≈øafe from the pe≈øtilence. He was al≈øo renoumed of naturall miracles. Vpon his graue were bees a greate ≈øea≈øon, with who≈øe hony were ≈øycke chylderen healed, that were anoynted therewyth.

About the tyme of Artaxerxes Mnemon, was Socrates, whych by the enuy of hys aduer≈øaryesSocrates. was poy≈øoned and dyed in the pre≈øon. He was accu≈øed to be a brynger vp of a newe learninge in the citye. But by the prouidence of God, were the aduer≈øaries not longe after puni≈øhed worthelye, for they were put to death al≈øo.

div.head: Of Plato, Eudoxus, Ari≈øtoteles.
div.p:
AFter the≈øe were Plato and Eudoxus aPlato, Eudoxus, Ari≈øtoteles. very connynge A≈øtrologian, whych al≈øo brought this ≈øcience oute of Egypte into Grece. After thys man was Ari≈øtoteles, I ≈øuppo≈øe the≈øe to be the chefe amonge the Philo≈øophers, and after my iudgement are the chefe of theÃÑ Eudoxus & Ari≈øtoteles, namely becau≈øe they were
not only garni≈øhed with plea≈øaunt wordes or rea≈øons, but ≈øtudious of the very thynges. For they accu≈øtomed that kynde of learning, as is mo≈øt profytable, partely to knowe the propertie of naturall thynges, and partly to learne what waye men may lyue hone≈øtly. It is a moo≈øt plea≈øaunt thyng to beholde, howe God hath ≈øett all kynde of vertues in oure owne nature. Ari≈øtotele was borne of parentesAri≈øtotles elders. Nicomachus‚ñ™ not of the bafe≈øt or lowe≈øt condicion. His father was Nicomachus, a man of very great authoritye by Amyntas kynge of Macedony: for he was hys Phi≈øicion. Hys of≈øpring was of Hippocrates kynred, & for thys cau≈øe had kynge Philippe that was ≈øonne to Amintas, Ari≈øtotele in ≈øuchreputacion, afterwarde he gaue vnto him Alexander hys ≈øonne to be taught of him his di≈øcipline: and was taught of Ari≈øtotle the learninge of Philo≈øophie, that he might become more ready and wy≈øer to make a relacion and to geue coun≈øell. Hetherto haue we ≈øpoken ynough of the Grekes affeares, which happened about the tyme of thys monarchy.

div.head: Of Rome.
div.p: WHan the kynges were dryuen out of theWhan the coun≈øels of Rome began citie, the ≈øtate of the common welth was chaunged. The Coun≈øuls beganne to beare rule, and yearly were two cho≈øen, who≈øe authoritie in that office was one yeare.

This chaunge of the commune welth happened in the tyme of Cyrus the fyr≈øte monarche of the Per≈øes, the yeare after the worldes foundacyon thre thou≈øande, foure hundreth and fyftye, and
the ≈øeuenth yeare after that Babylon was wonne by Cyrus.

But be≈øyde other great and innumerable affeires, that befell at Rome, were al≈øo horrible ≈øedityons and chaunges in the commune wealth: in the whych are examples geuen vnto vs, that great cicyties and commune wealthes do endure ≈øeldome without great alterations. Howbeit in this maner, yt two Coun≈øules wer chefe rulers, la≈øted perpetually, vntyll the tyme of Iulius, which v≈øurped the monarchye. There were betwene the beginnyng of the Coun≈øels rulyng vntyl Iulius raigne, foure hundreth and thre ≈øcore and fyue yeares.
It were to long to rehear≈øe here the Romane hi≈øtories. I will only recite the tyme of two notable chaunces, that were befallen at Rome in the tyme of thys Monarchye.

In the hundreth and ≈øecond yeare after that the citye was builded, that is, not longe after Xerxes warre, aboute the beginninge of Longimanus raigne, ro≈øe controuer≈øy and di≈ø≈øen≈øion by the Romanes.The occa≈øion of the Romane lawes. For ≈øeynge they v≈øed not yet a certayne iu≈øtyce or lawes, men were oft vniu≈øtlye wronged in and out of iudgemente: for noman knewe yet perfectly what was ryght. And whan the multitude dyd for this cau≈øe murmure, it was ordeined, that a certayne lawe ≈øhould be written. Wounder it is of what importaunce be written lawes, to entertayne commune peace and concord in the commun welath, the which this example doth witne≈ø≈øe manife≈øtly.The Ten meÃÑ were ≈øent into Grece. For this thing were ten men cho≈øen, whiche beinge ≈øente into Grece ≈øearched oute and
e≈øpyed the maners and lawes of the greate≈øt cities, and in gathering together the be≈øte lawes dyd v≈øe the coun≈øell of Hermodorus of Ephe≈øus and other Philo≈øophers. Twelue tables were written, theTwelue tables. which were hanged vp openlye before the court of Rome. This is the begynning of the written lawe of the Romanes, the which they haue fyr≈øt borowed of the Grekes.

The Ten men ruled thre yeare: for it behoued that the lawes were euery daye declared. But AppiusAppius. one of the Ten men dyd abu≈øe hys power, which cau≈øed one Virginius a cite ≈øins doughter to be demed for another mans bondewoman, that by that cloke of lawe he might drawe her to hym and de≈øtore her: The whiche as the father perceaued, and ≈øawe that by rea≈øon of Appius power his doughter coulde not be delyuered, he ≈ølewe her him≈øelf in the iudgement, le≈øt his ≈øtocke ≈øhoulde be ≈øtayned with ≈øuch a reproche. Afterward gathering an army, he made ready an ayde again≈øt Appius the tyraunt.The Ten meÃÑ were depo≈øed. An example of vengeauÃÑce Than depo≈øynge the Ten men from their office, a new dignitie was ordeined. Appius beyng taken and ca≈øt into pry≈øon, ≈ølew him ≈øelfe. Thys example ≈øheweth that tyranny and iniu≈øtice remayne not vnreuenged.

The thre hundreth and thre ≈øcore yere after theRome was brent of the Frenchemen and Germanes. Camillus. foundacion of the citye, fell into Italy an army gathered of the Frenchmen and Germanes, whyche brent Rome. But Camillus, whom the commune people had before dryuen out of the citye, played y‚Ä¢ part of an hone≈øt man: for coloring wholy the iniury, the which he had ≈øuffred vnworthely, gathering
an army out of the next contryes, he oppre≈ø≈øed the Frenche men and Germanes wythin the citye, kepyng the ca≈øtel from be≈øyegynge, and the re≈øidue of the cite≈øins that were e≈øcaped. The dammage had the citye in the tyme of Artaxerxes Mnemon, and about that tyme nearehande was Athenes taken and ≈øpoiled.

In this hy≈øtory is the fir≈øt mencion madeThe fir≈øte „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ion of the Germanes in hi≈øtoryes. of the Germanes, and this was not wholy four hundreth yeares before Chri≈øtes byrth. Of the≈øe Germanes was Milane and other cityes in Italy buylded.

div.head: Of the thyrde Monarchye.
div.p: THe thre thou≈øand, ≈øyxe hundreth and foure and thyrtyeth yeare after the worldes creation, whan the dominion of the Per≈øes had la≈øted an hundreth and nynety yeares, that is thre hundreth and twenty yeares before Chri≈øtesThe begynnyng of the thyrd Monarchye. byrth, began the thyrd Monarchy, the whych we call the monarchy of the Grekes: and nowe is the dominion of the worlde tran≈ølated from the coa≈øtes of the Ea≈øt, into the We≈øt: and oute of A≈øia, into Europa.

From that time began A≈øia by lytle and lytle, more
and more to dekeye, not onelye in tho≈øe thynges that were concerninge the power of the empyre: but al≈øo in tho≈øe thynges that concerned mode≈øtye of maners, vertues, gouernaunce of coÃÑmune welthes and good learning. And though the≈øe thyngs are in a maner redre≈ø≈øed and re≈øtored by the Romanes, yet at the la≈øt came by violence the Barbarians into A≈øia, and dyd ≈øpoyle it, in ≈øo much that the≈øameThe decaye of A≈øia. parte of the worlde, whiche was wont to bee the moo≈øt excellentes, by rea≈øon of the plea≈øauntne≈ø≈øe of ≈øituation, wy≈øedome, hone≈øtye of men and puy≈ø≈øaunce of countryes, is now turned nearehand altogether into a ≈øynke of fylthine≈ø≈øe, and murthurous denne. And contrary wy≈øe tho≈øe hyghe≈øt giftes are nowe in the We≈øte, ≈øeynge the worlde doth drawe by lytle and lytle to the ende.

This monarchy beganne at Alexander kyngAlexander the greate. of the Macedonians, whom we do worthelye call the Great. For he was ≈øo excellent, not only in power of gouernaunce, but al≈øo in all other princelye vertues, that one woulde ≈øuppo≈øe he haue had but few that were equall to him. He is pray≈øed in Ieremye and Daniel the prophetes, becau≈øe he was a mo≈øt ≈øharpe and happy gouernoure. Daniel de≈øcribeth a buck, of whom is a ramme ouercome & ouer throwen, and doth expounde manife≈øtlye, that the buck is the kyng of the Grekes, and the ramme the Per≈øian kynge. The vertues and notable victoriesAlexander the buck, Darius the raÃÑme wherewyth God had garni≈øhed kynge Alexander, gaue ≈øome men occa≈øyon to falle & fayne muche of hys of≈øprynge, but I pa≈ø≈øe them ouer.

But this is certayne, that great and fortunable
princes are gouerned and kepte of God, and that they are endued only of God wyth tho≈øe‚ñ™ vertues and gyftes. For God wyll haue the maie≈øtye of gouernaunces to be kept and maynteyned by tho≈øe, whych are noble by noblene≈ø≈øe of aunceters, and flori≈øhing of kynred: and it is euident, that Alexander was borne of this ≈øorte. Hys father was kyng Philippe, and hys mother was Olympias. And thatThe parentes of Alexander. Philippes „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ e. nyght whan Alexander was conceaued, it is ≈øayde that Philippe ≈øawe in hys ≈ølepe, that he had a ≈øeale on Olympias belly, wherin was karued the ymage of a Lyon. It was expounded, that by that dreame was ≈øignifyed, that Olympias hauynge conceaued of Philippe ≈øhould brynge forth a moo≈øt puy≈ø≈øaunt kynge As for Philippe and Olimpias both of them were borne of the hyghe≈øt and moo≈øt noble≈øt kynred of all Grece at that tyme. For Philippe (if wee maye geue credet to the moo≈øt true wrytynges of hy≈øtoryes) came of Hercules, and Olympias of Achylles, the valiaunt captayn before Troye. The≈øe are the aunceters, of who≈øe ≈øtocke the renowmed prince Alexander is borne:
