div.p: This is the genealogy of Alexander, gathered out of moo≈øt certayn hy≈øtoryes, the whiche wytne≈ø≈øeth that the of≈øprynge of Alexander was of the po≈øterytye of very great men.

Whan Philippe was ≈øtayne, becau≈øe he left thePhilippe was ≈øtayne becau≈øe he left a wicked dede vnpuni≈øhed. wicked dede of a great man, that had ≈øhamfully defloured a noble chylde vnpuni≈øhed, ≈øtrayght waye after rebelled the Illyrians and Grekes, and fell from the Macedonians, and the kyngdome of the Macedonians ≈øtode in greate daunger. For whan his father Philippe was ≈ølayne, Alexander was
only twenty yeare olde. This was in the beginning of the hundreth and eleuenth Olympias afterThe deedes of Alexander ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e great. the rekening of the Grekes. But wha ‚Ä¢ Alexander had takeÃÑ to him the admini≈øtration of the royalme, he fyr≈øt broughte the Illyrians agayne vnder the yock, after that wente he to Thebe. For they of Thebe be≈øyeged the garny≈øon of men, that his father Philippe had ≈øet in there ca≈øtell, and al≈øo made a league wyth the Per≈øes, the whiche inuaded the kyngdome of Macedony. In the meane ≈øea≈øon that Alexander be≈øyeged them of Thebe, dyd the Athenians ≈øende amba≈ø≈øadours to hym, for to optayne peace. Alexander receaued them fauourably. They of Thebe in the meane ≈øea≈øon beyng ob≈øtinate, nother ≈øoughte for grace, nor conditions of peace. And whan it was proclamed by the coÃÑmaundement of Alexander before the a≈ø≈øaulte, that who≈øo of them of Thebe that woulde yelde them frely, and go oute of the cytye, ≈øhoulde ≈øaue theyr lyues. They of Thebe cau≈øed to be proclamed contrarye wy≈øe, that they that would haue the libertye of the Grekes wyth theirs ≈øaued, and the kynge of the Per≈øes, again≈øt the tyraunte Alexander, ≈øhoulde drawe to them. Alexanders my ‚Ä¢ de beynge chafed wyth that reproche, the citye was a≈ø≈øaulted, and
‚Ä¢ h ‚Ä¢ he „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ o ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ate „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ o ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ er „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ s. wholy ≈øpoyled, and was neuer re≈øtored afterward. Thys was the fyr≈øte greate citye that Alexander ≈øubdued. For we ≈øe mo≈øt communely come to pa≈ø≈øe, that God ordeineth puy≈ø ‚Ä¢ aunt monarches for the de≈øtruction of great cityes.

Whan Alexander had now made a peace in Grece, he went into A≈øia with ‚Ä¢ n hoo≈øt of fourty thou≈øand
‚Ä¢ oote men, but of hor≈ø≈øemen onelye foure thou≈øand. The army that was in A≈øia, the whiche his father had ≈øent afore, was but lytle. With this ≈ømall hoo≈øt falleth he vpon the Per≈øes, and maketh very great feldes, and taketh many mighty cityes with ≈øtrong hande, amonge the whyche was Sardis, Miletus and Tyrus. In conquering of the whiche, Alexander was in many ha ‚Ä¢ ardes. Vanquy≈øhyng al≈øo in battaill Darius the kynge, he put him to flighte, and takyng hys mother, hys wyfe the quene, hysAlexanders gentlyne≈ø≈øe. doughters and ≈øonne, he entreated them gentely, and as it be≈øemed there royall kynred. The que ‚Ä¢ e that was aged, called he mother: he entertayned her ≈øonne none otherwy≈øe, than if it had bene hys owne. Wounder it is what pray≈øe Alexander de≈øerued for the≈øe vertues in all A≈øia, and with Darius him≈øelfe, in≈øomuch that frely he offred hym≈øelfe to treate of peace, offerynge to be content to delyuer vnto him euen the half of his royalme. To this an≈øwered Alexander. that this worlde can not be ruled wyth two ≈øonnes: but yf he were content to yeld frely him ≈øelfe and hys royalme, he wold gentlyDarius is ouercome of Alexander. take him to grace. But Darius renewynge an hoo≈øt, was vanquy≈øhed, and was thru≈øt through in the flight, by his own ≈øeruaunt and guyde Be≈ø≈øus. Alexander comming vpon Darius, founde him very greueou≈øly wounded, and nearehand dead, and had pitye vpon him, & promi≈øed him that this vnfaythfulne≈ø≈øe of Be≈ø≈øus again≈øt his owne lord, ≈øhuldThe di≈øloyal tye of Be≈ø≈øus is an example of vengeaunce. not be vnpuni≈øhed. Wherfore Be≈ø≈øus beyng taken afterward, he cau≈øed him to be hanged betwen two trees, that were bowed do ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ward, the which
whan they were ≈øuffred to dre≈ø≈øe them≈øelues agayne, wyth a great ≈øwynge, they tare hym paynfully. Of thys wy≈øe was Alexander become gouernoure of A≈øia, and toke in farther the re≈øidue of the contryes and cityes, as Babylon, Su≈øa &c. The beginnyngeThe begyn
‚Ä¢ yng of Ale
‚Ä¢ anders monarchye. of thys monarchye of Alexander was after the death of thys la≈øt Darius, that is, in the begynnyng of the ≈øeuenth yeare after that Alexander began to raygne.

Alexander beynge become proude by thys victory, began to be di≈ø≈øolut in exce≈ø≈øe of dronkenne≈ø≈øe. He cau≈øed ≈øome of hys frendes and coun≈øellers to be put to death, which was the moo≈øt excellent and ≈øage captayne, the aged Parmenion. Be≈øyde thysParmenion. in hys wrath he ≈ølew hys valiant captayne Clytus in a banket, becau≈øe he preferred Philip his father
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . before Alexander his ≈øonne. But whaÃÑ his maners were chaunged, fortune chaunged al≈øo, though the mynde was not pea≈øable. Ho warred al≈øo vpon the Iudyans and Scythians, but he liued not long after that. For he dyed the two and thyrtyeth yeare, and eleuenth moneth of hys age. He raygned after hys father Phylyps departure, no lenger than twelue yeare, and ≈øeuen monethes: and wythyn ≈øo lytle ≈øpace had he di≈øpatched ≈øo many and great warres, ≈øo that ≈øuche a multytude of men coulde ≈øcarce haue yournyed throughe ≈øo many contryes and realmes, euen whan it had bene peace and tranquyllyte.

He raygned at Babylon after Daryus, only fyue yeare, and eleuen monethes. Such hy≈øtoryes declare that greate kynges and princes are
guyded by a certayne heauenly power or will.

Alexander was endued with many and excellent princely vertues, the examples whereof to ≈øet forth here, by rea ‚Ä¢ on of oure indu≈øtrye to be ≈øhort, hath no place. I will recite only one amonge ≈øo many. As oft as the playntyfe in iudgement layde ought again≈øt any gylty man, the ≈øame beynge ab≈øent,A noble example of Alexander concerninge a good prince or iudge. he gaue only the one eare to the plaintyfe, and was wont to ≈øhut y‚Ä¢ otherwyth his hand: that he might ≈øignifie, he would kepe the other for the gylty man, and that both partes oughte to be herde alyke, the which pertaineth to an office of a good prince and true iudge. Alexander gaue here a notable example for greate princes, that not onely the one parte ≈øhould be admitted to ≈øpeake, and laye for him ≈øelfe, but both partes: euen as at Athens they were wont to ≈øweare, the iudges that were cho≈øen, thatWhat the iudges at Athens dyd ≈øweare. they ≈øhould geue ≈øentence accordinge to the lawe written, and that they ≈øhoulde heare both partes alyke.

div.head: Of the moderation and godlyne≈ø≈øe that Alexander dyd v≈øe agayn≈øt the Iewes.
div.p:
WHan Ieru≈øalem was now builded agayne, the Iewes lyued in greate peace vnder tho≈øe Godlye kinges of the Per≈øes. But whan Alexander be≈øieged the citye Tyrus, he requyred ayde of th ‚Ä¢ Iewes, which an≈øwered: that they coulde do it by no hone≈øte meane, becau≈øe they were ≈øubiectes to the kynges of Per≈øia,
whyche al≈øo had receaued many and great benefytes of them. Whan Alexander had hearde thys excu≈øation,The ≈øettynge forth of Alexander again≈øt the Iewes. Iaddus the hygh prie≈øt. Alexanders reuerence to the hyghe prie≈øt. he was wroth, and whan he had wonne Tyrus, he came wyth hys hoo≈øt towarde Ieru≈øalem. But Iaddus the hygh prie≈øte, puttinge on the pre≈øtly apparell, and other aged men, went oute of the citye to mete Alexander, for to a≈øke peace. WhaÃÑ he ≈øawe y‚Ä¢ hygh pre≈øt in that apparel, he lept incontinently from his hor≈ø≈øe, and fallinge vpon his knees before the pre≈øte, he promy≈øed hym peace frely. All hys princes maruayled that he v≈øed ≈øo greate lowlyne≈ø≈øe agayn≈øt a prie≈øt of a ≈øtraung nacion, and al≈øo that he had ≈øwaged the rage of hys mynd in ≈øo lytle ≈øpace. Parmenio which was entierly beloued of the kynge, by rea≈øon of his age and wy≈øedome, demaunded of him: what reuerence moued hym, that he fell ≈øo lowly before the pre≈øt. To the whiche he aun≈øwered: that in Macedony he ≈øawe a lykene≈ø≈øe in hys ≈ølepe, ≈øemblable to thys pre≈øt, that ≈øtode before him, and admoni≈øhed hym that he ≈øhould go into A≈øia, and promy≈øed to ayde him: and that he dyd the honour to the verye ≈øame God, that than had appeared vnto hym: At that tyme went Alexander peaceably into the citye, hearynge al≈øo reuerentlye the pre≈øtes rea≈øonynge of the doctryne of theyr religion, the whych taught hym al≈øo the prophe≈øy of Daniel, that the kyng of the Grekes ≈øhuld rule in A≈øia, and amonge the Per≈øes: Whereof was Alexander not a lytle coraged: and geuinge the Iewes great lybertye he enryched the temple al≈øo wyth great and noble gyftes. He returned to Babylon according to the prophecy of Ieremy.
Of thys wy≈øe ≈øaued God hys weake churche at that tyme, whan for ≈øo notable mutation of dominions, was warre nearehande in all countryes.

div.head: The diui≈øion of the realmes after Alexander.
div.p: ALexander had maryed Roxane the doughterRoxane wyfe to Alexander of a prince in Per≈øia, whiche was great wyth chylde whan the kyng dyed. Whan the kynge was deade, and there was none other true heyre of the kyngdome, than the kynges chylde, the princes toke coun≈øel among them, how to gouerne the kyngdome a ryghte. Fir≈øt they thought it good to appoint certayne gouernours, vntyll the quene were delyuered: yf a man chylde were borne, the ≈øame ≈øhould be kyng byThe ≈øtryft amonge the princes after Alexanders death. Perdicas Arideus brother to Alexander. Perdicas crafte. inheritaunce and ≈øucce≈ø≈øion. Contrarywy≈øe dyd ≈øome (among whom was Perdicas one) choy≈øe in the kynges ≈øteade Arideus brother to Alexander, a man fearfull, and ≈øyckely: and to this agreed the mo≈øte parte. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe were the princes con≈øtrayned to choy≈øe men, by whome the kyngdome ≈øhould be gouerned: but amonge the gouernoures was Perdicas the chefe, and that in the name of Alexanders brother: vnder which preten≈øe he procured in the meane ≈øea≈øon, that he myght by lytle & lytle optaine the whole kyngdome, and than began he to a≈ø≈øaye fyr≈øt wyth honc≈øte engyns, afterwarde with open force al≈øo.

For he wo ‚Ä¢ d Cleopatra the ≈øy≈øter of Alexander,Cleopatra. and tru≈øted by that meanes ea≈øelye to optayne the kyngdome. But Antipater that wasAntipater.
gouernour in Macedonia feling this gyle of Perdicas, dyd hynder thys weddinge: wherfore dyd Perdicas on the other part his diligence, that Antipater might be taken and ca≈øt into pre≈øon. This is to be brefe nearehande the cau≈øe of the warre, whych was ry≈øen amonge Alexanders princes. For Perdicas had hys rebellions: again≈øte him on the other ≈øyde con≈øpyred Antypater, Antigonus &Antigonus. Ptolomeus. Ptolomeus. And Perdicas inuaded Ptolome fir≈øt in Egypte, where he was forth wyth ≈ølayne of hys owne ≈øouldiours. This was a worthy puni≈øhment the which he de≈øerued, that was fyr≈øt begynner of the ≈øedicion amonge Alexanders princes. But ther could be no ende made of this tragedy, nother was there any hope of peace, without the adherentes of Perdicas were fyr≈øt oppre≈ø≈øed al≈øo: yee there coulde no ≈øtedfa≈øt peace be hoped for in the worlde, ≈øeyng whan Alexander was deade, the world was as headle≈ø≈øe. Nother appeared any thyng els in ≈øo great a perturbation of all thinges, than that al hone≈øtye and gouernaunce beynge wholy ouerthrowen, there ≈øhoulde be a continuall willfulne≈ø≈øe o ‚Ä¢ murthuringe amonge men. So lytle can lawful ‚Ä¢ gouernaunces la≈øt in this worlde, without they be in≈øtitute and pre≈øerued of God. But it ≈øemed toOf Alexanders kyngdome are made foure kyngdomes. God, that oute of Alexanders kyngedome ≈øhould ‚Ä¢ ≈øprynge foure mighty princes. For ≈øo was it prophe≈øyed of Daniel to come to pa≈ø≈øe, namelye, tha ‚Ä¢ whan the bucks (whiche ≈øignified Alexander) on ‚Ä¢ horne ≈øhoulde pery≈øhe, foure other hornes ≈øhould ‚Ä¢ growe: the whiche the angell expoundeth of th ‚Ä¢ foure kyngdomes in≈øtitute after Alexander. Bu ‚Ä¢
it is chefely to be maruayled at, that God woulde the realmes to come to tho≈øe princes, which by degre of bloude were neare to Philippe and Alexander. Perdicas, which was not of the kinges bloud, was in the meane ≈øea≈øon depryued of this honor. For ≈øo doth it mo≈øt commonely come to pa≈ø≈øe, that he which coueteth the common gouernaunce withoutLawfull calling mu≈øt be en≈øued. a lawfull callynge, & putteth him≈øelfe in greate admini≈øtrations of hys owne ≈øwynge, is reiected of God: as we ≈øe what happened to Ab≈øalon & ≈øome other. Moreouer the≈øe kyngdomes are diuided amonge tho≈øe princes, which before were made debities in the kyngdome by Alexander.

list.item: Seleucus was made kynge of Syria.
Ptolemeus was made kyng of Egypte.
To Antigonus befell the kyngdome of A≈øia.
Ca≈ø≈øander ruled in Macedonia and Grece.

div.p:
The≈øe kynges had cruel warres for the monarchye, the which euery one coueted. But in Macedonia was the greate≈øt ≈ølaughter. Ca≈ø≈øanderThe tyranny of Ca≈ø≈øander The mother of AlexaÃÑder a rare example of cha≈øtite is put to death. cau≈øed to put to death the moo≈øt hone≈øt quene, mother to Alexander, the whiche in dyenge ≈øhewed a very wounderful token of cha≈øtitye and con≈øtancy. For meting the hangeman frely wyth a coragious contenaunce, aboue the co≈øtume of women, ≈øhe toke hym her heade to cutt of: and whan ≈øhe fell doune, ≈øhe couered her ≈øo wyth her rayment, that her body ≈øhould no where be di≈øclo≈øed di≈øhone≈øtly. As for Roxane Alexanders wyfe, cau≈øed Ca≈ø≈øander to be taken & kept. But this vnfaythfulne≈ø≈øe hath God puny≈øhed ryght well, whaÃÑ after Ca≈ø≈øanders deathAn example of vengeaunce. hys two ≈øonnes Antipater & Alexander di≈øquieted
eche other wyth warres, for the kyngdome of Macedonye. Antipater one of them, drewe to hym Ly≈øimachus, which raygned by Helle≈øpontus, who≈øe doughter he had wedded al≈øo. But the other brother Alexander, requyred ayde of Demetrius, the ≈øonne of Antigonus. But ether of them was ≈ølayn of hys companyon, of whom they tru≈øted to haue ayde: Antipater of hys father in law, Ly≈øimachus, and Alexander of Demetrius. Fynallye be≈øell the kyngdome of Macedonye to Demetrius ≈øonne to Antigonus: for he was an hone≈øte and lucky prince in gouernaunce. Of this Demetrius haue all theDemetrius kyng of Macedony other kynges of Macedony theyr of≈øpringe, vntyll the≈øe tymes, whan the la≈øte of hys kynred was taken of the Romanes, in whom al≈øo ended the kingdome of Macedony.

I ≈øet forth here the hi≈øtory brefely, and as it were eueÃÑ in pa≈ø≈øing away, out of the which the≈øage reder may ea≈øely coÃÑ≈øider, that in Grece, whan they de≈øtroied them≈øelues, & v≈øed now the a≈ø≈øi≈øtaunce of foren princes, pery≈øhed all hone≈øty of good maners wyth the dominion and commone welth. For this Demetrius (of whom we haue now made mencion) whan he was oft conuer≈øaunt wyth the Athenians, theyThe vn≈øhamfa≈øt ≈øla ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ery of the Athenians. ≈ølattered him ≈øo ≈øhamefullye, that they called hym God, and wyth prayenge dyd hym godly wor≈øhip: yea and in theyr ≈øacrifice v≈øed they a ≈øeuerall ≈øonge of him, ≈øayenge: that the other goddes were a ≈ølepe, only Demetrius was a true God, whych dyd watche for theyr health. The≈øe vngodly and dredfull voyces te≈øtifye that at Athenes was vtterlye quenched and lo≈øt all hone≈øty and godlyne≈ø≈øe.

Now re≈øteth it, that pa≈ø≈øinge ouer the kynges of Macedony, I rehear≈øe the names of ≈øuche kynges, as haue raygned in Syria and Egypte. For the≈øe kyngdomes were the mightie≈øt among tho≈øe foure, and to knowe the order of the≈øe kynges, doeth greatly auayle al≈øo in holy ≈øcrypture, wherein often tymes is made mencion of them. For the Iewes had great conuer≈øacion and occupyenge wyth the≈øe two kyngdomes.

div.head: Of the kynges of Syria.
div.p: SEleucus was a prince borne in Macedonie,Seleucus. on who≈øe thingh appeared a naturall token, in maner of an anker, the which had al≈øo all his po≈øterity. He toke the citye Babylon by ≈øtronge hande. AfterwardeAntigonus Demetrius were Antigonus and Demetrius hys ≈øonnes kynges of A≈øia, ouercome of him. Antigonus was pear≈øed through: Demetrius dyed in pre≈øon. After thisOf whom Seleucus was ≈ølayne. di≈øcomfyted Seleuchs Ly≈øimachus. But in the ≈øeuenth moneth after thys victory, was Seleucus ≈ølayne by Ptolome Ceraunus brother to Ptolomeus Philadelphus. The≈øe are dredefull examplesAn example of the fea ‚Ä¢ e of God. of the ≈øettynge vp and fall of ≈øo great kynges, which worthely oughte to ≈øtyrre vs to feare God, le≈øt we thynke to do great thynges by mans coun≈øell and oure wy≈øedome.Antiochus Soter. Antiochus Theos. Selencus Callinicus Antiochus Hierax.
Antiochus Soter the ≈øonne of Seleucus, raigned in Syria after the death of his father.

Antiochus Theos his ≈øonne, had fyr≈øt to wife Laodice, wherof he had two ≈øonnes, Seleucus, Callinicus, & Antiochus, which was ≈øurnamed Hierax.
Ptolomeus Philadelphus gaue to the ≈øame Berenice his doughter afterward to wyfe. But whan Antiochus was deade, Laodice con≈øtrayned Seleucus her ≈øonne to take the kyngedome, and to take his ≈øtepmother Berenice. Seleucus folowed his mothers coun≈øell, be≈øieged hys ≈øtepmother, & finally brought her to yelde willyngly wyth great promi≈øes. But kepynge no promy≈øe, he cau≈øed that the quene was put to death very cruelly. For Daniel had prophe≈øyed openlye, that the quene of Egypt ≈øhould ≈øuffre ≈øuch a thynge, and that the kyng of Egypt ≈øhould reuenge the ≈øame. For whan thys cruel dede was done, Ptolemeus Euergetes brotherPtolomeus Euergetes. to Berenice went into Syria, droue Seleucus out of the kyngdome, and takynge in many cytyes, returned into Egypte. Afterward whan Seleucus had recouered ≈øome harte, he woulde recouer the kyngdome agayne, and requyred ayde of hys brother Antiochus Hierax: he was very yong, and tru≈øted by this occa≈øyon to optayne the whole kyngdome. For whan peace was made betwene Ptolomeus & Seleucus, Hierax inuaded his brother Seleucus kyngdome, to the which thynge he v≈øed the ayde of ≈øtraunge ≈øouldyours. For the Galathians,The Galathians were brought by Brennus ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of Germany into Grece. which Brennus brought out of Germany into Grece, went farther into A≈øia, beynge hyred wyth tho≈øe kynges wages, which had diuer≈øe warres agayn≈øt eche other. The≈øe Galathians had thaÃÑ geuen them tho≈øe landes in A≈øia, that they dwelled in. Of whom they be called Galathians, vnto whom S. Paule the apo≈øtle preached the Go≈øpell. Nether is it anye doubte but that they were Germanes.
For the Grekes dyd calle wyth one worde the Germanes and Gallies Celte, & by chaungyng of the worde, was the name Galate ≈øet for Celte. Finally ouercame Antiochus his brother Seleucus with the ayd of the Galathians, but Antiochus was lykewy≈øe vanquy≈øhed of the kyng of A≈øia, le≈øyng a great deale of the kyngdome of Syria: than was he con≈øtrayned to flye to king Ptolomeus Euergetes: & whan he was ≈øo receaued of hym, that he ≈øhould go no wher, he wold haue fled, but whan thys coun≈øell was perceaued, he was put to death. This ende finally gat Antiochus Hierax. AbouteNotable examples of vengeaunce. y‚Ä¢ tyme nearehand fell Seleucus his brother from a hor≈ø≈øe, & dyed. This mi≈øerable fortune & end had the≈øe two bretheren, which had done many wickedAntiochus magnus. Ptolomeus Philopater. dedes. Antiochus the great inuaded the kynge of Egypt Ptolome Philopater wyth warre, but he was dryuen back. Afterwarde whan Philopater was deade, he returned into Egypt with an army: but the Romanes had taken the child Ptolomeus Epiphanes into their ward≈øhyp, to whom he wasThe occa≈øioÃÑ of the warre of Antiochus wyth y‚Ä¢ Romanes. Hannibal. committed as a warde. This was an occa≈øion of a great warre, which was betwene the Romanes & Antiochus. Hanniball toke part with Antiochus, which was captaine in this warre a certayn ≈øpace, and many more contries of Grece dyd ≈øtycke to Antiochus. But beynge weakened by rea≈øon of ≈øome mi≈øhappe, he was dryuen to demaunde conditionsAntiochus Epiphanes is ≈øent to Ro ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ for a pledge. of peace. Than left the Romanes hym only y‚Ä¢ parte of the royalme, whiche lieth beyond the hyll Taurus: be≈øyde this was he con≈øtrayned to ≈øende his ≈øonne Antiochus Epiphanes to Rome in ho≈øtage.
But at the la≈øt whan Antiochus ≈øpoyled the rycheThe temple of Belus in Syria. temple of Belus in Siria, he was oppre≈ø≈øed of the communalty inhabityng there, whych ≈ølew hym & hys company euery one. This was the ende of Antiochus the great. Hieru≈øalem had metely goodThe ≈øtart of Ieru≈øaleÃÑ vnder Antiochus. re≈øt ≈øence the tyme of Alexander, vntyll Antiochus the great. But whan the warre betwen the≈øe two kynges was ray≈øed, by rea≈øon the Iewes laye betwene them both, they were a lytle oppre≈ø≈øed & vexed of both parties. And though Ieru≈øalem dyd hetherto ≈øtycke more to Egypte, yet was it nether ≈øubiecte to Syria nor Egypte. Howbeit PtolomeusScopa a captaine of Ptolomeus Epiphanes. Epiphanes ≈øent a capitayne, one Scopa again≈øt Antiochus, which toke in certayne townes of Syria, and part of Iewry. Howbeit whan Antiochus had vanqui≈øhed the ≈øame by ye Iordane, he went farther tyll he came at Ieru≈øaleÃÑ. Than did the Iewes kneling, yelded theÃÑ≈øelues frely to him, makyng al≈øo a commune league betwene them and the kyng: & for thys cau≈øe dyd the kyng Antiochus ≈øuffer them to lyue in peace, & a≈øy≈øted them in repayryng ye citye Ieru≈øalem. And of this wy≈øe, though they ≈øemed to be in daunger in the tyme of this warre, by rea≈øon of the neighburhead‚ñ™ yet lyued they quietly vnder this Antiochus. Antiochus the great left afterSeleucus Philopator. him thre ≈øonnes, Seleucus ≈øurnamed Philopator, Antiochus Epiphanes, & Demetrius. After ye fathers death raygned Seleucus a few yeres, the other two brethren were kept in ho≈øtage at Rome. Whan Antiochus Epiphanes knew of his fathers death, he ‚Ä¢ led priuely froÃÑ Rome, & as he was come againe into Syria, he was made king. For Seleucus
was vnmete to rule, nether liued he long after his fathers death. This Antiochus EpiphanesAntiochus Epiphanes, called Epimanes. truely was a man of much ≈øubtelty & hardine≈ø≈øe, & had well learned by the example of the Romanes, to apply him≈øel≈øe to the tyme and maners of euery man. For he could ea≈øely forbeare and ≈øuffre euery man that he was with: he was a wy≈øe man wyth ye wy≈øe‚ñ™ & agaynwyth vnbrydeled youth, he folowed ≈øuch exerci≈øe, as he knew them to delyte in. He procured the fauour of the comon people with familiaritye & beneuolence: and whan he made any co≈øtly banket, he cau≈øed great ≈øummes of mony to be ca≈øt among ye people. For his vnbrydeled maners was he called Epimanes for Epiphanes. For Epimanes ≈øignifieth madde, but Epiphanes ≈øignifieth noble.

His raigne began the hundreth & ≈øeuen and thyrtyeth yeare after Alexanders death. And whan he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed now hys kingdomes that came to hym by heretage, he went into Egypte. For about ye tyme dyed Ptolomeus Epiphanes, the ≈øame had to wyfe Cleopatra the ≈øy≈øter of Antiochus Epiphanes, the which vnder that pretence began to v≈øurpe ye kingdome of Egipt, as if he were tutor of the yong king called Ptolomeus Philometor. Nether ≈øhewed hePtolomeus Philometor. him≈øelf otherwy≈øe, but with all gentlene≈ø≈øe & beneuolence toward his co≈øin, & willed that Memphis & other great cities ≈øhuld yeld them to the kyng, y‚Ä¢ vnder ≈øuche a preten≈øe he mighte by lytle and lytle draw to him the whole realme. Whan he had now fini≈øhed all thinges, he left the kingdome, and went to Ieru≈øalem, & that at the reque≈øt of I ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ , which coueted the dignitye of the hygh pre≈øthode by the meane of Antiochus.

For ≈øo ≈øtode the ca≈øe thaÃÑwith the Iewes, that they myghte optayne the hyghe prie≈øthode by decepte, by con≈øpiracion offoren kynges, oppre≈ø≈øinge & ≈ølayenge in the meane ≈øea≈øon tho≈øe, that were the true ≈øucce≈ø≈øors. For which cau≈øe was this people greueou≈ølyThe yourney of Antiochus to Ieru≈øalem‚ñ™ puni≈øhed agayne of God. This was the fyr≈øt yourney of Antiochus to Ieru≈øalem, in the whiche he ordeined a hygh prie≈øt, and ≈øpoyled the temple‚ñ™ & ≈ølew many. This happened the ≈øyxte yeare of Antiochus, the which was the hundreth and thre and fortyeth yeare after Alexanders death.

Two yeare after, which was the hundreth and fyue and fortieth yeare after the death of Alexander,The ≈øeconde yourney of Antiochus into Egypte. made Antiochus ready hys ≈øeconde yourney into Egypt. For the cities had yelded them≈øelues agayne to the yonge kynge, the which al≈øo had ≈øought for ayde of the Romanes. Nowe whan AntiochusPopilius an Amba≈ø≈øadour of Rome ≈øent to Antiochus. inuaded Egypte, the Romanes ≈øente an amba≈ø≈øador Popilius, which ≈øhuld ≈øhew Antiochus in the name of the Romanes, to auoyde out of the coa≈øtes of Egypte, nether to warre vpon the yonge kynge Philometor. For the Romanes were mynded to retayne him in the kyngdome wyth theyr ayde. Wherevpon an≈øwered Antiochus, he would deui≈øe wyth him ≈øelfe, what he would do. But PopiliusAn example of Romane ≈øeueryte. wold graunt hym no ≈øpace to deui≈øe, but makyng a rynge wyth hys ≈øpeare aboute Antiochus, commaunded hym to ≈øaye ≈øtrayght waye, before he went out of the cyrcle, whether he wold auoyd out of Egipt, or no. Antiochus being aba≈øhed with this ≈øeuerite & con≈øtance of Popilius (for he knew & was afeared of the Romane power,) he promi≈øed frelye to go out of Egipt‚ñ™

Wherfore he was con≈øtrayned to leaue Egypt the ≈øecond tyme with great ≈øhame. But inflamed withThe ≈øecond yourney of Antiochus to Ieru≈øalem The tyranny of Antiochus again≈øt them of Ieru≈øalem. The bible is brent.
‚Ä¢ re for the impacience of the grefe, he went agayne to Ieru≈øalem: and this was hys ≈øeconde yourney to Ieru≈øalem: for he was there twi≈øe, and than v≈øed ‚Ä¢ e his tyranny much more cruelly, than before. For he commaunded the Iewes to wor≈øhyp the Idols of the Heythen, he commaunded to burn the bokes of the Bible, and left a great deale of noughtypackes to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the citye Ieru≈øalem, in ≈øteade of a garny≈øon: the which tormented then very cruelly that wolde not fall from theyr fayth, and to thys thinge dyd they a≈ø≈øi≈øt them, that were deceuered from the Iewy≈øh religion. The temple al≈øo was turned to a prophane v≈øe, fore an image was ≈øett therein of the Gentils ≈øuper≈øtition. But what nedeth many wordes? They bu≈øyed to roote out the worde of God, and the whole lawe, and in ≈øteade thereof to bringe in the maners of the Gentyls, Nether dyd Antiochus v≈øe that coun≈øel ra≈øhly, but with a great wytt & policye. For he perceaued that the Iewes wyth≈øtode the Heythen kynges, becau≈øe of theyr religion, and therfore wolde he auoyde the diuer≈øitye of religion. Of thys wy≈øe do mens thoughtesAn example of mans wy≈ødome in thinges concerning God Antiochus fygureth Antichri≈øte. dalye in matters concernyng God, and wyll ≈øet vp religion after theyr wyll & iudgement. Moreouer vnder ye example and figure of thys Antiochus, doth Daniel al≈øo de≈øcribe Antichri≈øte, & that ≈øuch a kyngdom ≈øhuld be, where in Chri≈øten men ≈øhuld be put to di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, and Gods word ≈øhuld be quenched: and lykewy≈øe ≈øhuld be ≈øet vp a religion for a ≈øhewe, which might be contrary to gods word, by y‚Ä¢ which
may be had an occa≈øyon, to optayne power & great ryches. Euen as it is euident that Mahomet hathWhy Mahometes religion is acceptable. ≈øet vp a fal≈øe religion, and vnder pretence thereof, haue ordeyned a newe kyngdome. And this religion ≈øemeth to be foly≈øh religion, for it doeth greatly flatter mens rea≈øon. For pa≈ø≈øing ouer nearehande all the hygher ≈øentences and articles of the fayeth, it hath kept onely that doctryne, whyche teacheth morall vertues. Wonder it is verely howe muche that ≈øame doth flatter mans rea≈øon, wherefore al≈øo it doth v≈øe to crepe more ea≈øely into mens mindes, than the doctryne of fayth.

As for the tyranny of Antiochus, thereof is written in the bokes of the Machabees: & Danyel wytne≈ø≈øeth that the people of the Iewes had de≈øerued thys puny≈øhment becau≈øe of theyr ≈øynnes. And allthoughe God dyd puny≈øhe hys people, yet for all that he dyd not de≈øtroye them vtterly.

For God ray≈øed Iudas Machabeus, whych gatheryngIudas Machabeus „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . a ≈ømall army, inuaded Antiochus captaynes: and by Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtaunce, ouerthrowynge the enemyes, he recouered the temple the thyrd yeare, after that Antiochus had ≈øett an Idoll therein.

Daniel hath comprehended all this tyme of the Iewy≈øh affliccion, in two thou≈øande and thre hundreth dayes, whych make ≈øyxe yeares and ≈øyxe monethes, and ≈øome dayes ouerplus. For the per≈øecution la≈øted from the thyrde yeare of Antiochus, vntyll the eyght yere & ≈øome monethes. Daniel dyd v≈øe thys diui≈øion of the tyme al≈øo, that the Idoll ≈øhould ≈øtande in the temple a thou≈øande, two hundreth and nynety dayes, whyche make thre yeare, and ≈øyxe monethes.

And y‚Ä¢ temple was recouered an hundreth & eyght and forty yeares after Alexanders death. Thys was the thre hundreth and eight and fortieth yere after that the Iewes were delyuered oute of the Babylonicall bondage, and the hundreth and two and fyftyeth yeare before Chri≈øtes byrth.

But Antiochus de≈øerued wyth hys vngodline≈ø≈øeThe puni≈øhment of Antiochus for his vngodline≈ø≈øe. and bla≈øphemy agayn≈øt God, not only the vtter extingui≈øhment of hys kynred, but al≈øo the ouerthrowynge of the whole kyngdome of Syria. For after Antiochus death, there was euer warre betwene one or other, and after manye tymes for the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion in the kyngdome. That it maye be playnely ≈øene by thys example, ho we begynneth matters to ≈øprynge, for the whyche kyngdomes be ouerthrowen: as we ≈øe nowe a dayes to befall in Hungary.

Antiochus Epiphanes dyed in that yourney, whyche made readye agayne to come agayn≈øt the Iewes, to reuenge the dammage done. After hys death, hys brother Demetrius fled from Rome, & toke in the kingdome, kylling the yong Antiochus,Antiochus Eupator. ≈øurnamed Eupator, ≈øonne to Antiochus Epiphanes. Alexander the capitayne ray≈øyng a ≈øedition agayn≈øt Demetrius ≈ølewe hym. DemetriusDemetrius, Antiochus Sedetes. left two ≈øonnes after him, Demetrius and Antiochus Sedetes. Of this Demetrius verely was Alexander ≈ølayne lykewy≈øe. Afterward was a ≈øedition ray≈øed by one Tryphon agayn≈øt Demetrius, the whych droue him out of the kyngdome: but Demetrius came agayne into the kyngdome, and dyed ≈øtryken thorough wyth a ≈øworde.
Antiochus Sedetes was ≈ølayne of the Parthes.

As for this Demetrius had a ≈øonne Antiochus Gryphus. Antiochus Sedetes left after him a ≈øonne Antiochus Cyzicenus. The≈øe ≈øtroue for the kyngdome of Syria, and were both ≈ølayne. Afterward dyd their children warre one agayn≈øt the other for y‚Ä¢ kindome wyth no le≈ø≈øe ≈øtryfe, than their elders: and had at the la≈øt ≈øo febled eche other, that Syria was con≈øtrayned to yeld it ≈øelfe to foren kinges. For it ioyned it ≈øelfe to Tigranes kyng of Armenia. And of this wy≈øe is the kyngdome of Syria tran≈øferred from Seleucus po≈øterity, to foren princes. But finally whan Tigranes was ≈ølayne byTigranes is ≈ølayne by Pompepus. Pompeius, Syria was broughte vnder the Romane power. Hetherto is ynough ≈øpoken of the kyngdome of Syria.

div.head: Of the kynges of Egypt after Alexander.

list.item: PTolomeus the ≈øonne of Lagus, wherofPtolomeus the ≈øonne of Lagus. Pau≈øanias wryteth, whych calleth hym the ba≈øtarde of Philippe father to Alexander.

ij. Ptolomeus Philadelphus. Greate pray≈øes arePtolomeus Philadelphus an endeuour of peace and ≈øciences. of thys kynge, by rea≈øon of his endeuour of peace, and al≈øo becau≈øe he delyted in all kynde of ≈øciences, and dyd in≈øtitute a very good forme of the common welth. To hym drew wy≈øe men out of all contryes, the which he maynteyned gently and liberally. He had a library, as there was none better furni≈øhedThe library of Ptolomeus. in the whole worlde, and for thys cau≈øe toke he
acquaintaunce of the Iewes. For whan he diligently ≈øearched for the begynnynge of all nacions, religions and ≈øciences, he founde that the people of the Iewes to be the elde≈øt, and that they onely had the ≈øure≈øt hi≈øtoryes of the worldes begynninge or creation. Wherefore he required to be ≈øent to hym from Ieru≈øalem thre ≈øcore and twelue men, by who≈øe diligence the wholy Bible myght be tran≈ølated oute of the Hebrue into his language: & by this occa≈øion were the Bibles ≈øyr≈øte tran≈ølated into ≈øtraungeThe Bible tran≈ølated. ≈øpeches. And no doubt it is, but that Ptolome was conuerted to the true fayth by this ≈øame meane.
iii. Ptolomeus Euergetes inuaded Syria, & dydPtolomeus Euergetes. reuenge the death of his ≈øy≈øter Berenice.

iiij. Ptolomeus Philopater, ouercame AntiochusPtolomeus Philopator. the great: afterwarde beyng become more ≈øen≈øuall and di≈ø≈øolute, he beganne to be enamoured vpon a wenche, in≈øomuch that he cau≈øed al≈øo hys quene to be put to death, for the loue ≈øhewed to that wench.Ptolomeus Epiphanes.
v. Ptolomeus Epiphanes, whom Antiochus the great dyd inuade: the ≈øame Antiochus gaue to him hys doughter.

vi. Ptolomeus Philometor, the ≈øame dyd hys vnclePtolomeus Philometor. Antiochus Epiphanes inuade: But the Romanes defendyng Ptolome, commaunded Antiochus to auoyde out of Egypt, the which we haue ≈øhewed before.
vii. Ptolomeus Euergetes re≈øtored Demetrius,Ptolomeus Euergetes. that was dryuen oute of hys realme, into the ≈øame agayne.

viii. Ptolomeus Phy≈øco, the ≈øame re≈øembled morePtolomeus Phi≈øco a bea≈øt and no man. a bea≈øt than a man, by rea≈øon of hys vylaynous crueltye.
He wedded hys ≈øy≈øter, and begatt chylderen of her. Afterwarde ≈ølayenge hys ≈øonne, ≈øet him before hys mother to eate, fynallye was he dryuen out of the realme. The re≈øidue en≈øuynge were notable of lyke ≈øhameful behaueour, as of bea≈øtly medlynge and of farre more cruell tyranny.
