xii. Ptolomeus Diony≈øius, which commaundedPtolomeus Diony≈øius. to ≈ølaye Pompeius, and afterwarde was al≈øo vnfaythfull to Iulius: wherefore Iulius droue hym out of the kyngdome, and gaue it to his ≈øy≈øter Cleopatra,Cleopatra ≈øy≈øter to Iulius Ce≈øar. the whiche finally ≈ølew her≈øelfe, whan Antonius (whom ≈øhe entertayned) was ouercome of Augu≈øtus. After that came Egypte to the Romanes, and ≈øo was the moo≈øt noble kynred of Ptolomeus quenched.

div.head: Of the Iewes.
div.p: WE haue ≈øayde before that the ≈øuperiorytie of gouernaunce remayned by the po≈øteritie of Dauid, after the returne of the Iewes oute of Babylon, only that they wanted the dignitie of the kynges name, and were only called Prynces. And the ≈øame rayned tyll the tyme of Antiochus, S. Luke doeth al≈øo make mencion of them in the genealogye of Chri≈øte.

row.cell: xiiij. in the tyme of Alexander.

div.p: The ≈øame had greate familiarite wyth Ptolomeus Euergetes, and by Eu≈øebius is he called Ar≈øes.
xv. Iaanna the ≈øeconde Hircanus xvi.Ianna .ij. Hircanus.

He had greate warres agayn≈øt the Arabians, and had oft victory. But whan he was be≈øieged in a ca≈øtell by Antiochus Epiphanes, nether coulde he defend hym≈øelf any lenger wyth his garny≈øon, yet woulde he not yelde him ≈øelfe, but wyth≈øtode his enemies valiauntly fightynge in battayl, tyll he was ≈ølayne. This was the la≈øte prince amonge the Iewes of kyng Dauids bloude. After hym ruled the Machabees, whyche were of the prie≈øtly kynred.

But after the≈øe was the kyngdome of the Iewes
tran≈ølated to Herods kynred, whyche was a Gentyle, but he was circumci≈øed. Thys thynge truely had God prophecyed before, that the ceptre and royall maie≈øtye ≈øhoulde be taken from Iuda, and Dauids ≈øucce≈ø≈øors before the comminge of the promy≈øedChri≈øtes coÃÑ minge. Chri≈øte. Nether was the kyngdome altered from Dauids po≈øteritye aboue an hundreth & thre ≈øcore yeare, before Chri≈øte was borne: ≈øo that it exceded not mens memory what kinred had raigned. Of this wy≈øe doeth Lucas rehear≈øe the princes of the Iewes, vntyll the la≈øt Ianna Hircanus, and after the ≈øame doth he counte the re≈øidue al≈øo, which ruled not, vntyll Chri≈øte. Wherefore I wyll brefely adde of the Machabees and Herodes kynred.

div.head: Of the Machabees kynred.
div.p: MAtathias exhorted hys chylderen,Matathias. to re≈øi≈øt Antiochus, and the≈øe raygned in order by ≈øucce≈ø≈øioÃÑ, as princes.

Iudas Machabeus the fir≈øt, vanquy≈øhedIudas Machabeus. the capytaynes of Antiochus Epiphanes, and recouered the temple wythin thre yeare, and had notable victories. But a≈ø≈øone as he had con≈øpyred wyth the Romanes,An example that no tru≈øt is to be ≈øet in mans helpe. makyng a league wyth them, he was ≈ølayn, and dyed. For God wyll not haue vs to leane to mans helpe, but that we ≈øhoulde ≈øett oure tru≈øte in hym. He raygned v. yeares.

Ionathas raygned nyneten yeare: he toke partIonathas. wyth Alexander, which v≈øurped the kyngdome in Syria. Afterwarde was he ≈ølayne of Triphon, very vnfaythfully. He had an vnhappye ende, for becau≈øe
he tru≈øted too the ayde of naughty and ≈øeditious men.
Simon reigned eight yeare: he ouercame AntiochusSimon. Gryphus. He was at the la≈øt ≈ølayn by trea≈øon, of his owne brother in lawe.

Ioannes Hircanus was Simons ≈øonne: the ≈øameIoannes Hircanus. reigned ≈øyx and twenty yeare. In his tyme be≈øieged Antiochus Gryphus Ieru≈øalem, but by geuyng of mony was he apea≈øed, and breakyng vp the ≈øyege, left the citie. Afterward gat Hircanus Samaria.

div.head: The Machabeis kynges.
div.p: Ari≈øtobulus the ≈øonne of Hircanus reignedAri≈øtobulus. one yeare, and woulde be crowned with a kyngely crowne. He was the fir≈øt kyng in Ieru≈øalem, after that the Iewes were returned out of Babylon. He ≈ølew his brother Antigonus, becau≈øe he feared le≈øt he woulde couet the kyngdome.
Alexander the yonger, ≈øonne of HircanusreignedAlexander ye yonger ≈øonne of Hircanus. ≈øeuen and twenty yeare: his wyfe Alexandra reigned after hym nyne yeare.

Alexander left two ≈øonnes after hym, Hircanus and Ari≈øtobulus. Though Hircanus were the elder, yet was he dryuen out of the kyngdom, by hys brother Ari≈øtobulus, whiche by violence caught from his brother the dignitie of the kynges name.Antipater prince of Idumea. Areta king of Arabia. But Antipater prince of Idumea and the father of Herodes, and Areta kyng of Arabia ayded Hircanus again≈øt Ari≈øtobulus. Nether was there a le≈ø≈øe barbarous ≈øtate at that tyme in Iewry, after the
Heythen maner, then in the kyngdomes of other nations.Pompeus. Afterward when Pompeius toke in Ieru≈øalem, he made Hircanus high prie≈øt, and taking Ari≈øtobulus pri≈øoner with his two ≈øonnes, Alexander and Antigonus, brought theÃÑ to Rome. But by the way as they went to Rome, e≈øcaped AlexaÃÑder, and commyng againe into Iewry, he became mighty againe. But then was he vanqui≈øhed by Gabinius y‚Ä¢ Gabinius. Romane capitaine in Syria, and afterward by the commaundement of Scipio, was he beheaded at Antiochia. Antigonus was relea≈øed at Rome by Iulius: but longe after was he commaunded to be put to death at Antiochia by Antonius, euen the third yeare when Herode was made kyng. And yf the whole tyme that Hircanus was high prie≈øt bee wel rekened, it ≈øhalbe euen foure and thirty yeares: finally was he put to death by Herode: It is a dredful thyng verely, to ≈øenerehande in al hi≈øtories that not only the mo≈øte renow mede≈øt kynreds and families amonge men decay, but that al≈øo the ≈øucce≈ø≈øours of holy men cleane doth degenerate from the hone≈øtie of there elders, and fall to all fylthyne≈ø≈øe of mi≈øche ue and ≈øynne.

div.head: What tyme the Phari≈øeys and the other ≈øectes began with the Iewes.
div.p:
WHen now the ≈øoueraintie and prie≈øthode by the Iewes began to be toren and pulled a≈øunder by the tyraÃÑny & the warres of Antiochus (I pa≈ø≈øe ouer that the MachabeesThe Machabeys. ioyned them with Heythen kynges, the which ordeined or depo≈øed princes & high prie≈øtes at their plea≈øure, the whiche cared for nothing le≈ø≈øe
then the endeuour of the religioÃÑ): it could not be ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t that ≈øectes and ≈øundry di≈ø≈øen≈øions mu≈øt & y≈øe in the Iewy≈øh religion. For uedes mu≈øt it happen ≈øo, wheÃÑ ether we want a certain head in the religion, or wheÃÑ the heades of the churche or congregatioÃÑ do not regarde the ≈øtudies of Godline≈ø≈øe, and ≈øeke onely outward puy≈ø≈øaunce, as prophane nacions do.

The ≈øectes that were ≈øprong vp, were of thre ≈øores:The maner of ≈øectes ri≈øen in Iewry. The Phari≈øeps. the fir≈øt wer called Phari≈øeis, that is Seuered of the word Phares. The≈øe v≈øed (for they were better learned then the other) certain con≈øtitutions of men aboue the lawe of Mo≈øes, whereby they were ≈øeuered from the other people. Howbeit their doctrine was a litle better & righter, theÃÑ the other. For they taught immortalitie after this life, & that God will puny≈øh ≈øynnes: they beleued al≈øo that Me≈ø≈øias ≈øhould come a ≈øaueour for the faithfull, and a iudge for the ≈øynnes. To the men of this ≈øecte al≈øo was coÃÑ mitted the coÃÑmon welth before other, and they wee of more aucthoritie.

The ≈øecond ≈øecte was of the Sadduceis. The≈øeThe Sadduceyes. hidde their wickedne≈ø≈øe with a very noble & not able callyng theÃÑ≈øelues. For zaddik ≈øignifieth righteous. Sadducei, they that be righteous or holy. So is it mo≈øte commonly receaued in v≈øage in this worlde, that tho≈øe that be mo≈øte wycked of all, do cloke their couetou≈øne≈ø≈øes wyth mo≈øte hone≈øte names. They taught that after death was no lyfe. That God had onely geuen the lawe to the intent we ≈øhoulde liue hone≈øtly & quietly, receiuing of God in y‚Ä¢ meane ≈øea≈øon in this lyfe the rewarde of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe. They did expounde y‚Ä¢ ≈øcriptures wholy according to mans iudgemeÃÑt, nether would they heare ought
els: & as concernyng for the maners that apperta ‚Ä¢
ned vnto man, very Epicures, (that is to ≈øaye, ≈øu ‚Ä¢ as did put the principall goodne≈ø≈øe in voluptuo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
tie,The Saduceyes were Epicures. as Epicurus the Philo≈øopher dyd.) And tha ‚Ä¢ more is when they at the length had gotteÃÑ power‚ñ™ they troubled not a litle the Phari≈øeis. It is a fearfull thyng verely to heare, that among the peculiar and cho≈øen people of God, are crept in euen heytheny≈øh doctrines: in≈øomuche that coÃÑ≈øtantly they were not a≈øhamed, euen openly to teache and ≈øaye, that after this lyfe, was none other lyfe.

The thirde were E≈ø≈øey, the whiche when theyE≈ø≈øey. The Anabapti≈øtes do r ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ble the≈øe. perceiued that both the Phari≈øeyes and Sadduceyes folowed their appetites vnder the coloure of hone≈øt titles, nether did ought in a maner that were worthy their profe≈ø≈øion: therfore ≈øemed it them good, to declare the ≈øtraitne≈ø≈øe and ≈øeueritie of lyfe with the dede, and would be called E≈ø≈øey, that is workers or doers. For A≈ø≈øa, whence the name E≈ø≈øey commeth, ≈øygnifieth to worke: as in the≈øe times the Anabapti≈øtes do reproue bothe the Lutherians and papi≈øtes, and endeuour to ≈øeme more holier then ether of them. For the E≈ø≈øey lyued in a maner in all thinges, as the Anabapti≈øtes lyue: they maryed not, and woulde haue all thynges common among them. This was an vtter fooly≈øh and doti≈øh ≈øuper≈øticion of monkerye, and whiche could not la≈øtThe Note of the churche at this tyme. long. Of this wy≈øe nerehand is the church deuided in thre partes al≈øo now a dates: for becau≈øe y‚Ä¢ ≈øecond commyng of Chri≈øte al≈øo is harde by. The Anabapti≈øtes re≈øemble the E≈ø≈øeyes, and on the other parte, ≈øome be Phari≈øeyes, ≈øome are Sadduceyes. For
the thniges that happened amoÃÑg the Iewes ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e a figuce of the Chri≈øteÃÑ religion. The≈øe ≈øectes ro≈øe fir≈øt among the Iewes vnder Ioannes Hircamus the ≈øonne of Simon before the byrth of Chri≈øt an hundreth and fyue and twenty yeares.

div.head: Of Herodes kynred.
div.p: WHen Iulius Ce≈øar had warre in EgyptAntipater is made gonernoure of Iewry by Iulius Ce≈øar. that was euery where full of daunger, Antipater prince of Idumea ayded him very faithfully, and for a remembraunce of this benefite, made hym Iulius gouernoure of Iewry, the whiche was now con≈øtrayned to obey foren and ≈øtraunge princes in her owne royalme. The Iewes ≈øet them≈øelues agayn≈øt it with great force at the fir≈øt, ≈øufferyng very di≈ødainfully the rule of the Idumean prince, in≈øomuche that he was poy≈øoned at the la≈øt by a Iewe, called Malchus, and dyed.

Herodes reuenged the death of his father Antipater,Herodes toke in Ieru≈øalem and demaunded the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of the Iewy≈øh kyngdome of Augu≈øtus and Antonius in the hundreth foure ≈øcore and ≈øeconde Olympias: and this was after Alexander two huÃÑdreth, foure ≈øcore and twelue yeares. This was the occa≈øion wherby Iewry receuied foren kynges out of Idumea and afterlong ≈øiege compelled Herode them of Ieru≈øalem to yelde theÃÑ≈øelues: nether was there litle bloud ≈øhedde, before the Iewes yelded them≈øelues frelyChri≈øt was borne. to Herodes dominion. As for Chri≈øt was borne in the thirtieth yeare of Herode. The≈øe are nerehand the greate≈øt and chefe≈øt mutations of the kyngdom
brefly comprehended, the whiche happened in Iewry in the tyme of this monarchie, vntill the la≈øt monarchie and the tyme of Chri≈øtes birth.

And though it is euident ynough, that the Iewy≈øh kynges after Chri≈øtes birth were of Herodes kynred, yet wyll I ≈øet them euery one orderly, that the reader may more ea≈øely knowe, how the one is borne of the other, and haue ruled the kyngdome lawfully by a certayn ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, vntyll the de≈øtruction of the citie Ieru≈øalem: though as concernyng the iu≈øt order of the hi≈øtorie, I am not come ≈øo farre. For I haue yet to reher≈øe the≈øe thynges of the Romanes, which happened in the tyme of the Grecian monarchie.

Herode the fir≈øt, whiche was al≈øo called A≈øcalon,Herodes A≈øcalon. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . had many children, among the whiche he hym≈øelfe cau≈øed thre to be ≈ølame, Ari≈øtobulus, Alexander and Antipater, by rea≈øon of a con≈øpiracy, that they had made again≈øt their father. But after him remained aliue Archelaus, Herodes, whiche was ≈øurnamed Antipas, and Philippus. The≈øe parted the kyngdome amonges them.

Archelaus was cho≈øen by a te≈øtament to ≈øuccedeArchelaus. his father Herode in the kyngdome: but Augu≈øtus the emperour would not confirme or ratifye thys wyl of the father, but made hym prince, howbeit vnder this hope, that he ≈øhould be made kyng, yf he ruled hone≈øtly. And ≈øo ruled he nyne yeares, and v≈øed great tyranny: he ≈øet vp and depo≈øed high prie≈øtes, and rauy≈øhed his owne brothers Alexanders wyfeArchelaus was exiledly Augu≈øtus. Finally he was accu≈øed before Augu≈øtus for his wicked dedes, who depriued hym of the dominion, and
in ≈øteade of a puni≈øhmeÃÑt was he banni≈øhed into Ga
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ le, that he ≈øhould leade the re≈øt of his lyfe there in exile: But that parte of Iewry was afterward gouerned by Romane gouernours, fir≈øt by Cyrenius,Herodes Antipas ledde away his brothers wyfe. afterward by Pilate. Herodes ≈øurnamed Antipas, y‚Ä¢ brother of Archelaus, was made prince of Galile by his father Herode. The ≈øame toke hys brother Philips lawful wife from hym, he being yet aliue, the which happened by this occa≈øion: Herode went to Rome, & by the way he lodged by chaunce with his brother Philip, who dwelled in y‚Ä¢ fore part of Iewry. As Herodes and Herodias had now made acquaintaunce, which Herodias was the daughter of Ari≈øtobulus, and ≈øi≈øter to Herodes Agrippa, they were agreed, that he coÃÑming froÃÑ Rome ≈øhould leade her with him, the which was done afterward.Ihon Bapti≈øt An example of vengeauÃÑce Ihon Bapti≈øt rebuketh this wicked dede, who was therfore beheaded. Howbeit Herodes went not vnpuny≈øhed at the la≈øt for it: For by Caius Caligula was he ≈øent in exile at Leonia in Galile with Herodias, the whiche con≈øtrained hym to go to Rome & require a kyngdome: but commyng home without doyng ought, he lo≈øt that part al≈øo of the kyngdom, whiche he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed before. He reigned foure and twenty yeare in Galile.

Herodes Agrippa was the ≈øonne of Ari≈øtobulus,Herodes Agrippa. of whom we haue mencioned before: for he was the ≈øonne of the fir≈øt Herode, & was ≈ølayn by his father. But Herode Agrippa was pri≈øoner at Rome, in the tyme of Tiberius, afterward was he in high fauour by Caius Caligula the emperour: For he optayned by reque≈øt of hym fyr≈øt the parte of Philippe
his brother, and the name of a kyng: afterward ‚Ä¢ that lande al≈øo, whiche Herodes Antipas had. He optayned of Claudius Samaria and Iewry, and by this occa≈øion was whole Iewry ≈øubiecte agayn ‚Ä¢ to one mans dominion. The Apo≈øtle Iames th ‚Ä¢
Iames the ‚Ä¢ ore. greater was put to death by this Herode, the whiche is meÃÑcioned in the twelfe chapter of the Actes. He reigned ≈øeuen yeares.

Agrippa, the ≈øonne of Herodes Agrippa was yet very yonge whan the father dyed, for the whiche cau≈øe the Romanes Pretores or debites gouerned Iewry now agayne. But Claudius gaue Agrippa afterward that part of Syria, whiche is called the kyngdome of Chalcis: he gaue hym that part al≈øo which Philip had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by Iewry. Nero the emperour gaue hym al≈øo ≈øome cities of Iewry. In the tyme of this Agrippa was Ieru≈øaleÃÑ de≈øtroyed, andIn Agrippaes tyme was Ieru≈øalem de≈øtroied of him is mencion made in the xxi chapter of the Actes. He reigned ≈øeuen and twenty yeares. Philo the hi≈øtory Ographer ≈øayeth, that this Agrippa had a ≈øonne, whiche reigned with Ben Co≈øban, who v≈øurpedBen Co≈øban a kynges dominion vpon the Iewes and ray≈øed great vproure in Syria and Iewry in Hadrian the emperours tyme.

This is all Herodes kynred, vntil the ouer throwyng of Ieru≈øalem: the whiche we haue brefely gathered therfore, that it maye clerely bee knowen in what order they haue ≈øucceded in the kyngdoÃÑ. And to know this, is very nece≈ø≈øary in the Bible. Sence the tyme of the fir≈øt Herode, vntyll the de≈øtruction of Ieru≈øalem are an hundreth and thre yeares.

div.head: Of Rome.
div.p:
IN the thyrd Monarchie haue we made mencion brefely of the decaye of the Per≈øes, the pro≈øperitie & fall al≈øo of the Grekes, and al≈øo the ≈øundry mutatioÃÑs di≈øtur
‚Ä¢ nces of the Iewes. Now remaineth that with yke brefene≈ø≈øe we reher≈øe the tymes of the mo≈øte reate≈øt battails that the Romanes haue had ≈øence the great Alexander. For it I woulde reher≈øe theeWherfore monarchies are chefely ordeined of God. whole hi≈øtories, it would be to great a worke. We haue noted aboue, that hygh monarchies are ≈øometyme ordeined to that intent, that great and mo≈øte mighty princes may be tamed, & that ryght ≈øhould be ≈øet again≈øt great tyranny. For this may be ≈øene in all monarchies, whiche are encrea≈øed by none other meanes in a maner, then that they haue ≈øubdued mo≈øte mighty kynges. Euen ≈øo the Romanes, as ≈øone as they began to be very mighty in Italy, they inuaded fir≈øt the Spanyardes and Carthaginians, and had mo≈øte cruell and durable warres: althoug they them≈øelues in the meane tyme were ≈øomtyme greuou≈øly vanqui≈øhed.

div.head: Of the Carthaginian Warre.
div.p:
SIcily was cau≈øe of the CarthaginiaÃÑ war.Sicilia was cau≈øe of the CarthaginiaÃÑ warre. Hieron. For kyng Hieron required helpe and aide of the Romanes again≈øt them of Carthag the whiche for as muche as they occupied now a great part of Sicily a long ≈øea≈øon, they ray≈øed many commotions. Wherfore the foure hundreth and foure ≈øcore yeare ≈øence the foundacion of Rome, did the Romanes appointe the fir≈øt ≈øetting forth again≈øt the Carthaginians: and this warre
la≈øted twenty yeares continually. As for the fyr≈øte di≈øconfiture whiche was very my≈øerable, ≈øufferedRegulus is taken by the carthaginiaÃÑs the Romanes, when Regulus was taken. This Regulus truely was ≈øent to Rome by them of Carthago, to entreate with the ≈øenate for the deliuery of the pry≈øoners: for if he could obtayne it, he ≈øhould be ≈øet fre at libertie. If not, according to his promi≈øe he ≈øhould returne agayn to Carthago. As ≈øone as Regulus came to Rome, it was ≈øayed that he hym≈øelfe coun≈øailed in the ≈øenate, that they would not ≈øuffre the exchaunge of the pry≈øoners to be done for his ≈øake, but that they woulde rather con≈øyder hee were an old man and feble of body, whiche could lyve not muche longer. What nedeth many wordes? The ≈øenate at the la≈øt folowed his mynde, and hee went to Carthago agayne, where he was tormentedThe tormentes of RegulÍù∞ with ≈øundry and new maners of tormeÃÑtes. And among the re≈øt of his tormentes, is this reher≈øed al≈øo, that his eye lyddes beyng cut of, he was trauayled with continuall wakyng. Fir≈øt is the principallThe loue and faithfulne≈ø≈øe of Regulus towarde the comon welth loue of this man toward the commoÃÑ welth alowed, namely who≈øe profite he regarded more, than the health of hym or his. His tru≈øt and faithfulne≈ø≈øe is pray≈øed al≈øo, becau≈øe he went agayn to Carthago, ≈øpecially ≈øeyng he knew that mo≈øte cruel puni≈øhmeÃÑ tes were appointed for hym. But at the la≈øt were the Carthaginians con≈øtrained to demaunde conditionsThe battayll by Egu≈øa. of peace of the Romanes. By the Ile Egu≈øa was a very ≈øore felde foughten, and the Romanes ≈ølew thirtene thou≈øand Cartaginians, and two and thyrty thou≈øand taken pry≈øoners. But whan the Carthaginians required peace, the pry≈øoners were
frely were di≈ømy≈ø≈øed without mony. The≈øe thynges happened after Alexander, whan Ptolomeus Euergetes ruled in Egipt.

div.head: Of Haniball.
div.p:
THe fyue hundreth and .xxxvi. yeare ≈øenceThe ≈øeconde warre of Carthago. The occa≈øion of the ≈øecond warre of Carthago in Spayne. the foundation of the citie of Rome, began the ≈øecond warre of Carthago again≈øt the Romanes. The occa≈øioÃÑ of this warre was begonne by rea≈øon of Spayne, the which whan the Cartaginians had once lo≈øt, Hannibal had now ≈øubdued it agayn. Nether truly had ye Romanes euer any greater di≈øcomfiture, then in this warre. For fortune was ≈øo contrary to them, that Hannibal beyng come into Italy, dyd thre tymes ouerthrowe them: & though the mo≈øt part of the Romanes wasThe di≈øcomfiture of the Romanes in the ≈øeconde warre of Carthago. ≈ølayn in the two fir≈øt battails, yet was it not to be coÃÑ pared to the third battail, wherin were ≈ølayn about fourty thou≈øand Romanes, many al≈øo were taken pri≈øoners. This di≈øcomfiture made the Romanes ≈øo ≈øore afrayd, that many nobles gathered together began to deui≈øe to flye into Grece, & leaue the cytie.Scipio the yonger. But wheÃÑ Scipio the yonger harde of that, he went to them, & exhorted theÃÑ to ≈øted fa≈øtne≈ø≈øe in defending the contrary, and ≈øayed: yf he perceiued any man to flye out of the contrey, he would ≈øtraightway ≈øtrike him thorow with his ≈øworde. Wherfore he compelled the young noble men to bynde them≈øelues with an holy othe, that they ≈øhoulde not leaue the citie, but that they would frely abyde euery chaunce, for loue of the countrey. As for this ≈øame Scipio made an end of this warre, when it had la≈øted ≈øyxten yeres. For he ouercame Hanibal in Aphrica,
and compelled the CarthaginiaÃÑs to require peace: and peace was concluded vpon this condition, that they of Carthago ≈øhould yelde Hannibal to the Romanes.Hannibal fli
‚Ä¢ th to Antiochus. But he beyng e≈øcaped, fled to kyng Antiochus the greate, whome he prouoked to ordeine a great and dredefull warre again≈øt the Romanes. But kyng Antiochus was ≈ølayne, whiche we haue ≈øayde before. It may ea≈øely be gathered out of this, what tyme this ≈øeconde warre of Carthago was, namely twenty yeare before Iudas Machabeus.

div.head: Of the warre of the Romanes in Macedonia.
div.p:
ABout the fyue hundreth and fyue andPhilippus. The occa≈øioÃÑ of the warre of Macebo
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . fortyeth yere ro≈øe fir≈øt the warres in Macedonia. Fir≈øt with Philippe, and that becau≈øe of the league made with Hanniball again≈øt the Romanes. For kyng Philippe hated greatly the name of Rome. For he perceaued that the ≈øame citie crept vp to the de≈øtruction of all kynges and mo≈øte myghty Monarches: in ≈øo muche al≈øo, that he ≈øhoulde haue ≈øayed ≈øomtyme: He feared, le≈øt a tempe≈øt ≈øhoulde once come out of Italy into Grece, who≈øe vehemency ≈øhoulde be ≈øo greate, that all the≈øe ≈ølaughters and di≈øcomfitures whiche Grece had ≈øuffered of the Per≈øes and othet compared to it, might be called but a triful & toie. WherforePer≈øeus ≈øoÃÑne to kyng Philippe, the la≈øt kyng of Macedony. when he was inuaded of the Romanes with warre, he required the coÃÑdicions of peace not vnwittingly, & made a treaty of peace & concord with the Rom. But afterward Per≈øeus his ≈øonne, as one yt
was more coragious, and of a more vnre≈øtly minde, gathered an army, and made aliaunce with many kynges, and inuaded tho≈øe cities of the Romanes, that were in Grece: and the Romanes were al≈øo greatly vanquy≈øhed of hym at the fir≈øt. But not loÃÑg after this battayll, he required frely the condicions of peace: howbeit the Romanes refu≈øed to graunt the ≈øame, and ≈øent Paulus Aemilius into Macedony,Paulus Aemilius. of whom Per≈øeus was ouercome and taken pri≈øoner, with his mother, wyfe, and children. Of this wy≈øe were kynges tamed by the Romanes & ≈øubdued. This Per≈øeus was the la≈øt of the Macedonian kynges, and with hym is that noble kynred of Demetrius gone to naught, where of we haue ≈øpoken before. Howbeit the ≈øonne of this Per≈øeus became a ≈øecretary at Rome: and the kyngdom of Macedony, was afterwarde alwaye gouerned by Romane gouernours. This warre with Per≈øeus began not long before, when Antiochus Epiphanes inuaded the Iewes.

div.head: Of the Spoylyng of Carthago.
div.p:
THe ≈øyxe hundreth and ≈øeconde yeareThe thirde CarthaginiaÃÑ warre. after the fouÃÑdacion of the citie, began the third & la≈øt Carthaginian warre, by this occa≈øion: The citie Carthago was at variaunce with the countreis adioynynge to it, (as ≈øomtyme ry≈øe debates betwene cities and princes,) and the≈øe required ayde of the Romanes, again≈øte the Carthaginians. After long rea≈øonyng, it was di≈øputedDi≈øputation whether Carthago ≈øhould be wholy ouerthrowen‚ñ™ Scip ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Ma≈øica. in the ≈øenate, whether Cartago ≈øhoulde be wholy
≈øpoyled, becau≈øe that it beyng re≈øtle≈ø≈øe, could not lyue in peace. For Scipio Na≈øica coun≈øailed that Ca ‚Ä¢
chago ≈øhould not be ouerthrowen: fir≈øt, becau≈øe it were not hone≈øt that the Romanes ≈øhoulde v≈øe ≈øo great tyranny, and ≈øhoulde ≈ølaye ≈øo muche people. Be≈øide this that it wer not profitable al≈øo: without that citie, could not Aphrica be entertayned too do her duetie, without it were wholy ≈øpoyled. Thyrdly, that it were moo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary for the Romanes, to haue ≈øuche a citie contrarieng them, by the whiche they ≈øhould be ≈øturred to lu≈øtine≈ø≈øe and courage, or els ≈øhould they ray≈øe warre within them≈øelues, yf they feared no foren enemy. Contrary wi≈øe did Cato
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
bring this argument among other, as the chefe≈øt: that the Romanes dyd by lytle and lytle become vn lyke their auncetours in vertues & prowes. Wherfore if the moo≈øt myghty citie Carthago remaining in her e≈øtate knewe the cowardne≈ø≈øe, negligence ≈øloughtfulne≈ø≈øe & feblene≈ø≈øe of the Romanes, there were nothyng more ≈øurer, but that ≈øhe would ≈øtriue againe for the empire and high gouernaunce, and oppre≈ø≈øe the Romanes, and bryng them vnder her power. Wherfore le≈øt this ≈øhoulde be, it were mo≈øte profitable and nece≈ø≈øary, to de≈øtroye Carthago.

Nether would the ≈øenate geue any certayn ≈øentence or verdice vpon this at that tyme: but they ordeined Cato the aged, and certaine other to be ≈øent with hym to Carthago, to trie out all the matter, whether any daunger were to be feared of the Carthagineans, that then at the la≈øt they might earne≈øtly deui≈øe what were to be done. But what nedeth muche to be ≈øayed? Cato beyng returned, ≈øhewed
that more daunger were to be feared of the Carthaginians, than euer was before. For though they of Carthago were depriued of their dominions, yet could they ea≈øely perceaue that the citie were both myghty and al≈øo cruell, whiche coulde not re≈øt but mu≈øt by proce≈ø≈øe of tyme a≈ø≈øay ≈øome thinge to reuenge her ≈øelfe. Be≈øyde this brought Cato with hym grene fygges of exceadyng bygne≈ø≈øe, the whiche he ≈øhewed openly in the ≈øenate. And when he was demaunded, whence he had brought tho≈øe fygges, he aun≈øwered: within thre dayes may be ≈øa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed thither. He ≈øaid moreouer: they growe in the lande of your enemies. So neare dwel your enemies, and they that couet your empire. The ≈øenate being ≈øturred with the≈øe ≈øo many per≈øua≈øions, ordeined, that Carthago ≈øhould be a≈ø≈øaulted with warre, & ≈øhould be roted out by the ground, that there ≈øhould be noScipio y‚Ä¢ yonger ≈øonne to Paulus Aemilius. hope of re≈øtoring it afterward. To accompli≈øh this warre, was Scipio the yoÃÑger the ≈øonne of Paulus Aemilius made capitaine, and in the fourth yeare, after the coÃÑtinuall a≈ø≈øault of ≈øyx daies, was Carthago taken. And though Scipio permitted euery man a ≈øpace to flye frely, yet was a mi≈øerable ≈ølaughter in the citie wheÃÑ it was di≈øpoiled. Afterward by the coÃÑmaundement of Scipio, was the citie ≈øet on fyre, and burned ≈øyxtene dayes continually. ThisCarthago is de≈øtroyed. is that my≈øerable decaye of Carthago the mo≈øte noble cytie, in the whiche neare hande alwaye haue ≈øo many renowmed princes gouerned, of whome to ≈øpeake by rea≈øon of their worthine≈ø≈øe, wyll not the brefene≈ø≈øe of writtynge ≈øuffre at this tyme. Carthago ≈øtode & continued about ≈øeuen huÃÑdreth
yeares. The godly reader may aboue all thynges behold here a dredeful example of Gods vengeauÃÑce in ≈øo truely ouerthrowyng of ≈øo mighty and very excellent a citie. It is ≈øayed al≈øo that after that it was ≈øet on fyre. Scipio came rydyng to the place of the citie, and ≈øawe the my≈øerable ca≈øe of Carthago that was ≈øpoiled and de≈øtroyed, and beyng moued with a pitiful affeccion, he did wepe very ≈øore, & ≈øaid at the la≈øt the≈øe wordes: I pitie the ca≈øe of ≈øo excelleÃÑt a citie, and I ≈øe before that Rome al≈øo ≈øhall once bee ouerthrowen of this wy≈øe: and that more is, it is playne, that no gouernaunce in this worlde is long la≈øtyng, and no power can be ≈øtable.

div.head: Of the warre of the Cimbry in Italy.
div.p:
THis is the ≈øeconde hi≈øtory of the Germanes,The ≈øeconde mention of y‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ es in „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . & of their pro≈øperitie, that they haue had in Italy. For the Cimbriare properly Germanes, whiche witne≈ø≈øeth the name Cimbrica Cherone≈øus. For ≈øo are called the countreis of Hol≈øatz and Denmarck. Moreouer by the witne≈ø≈øe of Strabo are Cimmery and Cimbriboth
„Äà‚óä„Äâ the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ es of „Äà‚óä„Äâ . one thyng. The beginnyng of the names is Go ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ the ≈øonne of Iaphet, who dwelt in the≈øe countries beyond Thracia, that he toward vs, wherein dwell the‚ñ™ people of Littow. And for this cau≈øe knew Homer the poet the people Cimery: For the Grecians knew Thracia and the countreis ioynyng to it. Howbeit the name of Cimbri remayneth onley by Denmark and Hol≈øatz‚ñ™ But the≈øe people that lie towardeGoth ‚Ä¢
the Ea≈øt of Thracia, are called Gotthi, of whome we ≈øhall ≈øpeake hereafter, in the hi≈øtory of
the Gothyes. There is al≈øo made playne mencyon of the lowe duchemen, whych went wyth the Cimbre. It is clere that it was an innumerable multytude, about thre hundreth thou≈øand gathered oute of all quarters of Germany, and ≈øuch an army, that parted a≈øunder they intended to take in partly Italy, partly Gallia. But whan they inuaded the Romanes, they were gathered agayne, and the Romanes were fyr≈øte moo≈øt greueou≈øly ≈ølayne of theThe battayll of the Cimbri with the Romanes. Cimbri, for they had the wor≈øt in foure greate battayls: and in that one battayl, wherein Cepio was captayne, were ≈ølayne foure ≈øcore thou≈øand Romanes: whych thynge made the Romanes and all the people of Italy ≈øo ≈øore afrayd, as they neuer were in the time al≈øo of Hannibal. At that time was MariusMarius was made capytaine again≈øt the Cimbri. appointed captaine agayn≈øt tho≈øe Teutones, For he was to be rekened amonge≈øt the moo≈øt valiaunt men of armes, that Rome had. He went to thys warre in the ≈øyxe hundreth and two and fyftyeth yeare after the foundacion of Rome: and this warre la≈øted tyll the thyrd yeare, ≈øo longe tyll the Cimbri were vtterly de≈øtroyed and oppre≈ø≈øed.

The hi≈øtories make mencion, that in the la≈øt fyghteAn example of vehement wrath of god the women v≈øed ≈øuche force, that they dyd no le≈ø≈øe ≈ølaughter, than the men: and with ≈øuch a rage, that runninge agayn≈øt the Romanes wyth theyr chylderen, ca≈øt them into theyr vi≈øages.

This truely is an example of ≈øo greate crueltye, that worthely maye he quake at the wrath of God, who≈øo fyndeth lyke mi≈øeryes in readynge of hi≈øtories. For it mu≈øt be a vehement and ≈øtrong indignacion, which bryngeth to mens wretched and
oppre≈ø≈øed ca≈øes ≈øo great a mi≈øery.

div.head: Of Sylla and Marius.
div.p:
THat whiche Scipio Na≈øica ≈øayde in theThe con≈øultation of de≈øtroyenge Carthago. Senate to be true, dyd the dede proue. For whan ye Romanes could not be weakened, wyth the power of a foren enemy, they were febled with theyr own ≈øtrengthes, within them≈øelues. Marius, of whom we haue ≈øayd before, broughte home notable victories of the foren enemies, but at the la≈øt was he cau≈øe ‚Ä¢ of a mo≈øt cruelMarine cau≈øe ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ n vproure‚ñ™ Sylla Mithridates vproure in the citie of Rome. For whan Sylla was ordeined captayne, to warre in A≈øia agayn≈øt kyng Mithridates: Marius toke it di≈øplea≈øauntly, that the yonge Sylla ≈øhoulde be ≈øet before him, and he brought much to pa≈ø≈øe by the Tribunes, that they ≈øhould ≈øet them≈øelues agayn≈øt the Senate, & by the commune voyce of the common people, to choy≈øe Marius. By thys hatred was the occa≈øyon ≈øprong of that great warre betwene Sylla & Marius. For whan Marius had ray≈øed thys rumoure at Rome, Sylla appointed a ≈øetting forth of an army into A≈øia. But Marius wyth con≈øente of the people had optayned, that Sylla ≈øhould not go into A≈øia: & ≈øome frendes of Sylla dyed in this commotion at Rome, amonge the which was the ≈øonne of Pompeius the con≈øul the ≈øonne in law of Sylla. But whan the Tribunes ≈øent to Sylla them, that ≈øhoulde ≈øhewe hym, he ≈øhould not go into A≈øia, he appoynted hys army incontinentlye, and came to Rome, and ≈ølew the tribune and many other. Marius fled into Aphrica. In the meane ≈øea≈øon ≈øet ‚Ä¢ Sylla all thynges in order in the citye, and wente
into A≈øia, and brought great thynges to pa≈ø≈øe. He ouercame Mithridates, and toke in wyth ≈øtronge handes Athenes, and whole Grece, and ≈øubdued al≈øo many other contryes of A≈øia. Whan SyllaThe tyranny of Marius. brought this to pa≈ø≈øe, in the meane ≈øea≈øon doth Marius returne oute of Aphrica into Italy well appointed, and goynge to Rome, he ≈ølew the be≈øt and mo≈øt excellent princes, and chefe of the Romanes, and thys ≈ølaughter at Rome was very mi≈øerable. Than was Sylla con≈øtrayned hay≈øtely to returne out of A≈øia, to ayde them that were of his part: but in the meane tyme dyed Marius. Howbeit the ≈øonne of Marius re≈øtored the warre agayn≈øt Sylla,Sylla feareth the incon≈øtancy of fortune. where wyth Sylla beynge afrayed, he ≈øayde as it is reported: that whan he was yonge, he had good fortune agayn≈øt an aged man: but nowe he feared, le≈øt a yonge man ≈øhould lykewy≈øe haue the≈øame fortune agayn≈øt him.

Thys example wytne≈ø≈øeth, that wy≈øe men haue earne≈øtly ouerlayde, and al≈øo douted the vn≈øtablene≈ø≈øe of fortune, whych happeneth in mennes affaires. But God pro≈øpered the enterpri≈øe of Sylla, that he triumphed of hys enemyes: for he had a moo≈øte ryghte cau≈øe. But yet doo hi≈øtoryesSylla is more cruell than nede is. make mencion that Sylla was afterwarde more cruel than nede requyred: For he ≈øpared in a maner noman, than fauored Marius parte, nother was there anye mea≈øure or ende to v≈øe tyranny at Rome. Of thys wy≈øe was the tyranny that Marius v≈øed agayn≈øt the princes reuenged by Sylla at the la≈øt, who re≈øtored them in the gouernaunce. Thou ≈øhalt chefely perceaue
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
gentle reader by thys hi≈øtory, that ≈øo great mi≈øery and debate in the commune wealth, ro≈øe of a ≈ømall begynnyng, and by a certaine alteracion or tourne crept it fyr≈øt in among princes, afterward among y‚Ä¢ people. But Sylla v≈øed great wy≈øedome, and de≈øerued great pray≈øe, that after this commotion, he ≈øet and confirmed the commune welth in a certaine order, vtterly depo≈øynge the authoritye of the Tribunes:The Tribunes were depo≈øed by Silla. The Tribunes are re≈øtored agayne by PoÃÑpeius. for they were wont euer to inflame y‚Ä¢ myndes of the commune people agayn≈øt the Senate. But Pompeius chaunged thys ≈øame afterwarde, who re≈øtored them, to doo the commune people a plea≈øure: Howbeit the euyll coun≈øell was wor≈øt to the coun≈øeller. For the Tribunes were al≈øo the doers in ≈øturrynge to the ciuyll warre betwene Iulius Ce≈øar and Pompeius.

div.head: Of Pompeius and C. Iulius Ce≈øar.
div.p:
THE moo≈øt haynous warre, that was betwene Ce≈øar and Pompeius, which cau≈øed an vtter de≈øtruccyon to the whole commune welth of Rome, toke occa≈øyon of very lyght cau≈øes: & that euen of only enuye again≈øt Ce≈øar, not ≈øo much of Pompeius, as of priuate per≈øones, the whych coueted tho≈øe prouinces, that Ce≈øar po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. The occa≈øion of the warre began of thys wy≈øe:Occa≈øyon of ‚Ä¢ ciuil warre Whan Ce≈øar was in Gallia, he requyred that regard ≈øhould be had of hym in his ab≈øence, and to be remembred in choy≈øynge of coun≈øuls: for it mu≈øt be pertayned to him, that it ≈øhoulde be ≈øo broughte to pa≈ø≈øe. For if he had returned to Rome wythout
there ≈øhould be a con≈øull, hys enemyes were minded to oppre≈ø≈øe him, and to brynge to pa≈ø≈øe, that he ≈øhoulde be exiled from Rome. But Ce≈øar brought to pa≈ø≈øe wyth the ayde of the Tribunes, that the dignity of Con≈øul≈øhyp was promy≈øed him, the which was done wyth the con≈øent of Pompeius the con≈øul al≈øo. But whan the tyme came to appoynte the con≈øuls, ≈øome haue ≈øtered the Senate, to ≈øet them≈øelues agayn≈øt him, nother ≈øuffre Ce≈øar to be made con≈øul, & the ≈øame alured Pompeius to be of their ≈øyde, and droue out the Tribunes, whyche fled to Iulius Ce≈øar. But whan Iulius perceaued that they woulde oppre≈ø≈øe and betraye hym, he laye ≈øore vpon the promy≈øe that was made hym, and demaunded the con≈øul≈øhyppe: be≈øyde thys would he haue the Tribunes re≈øtored into theyr place. Duryng this controuer≈øye, there were diuer≈øe con≈øultations. Marcus Cicero brought the moo≈øt vehementesM. Cicero. rea≈øon, whiche were to be borne of ether parte. For he wylled that Ce≈øar and Pompeius ≈øhould for≈øake theyr hoo≈øtes, and that Pompeius ≈øhould goo into Spayne, as he was al≈øo determined, and Ce≈øar, ≈øo ≈øone as he had for≈øaken the hoo≈øt, ≈øhoulde be con≈øul. Iulius Ce≈øar agreed to thys, but Pompeius refu≈øed it. Wherfore dyd Ce≈øar come to Rome wyth an army appoynted: Pompeius takyng the flyght, doth lykewi≈øe appoynt an hoo≈øt wyth all hys power. But Ce≈øar taketh in Italy & Spayne, and per≈øued Pompeius vntyll Grece. And though Iulius refu≈øyd not hetherto the condicions of an appointment of peace, but dyd al≈øo offreIulius a maÃÑ ad ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed & ≈øouer of peace. them frelye: yet Pompeius cea≈øed not to make
aun≈øwer, that he would graunt nor admitte no condicions of peace, before he ≈øawe the heade of Iulius cut of and brought to hym. But whan Ce≈øar heard that, he was greatly moued. Though Pompeius had a more righteous cau≈øe, yet oughte he to haue v≈øed more gentlene≈ø≈øe agayn≈øte ≈øo noble a prince, that offred condicions of peace, and ≈øought onelye that he might haue ben fre, and withoute daunger of feare. Therfore whan Ce≈øar ≈øawe that he mu≈øte v≈øe coun≈øel by con≈øtraynt, he inuaded Pompeius, and ouercame hym. Pompeius fled into Egypte, where he was ≈ølaine by an entray of the yong king, who≈øe father he hym ≈øelfe had ≈øet into the kyngedome. Afterward toke Ce≈øar A≈øia and Aphrica together, in≈øomuche that he alone had in all the empyre of Rome wyth great puy≈ø≈øaunce. Thys ≈øo great alteration and mi≈øery in the commune welth of Rome began of a mo≈øte lyghte thynge: for this warre was dolefull both to hygh and lowe e≈øtates of men. For hi≈øtories report that ther were ≈ølayne aboue thre hundreth thou≈øand men in thys ciuill warre. ‚∏™

div.head: The fourth and la≈øte Monarchy, namely of the Romane empyre Iulius Ce≈øar.
div.p: THre thou≈øand yeares, eight hundreth and foure ≈øcore and ≈øeuentene were ≈øence the creation of the worlde.
Seuen hundreth and ≈øyxe yeares ≈øence the buyldyng of Rome.

Seuen and forty yeares beforeThe begynnyng of the Romane monarchy. Chri≈øt was borne, began fyr≈øt the Romane monarchy: whan Iulius was made Con≈øul, and the warr agayn≈øt Pompeius, whereof we haue euen nowe ≈øpoken, dyd begynne. That the warre la≈øted fyue yeares. For whan Pompeius was deade, Iulius had yet much bu≈øyne≈ø≈øe to do in Egypte, A≈øia and Aphrica, where Cato had ≈ølayne hym ≈øelfe: and inCato ≈ølewe hym≈øelfe. Spayne, where he had al≈øo ≈ølayne one of Pompeius ≈øonnes. But whan all contryes were ≈øett in peace, returned Iulius to Rome, and that was in the moneth October, and after that in the begynnynge of Marche, was he ≈øtycked through in the Senate of Ca≈ø≈øius and Brutus wyth their companyons.

Wherfore raigned Iulius in peace, nomore but fiueThe ordering of the yeare was begonne by Iulius. monethes, and in that ≈øea≈øon cau≈øed he the yeare to be ordered, throughout all the Romane empyre, according to the cour≈øe of the ≈øonne. He brought al≈øo with him out of Egypt a notable and mo≈øt conning man in ≈øciences, which taught by demon≈øtracyons,
called a Mathematicus‚ñ™ and was the fyr≈øt autor ‚Ä¢ cau≈øe that tho≈øe ≈øciences were taughte in Italy. And this ordering of the yeare, which is hand≈øome and that we v≈øe yet now at this tyme, was begon ‚Ä¢ fyr≈øt by Iulius. But how di≈øhone≈øtly and very cruelly tho≈øe that kylled Iulius, that is playn ynoug ‚Ä¢ by theyr dedes. For Ca≈ø≈øius & Brutus wyth they companions fauoured Pompeius. But by the mercyfulnes of Ce≈øar, were they take in agayne into the citye, and re≈øtored into their former dignitye & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of goodes. For what ≈øhall I be prolixe? The worlde had neuer a prince ≈øo mighty, that euerThe „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ gentlyne≈ø≈øe of Ce≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
v≈øed more gentlyne≈ø≈øe towarde hys enemies, that frely yelded theÃÑ≈øelues. He neuer ≈øhewed anye notable wrath agayn≈øt anye man, wythoute it had ben in a battaill, where nece≈ø≈øitie to fighte dyd requyre: where neuerthele≈ø≈øe before him Marius & Sylla neuer cea≈ø≈øed of murtheringe, euen in tyme of peace. But Iulius did no ≈øuch thinges, ye he frely toke to mercy euen the be≈øt of the coÃÑmune welth, that were Pompeius adherentes, nether toke ought from them. He brought agayn al≈øo the true maner of gouerning the commune welth, whiche was decayed by ≈øedition, and re≈øtored it wyth no le≈ø≈øe wy≈øedome, than he kept it vp with authoritie. But how great a thinge this is, maye be gathered therby, that in ciuill commotions wee ≈øe iudgementes, lawes and all mode≈øtie of maners go to wrack and to nought. Iulius truely was one of the mo≈øt doughtye≈øt princes, whiche beynge garni≈øhed of God with mo≈øt greate≈øt vertues aboue other men, that haue gouerned very great dominions.

Be≈øyde this was it not po≈ø≈øyble to retayne commune peace long after that Iulius was deade: for there was noman after Iulius that had ether ≈øuch authoritie or power, that with very force could enterteyn the quyetne≈ø≈øe of the empyre: for to retaine the ≈øame in great kingdomes, is requi≈øite a greate and ≈øyngular puy≈ø≈øaunce. Moreouer it is reported that he ≈øhould haue ≈øayde: That he feared not for for his lyfe, but that his death ≈øhould be mi≈øcheueous and deadly to the commone welth & empyre.

But all this refrained not them from the cur≈øed enterpry≈øe, of whom by a coÃÑiuracion he was ≈ølaine. The fir≈øt beginner of this wicked dede, was Ca≈ø≈øius,Ca≈ø≈øius. and that only by enuy, becau≈øe for Ce≈øars ≈øake he could not obtayne tho≈øe prouinces, which he coueted.Brutus‚ñ™ Brutus was a man of great wytt, and therfore ≈øuffred he him lightely to be made a companyon of this wicked dede: cloking it with this colour, that it were not hone≈øt for the Senate of Rome, to ≈øuffre a lord greater in the empyre then he. Item, that Ce≈øar al≈øo was a tyraunt, and that it was lawfully permitted to ≈ølaye tyrauntes. With ≈øuch lyke inconuenient argumentes, whiche are oft wont to begyle yong and vnlearned men in lyke ca≈øes, was Brutus inflamed: for without his helpe had Ca≈ø≈øius brought nothynge to pa≈ø≈øe. This is the ≈øumme of this hi≈øtory. But God ≈øuffred ≈øo great a mi≈øcheuou≈øne≈ø≈øe not longe vnpuni≈øhed. For as manye as had con≈øpyred to the death of Iulius, were al≈øo ≈ølayne them≈øelues not longe after.

Ce≈øar was olde ≈øyxe and fyftye yeare whan he was ≈ølayne, and ruled fyue yeares: and the beginninge
of rulynge was in the con≈øul≈øhyppe, in the which he beganne the warre agayn≈øt Pompeius. This is the begynnynge of the Romane monarchye, the whych God hath paynted very horribly in the prophet Daniell: and wytne≈ø≈øeth, that the world ≈øhalbe much more heauely oppre≈ø≈øed by the≈øame, than euer it was before. Item that Chri≈øt ≈øhall come in the ≈øame monarchye, and therfore ≈øhal it be the la≈øt. For all the≈øe thynges are prophe≈øyed before by God, to ≈øtably≈øhe the fayth of the godly, concerninge the certayntie of Chri≈øtes comming. Be≈øydes thys al≈øo that it mighte be knowen that the world ≈øhall not endure foreuer, but ≈øhall once pery≈øhe, and that the vngodlye ≈øhalbe puny≈øhed, but the Godly ≈øhall loke at Gods hand for a lyfe euerla≈øtynge. I ≈øuppo≈øe verely that the prophecy of the Heythen prophetes, and ≈øayenges of the Sybilles of the durablene≈ø≈øe of the Romane empyre, are pertaynynge to thys, as is the ≈øayenge of Virgil: I haue geuen an endle≈ø≈øe empyre, the whych ≈øeme to be taken of this, whiche the ≈øcrypture ≈øayeth, thatThe Roman monarchy is the la≈øte on earth. the empyre of Rome ≈øhalbe the la≈øte monarchye on earth. Though the ≈øcripture doth in the meane ≈øea≈øon teache al≈øo, that thys monarchy ≈øhall decaye: yet ≈øhall parte of the ≈øame la≈øt euer, wherein ≈øhall re remayne the name and hygne≈ø≈øe of an Emperour, vntyll the worldes ende.

The≈øe thynges are to be knowen, that wee maye be a≈ø≈øured that thys empyre can not be ouerthrowen, whyche the examples of hi≈øtories wytne≈ø≈øe al≈øo. For after that the hyghne≈ø≈øe of an Emperoure was tran≈ølated to the Germanes, hath
thys kyngdome ≈øuffred many a≈ø≈øaultes, and hath oft bene weakened: but yet coulde it not be aboly≈øhed by nomans power, but remayned allwaye ≈øtable, and re≈øtored it ≈øelfe otherwyles.

For it had nowe Emperours of ≈ømall power, than very puy≈ø≈øaunt Emperours. To con≈øydre the≈øe thynges in hi≈øtoryes maketh greate matter, chefely to knowe the wyll of God aryghte in ≈øuche chaunces.

div.head: Augu≈øtus.
div.p: WHan Iulius was deade, ro≈øe greate commotions at Rome. Marcus CiceroMarcus Cicero. coun≈øelled to make a peace on thys wy≈øe: that thence foreward noman ≈øhould laye handes on the fauourers of Iulius, & that all they lykewy≈øe, whych had ≈ølayne Iulius ≈øhould be wythout daunger or feare: but all di≈øcorde layde doune on both ≈øydes, they ≈øhoulde prouide for common and perpetuall peace: none otherwy≈øe than of late dyd Thra≈øybulus make a concorde at Athenes, the whych they called Amni≈øtia, that is, that‚ñ™ ether parte ≈øhoulde forget the iniury done, and that nether of them ≈øhoulde inuade the other afterwarde. Thys was very gentely and hand≈øomly counceled and con≈øydered of Cicero, but thys contynuall peace coulde not endure longe. For whan afterwarde euerye man woulde rule, it was nece≈ø≈øarye that factions ≈øhoulde ry≈øe. The Senate drue Octauius Augu≈øtus to it, agayn≈øt Anthonius.

For Anthonius coueted y‚Ä¢ raygne. But the ≈øouldioursAnthonius. con≈øpyryng again≈øt the Senate, ≈ølew manye of the chefe men of the citye, among the which wasAnno. ‚Ä¢ l. before Chri≈øtes „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Cicero beheaded al≈øo. But the empyre remayned by Octauius Augu≈øtus only, which was kyn≈øman to Iulius: for Iulia ≈øy≈øter of Iulius had ≈øpou≈øed Accius Balbus, but theyr doughter was Accia, who≈øe hu≈øband was Octauius: of them was borne
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Octanius Augu≈øtus, whom Iulius had appointed and cho≈øen hys heyre, whereby he was ≈øurnamed Ce≈øar, and that name remayned euer afterwarde by the ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, euen as though by ryght of ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, they dyd entre into Ce≈øars kynred: as it was wont to be, whan ≈øucce≈ø≈øors were fir≈øt adopted and cho≈øen. Nether was Iulius called Ce≈øar fyr≈øte by
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
rea≈øon of the empyre, but many of his kynred were ≈øo ≈øurnamed before. For the old & approued Grammarians do wryte that the name of Ce≈øar coÃÑmeth of the worde or name Ce≈øaries, whiche ≈øignifieth goodly heare or a bu≈øh of fayre heare: and of that gat the Iulies fyr≈øt that name, becau≈øe that one or other happelye had a fayre heare in that kynred.

As for the name Augu≈øtus dyd the Senate adde to Octauius, for hys luckyne≈ø≈øe and pro≈øperitye
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
in hys affayres. Augu≈øtus commeth of Auguruim, (that is, a diumation or ≈øoyth≈øayenge by the crye or ≈ølighte of byrdes) and betokeneth fortunate, and he whom God doeth pro≈øpere by lucky ≈øygnes or tokens.

This addition, is a right geuen to a ≈øupreme gouernour of y‚Ä¢ world: for god is with y‚Ä¢ ciuil power, & the
gouernaunce of an empyre, is the gyfte and ordinaunce of God.

Augu≈øtus raygned ≈øyxe and fyfty yeares, but he gouerned not the empyre alone the twelue fyr≈øt yeares. For beyng yong, not pa≈ø≈øyng nyneten yeares of age, was he ≈øet in the gouernaunce: he was made coun≈øul, becau≈øe he ≈øtack by the Senate, of of the which he was made con≈øul, in de≈øpyte of Antonius. But the ≈øouldiours agreyng wythin them ≈øelues, ≈øet them agayn≈øt the Senate and his adherentes. But for ≈øo much as thys concord could not be durable, Augu≈øtus was fayne afterwarde to be at variaunce and ≈øtryue al≈øo wyth hys felowes, and ≈øo optayned he the whole empyre alone. But whan the gouernaunce was ≈øtably≈øhed with peace, he v≈øed moo≈øt hygh moderation in all thinges, and confirmed the whole empyre wyth hone≈øte lawes and ≈øtatutes: in ≈øo much that it is reported, he ≈øhuld haue ≈øayd: The kyngdome ≈øhall la≈øt for euer, yf the≈øe ordinaunces be not auoyded and di≈øanulled. But what ≈øhall I ≈øaye much? Augu≈øtus is ≈øca≈øely counted the fyr≈øte and chefe≈øt among the ≈øage and moderate princes.

div.head: ¬∂ The thyrde boke of the Cronicles, whych conteyneth the tyme ≈øence Chri≈øtes byrth.
div.p: BEfore, in the begynnynge of thys worke, haue we diuided thys whole Cronicle and tymes of the worlde in thre partes, and that accordinge to the ≈øayenge of Elias, that both the moo≈øt alterations of thynges in the world, and order of the tymes myght be knowen more ≈øurely. Be≈øydes thys, that we ≈øhoulde al≈øo knowe, that the worldes end is nowe not farre of. Howbeit we haue nowe di≈øpatched allmoo≈øt foure thou≈øand yeares, and about that time nearehande was Chri≈øt borne, the whyche Elias had prophecyed. Now in this thyrd boke, ≈øhall we lyke wy≈øe treate of the thyrde parte of Elias meanynge, and begynne thys boke wyth the ≈øame. And how lytle Elias had fayled in the order of the yeares, truely it maye be perceaued verye ea≈øely: for CHRISTE our LORD, very God and man,WhaÃÑ Chri≈øt was borne. was borne into thys lyfe of the virgin Mary euen the two and fortyeth yeare of Augu≈øtus raygne: and thys was thre thou≈øande, nyne hundreth and foure and fortyeth yeare ≈øence the creation of the worlde. But to counte the yeares exactely and narowly, there is ≈øomewhat requi≈øite in the nombre of the yeares. For the foure thou≈øande yeares are not fulfilled.

But the prophete ≈øayde moreouer: that God wold preuent and come ≈øpedely before the tyme of hys comminge, becau≈øe the ende of all thinges myght be more neare. Howbeit the thynges that are concernyng the knowledge of Chri≈øtes natiuyte, Pa≈ø≈øion and Re≈øurrection for euerye Godly man, the ≈øame maye all be ≈øearched in the Euangeli≈øtes. But as concerning the tyme whan Chri≈øt ≈øuffred, and ro≈øe agayne from death: al≈øo how the Go≈øpell is ≈øpred abroade in the worlde, and by what meanes al≈øo the holy Go≈øpell began in the worlde vnyuer≈øall, we ≈øhall intreate afterwarde.

div.head: Of the Germanes.
div.p: IN the tyme of Augu≈øtus were theThe Germanes were fyr≈øt couque≈øted by warre. Tiberius Dru≈øius. Germanes fir≈øt attempted of the Romanes. Tiberius and hys brother Dru≈øius were wyth an hoo≈øt in high germany, and inuaded tho≈øe coa≈øtes, that are ioyninge to Rhetia and Vindelicia. But they dyd not wholy ≈øubdue tho≈øe contryes vnder theyr empyre. The Rheti are tho≈øeRhetia. that dwell in the valley of the floude Enus or Ihn, they of Tyrol vntyll Bregetium or Rab, Kempte and dounwarde vntyll Nordlingen, where yet remaynethVindelicia. the name Ryes. They of Vindelicia are Aug≈øpurg and vpper Beyerlande. Dru≈øus went doune vntyll Mentz, and there gettynge a di≈øea≈øe he lo≈øt hys lyfe.

Aboute that tyme made the garny≈øon of the Romanes, that was appoynted at Colen an
a≈ø≈øaulte vpon We≈øtphalen and Saxony. But one called Hermannus was captayne of Saxony, whoÃÑ the hi≈øtoryeus do call Arminius lord of Cheru≈øia.Cheru≈øci. Armnius. As for the Cheru≈øci are euen the Saxons & Thurynges, dwellynge by the wood called Schwartzwalde, of that ≈øyde, that ≈øtretched beneth by the floude We≈øurgus vntyll the citye Breme, And by my iudgement is that called Cheru≈øci, whych now is communely called Hertzi≈øhe. This Arminius oppre≈ø≈øed the Romanes vnwarres, and ≈ølew about one and twenty thou≈øand of them. Be≈øydes al≈øo a great army of the ayders and confederates of the Romanes, whych warred wyth them, as Frenchmen do wyth the Scottes.

Quintilius Varus the captayne of the RomaneQuintilius Varus. hoo≈øt ≈ølew him ≈øelf wyth hys ≈øwearde. Tacitus the hi≈øtoryographes ≈øheweth at larg of the battayl that was had, namelye betwene the floudes Lyppia and Ami≈øia, that is, beneth the toune Ca≈ø≈øel, not farre from the toune Padeborne in We≈øtphalen. For thus ≈øayeth Tacitus: They ployled ≈øo much as lyeth betwene the floudes Ami≈øia & Lyppya, not farre from the woode of Teutoburgum, where the re≈øidue of Varus hoo≈øte and legions is ≈øayde to lye vnburyed. As for this ≈ølaughter made the Romanes no le≈ø≈øe afrayde, that in tymes pa≈øte whan the Cimbriway≈øted Italy. For the Romanes were afrayde le≈øt Arminius wyth force of armes had inuaded the Romane empyre, and come vntyll Rome. Augu≈øtus was in ≈øuche di≈øtre≈ø≈øe by rea≈øon of the feare of the greate daunger, that he cau≈øed euery man to be euery where in armes. It
is al≈øo ≈øayed, that he ≈øayed of wepyng & with great crye: Quintily re≈øtore the legions. But when the Romanes were dryuen out of Saxony, they brought to pa≈ø≈øe, that Arminius was inuaded with war of his neighbors, there was at that tyme the Swedes and Belhems, dwelling by the ryuer Albis: but Arminius ouercame them al≈øo, and takyng in their contreis, he had We≈øtphalen, Shwartwald, Saxony, Marck, Mi≈øen, and Bohemy. He reigned about twelue yeare, and finally was he ≈ølayne by the oppre≈ø≈øion of his. But this is ynough ≈øayed of Augu≈øtus tyme.

div.p: THough many excellent Emperours haue ben≈øence the time of Augu≈øtus, (for when God kepeth the common welthes, he geueth al≈øo ≈øuche men, that are mete to do great thynges.) yet haue the in the meane ≈øea≈øoÃÑ now and than princes di≈ø≈øolute and wicked: ≈øo that a mery conceated man ≈øemeth to haue ≈øayed very true: that the ymages of al good princes may be graueÃÑ in one rynge. It is very profitable to beholde in hi≈øtories the thynges that are declared and the examples of wycked princes, that we may drede y‚Ä¢ wrath of God, by the feare of the puni≈øhment, wherewith they are puny≈øhed.

Tiberius was not the ≈øonne of Augu≈øtus, but forTiberiu ‚Ä¢ .
≈øomuche as the true heyres of Augu≈øtus were deade, he toke in ≈øteade and cho≈øe for heyre Tiberius the ≈øonne of Liuia, whiche was already maried to Augu≈øtus: and becau≈øe Tiberius was a valiaunt man of armes, Augu≈øtus v≈øed hym alway for a captain. This Tiberius was the fir≈øt Emperour, to whome the ≈øenate of Rome did yelde it ≈øelfe. He reigned thre and twenty yeares.

The fyuetenth yeare of Tiberius was Chri≈øteWhaÃÑ Chri≈øt was bapti ‚Ä¢ ed our Lorde thirty yeare olde, and that yeare was he bapti≈øed of Ihon Bapti≈øte, and beganne the preachyng of hys Go≈øpell, of penaunce, of remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øynnes, and lyfe euerla≈øting. This was ≈øence the creation of the worlde the .iiii. M. ix. C. and lxxv. yeares. But after the beginning of Alexanders Monarchie the .CCC. and .xl. yeare. Adde an hundreth and fyue and fourty yeares vntyll the ≈øecond yeare of Longimanus. Thus haue ye the foure hundreth and foure ≈øcore and fyue yeares: and the≈øe are the thre ≈øcore and nyne wekes of the whiche is ≈øpoken by Daniel: whiche thynge we haue treated at length before.

In the eyghtenth yeare of Tiberius was Chri≈øtWhaÃÑ Chri≈øt was crucifyed. oure Sauioure crucified, dyed, and ro≈øe agayn the thyrde daye. But after his re≈øurrection he commaunded his di≈øciples, that they ≈øhould preache the Go≈øpell thorowe all the worlde, the whiche they began ≈øtrayght way, when they had receaued the holy gho≈øt from heauen vpon Wyt≈øonday, and after the vi≈øible a≈øcen≈øion of Chri≈øt into heauen.

Therfore is now the worde of God and ≈øpiritualWhere the Churche or ≈øpirituall kingdom is kyngdom, and al≈øo the churche or congregacion of
the faithful or chri≈øten people not only in the Iewi≈øh kyngdom: but in the whole worlde, where the Go≈øpell is preached by the Apo≈øtles, and where theyr writinges are brought For God promi≈øed to worke by preaching of his worde. Moreouer where Gods worde is taught, ther is it nece≈ø≈øary to be ≈øome that pertaine to Gods kingdom, where Chri≈øt is ruling and workyng, accordynge to that ≈øayenge: I ≈øhalbe with you vntyll the worldes ende. To this oure Lorde Chri≈øt our ≈øauiour and true God, be pray≈øe, glory and thanke≈øgeuyng for euer. Amen.

But now it remayneth that we do ≈øhew further how greate and heuy a≈ø≈øaultes the churche of chri≈øtenmen hath ≈øuffered, both by outwarde per≈øecutions of enemies, and al≈øo chefely by heretikes, whiche haue nowe and than toren wretchedly the vnitie of the churche with wicked doctrines: which thynge hath brought a farre more dammage and de≈øpy≈øynge to the Churche or congregacion, than any outwarde per≈øecutions.

The nyntenth yeare of Tiberius after Chri≈øtes re≈øurrection was Steuen the fyr≈øt martyr ≈øtonedWhan Steuen was ≈øtouen. and the ≈øame yeare was Paule conuerted to the fayth. And this befell.

CAius Caligula the fourth Emperoure reignedCaius Caligula. thre yeare and ten monethes: he was of a veri di≈ø≈øolute and vmbrideled lyfe, he defyled
all his ≈øy≈øters with an vnnamed or an vnnaturall medling: Fynally was he ≈ølayn by the chefe of hys hoo≈øt through a preuy con≈øpiracy. This Caligula cau≈øed his ymage to be ≈øet in the temple at Ieru≈øalem, to be wor≈øhipped, whiche thyng was al≈øo prophecied by Daniel, namely: When I≈øraell ≈øhall ≈øe anDaniel. ix. Idoll ≈øet in the temple, then ≈øhal the ende be at haÃÑd. This happened.

div.p:
NEro the ≈øyxt. Emperour reigned fourtenNero. yeare. At the begynnyng lyued he hone≈øtly fyue yeares, afterwarde was he mo≈øte vngratious by rea≈øon of hys intemperancy of maners and tyranny. He put to death his own mother & his wyfe, and al≈øo many noble men, amoÃÑg whom was al≈øo Seneca. Finally whan his officers
was gone from hym, whan he was ≈øought to be put to deaht by the Senate of Rome, he fleing ≈ølew him≈øelfe, before he was founde out by the ≈øouldiours: and this was done the two and thirtyeth yeare of his age. But the kyngdom of the Romanes is now wholy remoued from the po≈øteritie and kyn≈ømen of Augu≈øtus and Leuia.When Peter was crucified. Linus by≈øhoppe. Paul is beheaded.

In the tyme of Nero was ≈øaint Peter crucifyed at Rome. After hym was Linus made by≈øhop, and afterwarde was Paule the Apo≈øtle beheaded al≈øo. And yf ye counte the yeares of Paule, hee preached the Go≈øpell about foure and thyrty yeares.

In the tyme of Nero appeared a comete ≈øyxeA comete ≈øene in Nerois tyme. monethes contrary too all cometes, whiche are not wont to be ≈øene ≈øo longe. There was al≈øo a comete ≈øene before in the tyme of Claudius, and three ≈øonnes, whiche ≈øygnyfyeth doutle≈ø≈øe, that three princes ≈øhoulde ≈øhortely ≈øtriue for the empire. In lyke maner do I ≈øuppo≈øe, that their great Comete dyd ≈øygnifye not onely the ≈øedicion and vproure, but al≈øo the mutacion and chaunge in the Romane empire, and ≈øpecially the lamentable decaye of the Iewy≈øh kyngdom.

div.head: Sergius Galba, Otho, and Vitellius.
div.p:
AMong the≈øe thre was a ≈øtryfe for the empyre,Sergius Galba, Otho. after Neroes death. As for Galba was ≈ølayn in ye marketplace of Rome by y‚Ä¢ layenge wayte of Otho. Afterward was Vitellius cho≈øen Emperoure in Germany of theVitellius. hoo≈øt, and ≈øent ≈øome men of armes into Italy. The
whiche metyng Otho, he fought foure feldes with them: thre tymes dyd he ouercome them, but in the fourth was his hoo≈øt ouerthrowen. And though the ≈øouyldiours drue frely to hym, yet would hee warre no more. For it is reported that he ≈øhoulde haue ≈øaid: that he ≈øet more by the comon peace, then by his owne lyfe or priuate glory: and the fourth moneth after Galbas death, ≈ølew he hym≈øelfe with a daggar.

In the meane ≈øea≈øon was Ve≈øpa≈øianus cho≈øenVe≈øpa≈øianus Emperoure in the Ea≈øte, by the ≈øouldiours: the≈øame ≈øent an hoo≈øt into Italy, the whiche ouerthrewe Vitellius men of armes. Of that ro≈øe vproures at Rome, and Vitellius was taken his handes bound vpoÃÑ his backe, and with a halter ca≈øt about his neck, he was drawen through the myer in the ≈øtretes, and fynally was he ≈ølayne as he had de≈øerued. For he was ≈øuche one, that de≈øerued rather to bee called a cruell bea≈øte, than a man. This was the fyr≈øt vproure that was in the Empyre for the election or cho≈øyng, after Augu≈øtus.

VE≈øpa≈øianus the Seuenth Emperoure reigned nyne yeares. It was a man renowmed in wy≈øedome and hone≈øty, and a prince mo≈øte worthy of the Empyre. For where Caligula, Claudius and Nero dyd nott onely ≈øuffre all intemperancy out of mea≈øure in other, but dyd it them≈øelues al≈øo: this man contrarywy≈øe re≈øtored at Rome
the nourture of mode≈øtie and hone≈øt lawes. He augmented al≈øo the Empyre with all maner of victuals, and in the prouinces ordeined he nece≈ø≈øary aydes. Be≈øides this ordeined he al≈øo at Rome common pen≈øions for profe≈ø≈øers of phi≈øyck and other ≈øciences.

div.head: Of the la≈øt de≈øtruction of Ieru≈øalem.
div.p:
IN the ≈øeconde yeare of Ve≈øpa≈øianus beganWhen TitÍù∞ the ≈øonne of Ve≈øpa≈øiane be≈øyeged Ieru≈øalem. Titus the ≈øonne of Ve≈øpa≈øian to be≈øyege the cytie Ieru≈øalem, whan Ea≈øter began to be kept in the moneth of Apryll, and afterwarde in the moneth September dyd he ≈øpoyle and burne it. But in the meane tyme was ≈øo great my≈øery in the cytie for hunger, vproure and inwarde man≈ølaughter, as neuer was red to haue bene in any cytie. The mothers dyghted their owne chyldren to ≈øati≈øfye their hunger, but inuayne: For the ≈øouldyours tooke them awaye from them par force, and deuoured them, and the mothers dyed with hunger the whyles. Many ≈ølew them≈øelues. Io≈øephus wryteth that in the cytyTen huÃÑdreth thou≈øaÃÑd men were in the citie whan Ieru≈øalem was be≈øyeged. were about ten hundreth thou≈øand per≈øons. For becau≈øe it was Ea≈øter, a very great multitude came together into the cytie: Be≈øydes this, they that dwelt here and there in villages, in all Iewry, drue all together to Hieru≈øalem, for none other cau≈øe, but that they tru≈øted to bee in ≈øaue garde by the defence of ≈øo well afortified citie. In ≈øo great noÃÑ ber of people, the mo≈øte parte nere hande dyed with
hunger, pe≈øtilence and ≈øworde. Titus ≈øent ≈øyxtene thou≈øand to Alexandria, to do ≈øeruice, none other wy≈øe then ≈ølaues. He brought twoo thou≈øand with hym, whiche hee ≈øhewed in a triumphe, and ca≈øte them to wylde bea≈øtes in common games to be toren in peces. But what ≈øhall I ≈øaie muche? nomans oracioÃÑ can be ≈øufficient to expre≈ø≈øe ≈øo great a my≈øery. For God woulde propo≈øe to men a new and ≈øyngularAn example of Gods wrath. example, wherein myght be ≈øene the greatne≈ø≈øe of Gods wrath again≈øt de≈øpi≈øers of Godlyne≈ø≈øe. For it mu≈øt be a very ≈øtony and harde harte, whiche ≈øhoulde not be ≈øore afrayed at ≈øo dredefull an example. And it is aboue all thynges to be ouerloked in this hy≈øtorye, that yf God v≈øed no mercy towarde thys people in puny≈øhynge them for their wyckedne≈ø≈øe, whome he called hys peculiar people, whyche al≈øo was come of ≈øo holy fathers: He ≈øhall muche le≈ø≈øe ≈øpare the Heythen. And God in threatenynge thys, declareth al≈øo in the ≈øame example the ≈øhewe of mercy and Godly beneuolence: namely, that we do not doubt that after that the Iewy≈øh kyngdom is ouerthrowen, we that are Gentyls, are truely the cho≈øen people and Gods chyldren, yf we do truly beleue in Chri≈øte.

This de≈øtruction of Ieru≈øalem befell in the ≈øecoÃÑd yeare of Ve≈øpa≈øtanus: and it was the thre≈øcore and fortene yeare after Chri≈øtes natiuite, the fortieth yere after that Chri≈øt had ≈øuffered his pa≈ø≈øion. But from the creation of the worlde the foure thou≈øand and eightenth yere. And this temple dyd ≈øtande after the ≈øecond yere of Longunanus fyue hundreth and ≈øyx and twenty yeares.

Many dredefull tokens ≈øignifyed this de≈øtructioÃÑ Straung thiÃÑ ges were ≈øene before the de≈øtructioÃÑ of Ieru≈øalem. afore, which for ≈øhortne≈ø≈øe we can not here reher≈øe. A burnyng ≈øworde was ≈øene aboue the temple nearehande a whole yeare. I haue added thys therfore, le≈øt no man do ra≈øhly de≈øpy≈øe the tokens, which pretende the euideÃÑces of Gods indignacion, by the which we are called to repentaunce, that the wrath of God maye be ether auoyded, or mitigated: which thynge of mercy happened to the Niniuites.

div.p:
TRaianus the Emperoure reigned nynetene yeares and ≈øyxe monethes. This ≈øame wasTraianÍù∞ ‚Ä¢ as „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ho „Äà‚óä„Äâ . the fyr≈øte of the ≈øtraunge Emperours: For he was no Italian, but a Spanyarde by kynred. He was of ≈øuche notable hone≈øtie, that euer afterward, as oft as an Emperoure was electe, he dyd wy≈øhe‚òû with open reque≈øte, that: he might be lyke to Traianus in hone≈øtie, & Augu≈øtus in happene≈ø≈øe. When he
had made the principall officers of his court, he gaueThe noble ≈øayenge of Traianus when he gaue his heade officer the power of the ≈øworde. hym a ≈øworde in hys hande, ≈øayeng the≈øe wordes: V≈øe this ≈øworde agayn≈øt myne enemies in iu≈øte cau≈øes. If I do not iu≈øtly, then drawe it vpon my≈øelfe. The Romane empyre was neuer ≈øo large, as in the tyme of Traianus: and aboue the examples of other Emperours, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed he the realmes of the Ea≈øt mo≈øt largely. He had very great warres in Hungary and Germany.

Ihon the euangeli≈øt that was driuen out by Domitian,Ihon the Apo≈øtle returneth out of Pathmos. returned agayne to Ephe≈øus out of the yle Pathmos. If ye wyll reken the noÃÑbre of the yeres, it ≈øhalbe founde that Sainct Ihon hath preached aboue thre ≈øcore yeares. Good Lorde howe many‚òú my≈øeries hath Sainct Ihon ≈øene in ≈øo longe ≈øpace, among the whiche was euen the greate≈øt, the de≈øtruction of Hieru≈øalem hys countrey: I wyll pa≈ø≈øe ouer how greueou≈øly hee hath ≈øtryuen wyth many and euen peruer≈øet heretikes. For we reade that vpon a tyme Sainct Ihon came into a bath, and founde Cherinthus the Heretike ≈øittyng with hys company, and di≈øputynge earne≈øtly amonge them, and the vn≈øhamefa≈øt bla≈øphemer denyed Chri≈øte to be man. But Sainct Ihon ry≈øynge, bad hys frendes that were ≈øet wyth hym, to departe with hym from thence: For God woulde not ≈øuffre any lenger ≈øo vn≈øhamefa≈øt bla≈øphemies. But ≈øtrayghtwaye as he was gone out, the hou≈øeCherinthus the heretike was killed „Äà‚óä„Äâ the fallyng of an hou≈øe. An example of vengeauÃÑce fallyng downe, ≈ølewe Cherinthus wyth hys company. It is a dredefull example of Gods wrath agayn≈øt them whiche bla≈øpheme the name of GOD, wyth open and manife≈øt vngodlyne≈ø≈øe, howe
litle he wyl ≈øuffre them to be vnpuni≈øhed at length.

div.p:
ADrianus the .xii. Emperoure, reigned twenty yeares: He was adopted of Traianus. He was a prince of greate wy≈ødome, he was not geuen too warre after the example of Traianus, but was geuen to common peace by al maner of meanes: and of this wi≈øe re≈øtored he the Empyre in mo≈øte be≈øt fa≈øhion, wherfore he al≈øo de≈øerued mo≈øte hygh pray≈øe with euery man. Ther was neuer a more profytable Emperour to the Romy≈øh kyngdome, ≈øence Augu≈øtus, then this Adrianus. He was excellently learned in a≈øtronomy, andAdrianus a „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ learned „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ per ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ coÃÑ
‚Ä¢ ing „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ tronomy compo≈øed euery yeare a prono≈øtication for hym≈øelf. Vnlearned readers of ≈øciences put he out of wages, howbeit he prouided of hys own co≈øte for theÃÑ, that they had no nede in the meane ≈øea≈øon: and ≈øet other learned and profitable meÃÑ to teache in their ≈øteade. He furni≈øhed al≈øo excellent libraries: for he was reakened to be very well learned in Greke and Latin.

In the tyme of Adrianus began the Iewes to re≈øtoreThe Iewes‚ñ™ ray≈øe an vproure through one Me≈ø≈øias. their kyngdom, fyndyng al≈øo out one Me≈ø≈øias among theÃÑ: But Adrianus ouercame them, though it was not without great bu≈øyne≈ø≈øe. Afterwarde commaunded he to repayre Ieru≈øalem, and called her Elia, after his name Elius.

At the fyr≈øt was he ≈øore again≈øt the Chri≈øtians,The clemency of Adrianus towarde Chri≈øten meÃÑ and commaunded to torment them: but afterward, when ≈øome learned Chri≈øten men wrote bokes to the Emperoure, the whiche are yet now adayes a brode, he chaunged his mynde, and commaunded that from thence foreward no man ≈øhould be attached for his religion.

The ≈øame gouerned the Empyre by good ryght with hys brother Lucius Verus: and the≈øe two wereLucius Verus. the fir≈øt that ruled the Empyre together. But Verus liued not loÃÑg in the gouernauÃÑce. Marcus was lyke excellent, both in vertue and learnynge. He had al≈øo warre in Germany, agayn≈øte them that dwelt in Morauia and Sle≈øia, and al≈øo again≈øt the Vandali. He wrote many excellent lawes, the whiche are yet to be red in the Pandectes of the ciuyll lawe. He wrote al≈øo whole bookes wherof we haue ≈øene ≈øome.

Moreouer in his tyme lyued Ptolomeus thePtolomeus th ‚Ä¢ a≈øtrono
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . a≈øtronomian, of whom we do worthely make mencion. For it hath plea≈øed God, that ≈øo excellent doctrines ≈øhould be kept and re≈øerued vntyll the≈øe our tymes, through this man. Nether truely was this Ptolomeus a kyng, (for at that tyme had Egypte cea ‚Ä¢ ≈øed of hauyng kynges,) but was a philo≈øopherEgypt was garn ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ hed ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ mathematicall ≈øciences. at Alexandria in Egypte. For God had garny≈øhed Egypte with mathematicall ≈øciences, ≈øence the tyme of Io≈øeph the ≈øonne of Iacob the patriarke, by whome Egypte had fyr≈øt receaued them, and kept them vntyll this Ptolomeus: and that is about twoo thou≈øande yeares. For fir≈øt Alexander, afterwarde the Romanes al≈øo had Egypte in greate e≈øtimacion for thys cau≈øe, and le≈øt ≈øo noble ≈øciences ≈øhould peri≈øhe, they be≈øtowed muche co≈øt to entertayne the Schole, whiche then finally wente tooThe Schole of Alexandria. nought al≈øo, whan the kyngdome of Egypte was tran≈ølated from the Romanes, and was my≈øerably
≈øpoyled by Mahomet. But that at the lea≈øt ≈øome remnaunt of ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary ≈øciences ≈øhould remayne, no doubt but God would them to be ≈øet in an order by this man, that they maye be kept of them that come after‚ñ™ for the whiche thyng God is greatly toThe Mahometi≈øtes. be thanked. But how litle they of Mahomets ≈øecte are worthy to be called men, ye that they may be rather called bea≈øtes than men, doth it appeare thereby, that they willed ≈øo auncient a ≈øcole to pery≈øhe & be lo≈øt, whiche had now≈øtande and flory≈øhed aboue two thou≈øand yeres, being kept by ≈øo noble princes, in the whiche were taught all maner of wy≈ødome and learnynge, not wythout the hygh benefite of God.

div.p:
ANtonius Ba≈ø≈øianus Caracalla the .xix.Antonius Ba≈ø≈øianus. Emperoure reygned ≈øyxe yeares. He commaunded hys brother Germane Geta to be ≈ølayne. He was wedded to his ≈øtepmother. He required of Papinianus the great lawier to excu≈øe the man≈ølaughter that he had done with hys brother, to the whiche Papinian aun≈øwered:

div.head: Of the Manicheis the heretykes.
div.p:
STrayghte waye after the Go≈øpell was preached, ro≈øe ≈øectes and di≈ø≈øen≈øyous among Chri≈øten men. But I am not minded to rehear≈øe y‚Ä¢ erronious opinions of euery one in this treati≈øe: I wyll only recyte the moo≈øt greate≈øt, which haue infect and troubled many and greate cityes and contryes wyth theyr ven ‚Ä¢ m: that the reader maye knowe, nothynge to beHeretykes are b ‚Ä¢ gyn
‚Ä¢ ers of vproure‚ñ™ more venimous in this commune lyfe of man, than fal≈øe doctrine: and that all heretikes are de≈øyrous of vproure, nether couet ought els, but that they maye defende and ≈øpreade abrode theyr erroure by vprour and commune ryot. For Sathan their chefe doer, is both a lyar and man≈ølayer. Ether of theÃÑ truely is euident in all ≈øci≈ømatickes, which both teache fal≈øe, and are wonte to ray≈øe man≈ølaughter through ≈øedy≈øyon and per ‚Ä¢ urbatyon of commune welthes.Manichei the heretikes Manes born in Per≈øia.

In the tyme of Aurelyanus beganne fyr≈øt the Manycheis, and one Manes borne in Per≈øya was begynner of them. Thys≈øame ≈øpred hys venim abrod largely, fyr≈øt by y‚Ä¢ Arabians, afterward in Africa: the which went ≈øo ≈øpedely on, that it coulde notThe doctrine of the Manicheis‚ñ™ be ≈øwaged the ≈øpace of two hundreth yeares afterwarde‚ñ™ The chefe of theyr doctryne was: that
ther were two goddes‚ñ™ the one good the other euel, and both lyke euerla≈øtynge. This doctrine ≈øemed vnto mans rea≈øon alowable. For ≈øeynge God is good by nature, and that in the meane ≈øea≈øon the euell hath ≈øuch power: it is nece≈ø≈øary there be al≈øo a peculiar God‚ñ™ which is author and doer of euels, equall to the other God wyth power and euerla≈øtyngne≈ø≈øe. Be≈øyde the≈øe had they other opinions that they taught, namely, that Chri≈øte was no true God: nether receaued they the bokes of the Apo≈øtles, but fayned there ≈øeuerall doctrines, the which they called Chri≈øtes Go≈øpel al≈øo: they boa≈øted al≈øo of ≈øeuerall illuminations of heauen, and ≈øayde they gaue the holy gho≈øt. They ordeyned ≈øundrye ceremonies: they v≈øed al≈øo choy≈øe of meates: they forbadde wedlocke‚ñ™ ≈øayenge that thereby is optayned the holy gho≈øt. They taught al≈øo to reiect ciuil power. For matrimony and gouernaunce of communwelth they ≈øayde to haue theyr of≈øpringe from the euell God, and not to be ordeined of the good God. Thomas Monetarius or mynter at ThuringenThomas Monetarius was playnly falleÃÑ into the ≈øame here≈øy in our daies.

div.head: The yeare of Chri≈øt .CC. lxxxviij.
div.p: DIocletianus the .xxxv. Emperoure raygnedDiocletianus. twenty yeare, He was a prince of rype wy≈øedome, and garni≈øhed wyth manye noble dedes. He re≈øtored Egypt to the Empyre. But he was a very fearce enemy to Chri≈øtes religion. For be endeuoured to re≈øtore the olde ≈øtate of the empyre and olde fa≈øhyon of the commune welth: And for as muche as he dyd all thynges by the iudgement of rea≈øon, he woulde not ≈øuffre the opinions of religion that were di≈øagreynge. And whan he perceaued that in ≈øo greate trouble of warres he coulde not entertayne alone the largene≈ø≈øe of ≈øo great an empyre: be≈øydes that, that it had oft fortuned, other to couet the empyre by vproure, and to ben made Emperours, he willingly willed MaximianusMaximianus. to raygne wyth hym, and to be of lyke power, and the ≈øame warred in Gallia.

As for the≈øe two were a lyke called Augu≈øti in the empire. The≈øe two Augu≈øti cho≈øe other two‚ñ™ which
were not egall of power, but were as ≈øucce≈ø≈øors: nether were they called Augu≈øti, but Ce≈øares. Diocletianus cho≈øe Galerius, Maximianus cho≈øe Con≈øtantius. But ether of them both Diocletianus and Maximianus were called Augu≈øtus. Afterwarde layenge aparte the gouernaunce of the empyre, they returned both to the quietne≈ø≈øe of a pryuate lyfe. But Maximianus woulde fayne haue returned to the gouernaunce, that by the≈øame occa≈øion, he myght haue promoted hys ≈øonne Maxentius to the gouernaunce: and for that cau≈øeMaxentius Con≈øtantius dyd Con≈øtancius hys brother in lawe cau≈øe hym to be ≈ølayn. Communely doth it ≈øo befal, that whan great empyres ≈øhall decaye, all ≈øhalbe fyr≈øte fylled wyth vproures and inwarde debates, the whyche thys example doth wytne≈ø≈øe. Diocletianus lyued manye yeares priuate or withoute rule: at the la≈øt dyd he ≈ølaye hym ≈øelfe, whan he was afearde for Licinius and Con≈øtantinus, whyche ≈øu≈øpected hym that he woulde take Maxentius theyr enemyes parte.

div.head: The yeare of Chri≈øt .CCC. viij.

Emperoure wyth greate pray≈øe. After Diocletianus death, raygned Con≈øtantius foure yeares. The contryes of Fraunce and Germany were ≈øubiect to hym, and he ≈øet them at quiet. div.head: The yeare of Chri≈øt .iij. C. xij.
div.p: COn≈øtantinus the .xxxvij. Emperoure raigned thyrty yeares. He re≈øtored the empyre to hisCoÃÑ≈øtantinus former re≈øt and tranquillitye. For whan Maxentius had cruelly v≈øed tyranny at Rome, beynge ouercome by Con≈øtantinus, he was in a flyghte drouned in the ryuer Tybur, and receaued worthy puni≈øhment for hys tyranny, the whyche he v≈øed both agayn≈øt other men, and ≈øpeciallye agayn≈øtMaxentius drowned in the Tybur. Chri≈øten men. And ≈øo dyd Con≈øtantinus and Licinius gouerne the empyre together certayne yeres wyth greate concorde, and Con≈øtantinus wedded hys ≈øy≈øter to Licinius. But we ≈øee ≈øomtyme to befall in a great empyre ≈øuch cau≈øes, wherin two dooThe cau≈øe of di≈øagrement betwen Con≈øtantinus & Licinius. ≈øeldom agree. It is ≈øaide, that the cau≈øe of the di≈øagremente betwene Con≈øtantinus and Licinius ≈øhoulde thence haue ≈øpronge that Licinius ≈øhoulde haue ben enemy to the Chri≈øtians, and to haue oft required Con≈øtantinus to enterpri≈øe ≈øuch thynges nomore.

Finallye Con≈øtantinus beynge compelled wyth great nece≈ø≈øitye ouercame Licinius: howbeit left him alyue, vpon this condicion, that he layenge awaye the rule of the empyre, ≈øhould lyue pryuately. Wherfore Con≈øtantinus gouerned the empyre afterwarde alone, and broughte all thynges into peace and hone≈øte lawes. The emperour was the fyr≈øt that openly knowledged the name of Chri≈øte.
Nether is it to be doubted, but that he was a trueThe e ‚Ä¢ de

He commaunded al≈øo bokes of the Bible to be written at his owne co≈øte, and cau≈øed them to be ≈øent into all contryes here and ther. He brought to pa≈ø≈øe, that the holy and profytable councell of Nicene was gathered, that ≈øo in hys tyme, he might ≈øet the ≈øtate of the churche in a quietne≈ø≈øe. The≈øe finally are actes worthye for a good prince, which de≈øerue a farre greater pray≈øe, than that it is ≈øayde he haue geuen to the bi≈øhop of Rome many gyftes. Although the good Emperoure is worthy to be pray≈øed for that, that he gaue alme≈ø≈øes & benefyces to mainteyn Euangelycall doctryne and mini≈øters of the churche. But that Con≈øtantinus ≈øhould haue be ≈øo liberall toward the by≈øhop of Rome, that he ≈øhoulde haue geuen hym for his v≈øe the citye of Rome, and the halfe part of the empyre, as ≈øome do fable: no hi≈øtoryes that be alowed do wytne≈ø≈øe the ≈øame.

Moreouer ≈øeing it is‚ñ™ no doubt that this prince is one, and that of the chefe≈øt of tho≈øe princes, which God hath garni≈øhed wyth great vertues, we ≈øhall worthely recyte the of≈øpringe of hys kynrede, that

Claudius the Emperour of mo≈øt commendable name, had two brethren, Quintilius and Cri≈øpus. Claudia the doughter of Cri≈øpus was wedded to the noble prince Eutropius. And the≈øe areThe aunceters of Con≈øtantinus. the of≈øpringe of Con≈øtantinus kynred.
