div.head: Of Arrius the heretyke.
div.p:
ARrius lyued in the tyme of Con≈øtantinus.Arrius an open reader in the ≈øcole of Alexandria. The doctrine of Arrius. He was an open reader in the ≈øcole of Alexandria in Egypte. The churches concorde was mi≈øerably ≈øpoiled wyth hys error and here≈øy: For he taught yt Chri≈øt was not truely and naturallye God. But what practy≈øe and vicious plea≈øauntne≈ø≈øe of per≈øua≈øyons he dyd v≈øe to confyrme this error, it were to longe to rehear≈øe. Howb ‚Ä¢ it it plea≈øed the world ≈øo wel, that great learned bi≈øhops, and neare hande the whole churche of the Ea≈øte, wyth manye al≈øo in the We≈øte
dyd embrace hym. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe in the meane ≈øea≈øon wyth≈øtode heauely this here≈øy two bi≈øhops of notable godlyne≈ø≈øe. The fyr≈øt was Alexander, whoAlexander & by≈øhop. optayned of Con≈øtantinus to gather the councell of Nicene, wherein was condemned the here≈øye of Arrius. Wherfore was Arrius for≈øaken and banni≈øhed out of the dominion. But whan Con≈øtantinus was deade, a certayne pre≈øte was in fauoure wyth Con≈øtantius, whom al≈øo he committed al his coun≈øels: the ≈øame broughte to pa≈ø≈øe wyth his per≈øua≈øyon by the Emperoure, that Arrius beyng called agayne, was ≈øett in hys former office. The fyre that was metely well quenched afore, began nowe agayne to burne more fearcely, in≈øomuche that the Emperoure Con≈øtancius beganne al≈øo to embraceCon≈øtancius „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Arrius. thys erroure of Arrius. Whan at the la≈øt a daye was appointed by Con≈øtantius, wherein Alexander and Arrius ≈øhoulde openly rea≈øon of the ≈øcrypture, concerninge this learninge, Alexander ≈øpent the whole nyghte in prayenge in the temple, prayenge God, that the ≈øecte of Arrius ≈øhould crepe no farther. Wherfore in the morninge before the appoynted houre of the di≈øputation, whan Arrius went to the place, he beganne (as he went) to haue payne in the bellye, and went to a preuye to do hysThe death of Arrius i ‚Ä¢ an ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ample of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . ea≈øement, where he aboue all mens e≈øtimacion, dyed incontinent. Howbeit whan Arrius was of this wy≈øe deade, yet cea≈øed not the ≈øede of his poy≈øoned doctrine to be ≈øowed larger abroade, becau≈øe that they that were con≈øpyred together of this ≈øecte, beganne to ≈øprede it more vehemently. At the la≈øte whan Alexander was deade al≈øo, Athana≈øius hys
≈øucce≈ø≈øor di≈øputed hym≈øelfe agayn≈øte the Arryans: but the ≈øame beynge bany≈øhede by Con≈øtantius, heAthana≈øius beynge banni≈øhed, flyeth to Triere out of Egypt. fled from Egypt, vntyl the citye Tryere in Germany. And though thys was a very farre flyghte, yet was the banny≈øhed man fayne to hyde hym≈øelfe ≈øecretly at Tryere vntyll the eyght yeare. In the meane ≈øea≈øon was that here≈øy fearcely growen thorough out in the Ea≈øt churche, euen ≈øo muche, that for a ≈øea≈øon a greate part of Chri≈øten men did leane to the Arrian ≈øecte, and out of thys ≈øecte ≈øprange by lytle and lytle, other ≈øectes many. Fynally whan the name of Arryans was by the decrees of many councels quenched, yet was it now and than renewed againe in the churche vnder other names. In one citye were ≈øundery opinions, and diuer≈øe ≈øectes per≈øecuted eche other, in≈øomuche that the one running vpon the other in theyr temples, made ryots and committed man ≈ølaughter. At that tyme was the ≈øtate of the church very wretched and pyteous, the which worthely gaue an occa≈øioÃÑ of ≈ølaunder, not only to the Gentyls, why they dyd not embrace the word of God: but dyd offende other al≈øo, that they went from the Chri≈øtianity to the Idolatry of the Heythen, among the which was al≈øo Iulianus the Emperoure. In the tyme of this ≈øo my≈øcheuousArrius was yc forerunner of Mahomet here≈øy, came vp finally Mahomet, to whoÃÑ by Arrius was as it were a window hand≈øomly opened: & was the forerunner of this mo≈øt cruel Antichri≈øt. For whan the myndes of men went a≈øtray in ≈øo great di≈ø≈øen≈øion of opinions, came Mahomet, & inuented very wy≈øely the thirde way, wherwith he ≈øhould heale the variete & diuer≈øyty of errours.
For he toke awaye all di≈øputacions, whiche thinge men dyd alowe. But hereof ≈øhall we ≈øpeake afterwarde. And let thys ≈øuffi≈øe to be rehear≈øed of the Arryans erroure and other lyke here≈øyes: of the whiche we haue here made mencyon therfore, that it may be ≈øene how greate dammages, man≈ølaughters, ≈øeditions & ryotous here≈øyes do brynge both to the commune welth, and to the churche.

div.head: The yeare of Chri≈øte .CCC. xli ‚Ä¢ .
div.p:
COn≈øtantynus the .xxxviij. Emperoure raygned.Con≈øtantinus. Thre bretherÃÑ raigned together. xxiiij. yeares. But the father had ≈øo ordeyned the empyre, that the thre bretheren ≈øhulde raigne together, Con≈øtantinus in Fraunce, Spayne and Germany: Con≈øtantius in the Ea≈øte, Con≈øtans in Italy and Illyrieus, But the yonger brother Con≈øtantinus, was not content wyth the dominion of his empyre, but woulde raygne alone, and wente into Italy agayn≈øte his brother Con≈øtans, tru≈øtynge to his puy≈ø≈øaunce, becau≈øe he had valyaunt ≈øouldyours. But God ≈øuffred not thys ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe longe vnpuni≈øhed: for thys Con≈øtantinus
was ≈ølayne not longe after.An example of vengeaunce.

And by this occa≈øion optained Con≈øtans y‚Ä¢ whole empyre of the We≈øt, the which he gouerned luckely. Moreouer had he a captayne called MagnentiusMagneÃÑtius an example of an vnkind vnfaithfull and di≈øloyal man. at Au≈øburch, who≈øe life he had once ≈øaued. The ≈øame ≈ølewe his mo≈øt gentle may≈øter, and made hym ≈øelfe Emperoure, and made a ≈øettyng forth of war vpon Con≈øtantius. Con≈øtantius made hys nepheu Gallus Emperoure of the Ea≈øte, and went wyth an army agayn≈øt the ≈øeditious captayne, and ouercame hym. The man≈ølaughter in thys ≈øtryfe was ≈øo great, that as it is redde, y‚Ä¢ power of the empyre was ≈øo abated, that many yeares after they coulde not come to theyr former ≈øtrength: becau≈øe the be≈øt and cho≈øen part of the people was ≈øo ≈ølayne, that the empire could not a great while re≈øi≈øt and with≈øtand the Barbarians. After that this man≈ølaughterMagnentius ≈ølayeth him≈øelfe. was done the moo≈øte my≈øcheuous man Magnentius ≈ølew him≈øelfe, and ≈øo puni≈øhed God the death of Con≈øtans the good prince.

But whan this Iulius was deade, was LyberyusLiberius by≈øhop of Rome Felix bi≈øhop of Rome a di≈ølembler. the .xxxv. made by≈øhop who (becau≈øe he wyth≈øtode the here≈øye of Arryus) was dryuen awaye by Con≈øtantius, and Felix was ordeyned in hys ≈øteade, who for feare of the Emperoure dy≈ø≈øembled the erroure of the Arryans. div.head: The yeare of Chri≈øt .CCC. lxv.
div.p:
IVlianus the Apo≈øtata or for≈øaker of his profe≈ø≈øionIulianus apo≈øtata. the .xxxix. Emperoure raygned two yeares. He was the nephew of Con≈øtantius & brother to Gallus, the which we haue ≈øpoken of before. He was of ≈øo greate learnyng, that beynge yong, he taught holy ≈øcripture openly in the church of Nicomedia: afterwarde goynge to Athenes, he learned philo≈øophy. But whan hys brother Gallus was ≈ølayn, Con≈øtantius ≈øent hym into Fraunce and Germany, and not farre from Stra≈øburch he vanquy≈øhed thyrty thou≈øande Almanes, for whych cau≈øe he was ≈øodenly by the fauoure of the ≈øouldyoursIulianus ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ Empe

made Emperoure at Stra≈øburch. Moreouer whan greate dy≈ø≈øen≈øyons were amonge the Chri≈øtyans, by rea≈øon of the varyetye of opinyons, for the whyche ≈øome di≈øpayred, ≈øome dyd wholy decyuer from the Chri≈øten fayth to the wor≈øhyppinge of Idols, Iulianus became an apo≈øtata al≈øo: for he was yet yonge, and v≈øed the company of Rhetoricyans and Phylo≈øophers, whiche di≈øputed of God after the vnder≈øtandynge or meanynge of mans rea≈øon. Yet dyd he not per≈øecute Chri≈øten men by open force, but he thought rather to de≈øtroye them by ≈øuttelltye. For openly he forbadde them to haue ≈øcoles, that they myght not be taughte: thynkynge (as it is in dede) that whan teachyuge were auoyded, the doctrine of relygyon ≈øhulde ea≈øely go to nought. He forbadde al≈øo, that Chri≈øten men ≈øhulde
haue no authoritye to v≈øe warrefaringe wyth theIulianus fo „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
badde Chri≈øten men the authoritie of warrfare. Romanes: that by no occa≈øyon they might come to the gouernaunce of the commune welth. He toke the goodes of the churches with laughter, ≈øayenge he dyd Chri≈øten men a plea≈øure, namely that they beynge become poore, might the≈øooner come to heuen, ≈øeynge the Go≈øpell promy≈øeth heauen to the poore. He dyd a≈ø≈øault the Chri≈øtian fayeth fearcely, euen with wrytinges al≈øo. Agayn≈øt tho≈øe hath Cyrillus the bi≈øhop of Alexandria written, who≈øe bokeCyrillus & Nazanzenu ‚Ä¢ haue an≈øwered Iulianus. is yet founde among the remembraunces or monimentes of Ihon Reuchlin in the toune Pfor≈øa in Germanye: not vnprofytable veryly to be redde. Gregorius Nazanzenus hath an≈øwered him al≈øo, but very ea≈øely: for he was not effectual ynough to put of tho≈øe reproches, which Iulianus v≈øed in confutinge the Go≈øpell. For he intreated moo≈øt chefe≈øt vpon that: ≈øeyng the Go≈øpel teacheth that man ought not to reuenge, that thereby is taken awaye and forbodden ciuill vengeaunce in iudgementes, and gouernaunce of commune welthes: wythoute the which mans e≈øtates can by no meanes endure. And this ≈øame fal≈øe accu≈øation doth he treate wyth many wordes, where as yet euerye Godlye ≈øtudyant of true godlyne≈ø≈øe doeth knowe that the ≈øameHow vengeaunce is forbodden. vengeaunce, whiche euery office v≈øeth, is not forbydden in the Go≈øpell: but only the for ‚Ä¢ yng of pryuate vengeaunce, which is done withoute officers authoritye. The≈øe ≈øuttyll forged and ≈ølaunderous reproches of Iulianus were very greueous to Chri≈øten men, in≈øomuche that they prayed openly again≈øt ≈øo perni≈øius ho≈øtilitie of the Go≈øpell.
And therfore whan he was gone into Per≈øya, he was ≈ølayne in a wylderne≈ø≈øe. It is wrytten thatThe death of Iulianus is an exampl „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ o ‚Ä¢ venge
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nce. whan he was wounded, and laye vpon the ground dyenge, he ≈øhulde haue taken hys hande fulle of bloude, and ca≈øtynge towarde heauen, to haue ≈øayde: Thou Galylean ha≈øt vanquy≈øhed at the la≈øte‚ñ™ Meanynge Chri≈øte, whome he called a Galylean. Therfore it is come by Iulyanus vngodlyne≈ø≈øe, that the Empyre is remoued and tran≈ølated from the moo≈øte noble ≈øtocke of Con≈øtantynus.

div.head: The yeare of Chri≈øte .CCC. lxvii
div.p: IOuinyanus the ‚ñ™xl. Emperoure raygned ≈øeuen monethes. It was a noble prince of godlyne≈ø≈øe.Io „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ nus a godly Emperoure. div.head: The yeare of Chri≈øte .CCC. lxviii
div.p:
VAlentynianus the .xli. Emperoure raygned twelue yeares. He ordeyned hys brother Valens a companion in the empyre. Valens ruled in the Ea≈øte, Valentinyanus went into the We≈øte, Ether of them was a Chri≈øtian. Valentinyanus had ben a captayne of the louldyours vnder Iulianus: but he for≈øoke him, becau≈øe he wolde notValentinianus ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ eth a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ then pre≈øt a blow. for≈øake ye integrity or ≈øoundne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øten religion: be≈øide al≈øo becau≈øe he had geuen a Heithen pre≈øt a blowe, by whom he was biddeÃÑ to do ≈øacrificy with
reachynge hym water of Idolatrye, whan he taryed for the commynge of Iulyanus. But God recompen≈øed hym afterwarde wyth the honoure where he came to, for the iniurye that Iulyanus dyd hym. He had greate warres in Germany he ≈øubdued the Saxons and Burgunnyons: ForBurgunnions be S ‚Ä¢ xo ‚Ä¢ s. they al≈øo are counted amonge the Saxons, whiche aboute that tyme went by the floude Rhe ‚Ä¢ e. And though they were vanquy≈øhed by Valentinian yet afterwarde recouerynge ≈øtrenghte, they pa≈ø≈øed the Rhene, and toke in the≈øe contryes, whych yet hetherto are called Burgundy. But of the≈øe ≈øhall we ≈øpeake hereafter.

But for thys vngodlyne≈ø≈øe was he puni≈øhed, whan he was ‚Ä¢ layne by the Gotthyes by Con≈øtantinople. For whan Valens beinge put to flyghteAn example of vengeaunce. gat hym into a lytle towne, the Gotthyes ≈øet it on fyre, and burnt hym. Whan Valens was deade, the Gotthyes dyd muche harme to them of Con≈øtantynople: but the quene Valens wedowe, geuynge them large mony refrayned them from the de≈øtructyon of it.
Whan Liberius was dead, Dama≈øus was made the xxxix. by≈øhoppe of Rome. By this man was S. Hierome in his youth lyke a notarye.S. Ierome was notarye to Dama≈øus

div.head: The yeare of Chri≈øte .CCC. lxxxiii.
div.p:
GRatyanus the xlii. Emperoure raygnedGratianus. after the deathe of Valens ≈øyxe yeares. This ≈øame was the elde≈øt ≈øonne of Valentynianus,

But ≈øeynge the empyre was here and there troubled by rea≈øon of many vproures, nether couldbe gouerned without ≈øome ≈øage and fortunable prince, he cho≈øe Theodo≈øyus for a companion in the empyre, and ≈øenteTheodo≈øius „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ercoÃÑ

Gratyanus was ≈ølayne by intrappe in Fraunce of hys gouernoure Maximus, who made hym≈øelfe Emperour by tyranny. Gratyanus was a prince excellente both in hone≈øtye and learnynge, and a true maynteyner of Chri≈øten relygyon: he ≈øent the knowledge of his fayth in wrytyng to. S. Ambro≈øe. Valentinianus hys brother was al≈øo ≈ølayne by a trayne of hys gouernoure Arboga≈øtes: but Theodo≈øyus gatheryng a greate army, ouerthrew
„Äà‚óä„Äâ & „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ tes „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ es of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ y both Maximus and Arboga≈øtes. Maximus beynge taken, was put to execucyon. Arboga≈øtes ≈ølew hym≈øelfe. Wherfore Theodo≈øius had the Empyre alone.

div.head: The yeare of Chri≈øte .CCC. lxxxviij.
div.p: THeodo≈øyus the xliij. Emperour raygned afterTheodo≈øius that Gratianus was ≈ølayn by Maximus xi. yeares. He was a ≈øpanyarde, and ≈øet all the Empyre in quyet, from Germany vntil Egipt. He was fyr≈øt in Germany, but beynge called into Thracya by Gracyanus, afterwarde was StyllicoStillico. ≈øent in to Germany by Theodo≈øyus, who compelled the Frankes and Saxons to kepe peace.

Be≈øides this re≈øtored he peace al≈øo to the church:The godlyne≈ø≈øe of Theodo≈øius towarde the churche. He gathered commune conuencyous, and willed the doctrine of relygyon to be publy≈øhed in all contryes. S. Ambro≈øe bewayled his death, & amonge other wordes he ≈øayeth: I loued the man whan he‚òú dyed: for he was more combred for the ≈øtate of the churches, than for hys owne daungers. To be combred ≈øo greatly wyth cares for the relygyon, that be verily true vertues worthy for goode princes.

div.head: Of Pelagius the heretike.
div.p:
IN the tyme of thys by≈øhop of Rome, onePelagius an heretyke in Britanne. Pelagius liued in Britanne. The ≈øame taughte, that we are not iu≈øtyfyed and ≈øaued by the mercy of God for Chri≈øtes ≈øake, wythout our de≈øeruynge: but by oure owne workes and naturall vertues, is true and ≈øounde ryghteou≈øne≈ø≈øe purcha≈øed by God, and remy≈ø≈øyon of≈øynnes optayned not by the fayth of Chri≈øte, but by oure workes and procuracyons. Agayn≈øteS. Augu≈øtin hath written again≈øt Pelagius‚ñ™ thys man hath. S. Augu≈øtine wrytten moo≈øt ≈øub≈øtancially, and hath bickered fearcely wyth this ≈øentence, and hath defended it agayn≈øt hym, that we are ≈øaued by fayth wythout oure de≈øeruynge, and that we optayne remy≈ø≈øyon of≈øynnes by the mercy of God only, yf we do tru≈øte to it. For yf remy≈ø≈øyon or forgeuene≈ø≈øe of ≈øynnes came by
oure workes, the con≈øcience ≈øhould neuer be in qu ‚Ä¢
er and a≈ø≈øured, but ≈øhould alwaye be in doubte: For mans endeuoure is to weake, than that God beynge di≈øplea≈øed, can be apea≈øed therewyth, and the drede of death taken awaye. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe God requyreth of vs obedience and good worckes and that the con≈øcyences be ≈øure, we doo plea≈øe God, that he wyll heare them that call vpon hym, and ≈øaue vs. Howbeit that thys doth not ≈øtande in the worthyne≈ø≈øe of oure worckes: but in the promy≈øe and mercy of God. Thys mynde of S. Augu≈øtyne whan it is knowen, doth brynge greate comfort to the con≈øciences of the godlye, and teacheth what the true fayth is, and that God in the meane ≈øea≈øon requireth good workes of vs. The ≈øame veryly doth he requyre of vs: but by fayeth onely wyll he haue vs to receaue the forgeuene≈ø≈øe of≈øynne, without regarde of oure de≈øeruynges. The doctryne of Pelagius is condempned in ≈øome councels of our tyme.

div.head: The yeare of Chri≈øt, CCC. x ‚Ä¢ viij.
div.p: ARcadius the ≈øonne of Theodo≈øius raignedArcadius. thyrtene yeare in the Ea≈øt at Con≈øtantinople. Honorius hys brother raygned in the We≈øte wyth lyke authoritie nyne and twenty yeares‚ñ™ Honorius. both whyle hys brother was alyue and whan he was deade: for whan Arcadius was deade, Honorius was yet alyue.

div.p: ABout thys tyme came the Gotthy fyr≈øte intoThe Gotthies‚ñ™ came fyr≈øt into Italy. Italy, wyth a greate and dredeful army. But for a≈ømuche as euerye where is made muche mencyon of the Gotthyes‚ñ™ we ≈øhall here ≈øummarely draw the hi≈øtories of theyr of ≈øpryng and actes.

The Gotthi, Vandali, Rugiani and Hunni be not e≈øtimed to be one people: but the Gotthi are Dutchmen out of the Ile Godtlande, which dwelt in a parte of Li≈ølande and Littowe: For ether of the≈øe contryes lyeth ouer again≈øt Godtland by the ≈øea≈øyde. And therefore doth Procopius call them aryght Cimme ‚Ä¢ ij and Gethe. The≈øe than in the time of the Romanes were gone into Thracia and Hungary, and the Romy≈øh Emperours a≈ø≈øayed to dryue them out agayne, but all was in vayne. In the rehear≈øall of Decius, haue we touched the begynnyng of their hi≈øtory: For the fyr≈øt great battail of the Romanes agayn≈øt them was vnder Decius, wherein al≈øo Decius was ≈ølayne. But afterwarde though the Romane Emperours made the Gotthies haue much ado: yet remayned they in Thracia and Hungary, and in, A≈øia about Con≈øtantynople they toke in certayn contryes. It is ≈øayde, thatGotthies in the halfe Ile Taurica. yet now adayes dwell Gotthy in the half Ile Taurica, which ≈øpeake Dutche, and call them≈øelus Gotthi. Howbeit they lefte Hungarye and al≈øo Thracia ≈øo at the la≈øte, that of theyr free wyll they
went fyr≈øt into Italy, and afterward into Spayn: Afterwarde were the re≈øt of the Gotthies de≈øtroyed by the Vandalyes and Hunmes commyng out of Scythya. The Hunny made theyr dwellinge place in Hungary. But the contryes that lye partly vnder, partly aboute Hungary, haue the Vandaly taken in.

But in the tyme of Arcadius and Honorius are the Gotthy come into Italy. The moo≈øte noble Emperoure Theodo≈øius ordeined to his ≈øonnesTheodo≈øius two capitaines Rufinus and Stillico, and wylled them to care for the Emperours yong ≈øonnes: but the one was di≈øloyal to hys lorde. Rufinus was of Gallia: the ≈øame enticed the Gotthies again≈øt Arcadius, and hoped to optayne the kyngdome by that meane: but he was fru≈øtrated of his purpo≈øe, for he was ≈ølaine by Stillico. As for Stillico was a Vandale:Stillico. and whan ≈øome of the Gotthi were come agayn≈øt Arcadius, Stillico broughte to pa≈ø≈øe, that the Gotthi which Theodo≈øius hadde taken in wages, were letten go. Be≈øide that did Stillico ≈øett the Vandalies again≈øt the Gotthies: and ≈øo whan the Gotthies were fyr≈øte angered thorough Rufinus, and than chafed by Stillico, their kinge Radaga≈øus brought two hundreth thou≈øand GotthiesRadaga≈øus. into Italy the ≈øame yeare that we haue ≈øpecified a fore. And as hi≈øtories do make mencion here, that at Rome wer great coÃÑplaintes again≈øt Chri≈øt. becau≈øe that ≈øo lamentable decaye of the empyre they ≈øuppo≈øed to come of the de≈øpi≈øynge of the goddes, and ≈ømall regarde of the wor≈øhyppe and honour of the former religion. As for Stillico vanqui≈øhed
and ouercame Radaga≈øus and hys hoo≈øt in the ≈øtraytes comminge from the citye Florence, goynge to Apenninum. This is the fyr≈øt hi≈øtory of the Gotthies in Italy.Alaricus.

After Radaga≈øus came another hoo≈øte of Gotthies into Italy, who≈øe captayne was Alaricus. With the ≈øame dyd Honorius agree, that he ≈øhould depart out of Italy, & go into Gallia, the whyche at that tyme was away≈øtynge of y‚Ä¢ Frankes, Burgundions & Vandales: in≈øomuche that Honorius mi≈øtru≈øted he could kepe Gallia no lenger: & therefore thought he to bringe to pa≈ø≈øe, that the Barbarians ≈øhuld ≈øtryue among theÃÑ≈øelues for it. But what happened? Whan Alaricus taketh his yourney vpon him, Stillico doth fall vpon him vnwarres, vpon Ea≈øter daye, whyle the truce did yet la≈øt. The next day after, doth he lykewi≈øe wyth an appointed army ouerthrowe and vanquy≈øhe Stillico, and being angry vpoÃÑ him, he be≈øyeged Rome. Honorius was at Rauenna, & cau≈øed Stillico to be putt to death, as one y‚Ä¢ had not done faithfully, & willed ye empyre to be taken froÃÑ Honorius & to be geuen ouer to him. Wherfore there was now no captayne mete to delyuer the citye of Rome from the ≈øyege. TherforeAlaricus wynneth Rome. dyd Alaricus take in Rome after two yeres ≈øyege: and that was about the xv. yeare of Honorius, the foure hundreth and twelft yeare of Chri≈øt, and the thou≈øand, hundreth and thre ≈øcore and fourth yere after the building of Rome.the .xij. rauens or rauenous bea≈øtes whiche Romulus ≈øawe.

That Var ro writeth of the xij. rauens, whiche Romulus ≈øawe, to ≈øignify, that Rome ≈øhould la≈øt a thou≈øand and two hundreth yeares, though thys
nombre of the yeares be not farre from this rekening: yet I ≈øuppo≈øe their interpretation rather toTotilas. pertayne to Totilas, who afterwarde in the tyme of Iu≈øtinianus dyd ≈øet Rome in fyre, & wholy ≈øpoyled it, and that was an hundreth and ≈øyxe and thyrty yeares after Alaricus. For Alaricus dyd not ≈øpoyle the citie, but rather gaue a commaundement that they ≈øhould be ≈øpared, whyche fled to the temples of the Chri≈øtians, Alaricus drue back agayne out of the citie and not longe after dyed. Whan heAtaulphus. was deade, Ataulphus was made kyng of the Gotthies: the ≈øame came agayne to Rome, and takynge to wyfe Placidia Honorius ≈øy≈øter, beynge pacified by her, he ≈øpared Rome, and wente into Fraunce, and afterwarde into Spayne: and of this wy≈øe did finally the Gotthies leaue Italye, and went into Spayne. For Alaricus had before inuaded y‚Ä¢ Spaniardes, & the Gotthies remaining in Spayne afterward, had ye dominion ther. The Vandali came into Spayne, & after that the Suein: but the Gotthies remaining ther, the Vandali came into Aphrica. Of the≈øe Gotthies are borne the Chri≈øteÃÑ kingesThe kynges of Spayne are ≈øprong of y‚Ä¢ Gotthies. in Spayne, of whom hath his of ≈øpringe the mo≈øt famous Emperoure that now is, Charles the fyft of y‚Ä¢ name. For though y‚Ä¢ Sarraceni inuaded Spaine afterward, & became mighty in it, yet could thei not de≈øtroy the re≈øidue of the other kinges of y‚Ä¢ linage.
The yeare of Chri≈øte .CCCC. lvi.

The yeare of Rome. M. CC. vij. came out of Aphrica to Rome Gen≈øerichus the Vandall, and ≈øpoiled the citye haynou≈øly. But what was y‚Ä¢ cau≈øeGen≈øerichus of Gen≈øerichus comminge, ≈øhall we ≈øhew, whan we
≈øhall haue occa≈øyon to treate of the Vandalies.

div.head: Dietrichus of Berna.Some call him Theodericus, ≈øome Titricus of ‚Ä¢ erona. Othacarus.
div.p:
THe Gotthies came nomore into Italy afterward, ≈øaue in the tyme of Zeno the Emperoure, whan Othacarus was become mighty at Rome. The ≈øame was a Barbarian, borne in Rugia, & was a ≈øouldiour vnder Augu≈øtulus, & being become pui≈ø≈øaunt by that meanes he v≈øed great tyranny at Rome: in≈øomuch ye the Romanes required ayde again≈øt him: Than was ≈øentDietrichus of Berna. by Leno into Italy Dietrichus ≈øurnamed of Berna. The ≈øame ≈ølayenge Othacarus, raigned two & thyrty yeares in Italy: he loued peace out of mea≈øure, and had mo≈øt de≈øerued to haue the fauoure of Italy, in≈øomuch, that as hi≈øtories do make mencioÃÑ, Italy neuer had a foren prince more frendelier and gentlyer. He gaue al≈øo much goodes to the churches v≈øe, to entertayne the mini≈øters of the word, & to mainteyne the doctrine of religion. But he was infect with the here≈øy of Arrius, as al≈øo the re≈øte ofThe Gotthies were Arrians. y‚Ä¢ Gotthies. For whan y‚Ä¢ Gotthies required of Valens ye Emperours pre≈øtes, of whom they might be in≈øtructed in yt Chri≈øten religion, he ≈øent them Arrian doctors. Howbeit y‚Ä¢ mo≈øt noble vertues of this Dietrichus de≈øerued tho≈øe prai≈øes, which coÃÑmonly are ≈øonge in tho≈øe dityes as are v≈øed now adayes. In theÃÑ is made mencion of giauntes, which ≈øignifieth the Barbarous, whoÃÑ Dietrichus hath vanqui≈øhed & ≈ølayne. He is ≈øurnamed of Berna, becau≈øe he was wonte to be muche at Verone wyth the court. Be≈øydes this man was al≈øo another Dietrichus
a Gotthian lykewy≈øe, by who≈øe valiauntne≈ø≈øe Attila was ≈ølayne, but he dyed in the ≈øame felde. HeAttila. was ≈øo great a man, that be≈øyde him, noman coulde lyghtely haue enterpry≈øed oughte again≈øt Attila. The ≈øame Dietrichus was not ≈øurnamed of Berna, but he was his co≈øyn. He was fyue and forty yeare before the tyme of Dietrichus of Berna.

div.p: HImel≈øuitha the doughter of Dietrichus of Berna had a ≈øonne called Adelrichus: the≈øame raygned eight yeres at Rome in Italy after the death of Dietrichus of Berna, and the mother ruled with great prai≈øe. Whan her ≈øonne was deade, ≈øhe delyuered the gouernaunce to her nephew Theodatus: but the ≈øame not remembrynge the benefyte that he had optayned, cau≈øed by a trayne her to be ≈ølayn, in the tyme of Iu≈øtinian the Emperoure. Dietrichus of Berna had mo doughtersAn example of di≈øtoyalty. be≈øydes this: he had al≈øo geuen hys ≈øy≈øters doughter in mariage to the kynge of Thuringen: whyche thynge I would not pa≈ø≈øeouer here, without the ≈øyngular pray≈øe and commendacyon of the princes of Thuringen.

THeodatus raigned ii. yeres, & was worthely puni≈øhed. For whan the moo≈øt hone≈øte queneTheodatus.
Himel≈øuith a had commended her≈øelfe and her ≈øoÃÑne to. Iu≈øtinian the Emperoure, Iu≈øtinian toke an occa≈øion to reuenge the murther, and ≈øent Belli≈øarius into Italy again≈øt the Gotthies. Now was Theodatus ≈øu≈øpected, becau≈øe he with≈øtode not Belli≈øarius, as though he would betray the Gotthies: theAn example of vengeauÃÑce Witichus. whiche Gotthies made Wittichus kyng, by who≈øe commaundement was Theodatus ≈ølayne.

VVitichus reigned thre yeares. Again≈øt hym warred Belli≈øarius with greate policy: For Wittichus had an appoynted army of more then twoo hundreth thou≈øand men. Belli≈øarius kept hym≈øelfe within the walles of Rome, whome Wittichus be≈øyeged a whole yeare, and there was a great derth, not onely at Rome, but al≈øo in al Italy. But as the Gotthies fled and ≈øtrayed here and there without order, by rea≈øon of the great derth. Belli≈øarius folowed vpon them and ouerthrue theÃÑ and enclo≈øyng in Wittichus by an intrap, toke him. But in y‚Ä¢ meane ≈øea≈øoÃÑ could not the Gotthies be vtterly weded out, but Iu≈øtinianus making peace wt them, graunted them to dwell in the contreis from the Alpes, vntyll the ryuer Padus, nether ≈øhoulde pa≈ø≈øe the≈øe bondes. He called Belli≈øarius back agayne: for he feared, le≈øt he being made Emperour, he ≈øhould take to hym the empyre of Italy: though Belli≈øarius tru≈øtyd in his affayres, went not about ≈øuche thynges. Wherfore beyng returned to Con≈øtantinople, he brought Wittichus and other of the greate≈øt nobilitie pry≈øoners with hym in a greate triumphe.

Totilas was made king of the Gotthies after the depar

div.head: The yeare of Chri≈øte .CCCC. lvi.
div.p: THyrdly by Totilas kyng of the Gotthies: and this oppre≈ø≈øion of the citie was the mo≈øte heuie≈øt of all. For ≈øhe was both taken and burnt the .xxi. yeare of Iu≈øtinianus: the yeare after the buyldyng of her a thou≈øand, and thre hundreth.
The yeare of Chri≈øt .CCCCC. xlviij.
Fourthly, the third yeare after this de≈øtruction.
The yeare of Chri≈øte .CCCCC. li.

After this ≈øpoylyng beganne Totilas to re≈øtore agayne the citie of Rome, and ≈øuffered the cyte≈øens to returne agayne into her. But what fauoure he ≈øhewed, and how gently he behaued hym≈øelfe, wytne≈ø≈øe the wordes that are written concernyng hys frendlyne≈ø≈øe, that he bare ≈øuche an affection toward his ≈øubiects, and ≈øpecially the Romanes, as becommeth a father to haue toward his chyldren: and it is ≈øayde that Totilas learned by ≈øaynt Benets doctrineTotilas was „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ h ‚Ä¢ of S. „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ e ‚Ä¢ . and admonition to beare rule of that ≈øorte.

Afterwarde ≈øent Iu≈øtinianus a prince of ≈øyngulare wy≈ødom, called Nar≈øes, into Italy again≈øt Totilas. The ≈øame called the Lombardes to ayde him.Nar≈øes. The ≈øame were Saxons, whiche with appoynted armies had brought them≈øelues to the coa≈øtes of
Au≈øtria: the ≈øame brought Nar≈øes into Italy, and by their ayde ouercame he Totilas, and after ward Teia, whiche was the la≈øt kyng of the Gotthies inTeia. Italy. And this is the ende of the Gotthies kyngdome by the Italians, whiche had la≈øt ≈øence Dietrichus of Berna vntyll Teia thre ≈øcore yeares. That Dietrichus, Totila and Teia were both very wy≈øe and doughty princes, te≈øtifye their dedes and noble actes, in≈øomuche that if ye wyl e≈øteme them by their vertues, they ought not to be called Barbarians. When the Gotthies were ouercome the power and ryche≈ø≈øe of the Lombardes beganne to growe, and gatte one of the kyngdomes of Italy: howbeit they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed not whole Italy, but onely that part of Italy that yet is called Lombardy. The kyngdomeLombardy. of Lombardy la≈øted vntyll the tyme of Carolus magnus. Though the Gotthies were dryuen out of Italy, yet were they myghty in Spayne, and ruled there vntyll this oure tyme. And of this wy≈øe wasWheÃÑ Spain and parte of FrauÃÑce was traÃÑ≈ølated froÃÑ the empyre. at the la≈øt Spayne and part of Fraunce tran≈ølated from the empyre of Rome vnder Homorius. As for Italy was re≈øtored to his tranquilitie while Honorius lyued yet. For the Gotthies drue partly into Lombardy, partly into Spayne: be≈øyde this were the Frankes myghty in Fraunce.
After Innocentius was So≈øimus made the xliiij. by≈øhop of Rome.
Bonifacius the fir≈øt of that name and xlv. by≈øhop of Rome ≈øucceded So≈øimus.
After Bonifacius death was Cele≈øtinus the fir≈øt of the name made by≈øhop of Rome.

div.head: The yere of Chri≈øte .CCCC. xxvij.
div.p: THeodo≈øius the yonger the ≈øonne of ArcadiusTheodo≈øius the younger. the .xlv. Emperoure reigned at Con≈øtantinople ≈øeuen and twenty yeares after the death of Honorius. He made Valentinian the ≈øonne of Con≈øtantius and Placidia, whiche was the daughter of Theodo≈øius, fellow in the Ea≈øte empyre.

div.head: Of the Vandalies.
div.p:
IN the tyme of this Theodo≈øius the yereWhan the Vandali ca
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ into Aphrica. of Chri≈øt, CCCC. xxxiij. came the VaÃÑdali into Aphrica by this occa≈øion. Thos two capitaines of the Romanes hated eche other, and fought other whiles with playn fielddes. Wherfore the one, called bonifati ‚Ä¢ s, entyced bu≈øely the Vandalies that were in Spayne at that tyme to come into Aphrica, which thyng they did gladly. For the Gotthi beyng myghty in Spayne, coulde not ≈øuffre the VaÃÑdalies. For (as we ≈øhewed before) the Vandalies moued by Stillico again≈øt the Gotthies, toke in the contreis that be about Hungary, namely Walachia & Illyricus, where the Gotthies dwelt afore. Be≈øyde that were they al≈øo in Germany, from whence as they went into FrauÃÑce, they did much hurte: howbeit they were driuen out of FrauÃÑ ce by the Frankes and Gotthies. Afterward beyng come into Spayne, they vere con≈øtrayned to fyght agayne with the Gotthies: but in Aphrica beganne the power of the Vandalies to growe and encrea≈øe S. Augu≈øtine al≈øo died about that time, when Gen≈øerichus
‚Ä¢ . Augu≈øtin kyng of the Vandalies be≈øieged the towne Hippo, wherein. S. Augu≈øtine was by≈øhop.Hippo.

When Valentintanus was dead, one Maximus
made hym≈øelfe Emperoure at Rome of his owne mynde. But the quene E ‚Ä¢ doxia, becau≈øe ≈øhe would haue the heires that were left to ≈øuccede in the empyre, ≈øought ayde by Gen≈øerichus again≈øte Maximus, by who≈øe helpe the citie of Rome was taken & ≈øpoyled. But the Vandall v≈øed a Vandalians faithfulne≈ø≈øeA VandaliaÃÑ faythfulne≈ø≈øe and ≈øtedfa≈øtne≈ø≈øe with the quene: for he lede her, with her two daughters away with hym intoAn example of dy≈øtopa ‚Ä¢ te Aphrica pry≈øoner. For ≈øo doth it ≈øomtyme befall, when we call foren ayde to defende oure goodes. Howbeit afterwarde vnder Iu≈øtinianus, though the Vandalies were not vtterly roted out in Aphrica: yet were they brought to ≈øuche ≈øtrayghtne≈ø≈øe, that they could neuer flory≈øhe any more. For Gelimerus the kyng was taken by Belli≈øarius, & Aphrica beyng ≈øubdued, obeyed the Empyre agayne. But not loÃÑg after began the Saracens to haue dominioÃÑ in Aphrica. Let this ≈øuffi≈øe to ≈øpeke of the VaÃÑdalies

div.head: Of the Boemes.
div.p:
IT is al≈øo to be noted, that about this timeWhan y‚Ä¢ VaÃÑ dali came fir≈øt into Germany. came fyr≈øt of all in Germany the Vandali, wherein they haue yet a great part nowe a dayes, namely the kyngdom of Boeme, whiche was in tymes pa≈øt part of Germany: whichThe Boemes are Germanes. the word Boeme, which is a Germane worde doth te≈øtifie ≈øufficiently, whiche was before the Vandali came into the≈øe countreis. The worde hath his ≈øygnificacion of the Bauaries or Beyers, to whoÃÑ it was wont to be ≈øubiect, wherfore it is properly called Boienheim. Nether wyll the Vandali of Boeme be called Boemes, but ze≈øki, after their capitayne, by
who≈øe guyde they were fyr≈øt brought into Boeme. But the≈øe auncient Boemes, the Germanes, were in greate admiracion and confederacion with the Romanes, and by Cornelius Tacitus the hi≈øtory writer they are highly prai≈øed. By this occa≈øioÃÑ al≈øo is Germany tran≈ølated from the Roman empyresGermany is „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ froÃÑ
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . monarchy. For in low Germany were the Frankes puy≈ø≈øaunt, in hygh Germany Alemanni, and in Boeme the Vandali. But what is happened to Boeme afterward, and whan it was ≈øubdued again by the Germane Emperoures, that ≈øhall we ≈øhewe in the hi≈øtories of the Emperours: for there ≈øhall we ≈øhew ≈øome other thynges of the chaunge of the thynges of Germany.

div.head: The yere of Chri≈øt .CCCC. liiij.
div.p:
VVhen Theodo≈øius the younger was deade,
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . reigned Valentimanus the .xlvi. Emperour in the We≈øte, fyue yeares, and whyle Theodo≈øius liued, reigned he fyue and twenty yeres. But after Theodo≈øius death was the .xlvii. Emperour in the Ea≈øte Martianus. In his tyme was the horrible ≈øettyng forth of Attila.

div.head: Of Attila.
div.p:
FIr≈øt of all came into Hungarye the Gotthies afterward the Vandali, la≈øt of al the HuÃÑni, and the≈øe la≈øt kept the lande, of whoÃÑ it is called Hungary. This cruell peopleThe callyng of Hungary. ‚Ä¢ in dedes of Attila. dyd mo≈øte mi≈øchefe nerehand to all Europa. Attila brought an army of three hundreth thou≈øande into Germany, and toke in many myghty cities, among the whiche was Ba≈øil, Au≈øborowe, Stra≈øborowe,
Wormes, Coelen, and many other cities. Goynge forth from thence into FrauÃÑce, toke the kyng of the Bourgunyons, he be≈øieged the citie Aureola, and entended to v≈øurpe the dominion of whole Europa

At that tyme was in the hether part of Fraunce whiche the Romane Emperours kept, a Romane captaine, called Aetius: the ≈øame made a confederacionAetius. with the Frankes and Gotthies, that with lyke hande they ≈øhould re≈øi≈øte the mo≈øte cruell tyrauÃÑt. But Attila, becau≈øe he was afrayed for the power of the Gotthies he procured by Dietrichus theyr kyng, that they ≈øhould not ayde the Romanes: but after their ≈øingular con≈øtance refu≈øed the Gotthies al maner of frend≈øhyp or allegeaunce with the Barbarous tyraunt. Wherefore both ho≈øtes met at Tolou≈øeThe battaill with Attila by Tolou≈øe. in Fraunce: on the Romane ≈øyde Aetius, the Gotthi and Frankes, and of the other ≈øyde Attila. And hi≈øtories make mencion, that in the We≈øt came neuer ≈øo great an hoo≈øt and multitude together, as at that tyme. The battaill la≈øted from the Sunne ry≈øyng, vntyll nyght. At the la≈øt Attila beyng driueÃÑ to the flyght, lo≈øt a hundreth and foure ≈øcore thou≈øand men: he him≈øelfe al≈øo was driuen to ≈øuch ≈øtraitne≈ø≈øe, that he had nearehande ≈ølayne hym≈øelfe. And though Aetius, the Frankes and the Gotthies had the victory, yet dyed Dietrichus kyng of the Gotthies in that battayll. The ≈øonne would haue reueÃÑ ged the fathers death, and entended to gather an army, and per≈øue Attila, and to de≈øtroie the re≈øydue of his hoo≈øt: and would vndoubtedly haue done it had he not chaunged his mynde through the coun≈øaill of Aetius. But that coun≈øaill of Aetius was
nought, for Attila myght at that tyme haue bene ouer come with a ≈ømall army. But afterward beyng returned into Hungary, re≈øtoring his ho≈øt, & recoueryng ≈øtrength, he inuaded Italy, taking in the cities from the fir≈øt entry of Italy, vntyl the mouÃÑtayn Appenninus. Then Leo the by≈øhop of Rome metyng hym, knelyng be≈øought hym, that he would go back again. It is reported y‚Ä¢ Attila ≈øhuld haue ≈øaid, he ≈øaw the image of a man ≈øtanding by the by≈øhop, threatening him with a drawen ≈øworde, & he being afraied, promi≈øed to go backe again. WheÃÑ he was come again

Stillico Aetius & afterward Belli≈øarius were mo≈øt excelleÃÑt captaines. Nether were in the empyre any els, which re≈øeÃÑbled the vertues and ≈øtrength of the auncient Romanes

After ValeÃÑtinianus was the empire of Rome nere hand toren in peaces, & many called theÃÑ Emperours in Italy. Yet in ye meane ≈øea≈øon remained y‚Ä¢ mai≈øtie of an Emperours name by them of CoÃÑ≈øtantinople, & afterwarde re≈øtored Iu≈øtinianus the We≈øt empyre by Belli≈øarius & Nar≈øes. But after that ValeÃÑtinianus was deade, many were called Emperours at once, & within .xx. yeres had Italy .ix. Emperours, whiche reigned by a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, & the one was ≈ølayn of the other by occa≈øion. The la≈øt was called Augu≈øtulusAugu≈øtulus. (that is, litle noble or litle ful of maie≈øty.) The diminution of the name, was an euidence that the gouernauÃÑce of the Augu≈øtus‚ñ™ ≈øhould fayle in Italy: for with this Augu≈øtulus failed finally the empyre. Othacarus droue out the ≈øame Augu≈øtulus, agaiÃÑ≈øt whom was Dietrichus of Berna≈øent into Italy, in the tyme of zeno the Emperoure. Wherefore was the empire of Italy tran≈ølated to the Gotthi, which afterward were ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed vnder Iu≈øtinianus, as we haue ≈øayde before.

div.p:

Belli≈øarius ouercame y‚Ä¢ Per≈øes, & ≈øaued Syria, & re≈øtored Aphrica to ye empire: be≈øide y‚Ä¢ had he al≈øo great victories in Italy again≈øt the Gotthies, who≈øe power was afterwarde vtterly brought to nought by Nar≈øes. When euery where was peace made, Iu≈øtinianus cau≈øed al≈øo the auncient lawes of the Romans to be gathered in bookes called Dige≈øta, that is, bokes appoynted in order: but the ≈øame bookes were darkened not long after Iu≈øtinianus, through lawes of the Lombardes and Frankes: neuerthele≈ø≈øe after a good ≈øea≈øon, were they brought too lyght agayne by. Howbeit, it were to long to reher≈øe here how greatly this wy≈ødome is to bee pray≈øed in the Emperoure, who wylled that iu≈øtice and the≈øe lawes to be commonly executed, as by the iudgement of all ≈øage and good men can nothynge be more hone≈øt, holy and more profitable.

div.head: Of Belli≈øarius.
div.p:
I can not worthely ouerpa≈ø≈øe that of Belil≈øarius, which he hath handled mo≈øt faithfully in all thynges: he was a peace and concorde maker in all the worlde. He dyd wholy re≈øtore the empire of Rome, that was nearehand decaied and altogether weakened: to be ≈øhort, he ≈øhewed hys lorde and all the worlde ≈øuche plea≈øure,‚òú that none coulde be greater nor more pray≈øe worthy: and if they were e≈øtymed aryght, they are hygh and incredible gyftes of God. But what thaÃÑ kes the worlde geueth agayn for ≈øo great vertues, and ≈øuche g ‚Ä¢ ≈øtes of God, that doth the example ofBelli≈øarius was very Belli≈øarius declare ≈øufficiently: whom Iu≈øtinianus
of a very lyght ≈øu≈øpicion without cau≈øe, cau≈øed to put out his eye ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , and droue him away, that he ≈øhuld be fayne to ≈øeke his meate with beggyng: at the la≈øt dyed he lyke a mo≈øte wretched begger. Of this wy≈øeThe ende

div.p:
MAhomet auaunted hym≈øelfe a prophet & al≈øo a king in Arabia, by the AgareniesMahomet „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ

warres, they receyued wages vnder Heraclius. And whan it was ≈øhewed them by ye Emperoures captaynes, they lokynge for no more wages, ray≈øed an vproure agayn≈øt the Romane captayns. By rea≈øon of thys commune vproure beganne Mahomets power to encrea≈øe. For ≈øeynge the commune people coulde want no captayne, they dyd lyghtely ≈øtycke to Mahomett, who pa≈ø≈øed all other for his greate ryches, and other ≈øyngular vertues. But that he myghte the more ea≈øely bryng the peoples maners into ≈øome certayne order, he purpo≈øed to make lawes, not only in ciuill matters, but al≈øo to bind the mindes of the coÃÑmune people to a certaine and new forme of religion, that he might the better kepe them all in their duety, nother might ry≈øe any occa≈øion of di≈ø≈øcucion. For he ≈øawe that euery wher were ≈øondry & di≈øagreing mindes of the doctryn of religion. For ye concord of the Churches was ≈øpoyled
by ≈øundery here≈øyes, and chefely wyth the wicked learning of Arrius. But whan the con≈øciences are tangled wyth errour, and the myndes wauer, than do they lightely ≈øu≈øpect the doctrine of Chri≈øt, and be in ≈øhorte ≈øpace dryuen hether and thether. Wherfore as mens myndes were thus relyng andThe fourme of Mahomets religioÃÑ. vncertayn, Mahomet hauyng gotten oportunitie, pre≈øcribed ≈øuche a forme of religion, wherein tho≈øe heade chapters of the fayeth, that ≈øpake of Chri≈øte were pa≈øt ouer, and that therefore, le≈øt the doctrine of the fayth ≈øhould more be broughte into doutfull di≈øputatyons: but re≈øtynge only in the vnder≈øtandyng or capacyte of rea≈øon, myghte commaunde of courte≈øye of maners, and maner to lyue hone≈øtlye. Thys truely is acceptable to mens nature. Therfore embraced thys doctryne the Gentyls, Iewes, Arrians and ≈øuch as were deciuered from the Chri≈øten religion. For thys fayth ≈øemed to be alowable to euery man: Wherfore men of vnlyke kynred, vnlyke language‚ñ™ the one liuynge otherwy≈øe than the other, it is vnpo≈ø≈øyble to ≈øaye how ea≈øely they grew and increa≈øed in myght to re≈øy≈øt the Romanes valiauntly. For fir≈øt began they to ≈øubdue Arabia andMahomet ≈øubdueth fyr≈øt Arabia. part of Syria. For Dama≈øcus was Mahomets courte. Afterwarde became they myghty in Egipt al≈øo. Let thys ≈øuffy≈øe brefely ≈øpoken of the begynnyng of ye dredefull kyngdome of Mahomet, wherin raygned fyr≈øt the Arabians & Egypcians, which called them Sultan or Souldan, that is, prince:Sultan or Souldan. afterward was the empyre brought to ye Turkes. As for ye kingdome is ye greate≈øt part of Antichri≈øt, & in the Prophetes are ye mo≈øt certayne prophecies
of it, wherein voe are earne≈øtlye warned of GodThe place in Daniel of Maho ‚Ä¢ et. to e≈øchue thys pe≈øtylence. In Danyell is he paynted of thys wy≈øe: In that terryble bea≈øte, whyche is the figure of the Romy≈øhe empyre, doth growe a horne, throughe who≈øe power are thre hornes pulled out, and hath eyes, and ≈øpeaketh dredefull bla≈øphemyes agayn≈øt God. Thys horne is Mahomet: the eyes and dredeful bla≈øphemies again≈øt God is the Alco ‚Ä¢ an and doctryne of Mahomette, whiche ≈øpred farther, than the dominio ‚Ä¢ was. For neare hand all the Ea≈øt quarter is infect wyth that de ‚Ä¢ ely≈øhe doctryne. The thre hornes ‚Ä¢ ignifye the ‚Ä¢ hre kyngdomes Arabia, Sirya and Egy ‚Ä¢ t which Mahome ‚Ä¢ e had taken in. All tho≈øe thinges ≈øhewed God before, that we beyng aduerti≈øed ≈øhould not be offended at thys tyme. The po≈øteritye of Mahomet, not beynge content wyth the boundes of hys kyngdomes, ≈øt ‚Ä¢ oue al≈øo wyth the Emperours of Con≈øtantinople, for the kingdome of A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a.

div.head: Of the ‚Ä¢ urkes begynnyng.
div.p:
THE cau≈øe of the comming of the TurkesThe Turkes were Tartares. out of Tartary into A≈øia was, that whan the Saracens warred again≈øt y‚Ä¢ Per≈øes, the Per≈øes required ayde of the Turkes. div.p: LOn≈øtantinus Leo the fourth ≈øonne the lxxi. Emperoure raygned wyth hys mother Irene ten yeares.

She was of Athens, and ruled moo≈øt ≈øagely, aboue
the vnder≈øtandyng of woman kynne, and wyth the alowance of euery man. After her, raygned her ≈øon fyue yeares, ≈øhe beynge put from the gouernaunce. But they of Con≈øtantinople not ≈øufferyng hys wickedne≈ø≈øe, called the mother agayne from the aexile, whych raygned after warde thre yeare. Of thys wy≈øe were Irene and Con≈øtantinus gouernynge the empyre together xviij. yeares, vntyll the yeare of Chri≈øt .viij. C. and i.

But though the Chri≈øten Emperours were allwaye at Con≈øtantinople, whiche called them≈øelues Emperours of Rome al≈øo, vntyll at the la≈øt, the citie was taken in of the Turkes: yet in ye meane ≈øea≈øon whan the power of the empyre began ≈øo to faid, that the Emperours were notable to defende nother theyr tytle, nor Italy, the Romanes were con≈øtrayned to ≈øeke ayde at the Frankes, who≈øe power was than the greate≈øt. Wherefore came the maie≈øtie of the Emperours name to Carolus. And becau≈øe oure Emperours haue alwaye maynteyned and defended Italy wyth ≈øtronge hande, we wyll aduy≈øedly pa≈ø≈øe ouer here the Greke Emperours, (for ≈øome were tangled with want on plea≈øure, effeminate, and wholy vnapt to haue gouernaunce,) & recite orderly our Emperours, which are worthy to be coÃÑmeÃÑded for their notable vertues & prowe≈ø≈øes. div.p:
CArolus magnus was crowned EmperourCarolus magnus. The begynnyng of the tran≈ølatyng the empyre to the Germanes. of Leo the iij. the very Chri≈øtma≈ø≈øe daye. Thys was the begynnynge of tran≈ølatinge the empyre to the Germanes, and by this tran≈ølatynge happened vnto Italy and the Be≈øt kyngdome a moo≈øt mightye heade, and a moo≈øt ≈øure fortre≈ø≈øe. For though the Emperours of Germany were not alway of lyke power, as in no kyngdome the kynges were alwaye of lyke power or lyke fortunate: yet in prowe≈ø≈øe were they ≈øuch ≈øomtyme, that they dyd rydde Italy out of daungers, and pre≈øerued not onely in the We≈øte quietne≈ø≈øe in the commune welth: but al≈øo kept the Chri≈øten religion ≈øound in the churche. And if ye wyll ponder the feates dedes, and maners of oure Emperours, ye ≈øhall iudge them to haue ben excellent wy≈øe princes, and not barbarous, and in nothing to be e≈øtimed le≈ø≈øe, than tho≈øe excellentand allowable Emperours Augu≈øtus, Traianus, Adrianus and Con≈øtantinus: yee yf ye do adui≈øedly ponder all thynges, ye ≈øhall ≈øaye, that ther hath bene more hone≈øtye and mode≈øtye in oure Emperours, than in them. Thys ≈øhall ye fynde al≈øo, that ours haue enterpry≈øed no warre of any ambicion or priuate
profyte: but only of nece≈ø≈øitie, to mayntayne religion, to defende the liberty of the empyre and the ≈øauegarde of the ≈øubiectes.

As for me, beynge certayne of myne owne vnablene≈ø≈øe, though I can not iudge nor ≈øpeake of the vertues of greate men acrording to theyr worthyne≈ø≈øe: yt is my mynde to prai≈øe ≈øome princes aboue the other. For I iudge it to be pertaynynge to the duety of euery hi≈øtory wryter, that he do nowe and than turne a≈øyde into the rehear≈øall of the mo≈øt be≈øt vertues, and ≈øhewe them to the reader for a ≈øhewe as an example to folow. Now in mens a≈ø≈øaires can nothinge ‚Ä¢ e more hone≈øte nor more plea≈øaunt, than the con≈øyderacion and knowledge of princely vertues in great men. Wherfore I woulde oure Germane Emperours were ≈øo ≈øet before the eyes of our Germanes, that they myght know theyr vertues, and wonder at them: wonder it is how greatly the ≈øame wolde helpe and further to the amendement, and al≈øo ray≈øe a flame in the hartes of good men to folowe. In my iudgement are the≈øe princes doutele≈ø≈øe ≈øuche, whyche be worthy farre to be preferred before the auncient Romanes, whether ye wyll regarde wy≈øedome, or ≈øtrength, or finally the endeuour of hone≈øty and mode≈øtye.

div.head: Of Germany, and occa≈øyon of the kyngdome of the Frankes.
div.p: ALl Germany was not ≈øubiecte to the empyre, but had onely tho≈øe contryes, that are betwene the Rene and the Danow. And much worke had the Emperoures, before oure nacion could be ≈øubdued and kept.

For in the tyme of Augu≈øtus had Dru≈øus warresBy whom Germany was vexed wyth warres, ≈øence the tyme of Augu≈øtus. and Germanicus, afterwarde Caius, and after him Vitellius, Domitianus. Traianus had ≈øubdued the lower Germany vntyll Moganus. Maximinus was come vntyll Schwartzwald. Valerianus was wyth an hoo≈øt in hygh Germany.
After hym vnder Galienus the Frankes beynge ≈øett in a commotion, began to ry≈øe: but by the Emperoures folowynge, were theyr violences ≈øometyme a≈ø≈øuaged. For Aurelianus vanquy≈øhed them by Mayntz. Probus had many and noble victoryes in lowe Germany. Con≈øtantinus buylded the citye Spyre. Iulianus, Valentinianus and Theodo≈øius dyd lykewy≈øe ≈øubdue the Alemans & Frankes, and the contries that lye by the Rhene, and toke in Schwaben land al≈øo.

But after that the power of the Frankes and Alemans begonne to encrea≈øe, the Emperours returnedThe of≈øpringe of y‚Ä¢ Frankes not into Germany. Some fable diuer≈øly of the fyr≈øt begynnynge of the Frankes: but it is certayne, that they were hyghe Germanes in Augu≈øtus tyme. For we haue no certaynty of the Germanes e≈øtate out of hi≈øtories before Augu≈øtus. But that the Frankes were in ≈øuche e≈øtimacion by the hygh Germanes, that it can ea≈øely be proued out of Strabo, who wrote an hi≈øtory in the tyme of Augu≈øte, and warrefared wyth the Romanes. As for Strabo ≈øayeth that the Frankes were ioynyng to the Vindelici, that is, Bayerlanders, vpon the which they border partly at thys tyme al≈øo. TheThe dedes of the Frankes, and by what occa≈øion they de
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ iuered froÃÑ the empyre. commotion of the Frankes beganne by thys occa≈øyon: In the tyme of Galianus the Emperoure, was Po≈øthumus captayne in Germany: the ≈øame was made Emperoure by the people for hys ≈øyngular hone≈øtye, and vertues in gouernynge the empyre, Galienus in the meane ≈øea≈øon lyued in ydelne≈ø≈øe and plea≈øure at Rome. But whan Galienus hearde that Po≈øthumus was made Emperoure,
he ≈øent again≈øt hym an apointed army. Po≈øthumus likewy≈øe commaunded his men to be in a readine≈ø≈øe among the whiche were euen the Frankes the principall. And though Po≈øthumus was afterwarde ≈ølayne priuely by an intrap, yet the Frankes once prouoked to weapons, remayned alway in the ≈øettyng forth to warre, and came downe from Moganus to the Rene, and ouer the Rene toke they fir≈øt the citie Trier from the Romanes, and afterwards went into fraunce. But after that they had foughteÃÑ again≈øt Attila with the Romanes, they were alway in great fauour wyth the Emperours, in ≈øo muche‚ñ™ that Iu≈øtinianus the Emperoure through a conuenaunt made with the Frankes, ≈øuffred them to haue and inhabite that parte of Gallia, whiche at this tymeFrancia or Fraunce ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ part of Gallia. is yet called Francia or Fraunce. Wherefore the Frankes toke in both the contreis of the Ryne, and parte of Fraunce and both the contreis were maynteined by one common kyngly gouernaunce. The hi≈øtories make euery where mencion of great pray≈øes of the Frankes, partely for their goodly polycy and pro≈øperitie in gouernyng their kyngdome, but ≈øpecially becau≈øe they embraced the Chri≈øten religioÃÑ in the begynnyg of the kyngdome, and wylled it to be publy≈øhed and ≈øpred abrode. In the meane tymeBy what orca≈øion the Almanes decyuered from the emppre. dyd the Alemans decyuer from the Romy≈øhe empyre al≈øo. The Alemans were the hygh Germanes, whiche now are called Schwaben, Schweitzer & Baier. Therefore when the Romane Monarchy was ≈øundered, then was Germany fir≈øt deuyded inGermani is deuided in Almanes and ‚Ä¢ Frankes. Alemanes and Frankes. But in the time of Pipine, father to Charles the greate, became the Frankes
lordes of the Almaines: and therfore as the empyre was thus deuided, they called hygh Germany the Ea≈øte kyngdome, and lowe Germany wyth Fraunce the We≈øt kyngdome: And by thys partynge of the kyngdomes remayne the names yett in Germany.

But when now Charles ‚Ä¢ erceyued certeynly, that no peace could be ≈øatteled in Italy, vntyll ≈øuche cyties in Italy as had fraunchy≈øes graunted them, dyd cea≈ø≈øe to do all thynges accordyng to their appetite, he was con≈øtrayned by nece≈ø≈øitie to take to him the dominion of whole Italy. But he betoke to the by≈øhop of Rome ≈øome cities and contreis, for the mayntenaunce of mini≈øters in the churche. In the Chri≈øtma≈ø≈øe nyght cryed the by≈øhop of Rome: Charles to be Emperoure of Romanes, and alwaye full of maie≈øtie. And it is ≈øayde, that Charles ≈øhuld haue
aun≈øwered to this: yf I had knowen that any ≈øuche thyng ≈øhould haue happened to me, I would not haue entered into the temple. We≈øt, to that dyd they con≈øent frely: for the≈øe countreis dyd not obey to the Emperours of Con≈øtantinople, any more.

But as ≈øone as Charles was made Emperoure,The Hungarians are a≈ø≈øaulted with warre by Charles the greate. and that the ≈øtate of Italy was nowe ≈øatled with great trauaile, he determined to warre vpon the Hungarians. And this warre la≈øted eight yeares, wherein the Hungarians were in a maner rooted out. He ≈øet al≈øo garny≈øons of Germanes in Hungary, to kepe the realme: by the whiche occa≈øion do vntyll this tyme Germanes dwel in the coa≈øtes of HuÃÑ gary, whiche is called Seuenburge. It is mencionedTra ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ luania or Sept ‚Ä¢ ca≈øtra called Seuenburg. in hi≈øtories, that Charles brought great ryches out of Hungary, and that is lyke ynough: for the HuÃÑ garians had bene occupied in warrefarre and robbery aboue two hundreth yeares, they ledde prayes of al nacions nerehande, in the meane ≈øea≈øon was their realme inuaded of no foren nacioÃÑs: wherby no doubt were great and precious trea≈øures founde by them. In the meane tyme dyd Charles, the ≈øonne of Charles the great, ≈øubdue Bohemy, vanquy≈øhyng LechoBohemy was ouercome wt Lecho theyr kynge. their kyng: and thus was charles at the la≈øt a moo≈øt myghty prince of all Italy, Fraunce, Germany, Bohemy and Hungary, and brought the whole We≈øt empyre in a quiet e≈øtate, & kept it in the ≈øame. Wherfore
for the≈øe vertues, and thys ≈øtrength of courage, whiche he v≈øed in all his enterpry≈øes, is Charles worthy to be counted amonge the≈øe princes, which God hath now and than geuen to the worlde to repayre common welthes, iu≈øtice, equitie, ≈øhamefa≈øtne≈ø≈øe, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ally to re≈øtore amonge men the bandes of mode≈øtie and common peace, as were in tymes pa≈øt Dauid, Hercules, Cyrus, Alexander, Iulius, Augu≈øtus, Con≈øtantinus, The odo≈øi ‚Ä¢ s. In Charles affaires is chefely worthy to be noted, how kynges and great men make ‚Ä¢ umors among them. For GodWh ‚Ä¢ rfore monarches & „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of God ≈øendeth ≈øometyme the chefe monarches to repre≈ø≈øe them. But it is expedient for mo≈øte hygh princes to be excellent, not onely in feates of warre and handlyng of weapon: but al≈øo to enforme common welthes with hone≈øt lawes and dectrine of religion. And this was Charles chefe care. He cau≈øed ≈øome coun≈øails

In Germany dyd he lyke wy≈øe founde many mona≈øteries, for to teache youth in ≈øteade of ≈øcoles. For that olde lawe of the Romans was long before put out of ‚Ä¢ re throug the Lombardes and Frankes.

of the Germanes and ≈øonges, wherein it is ≈øaid he had ≈øuche plea≈øure, that he learned them by rote.

He was excellently well ≈øene in the GermaneCharles the greate was learned in Greke & Latin. toungue and Latine: he coulde al≈øo ≈øpeake Greke, for he herde the Greke me≈ø≈øangers, and aun≈øwered them in Greke: but in along and durable relacioÃÑ did he ≈øpeake Latine. There are yet ver≈øes that be not greatly vn≈øemely, whiche is ≈øayde he dyd make at the death of his cou≈øin Roulande. In his olde age he gaue hym≈øelfe to A≈øtronomy. At diner and ≈øupper at home delyted he in hearyng reade the bokes of ≈øaincte Augu≈øtine.

In the temple dyd he ≈øyng the canonicall houres and al≈øo le≈ø≈øons with the pri≈øtes, and he woulde other princes to do likewy≈øe after his example, whoÃÑ he pre≈øcribed le≈ø≈øons, which ≈øemeth to pertain to his and their amendemeÃÑt. For he was an exciding louer of chri≈øten doctrine. In all maners of liuyng dyd be haue hym ≈øo, as nomaÃÑ might pa≈ø≈øe him in godline≈ø≈øe. Be≈øide this ≈øent he ≈øuccours of mony to the chri≈øtiaÃÑs in ≈øtraunge contreis, and obteined by the Saracen kynges that the chri≈øtians ≈øhould be more ea≈øely entreated.

He gaue the wyndes and monethes tho≈øe names, whiche remayne yet now a dayes: ≈øo that by the≈øe thynges may ea≈øely be gathered, that thys prince was garny≈øhed of God with greate vertues and hygh happene≈ø≈øe by hys ≈øtudyes, ≈øo that he may worthely be ≈øurnamed great. When he was nowrenowmed throughout all the worlde of all the≈øe vertues, peace ≈øtably≈øhed, y‚Ä¢ lawes re≈øtored, the ≈øtate of religioÃÑ ≈øet in order, becau≈øe he might auoyde the occa≈øion of
great euels, he appoynted hys ≈øonne Lewis before hys death to be an heyre and ≈øucce≈ø≈øour in the empyre, afterward dyed he at Aken the two and ≈øeuentyeth yeare of his age. THe yere of Chri≈øt .viij. C. xli. after ye death of Lewis the Godly or gentle reygned Lotharius hys ≈øonne fyften yeares. But now hath the golden worlde of this progenyThe brethren of Lotharius were th ‚Ä¢ e, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢

div.p: THe yeare of Chri≈øte .viij. C. lvi. toke Lewis the .ij. the ≈øonne of Lotharius the empyre: he reigned twenty yeares. div.head: Charles the bald of Fraunce.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øte, viij. C. lxxvj. cameCharles the balde. Charles the balde at Rome, and by the ayde of the by≈øhop of Rome Iohannes the .ix. was made Emperoure. Charles the balde was Lotharius brother, ≈øonne to Lewis the gentle, who≈øe part in deuydyng became Fraunce or Gallia. Now went the by≈øhop of Rome about, to tran≈øferre the maie≈øty of the Empyre from the Germanes, vnto the Frenchemen, but that the ≈øonnes of Lewis woulde not ≈øuff ‚Ä¢ e the Germanes. Which thyng when Charles the balde had herde, he threatened to bryng ≈øo many hoo≈øtes of enemies ouer the Rene, that the hor≈øes drynkyng vp the Rene, the hoo≈øt ≈øhould go thorow it drye ≈øhodde. Yet in the meaneThe death of Charles the balde. ≈øea≈øon per≈øy≈øted by≈øhop Iohannes in tran≈øferryng of the empyre, and willed the ≈øonne of Charles the balde to ≈øuccede in his fathers place. div.head: Charles the gro≈ø≈øe, the fyft Germane Emperoure.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øte .viij. C. lxxxi. came theCharles the gro≈ø≈øe. empyre agayne to the Germanes. For the Saracens commyng agayne into Italy, and ≈øpoylyng all thynges, dyd the Romanes call their by≈øhop agayne out of Fraunce: for the Italians had nede of ≈øuccour≈øe agayn≈øte the Saracens. And when the kyng of Fraunce was deade, ≈øeyng the kynges heyre was not yet of ful age, there were ray≈øed euery where great di≈ø≈øencions and debates in Fraunce, for the gouernaunce of the realme vntyll the kynges ≈øonne were come to age. Wherefore the by≈øhop of Rome con≈øtrayned by this nece≈ø≈øitie required ayde of the Germanes to re≈øcue Italy out the brunt of daungers. Then came Charles the gro≈ø≈øe ≈øonne to Lewis the Germane into Italy, &
driuing out the Saracens, toke the emperial crown the yeare of Chri≈øte .viii. C. lxxxij. Charles reigned after that he was crowned, ix. yeares. About thisThe NormaÃÑ des fell into Fraunce. tyme the Normandes fallyng into Fraunce, dyd ≈øo much harme euery where, that the Frenchmen wer compelled to require ayde of the Germanes: and by con≈øent of euery man, was Charles made kyng of Fraunce, and by thys occa≈øion gott Charles the Gro≈ø≈øe the realme both of Germany and Gallia or Fraunce agayne. But the≈øe kyngdomes were ≈øeparated againe not long after. Charles beynge wery of the warre in Morauia or Meerhen by rea≈øon of the greate combraunce and trauail, for≈øakyng the empire, he made Arnolfus his brothers ≈øonne Emperour, who pointed Charles out of the empire ≈øo muche reuenues, ≈øo long as he lyued, as was ≈øufficient for a kynges ≈øtate.

div.head: Arnolfus the .vi. Germane Emperoure.
div.p:
ARnolfus the ≈øonne of Carolomanus, dukeArnolphus Emperoure. of Baierlande, Schwaben and of the FraÃÑ kes y‚Ä¢ co≈øin of Charles the third, was ≈øub≈øtitute by hym in the empyre the year ‚Ä¢ of Chri≈øte .viij. C. xci. he reigned .xij. yeares. Fyr≈øt ouercame he the Morauians or Meerhlanders, after that the Normandes, whiche beyng now returned out of Fraunce, came vntyll the Rene, and commyng to Worms, put the by≈øhop of Mentz to execution. As the Normandes, were vanquy≈øhed by theThe NormaÃÑ des are ouercome. Emperours, at the la≈øt became they Chri≈øten. Afterwarde when V ‚Ä¢ ido duke of Spoleta by a rumor was made Emperoure, Arnolfus goyng into Italy, toke in Rome by greate force, and was crowned
of Formo≈øus the by≈øhop of Rome. Wherfore wheÃÑ he had taken in Italy agayne, V ‚Ä¢ ido was banny≈øhed. He re≈øtored againe al≈øo the duchy of Bourgondie to the Germane dominion.
Marinus the .C. xi. by≈øh. of Ro. ≈øucceded IoaÃÑnes Adrianus the .iij. was by≈øhop after Marinus.
Stephanus the fift C. xiij. by≈øh. ≈øucceded AdrianÍù∞ Formo≈øus ≈øucceded Stephanus.

At that tyme was again a great debate at Rome for the election: For Sergius was al≈øo created by≈øhop: but the fauoures of Formo≈øus driuynge out Sergius, Formo≈øus ≈øent for the Emperoure into Italy, that he myght kepe ≈øtyll the by≈øhopryke by that meanes. For Sergius was fled into Fraunce, and went about to obteine the by≈øhopryke by the aide of Frenchemen. Howbeit after certaine yeares, when Formo≈øus was deade, he was made by≈øhop, & v≈øed more tyranny and pre≈øumpcion, then he ought to haue done, accordyng to by≈øhoply mekene≈ø≈øe. HeAn example of mo≈øte notable cruelne≈ø≈øe of a Romp≈øh by≈øhop. Sergius vnlearned and a tyraunt. cau≈øed to digge vp the deade carcas of Formo≈øus, to degrate it, and beheadyng it ca≈øt it into the floude Tyber with mo≈øte ≈øhame. It is written that this Sergius was very vnlearned & vnmanered, which thinge his cruell dedes declare plaine ynough.
Bonifacius the .vi. the .C. xv. by≈øhop ≈øucceded Formo≈øus.
StephanÍù∞ the .vi. folowed Bonifacius. Thi≈ø≈øame di≈øanulled & condempned al Formo≈øus ordinauÃÑces.

dorus thi≈ø≈øame alowed agayne the ordinaunces of Formo≈øus, whiche Stephanus the ≈øyxte had di≈øanulled.
Benedictus the .iiij. was the .C. xx. by≈øhop after Iohannes.
Leo the .v. was after Benedictus the .C. xxi. by≈øhop of Rome. The ≈øame was taken pry≈øoner by Chri≈øtophorus.
Chri≈øtophorus was by≈øhop after Leo. Thi≈ø≈øame was taken by Sergius.

After Chri≈øtophorus was Sergius the .iij. made the .C. xxiij. by≈øhop of Rome. The ≈øame cau≈øed the deade coar≈øe of Formo≈øus be dygged vp agayneThe tyranny of y‚Ä¢ by≈øhops of Rome. and beheaded. It is a thynge full of drede ether to reade or to reher≈øe by≈øhops of Rome to haue v≈øed ≈øo great tyranny among them≈øelues. And it could not be that any regarde could be had of Chri≈øten godlyne≈ø≈øe: let no man then marueill in the meane ≈øea≈øon, yf any abu≈øes and wycked opinions be broken into the churche in the meane whyle.

div.head: Lewis the .iii. the .vii. Germane Emperoure.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øte .ix. C. iij. Lewis theLewis the. iij ≈øonne of Arnolphus, being ≈øub≈øtitute in the empyre of hys father, reygned ten yeares. It is no where redde that he was crowned.The Hungarians way ‚Ä¢ t Germany & ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ly. For when Arnolphus was deade, the Hungarians inuaded Germany wyth greate violence. Agayn≈øt them dyd the good prince Lewis the Emperoure ≈øet hym≈øelfe, and dyd greuou≈øly di≈øconfite them by the ryuer Lyeus, but he was afterwarde ouercome of them lykewy≈øe. Then the Hungarians
beynge vanqui≈øhers, dyd euery where muche my≈øchefe and harme to the Schwoben, Frankes, Baierlanders and them of O≈øtenryche. Slayeng euery one wythoute regarde or mercy, burnynge temples, cityes, tounes, villages, yee euery thynge.

Afterwarde entrynge into Italy, v≈øed lyke crueltye.Berengarius prince of Foroiulium. At that tyme was Berengarius prince of Foroiulium, which gatherynge a great army agany≈øt the Hungaryans, although ≈øomtyme he fought vn luckelye: yet gat he hym ≈øuch a good name by thys ≈øettynge forth, that afterwarde he wylled to be called Emperoure.

div.head: Cunradus the .i. the viij Germane Emperoure.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øt .ix. C. xii. was ConradusConrade the fyr≈øte‚ñ™ made Emperoure, he raigned ≈øeuen yeares. But he was not crowned of the Romy≈øh by≈øhop. He was Lewis the .iii. brothers ≈øonne: he was duke of the Frankes, and the la≈øte of the moo≈øte noble po≈øteritye of Charles the great, whiche ye maye ge≈ø≈øe by the order of the genealogye wrytten hereafter: the whych I haue added therfore, yt it maye be knowen, to how great chaunces, and how many alteracions the kingdom of the Germanes hath ben putt, the which thynge can not be red wythoute greate wonderynge at. For that maye be ≈øene euerye where that greate kyngdomes flory≈øhe a certayne ≈øpace in the world, but at the la≈øte they be weakened, and to≈ø≈øed wyth troublous commocions: howbeit in the meane ≈øea≈øon be they ≈øo kept by Godes prouidence, that they
do not wholy pery≈øh. Lewis the thyrd left no ≈øo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ after hym: and therefore ≈øtroue the Frankes and Sacons together, to make Otho duke of SaxonyOtho duke of Saxony. Emperour: but the good prince with≈øtode the ≈øame not wylling that to the moo≈øt noble ≈øtocke of Charles, ≈øhulde happen ≈øuche a reproch. Therefore coun≈øelled he to make Conradus duke of the Frankes Emperoure. Of thys wy≈øe ≈øucceded Conradus in the empyre, but Otho was in more greater authority, & whyle Conradus lyued, he di≈øpatched more bu≈øyne≈ø≈øes al≈øo: yet in the meane time ≈øhewed he great loyalty and hone≈øtye toward Conradus the Emperoure.

But in the meane tyme v≈øurped BerengariusBerengarius duke of Foroiulium the name of the Emperoure in Italy, and enticed the Hungarians, that they ≈øhuld ≈øpoyle Germany agayn: but Conradus ouer came tho≈øe, by the ayde of Otho.

But whan Otho was deade; Conradus the Emperour fearyng happely, le≈øt the ≈øon of Otho HenryHenry the Fouler. The occa≈øioÃÑ of the warre betwene the Frankes & Saxons. the Fouler ≈øhoulde growe ouermuche in power: therefore wythdrue he parte of tho≈øe thynges, whyche before he had graunted hys father Otho. And whan Henry toke it greueou≈ølye, the Empetoure endeuoured to ≈ølaye him by an intrap, and to bryng thys to pa≈ø≈øe, was ye by≈øhop of Mentz made out: But the intrap was di≈øclo≈øed. Than was Henry very greuou≈øly moued‚ñ™ & went home, and toke from the by≈øhop of Mentz all that was hys dominion in the land of Turyngen and He≈ø≈øe. But hereof ro≈øe a greate warre betwene the Frankes and Saxons.

But whan Conradus was a dyenge, callyng to him his brother Eberardus, he commaunded hym to brynge the Emperyall croune to Henry duke of Saxony: for him he iudged be≈øt worthy to gouern the Empyre. He admony≈øhed prince Eberarde al≈øo with al diligence, to make an ende of the warr that he had taken in hande wyth Henry duke of Saxonye,The empyre is tran≈ølated to the SaxoÃÑs le≈øt the Frankes that were yet alyue, ≈øhuld vtterly he roated out and pery≈øh. For he marked wel that God pro≈øpered Henryes affayres. To thys coun≈øell dyd duke Eberardus agre willyngly, and bringyng the crowne to Henry, and makyng peace on both ≈øydes, he was afterward loyall to Henry. And by thys occa≈øyon came it to pa≈ø≈øe, that the empyre was remoued from the ≈øucce≈ø≈øors of Charles the greate to the Saxons.

div.head: Henry the .i. ≈øurnamed the Fouler, the ix. Emperoure of Germany.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øt .ix. C. xx. was Henry the fyr≈øte, ≈øurnamed the Fouler,
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . duke of Saxon made Emperoure, he raygned ≈øeuenten yeares. He was not crouned of the bi≈øhop of Rome, nether went into Italy, though twayne toke vpon them the name of the Emperoure, and by vproure ray≈øynge battayll fought now and than a great felde.
For Henry had bu≈øyne≈ø≈øe more than ynough in Germany, which the good prince apeaced wyth greate diligence, accordinge to hys ≈øyngular policye, and endeuored to make it more excellent.

Surely the kyngdome of Germany dyd neuerThe kyngdome of germany neuer wanted vproures. in a maner want vprouri≈øh commotions, ther was almo≈øt neuer an Emperour cho≈øen, wythout the ≈øedition of ≈øome princes, which went aboute to take vpon them the name of the Emperoure. Yet was God alway wyth tho≈øe Emperours, that were du
‚Ä¢ lly called, detended the authoritye of the lawfull empyre, and the ≈øedicious were puni≈øhed. Arnolde duke of Bayerlande ≈øet him ≈øelfe wyth hurtfull enterpry≈øe agayn≈øt Henry, who recountred ye Baiers wyth appointed armyes: but behauynge him≈øelfe not as an enemy, he requyred to ≈øpeake wyth duke Arnolde familiarly. He rea≈øoned wyth hym, & earne≈øtlyThe rea≈øonyng of Henry the Emperour wyth Arnold duke of Bayerland. admony≈øhed hym, that the maie≈øty of the empyre, is geuen of God: yf it were ≈øo, that he wer cho≈øen Emperoure by the con≈øente of other prynces, than wolde he frely geue place, and be ready y‚Ä¢ fyr≈øt that ≈øhuld ≈øubmitte them≈øelues. Duke Arnold ≈øhewed the≈øe thynges to his coun≈øel, which an≈øwered: That it were euident that Salomons ≈øayenge of wy≈øedome were mo≈øt true, which is: By me do kynges rule. And for a≈ømuch as it appeareth euidently ynough that Henry is endued with wi≈øedome and gentlene≈ø≈øe, it is no dout, but God doth a≈ø≈øi≈øte him: he ≈øhuld therfore thenceforth leaue of from his enterpry≈øe, nether to go about any thing again≈øt Henry. Wherefore duke Arnolde cea≈øed, & obeied frely without ye ≈ølaughter of any of his men. Who I pray
you wold not ≈øaye, y‚Ä¢ the≈øe Germane princes were no Barbaryans, and that they excelled in pryncely wi≈øedome & high gentlene≈ø≈øe? This is al≈øo wrytteÃÑ: that. S. Vdalryck had a vi≈øty on of the duke of Baierland,The vi≈øion of S. Vdalr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ke. which he ob≈øerued: For it was ≈øhewed him by God, that the duke had a ≈øwearde wythout hyltes or handel: wherby was ≈øignified, that the duke ≈øhulde not v≈øe the ≈øweard, that is, that he ≈øhuld not retayn the empyre. Wherefore he admony≈øhed the duke to do nothyng vnadui≈øedly.
After that dyd Henry take Brandenburge: andThe d ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ by Henry the fyr≈øte. the Vandales beyng ≈øubdued, they receaued the Chri≈øten fayth vntyl the ≈øee.
He be≈øieged the city Praga, and brought the Bohemes to the Empyre.

After that vanquy≈øhed he fourty thou≈øand Hungaryans by Mer≈øburge, whereby he gatte hym a great renowme and drede by the ≈øtraunge nacions and gat tranquillitye to al Germanye: He re≈øtored the contry of Lothring or Lorayn to the kingdom of Germany, and gatt the ≈øpeare that Chri≈øte was pear≈øed through of Rudolphe kyng of Burgundy: the ≈øame was Con≈øtantinus wont to haue.

Henry the Fowler beynge now neare to his death, made his ≈øonn Othe ≈øucceder in ye empyre after him, le≈øt any ≈øtryfe ≈øhuld happen in the empyre after hys death, concernyng the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of it.
