div.head: Otho the .i. the .x. Germane. Emperoure.
div.p: OTho the fyr≈øt the ≈øonne of Henry the FowlerOtho the fyr≈øt. beganne hys domynyon the yeare of Chri≈øt .ix. C. xxxviii. and raigned .xxxvi. yeares. He toke the emperyall crowne at Aken of the by≈øhop of Mentz. In the begynnyngeThe vpronres ray≈øed again≈øt Otho Eberardus the Palatine Gi≈øelbert prince of Lotharing or Loraine‚ñ™ of Othes gouernaunce ro≈øe thre greate and daungerous vproures at one tyme.

The doers of the fyr≈øte vproure were Eberardus the Palatine, and Gi≈øelbert prince of Lorain. The≈øe (becau≈øe they were of the po≈øteritie and linage of Charles the greate,) affirmed, that the empyre came from the Saxons to the Frankes by right of ≈øucce≈ø≈øion: and that ≈øuch enterpry≈øes myght ≈øeme to be more ryghtfull, they drew on their ≈øyde Henry the elder brother of Otho, vnder the pretence,Henry brother to Otho that by rea≈øon of the age, he oughte to gouerne the empyre, and not Otho.

Thys warre wyth the counte Palatine Eberardus and duke Gi≈øelbert la≈øted ≈øyxe yeares, and many feldes were foughteÃÑ in the mean ≈øea≈øon. Herman duke of Scwaben, and Conradus duke of theHerman prince of Schwaben‚ñ™ Lonradus duke of the Frankes. Frankes toke the Emperours parte. This Conradus of Worms, called the wy≈øe, was co≈øyn to Eberardus. The≈øe fought the la≈øt again≈øt ye enemies by Andernak, with a great camp, wherin Eberardus countye Palatine was ≈ølayne, and duke Gi≈øelbert
in the flighte, was drowned in the Rene. It is a dreadfull example, wherein we may be aduerti≈øed,An example of ‚Ä¢ eage
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ al≈øo on greate „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . that the endeuoure of ≈øedition remayneth not vnreuenged, euen in greate princes al≈øo. But whether thys Eberardus be he, yt we haue ≈øayde of before to haue broughte the Emperyall crowne to Henry the Fowler, it is not ≈øpecifyed for a trueth. For the hy≈øtorye wryters of the Germanes, were gro≈ø≈øe and vnlearned men, ignoraunt of the≈øe thinges, whyche are nece≈ø≈øary to be ob≈øerued in wrytynge of hy≈øtoryes.

But after thys victory, was not the ≈øtryfe yetThe ≈øeconde vp ‚Ä¢ ouce was wyth hys brother. alayed which Otho the emperoure had wyth Henry his brother, and be≈øyde that wyth the by≈øhop of Mentz: Henry was be≈øyeged at Mer≈øburg: but he ≈øeynge that hys interpry≈øes were inuayne, and that hys defence beganne to be feble, he hym≈øelfe came knelynge to ye Emperoure, de≈øyryng pardon for his offence, was receaued to mercy by Otho: and not long after, the duke of Baier decea≈ø≈øynge wythout heyre male, Otho the Emperoure gaue hys brother Henry the duchy of Baierland. As for that Henry the Emperoure whyche is buryed at Bamberg, was thys Henryes ≈øonnes ≈øonne, as we ≈øhall ≈øhewe hereafter.
Afterwarde was Mentz be≈øyeged and taken in by the Emperoure, and the by≈øhop taken al≈øo: but ≈øhortly after was he letten lou≈øe agayn.

The thyrde ry≈øynge agayn≈øte Otho was manyThe thyrde „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ was by his owne „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . yeares after, by his owne ≈øon Ludolfe, by this occa≈øion: Otho had fyr≈øte a quene out of Englande called Edyth or Ide, which is buryed at magdeburg.
Of the ≈øame had he hys ≈øonne Ludolphe. After the ≈øame was deade toke he another quene of the Burgundyon bloud, which thynge Ludolphe dyd not alow. But what happened farther, that is vnknowen. For the Germane hy≈øtory wryters dyd in maner expre≈ø≈øe no thynge wholye by theyr occa≈øyons and circum≈øtaunces: nether ruely could they do it, ≈øeyng they were monkes, lyuynge in priuate idelne≈ø≈øe‚ñ™ beynge ≈øomtyme farre from all thynges, that be done in gouernynge the commune welthe: I pa≈ø≈øe ouer that they were to ≈ø ‚Ä¢ outhfull al≈øo to ≈øearch & enquyre the cau≈øes and occa≈øions of great matters of other men, as ye duety of a true hy≈øtory wryter is to do. Yet do they make mencion of thisSalfelde ‚Ä¢ deadly place for coun≈øels. that Ludolfus kept an a≈ø≈øemble at Salfelde, & to haue con≈øpyred agayn≈øt hys father: and that place Salfeld, is called a deadly place for coun≈øels. Ludolfus had neuerthele≈ø≈øe in the meane ≈øea≈øon mo≈øt great princes y‚Ä¢ were partakers wyth hym in thys con≈øpiracy and coun≈øel, among the which al≈øo was Conradus the wi≈øe duke of the Frankes. But in y‚Ä¢ meane tyme that thys was in bruynge, was the father in Italy, who be≈øieged hys ≈øonne at Mentz ≈øoRegen≈øpurg ≈øone as he cameinto Germany: Ludolfe e≈øcapyng, fled vntyl Regen≈øpurge: but the father folowyng, be≈øyeged Regen≈øpurg al≈øo ≈øtraytly two moneths. In that ≈øyege dyed not a few men, among ye which was the chefe, Arnolde the yonger duke of Bayer. After hys deathe Ludolfe requyrynge peace frelye, came barefooted knelynge befoore hys father, and lyenge vpon the grounde, he de≈øyred pardon for hys tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe very humblye. Wherfore
the father toke hym to mercy, and a verye ≈øtronge peace was made.

No Emperoure in a maner dyd di≈øpatche euer anye more greater and daungerous bu≈øyne≈ø≈øes than the Emperour Otho, ≈øo farr as I can marke. But in all them was he in the meane ≈øea≈øon luckye, not wythout the incredible fauoure of God. For whyle he had the≈øe warres he ouercame the Bohemes, the Hungarians, and Frankes, be≈øyde that made he quyet the troublous ≈øtate of Italy, which thynge we ≈øhall brefely ≈øhewe.

He vanquy≈øhed the Hungarians by Aug≈øburgeThe Hungarians are vanqui≈øhed. neare the floude Lycus, and weakened he the ≈øtrenght of them ≈øo, that they dur≈øte neuer after come into Germany. In thys battayll dyed Conrade
‚Ä¢ . „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
the Wy≈øe, and. S. Udalricke by≈øhop of Augu≈øpurg was wyth the Emperoure in the hoo≈øte.

Moreouer whan Otho enuironned euery wherwith greate peryls, the Frenchmen tru≈øted ea≈øely to bryng the empyre to them agayn: but here wasAn example that „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ God „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . it founde in Otho, that it is inuayne for men to ≈øett them≈øelues agayn≈øte him, whome God fauoureth. Innumerable enemyes had compa≈ø≈øed Otho about, the Bohemes, the Frankes, the Hungarians Italyans, the Frenchemen: but the power of all the≈øe, coulde not breake and oppre≈ø≈øe the vertue of thys good prince. The Frenchemen threatened to brynge into Germanye ≈øo greate an hoo≈øte, as neuer had ben ≈øene afore. Whereto it is reportedThe aun≈øwer of Otho to the Frenche ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s threaten ‚Ä¢ y ‚Ä¢
ges. Otho ≈øhuld haue aun≈øwered: That ≈øuch vayn mynaces became not wy≈øe princes, ≈øeyng it is euident, that ye victory & fortun of warr is in Goddes hand.
He aun≈øwered thys al≈øo: that he wolde brynge ≈øoStrawe hattes. many couered with ≈øtrawe hattes into Fraunce, as they neuer had ≈øene before: and therefore had all they that were in the hoo≈øte ≈øtrawe hattes, whych hoo≈øte he broughte vntyll parys. For Hugo princeHugo prince of Fraunce of Fraunce had taken the kynge his lorde pri≈øoner, and entended to take to him Fraunce and the dignyty of the empyre. Thy≈ø≈øame Hugo was taken ofLewis is re≈øtored agayn to the realme of Fraunce. Otho in the citye of Paris, and delyuerynge Lewis his brother in Lawe, re≈øtored him to y‚Ä¢ realme of Fraunce agayne. For Gerberga the ≈øy≈øter of Otho was maryed to Lewys. Otho re≈øtored than to to the Germane empyre lowe Germanye, Lorain and Burgundye.

The Hungaryans had many ≈økyrmy≈øhes al≈øo in Italy, but ≈øome Emperoures before Othoes tyme were ≈øo occupied in Germany, that they could'not ayde Italy. Whan now the princes of Italy were dryuen to extreme nece≈ø≈øity for to re≈øi≈øt the Hungarians, it happened that Berengarius prince of Foroiulium, gat hym a great wonderyng at his prowe≈ø≈øe, and afterwarde coueted the gouernaunce of whole Italy. And though other prynces dyd al≈øo ≈øtryue for the ≈øouerayntye of Italye, yet dyd Berengaryus, excellynge in power, kepe Italye tyll the thyrde heyre. The ≈øame toke vpon hym the tytle of Emperoure, and v≈øed greate crueltye in Italye. The Italyans requyred ayde and ≈øuccoureBerengarius peldeth hym≈øelfe to Otho. of Otho agayn≈øte hys tyrannye. Wherefore Otho goynge into Italye, he inuaded Lombardye, and gat it. Berengarius wyth yeldynge him≈øelfe frely, optained of Otho that grace, that he
≈øhuld not wholy be dryuen out of Italy, but ≈øhould retayne a duchy to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe. After twelue yeares was Otho called into Italy agayne, to defende or clayme the Italians wyth the clergye and by≈øhop of Rome, from the tyranny of Berengarius, which thynge he al≈øo dyd valyauntly. For whan he cameBereÃÑgarius wyth hys ≈øonne are ‚Ä¢ a
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ for their di≈øloyaltye. agayne into Italy, he toke Berengarius and hys ≈øonne Alberte, and banni≈øhed them for theyr di≈øloyaltye: the father wyth hys wyfe to Bamberge in Germany, wher they ≈øpent theyr liues al≈øo as outlawes: but the ≈øonne ≈øent he to Con≈øtantinople.

Otho entrynge into Rome in thys ≈øettynge forth,Otho y‚Ä¢ fir≈øt made the „Äà‚óä„Äâ othe to the bi≈øhop of Rome. was crow ‚Ä¢ ed of Ioannes the .xii. This Otho was the fyr≈øte Emperour that made an othe to ye bi≈øhop of Rome, wherof the maner and tenor is in ye canon lawes, begynnynge: Tibidomino Ioanni .iii. & ce. After that is Otho come the ≈øecond tyme to Rome to rebuke Ioannes bi≈øh. of Rome, becau≈øe he was accu≈øed of many fautes. Wherfore the bi≈øhop knowynge him≈øelfe gyltye, fled for feare of Otho. And therfore was Leo the .viij. made bi≈øhop in his ≈øteadThe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es of the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ppes of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . But before that Otho went from Rome, Ioannes commynge to Rome, thru≈øt Leo out agayne: Leo fled to the Emperoure. But the moo≈øt wy≈øe Emperoure v≈øed greate policy, le≈øt he ≈øhoulde geue an occa≈øion of debate: He ≈øuffred Ioannes to v≈øe the bi≈øhopryck, ≈øo longe as he lyued. But ≈øo ≈øone as he was deade, to take Leo as lawfully cho≈øen bi≈øhop: but the Romanes wolde not alowe it, whych refu≈øyage Leo, cho≈øe another called Benedictus in ≈øpete of the Emperoure. Otho than returnynge, inuaded the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øyons of the Romy≈øhe
by≈øhops, and dyd much hurte. He be≈øyeged al≈øo the citye of Rome, vntyl the cithe≈øins con≈øtrayned by famine & nece≈ø≈øity, opened the gates frely to Otho. He than puttynge to death manye Romanes, and banny ≈øhinge the Con≈øuls, re≈øtored Leo: & whan he had apea≈øed al thynges, returned into Germany, leadynge wyth hym Benedictus, who was kept at Hamborowe.

Otho goynge the thyrde tyme to Rome, droue the Saracens and Grekes out of the farther coa≈øtes of Italy. Than cho≈øynge Otho hys ≈øonne to be partener in the Empyre, bringyng hym wyth hym, commaunded to crowne hym, and cau≈øed the Emperour of Con≈øtantinoples doughter to be geuen hym in mariage. By all the≈øe thynges maye it ea≈øely be gathered, that this Otho was one al≈øo of the≈øe princes, which God hath now and than geuen to repayre the decayed ≈øtate of the worlde. For he ≈øet vp agayne the decayed empyre of Rome, and ≈øet all Europa in quiet: by hys ≈øuccour hath he defended whole Italy and Germany. He ≈øubdued the Hungarians and Frenchmen. To be ≈øhorte, he hath re≈øtored the maie≈øtye of the empyre to hys former bryghtne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øet it in order: afterward dyed he at Quedelnburg in great quyetne≈ø≈øe. It is writtenQuedelnburg. Who fande fyr≈øt the ≈øyluer Mines in Mi≈øen. al≈øo, that he found fyr≈øt the ≈øyluer mines in Mi≈øen. He gaue al≈øo muche good to the churche, to maynteine religion, and to promote the doctryne of godlyne≈ø≈øe, to which intent he made al≈øo not a fewe by≈øhops, as at Magdeburg, Mi≈øen, Brandenburg, Mer≈øburg, and Ceitz.
Martinus the .iij. was the .cxxxij. by≈øhop after Stephanus.
Agapetus the .ii. ≈øucceded Martinus.

Ioannes the .xiii. the C. xxxiiij. bi≈øhopp was after Agapetus. The ≈øame crowned Otho the fyr≈øt: afterwarde fled he from Rome, fearynge le≈øte for hys vnclenne≈ø≈øe of lyfe, he ≈øhulde be ca≈øte from the offyce by Otho.
Leo the .viii. was cho≈øen in Ioannes ≈øteade.
But whan Ioannes was returned to Rome. Leo fled to the Emperour, but whan IoaÃÑnes was deade, was Leo re≈øtored agayne.
Ioannes the .xiiii. and .C. xxxvi. bi≈øhop ≈øucceded. Leo. Of hym was Otho the ≈øeconde crowned.

div.head: Otho the ≈øeconde, the .xi. Germane Emperoure.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øt .ix. C. lxxiiii. raygnedOtho the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚ñ™ Otho y‚Ä¢ .ii. after hys fathers decea≈ø≈øe ten yeares: again≈øt him was an vprour ray≈øedHenry du ‚Ä¢ e of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . al≈øo. For Henry duke of Baier hys co≈øyn coueted ye empyre. This Henry is not the brother of Otho the fir≈øte, of whome is ≈øpoken before, which con≈øpiringe ro≈øe agayn≈øt his brother Otho, and afterward reconciled again to his brother, gat the duchy of Baier. Thys fyr≈øt duke of Baier, that was of the Saxons bloude, dyed .xv. yeare before Otho. But thys fyr≈øte Henryes ≈øonne is the ≈øame whyche ≈øet hym≈øelfe agayn≈øte Otho the ≈øeconde: but Otho had ≈øoone tamed this newe enterpry≈øer.

Afterwarde dyd the Frenchemen fall ≈øodenlye vpon the Emperoure at Aken, and he dyd ≈øearcely e≈øcape theyr intrap. But Otho repayring an army, went into Fraunce, and ≈øpoyled euery where vntyl
Paris, & con≈øtrained the Frenchmen to demaunde peace: whyche dyd than bynd them wyth an othe,The French men are ≈øubdued of Otho the ≈øecoÃÑd that they wold neuer claime Lorain any more.

Whan he had ≈øet Germany at quyet, he went into Italy. There did he fight wyth the Grekes and Saracens in Apulia: but hys hoo≈øt beyng vanquy≈øhed, he was taken by mariners, as he fled. But becau≈øeOtho the ≈øecond was taken by mariners. he was vnknowen to the mariners, by rea≈øon he could the greke language, nether was he taken for a Germane prince, he redemed him≈øelfe with an ea≈øy price, and comming to Rome, he gouerned the empyre as he dyd before. It is ≈øayd that the Italians poi≈øonned hym, for his rigoure that he v≈øed in the gouernaunce.
Benedictus the .v. the .C. xxxvii. by≈øh of Rome was after Ioannes the .xiiii.
Donus the .ii. ≈øucceded after Benedictus
Bonifacius the .vii. the .C. xxxix. by≈øh. ≈øucceded Donus.
Benedictus the vi. ≈øucceded Bonifacius. In his tyme became Otho the thyrde Emperour.

div.head: Otho the .iii. the .xii. Germane Emperoure.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øt .ix. C. lxxxiiij. raygned Otho the thyrd after hys fathers decea≈ø≈øe .xix. yeares. He was yonge, ≈øcarcely pa≈ø≈øed xii. yeres whan hys father dyed: wherefore Henry duke of Bayer, co≈øyn to thys Otho, cau≈øed him to be kept at Rome, and beganne agayne to v≈øurpe the Empyre. Some Italians coun≈øeled to make Cre≈øcentyus Emperoure, that the emperyall maie≈øtye myghte be broughte agayne to the Italyans.
But the Germane princes beynge loyall to theyrThe endeuoure and faythfulne≈ø≈øe in keyyng the empyre‚ñ™ lorde, called the yonge Otho agayne from Henry, and made hym Emperoure wyth commune a≈ø≈øent, whereto Benedictus the by≈øhop of Rome gaue his con≈øent al≈øo.

The fyr≈øte warre that he hadde, was wyth the Frenchmen, whyche forgettynge theyr othe that they had made, inuaded Lorayne agayn, takynge in many cityes: but Otho dryuyng out the French men, kept Lotharyng or Lorayn.

In the meane tyme a Romane prince, called Cre≈øcentius, takyng vpon hym the name of an Emperoure, v≈øed great crueltye in Italy. Wherefore Otho commynge to Rome, enuyrouned wyth a greate army, and takyng Cre≈øcentius, cutt of hys no≈øe and eares, ≈øet hym ar≈øwarde vpon an a≈ø≈øe, cau≈øedThe puni≈øhment of Cre≈øcentius a Roman ‚Ä¢ Prynce for ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ yng y‚Ä¢ Emp ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
hym to be caryed about the city Rome to wonder at, and at the la≈øt to be hanged.

div.head: Of the begynnynge and in≈øtitution of the Electors in Germany.
div.p:
WHan Otho was nowe eyghte and twentye yeares olde he was endued wyth ≈øo ready wytt, that for hys ≈øyngularOtho the iij. called the Worldes wonders‚ñ™ wy≈øedome, he was called the Worldes wonders. Be≈øyde that knewe the Saxons readye wytted and valyaunt men, the deceatfull traynes of the Frenchmen. Wherfore whan they perceaued that great and dangerous commotions were ray≈øed by the. Ro. by≈øhoppes, bothe agayn≈øte Emperoures, and al≈øo in the commune welth, Otho cho≈øe Bruno
a Saxon his co≈øin to be by≈øhop of Rome, who wasBruno a Saxon was made by≈øh. of Ro. called Gregorius the fyft after that he had the by≈øhopryke. Of hym was Otho the thirde crowned. Be≈øyde this when the wy≈øe prince con≈øydered that the Frenchemen and Italians raged euer to tran≈øfer the emperiall maie≈øtie from the Germanes, and that among the aunceters of him was now and thaÃÑ ≈øtrife al≈øo for the election: and that in the meane tyme is ≈øo greatly requi≈øite a myghty monarche to the Chri≈øtiantie, for to defende the bi≈øhop of Rome, and libertie of Italy: yea to maynteyne concorde of religion in whole Europa. But that the ≈øame monarchy could not la≈øt long and be ≈øtable euermore, without the ayde and ≈øuccour≈øe of ≈øome peculiar & mo≈øte mighty nacion. Therfore with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtence and ayde of Gregorius the by≈øhop of Rome (who, becau≈øe he was a Germane, did lyghtely con≈øent to ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary a thyng,) dyd make the ordinaunce of the princes Electors for to choy≈øe an Emperoure. And that concorde might be had in the election becau≈øe of religion, among the prelates ≈øpirituall and princes temporall the aucthoritie to cho≈øe an Emperoure is committed to ≈øeuen Germane princes,To what pr ‚Ä¢
ces the election is committed. the Archeby≈øhops of Mentz, Colen and Trier. To the≈øe are ioyned the prince of Boheme: (for at that tyme had Bohemy yet no kynge,) the County Palatine of the Rene, the duke of Saxony, & the Marques of Brandenborowe. I maruayll verely why ≈øo hygh a dignitie is not bequyethed to other princes, which at that tyme were farre more puy≈ø≈øaunt, as namely to the dukes of Baier, of Schwaben & of the Frankes, and ≈øpecially the duke of Baier, who
was nearer of kynred to Otho, than the other, and more greater of domynyon. For he had ≈øubiect to hym Bayerland and Ea≈øtenryche, vntyll Aglar or Aquitanya, the whyche Henry brother to Otho the fyr≈øte had wonne. The duke al≈øo of Schwaben was neare kyn≈øman to Otho the Emperoure. For whan Herman duke of Schwaben vnder Otho the fyr≈øte had no heyre male, He gaue his doughter in maryage to Ludolfe ≈øonne to Otho the fyr≈øte, agayn≈øte whome hys father Otho dyd warre for hys rebellyon. Of this Ludolfe come the dukes of Schwaben. Therefore maye it be maruayll, what was the occa≈øion to orden that in≈øtitutyon of prynces Electors. The Germane hi≈øtory wryters ≈øeme to be ≈øo voyde of all iudgment, that it may of goodIhon Stabius an a≈øtronomer. ryght lothe any man to reade them. Ihon Stabius the a≈øtronomer of Maximylyan ≈øhewed me oft, that Maximilian was went to complayn vpon the rudene≈ø≈øe of the Germane hy≈øtorye wryters, thatThe Germane hi≈øtory wryters vnlearned. they dyd not only wryte the dedes of ≈øo noble and wy≈øe princes, that God had ≈øent wythoute order: but dyd al≈øo corrupte them wyth euell wrytynge. And he had commaunded to compile in a ≈øhort Cronycle orderly the moo≈øte notable≈øte thynges out of all hy≈øtorye wryters: whych thynge doutle≈ø≈øe had ben done, yf the moo≈øte wy≈øe Emperour had ether lyued longer, or had not left it by rea≈øon of the care of more weyghty matters.

As for me, (though I might ≈øeme to be ra≈øh, yf I allege or ≈øhewe what me thynketh,) yet wyll I declare what ge≈ø≈øynge I haue, wherewyth I maye ≈øhewe ≈øome certayntye of ≈øo great a thynge. Bohemy
no doute is come in the election for his coÃÑmodyousWhy Bohemy hath the authorytye of eleccion. Saxony. ≈øytuatyon, & becau≈øe yt is fen≈øed round about.
To the Saxons hath Otho that was a prince of the Saxons bloud worthely geuen that honour: for at that time was the ≈øame duchy mo≈øt pui≈ø≈øaunt.
The princes of Saxony kept Brandenburg atBrandenburg. that time al≈øo, the Emperours kin≈ømen: and it may ea≈øely be gathered, that Otho dyd fauer tho≈øe contryes more, than other duchyes.

I ≈øuppo≈øe that to y‚Ä¢ county≈øhyp of Palatyn wasThe county≈øhyp of Palatyne. geuen thys prerogatiue, more than other princes dominions, for none other cau≈øe, than that to Charles the greate≈øt po≈øterity myght rebound thys honor, ≈øo that it ≈øhuld be not only by the Saxons, but part thereof ≈øhuld al≈øo be ≈øent ouer to the Frankes: for the countyes of Palatine were at that tyme of the kynred of Charles the greate.

What pray≈øes thys ordinaunce of the princes ElectorsWhat profite is by the princes Electors. is worthye, that can I not now ≈øufficiently declare according to the worthyne≈ø≈øe of it: the dede proueth yt ≈øelfe what profite it hath broughte. For by thys ordinaunce hath the Empyre remained in Germany aboue fyue hundreth yeares. Be≈øydes that is nothyng ≈øo good nor whol≈øome in mens e≈øtates, than tho≈øe coun≈øels and ordinaunces, whereby is auoided the occa≈øion to alter of tymes the gouernaunce of Empyres: whyche thynge by the goodne≈ø≈øe of God is done by thys in≈øtytutyon of the Electors. By thys meanes is yt come to pa≈ø≈øe, that the Empyre is prouyded, that the traynefull and ≈øecrete con≈øpiracyons of the by≈øhoppe of Rome and Frenche kynge dyd not pro≈øpere,
whiche endeuoured oft to tran≈øferre the hyghne≈ø≈øe of the Empyre from the Germanes to the Frenchemen. The Emperoure al≈øo hath more ≈øauegarde or defence of the princes, when he is cho≈øen by their coÃÑ ≈øent: and le≈ø≈øe ≈øtryfe can ry≈øe for the election, when the de≈øyres of the chefe princes con≈øent to one. Be≈øydes this al≈øo, for≈øomuche as the maie≈øtie of the empyre is remitted to many princes together, it is to be tru≈øted that the ≈øtate of the empire ≈øhalbe both ≈øtronger and more durable, then if it dyd ≈øtycke by the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of one bloude. All the≈øe thynges make for that purpo≈øe, that no great ≈øtryfe come by re≈øon of the election or choy≈øyng: and al≈øo that the heade of the We≈øt empyre be in ≈øome certayn place, and that becau≈øe the concorde and tranquillitie of the religion in all this We≈øt kyngdome, be maynteined vnder one certayne heade. The Athenians in tymes pa≈øt auaunced their ordinaunce of the Areopagites with great pray≈øes: lykewy≈øe dyd the Lacedemonians their ≈øtatutes of the Ephories: and that worthely, for by them remained their common welthes ≈øtedfa≈øte a great while. But for≈øoth this in ≈øtitucioÃÑ of Otho made of the Electors, as it is farre more profitable, ≈øo it is worthy muche more pray≈øe and auauncement: as by the whiche ≈øtablene≈ø≈øe of the empyre and con≈øtant religion are mainteyned many yeares, not onely in one or other citie or contrey, but in the whole We≈øte. And the princes Electors ought worthely make muche of this their prerogatiue. Fir≈øt becau≈øe of the whole Chri≈øtiantie, that by them is this hyghne≈ø≈øe ≈øet aparte. For they are as a ≈øtedfa≈øt heade, wherewith foreuer all this
We≈øte kyngdome is kept and bounde together: for they maye be called the very route, out of the which emperoures mu≈øt euermore growe. Moreouer al≈øo can no hygher dignitie happen them in this lyfe then that worthyne≈ø≈øe is geuen them lawfully, whiche pa≈ø≈øeth farre the hyghne≈ø≈øe of kynges and princes. Then mu≈øt this ordinaunce be e≈øtemed a hygh gyft and an ordinaunce of God: Wherefore al≈øo it mu≈øt greatly be made of and kept without blemy≈øh, lea≈øt any occa≈øion bee geuen to di≈ø≈øolue ≈øo Godly and whol≈øome, yee and mo≈øte fayre harmony in this lyfe. For by them ≈øtandeth the ≈øumme of the Romane Empyre. And therfore whan the Electours are ≈øeuered, it is nece≈ø≈øary that the kyngdome or empyre fayle, and that the la≈øt iudgement is at hande. For the worlde ≈øhall ende vnder thys empyre. It is written that the in≈øtitucion of the Electours was.
The yeare of Chri≈øte .M. ij.
The yeare of the worlde .iiij. M. ix. C. xlvi.
The yeare of Rome .M. vii. C. lij.
The yeare after Charles the greate his coronacion .ij. C. i.

When this ordinaunce was made, the Italians made diuers vproures again≈øt Otho the .iij. in≈øomuche that he could not be ≈øafe at Rome: and when he went towarde Germany, Cre≈øcentius wyfe ≈øendingOtho the. i ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ was poy≈øo≈øoned. hym poy≈øon by an intrap, was kylled the thirtyeth yeare of his age.
Iohannes the .xv. the cxli. by≈øhop of Rome ≈øucceded Bonifacius the .vi. He was taken by BonifaciÍù∞ father, becau≈øe he wold not con≈øent to Bonifacius election.
Iohannes the .xvi. ≈øucceded Iohannes the .xv.
Iohannes the .xvii. ≈øucceded Iohannes .xvi. Beynge taken and dryuen out by Cre≈øcentius, he ‚Ä¢ ought ayde of Otho.

After Iohannes the .xvii. was Gregorius the fyft made the .C. xliiij. by≈øhop of Rome a prince of the Saxons bloude, and that for the ≈øame cau≈øe, as we haue declared a lytle before. For the Italians deui≈øed now and then newe thynges agayn≈øte the Emperours, nether dyd they euer want matters of vproures. Therefore ≈øemed it a nece≈ø≈øary thyng to maynteyne common quietne≈ø≈øe that a Germane ≈øhoulde be made by≈øhop of Rome. But yet in the meane ≈øea≈øon was Gregorius driuen out by the Italians, ordeinyng in hys ≈øteade one Iohannes: but Otho returning to Rome with a great power, re≈øtored Gregorius kyn≈øman againe.Sylue≈øter by≈øhop of Ro a w ‚Ä¢ other with ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ll ≈øpectes.
Silue≈øter the .ij. ≈øucceded Gregorius the .v. It is ≈øayde he was an Inchaunter.

After this ≈øorcerer was Iohannes the .xviii. made the .C. xlvi. by≈øhop of Rome. In hys tyme appeared towarde the South a comete of a dredefull ≈øyght, the whiche folowed no le≈ø≈øe hunger then pe≈øtilence.

div.head: Hrnry the .ij. ≈øurnamed the Haultynge, the. ‚Ä¢ iij. Germane Emperoure.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øt .M. iij. was HenryHenry the .ij. the ≈øecoÃÑd of that name duke of Bayer cho≈øen Emperoure. We haue ≈øayd before that Otho the fyr≈øt gaue his brother Henry the duchy of Baier. But I reken this Emperoure Henry was
the brothers ≈øonne of that Henry. For HeÃÑry Otho the fir≈øt brother died .xv. yeares before Otho decea≈øed. The Germane hi≈øtory writers were ≈øo negligent, that out of their writynges I can not ≈øaye for a certayne, whether he were that Henries ≈øonne, or his brothers ≈øonne. Truely that is wonder that the chanons of Bamberg knewe not certaynly the genealogy of their founder.

This Henry was the fir≈øt that was cho≈øen Emperoure by the Electors, and raygned .xxii. yeres. He was famous by wy≈ødome and noble victories, he made many and greate warres with maruaylous luckine≈ø≈øe. Fyr≈øt making werry y‚Ä¢ Bohemes &The dedes of Henry the .ij. Vandalies wyth warre, he ≈øubdued and made theÃÑ tributaries to hym. He be≈øyeged Metz and Gaunt: he wanne al≈øo Lorain and Flaunders. He ‚Ä¢ ought in Italy agayn≈øt the Saracens, and droue them out of Italy. Then was he crouned victoriou≈øly at Rome by Benedictus the ≈øeueÃÑth. He brought the Hungaryans to the Chri≈øten fayth, and gaueSteuen kyng of the Hungarians. to Steuen the Hungarian kyng his ≈øy≈øter in mariage. Before his death optayned he of the Electors lawfully, that Cunradus the .ij. of that name a Franke, ≈øhould ≈øuccede hym in the empyre. He fouÃÑ ded the by≈øhopryck of Bamberge, and is buryed there.
Iohannes the .xix. the .C.xlvii. by≈øhop ≈øucceded Iohannes the .xviii.
Sergius the .C.xlviii. bi≈øh. of Ro. ≈øucceded Ioh.
Benedictus the .vii. folowed Sergius. Of hym was Henry the Emperoure crowned.

Iohannes the .xx. the .cl. by≈øhop of Rome ≈øucceded
Bedictus. Of hym was Cunradus crowned‚ñ™

div.head: Cunradus the .ij. the .xiiij. Germane Emperoure.
div.p: THe yere of Chri≈øte .M. xxv. was CunradusCunradus y‚Ä¢ ≈øecond. a Franck cho≈øen Emperoure, who dwelt in the Limburg ca≈øtell by the citie Spire, and gouerned the empyre fyftene yeares. But in the begynnyng of hys reigne when he perceaued all thynges in a rumour euery where, he brought to pa≈ø≈øe that hys ≈øonne ≈øhould be cho≈øen a party ruler with hym, le≈øt when he were gone in to Italy, the ≈øubiectes in Germany ≈øhoulde make a rumour without a certayn heade.

Erne≈øtus duke of Schwaben and the Catuli: forErne≈øtus duke of Schwaben the Catuly were al≈øo lordes in Schwaben. The≈øe (I ≈øaye) were rebelles to the Emperoure: but he dyd ≈øo a≈ø≈øuage them, that they dyd ≈øtrayghtwaye obeye frely. From thence went he into Hungary, and redre≈ø≈øed that al≈øo. He toke Bourgundy and Liege or Ludich, he toke the realme of Orleaunce agayne, and gouerned it vnder his dominion. Afterwarde going into Italy, he be≈øieged Milan, and commyng to Rome, he was crowned of Iohannes the .xx. The Romanes about that tyme ry≈øynge agayn≈øt Cunradus, were fearcely ≈ølayen of the Emperours men: But the Romane affaires were apeaced. In the meane tyme whyles this was done in Italy, Erne≈øtus duke of Schwaben, ray≈øed a newe commotion wherfore Cunradus in hys returne droue hym awaye, and pear≈øed hym through. Cunradus gaue the duchy to Herman hys brother.
This Cunradus made many lawes, which are yet now a daies. Vnder this Emperoure, was a couu≈øaill kept at Tribur by Ment ‚Ä¢ . He builded wyth great co≈øtes the Churche of Spire, wherein he is buried with his quene Gi≈øela.

Greate pray≈øes are of this Gi≈øela. She was aGi≈øela a quene of Bourgundy. quene of Bourgundy, of Charles the greates po≈øte ritie. Her fir≈øt hu≈øbande was Erne≈øtus duke of Schwaben, of whom ≈øhe had two chyldren: Erne≈øtus that was driuen out, and Herman: afterward was ≈øhe wedded to Cunradus the Emperoure.

Here do the writers make the fir≈øt mencioÃÑ of theThe fir≈øt meÃÑ cion of y‚Ä¢ marque≈øhyp in Ea≈øteuriche. marque≈øhyp in Ea≈øtenriche, whiche at that tyme po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Albert duke of Schwaben, brother to Erne≈øtus the elder. Nether was Ea≈øtenryche yet at that time a duchy, but the Schwaben kept it, which had taken it from the Hungarians by ≈øtrong hand.The begynnyng of the erldome of Thuryngen and whence y‚Ä¢ lordes therof be. Lewis the Bearded.

The Erldome al≈øo of Thuryngen beganne in the tyme of thys Cunradus: For Lewis the Bearded of the lynage of Charles the greate was co≈øin to Gi≈øela. The ≈øame becau≈øe he had longe bene conuer≈øaunt in the courte of the Emperoure, and had bene diligent in many thynges, was made Earle of Thuringen. And by this meanes haue the Lordes of Thuringen their of≈øprynge of Charles the greates bloude.

Benedictus the .vij. was made the .C.li. by≈øhop of Rome after Iohannes the .xx. who beynge driuen out, one Sylue≈øter bought the by≈øhoprycke with money. Therefore Benedictus beyng returned, to the intent he myght ray≈øe factions or commocions agayn≈øt Sylue≈øter, he ≈øolde hys ryght of
the by≈øhoprycke to one that was the thirde, called Gregorius the .vi. And ≈øo did Benedictus geue place to hym: but Sylue≈øter woulde contrarywy≈øeThre bi≈øhops of Rome ≈øtronyng for the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ depo≈øed defende hys ryght again≈øt Gregorius. This controuer≈øye dyd compell the Emperoure Henry the black to come to Rome, who dyd worthely depo≈øe tho≈øe thre mon≈øters from the by≈øhoprycke, and ordeined in ≈øteade of them one Syndeger by≈øhop of Bamberg, who was called Clemens the .ii. the .clii by≈øhop, of whom Henry the blacke was crowned.
About this time began the name of Cardinals toWhen ‚Ä¢ Cardinals began „Äà‚óä„Äâ . be v≈øed: whereby it may be ≈øuppo≈øed, that this ≈øame dignitie in the church, was not elder.

But for ≈øomuche as oftymes happened mo≈øte heuy contencions and ≈øtryfes, of the diuer≈øitie of wylles in makynge of the by≈øhop of Rome, Henry the Blacke made an ordinaunce, that thenceforth no by≈øhop of Rome ≈øhould be cho≈øen, without the con≈øent of the Emperour & al≈øo his confirmacion. This ordinaunce was afterwarde ≈øore foughten again≈øt of the by≈øhops of Rome, in≈øomuche al≈øo, that mo≈øt haynous warres are ry≈øen thereof in the tymes of HeÃÑ ry the fourth and fyfth Emperours.

div.head: Henry the thyrd ≈øurnamed the Black, the .xv. Germane Emperoure.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øte .M.xl. beganne toHenry the .iij raygne Henry the third, called the Black, and raygned ≈øeuentene yeres. Fyr≈øt inuaded he the Bohemes with warr, but they beyng ayded of the Hungarians, ouercame hym. The yere after were the Bohemes ≈øo weried with
warres of Henry, that their prince con≈øtrayned by nece≈ø≈øitie came to Regen≈øpurg, and made hym≈øelfe tributary frely to the Emperour. After that going into Hungaty, warred thre yeares, and takynge in certayne cities, he compelled the Hungarians to demaunde peace. He ≈øubdued al≈øo the duke of Lorain, that he obeied the empire.

At Rome put he down thre by≈øhops at once, ≈øtriuing for the ≈øee, and made a Germane by≈øhop to be by≈øhop there, whoÃÑ they called Clement the .ii. TheÃÑ ceforth ouercame he the SaraceÃÑs by Capua. Afterward came he again into Germany & kept a coÃÑgregatioÃÑ at Mentz, wherein was Leo the by≈øh. of Ro.

Cuno duke of Bayer, whiche was after. S. HeÃÑ ry,Luno duke of Baier. An euel coun≈øayll. &c. tru≈øtyng to the ayde and con≈øpiracion of the HuÃÑ garians, ≈øet hym agai≈øt the Emperoure: for by that meanes entended he to drawe the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the kyngdome to hym. But the Hungarians were ouercome, the duke Cuno was driuen out, and liued all his lyfe a banny≈øhed man in Hungary. The land of Bayer was in the meane tyme wythout a duke and gouernoure.

Before Henry the Black dyed, he cau≈øed hys ≈øonne Henry, fyue yeare of age to be cho≈øen Emperour, and was crowned at Aken, to the inteÃÑt there ≈øhoulde be a certayne heade of the empyre, nether ≈øhould any rumour be for the election. Wherefore the ≈øonne raygned a certayn ≈øpace vnder the mothers protection. The mother of Honry the .iiij. was called Agnes, borne in the county of Pi≈øto in Fraunce.

After Clemens was Dama≈øus the .ij. made the
cliij. by≈øhop of Rome, whiche optayned the by≈øhopricke by force.
Leo the .ix. ≈øucceded Dama≈øus. The ≈øame was in the coun≈øaill kept at Mentz and was conuer≈øaunt wyth Henry the black a whyle afterwarde.

In his tyme Berengarius a deacon of AngeweBerengarius „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ trewe „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ar ‚Ä¢ i the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of Chri≈øtes body and bloud in Fraunce taught, that the true body and bloud of Chri≈øt were not in the breade and wyne, according to Chri≈øtes in≈øtitucion. Leo the by≈øhop of Rome condempned this in the coun≈øaill of Vercelli: but the ≈øedes of this doctrine that were left hath cau≈øed great per≈øecucion to them that came after.
Victor the .ij. the .clv. by≈øhop of Rome ≈øucceded Leo. The ≈øame was before by≈øhop of Eich≈øtet.
Stephanus the .ix. ≈øucceded Victor.
Benedictus the .ix. the .clvij. by≈øhop of Rome ≈øucceded Stephanus.

Nicolaus the .ij. folowed after Benedictus. The ≈øame depo≈øed Benedictus, and is ≈øayde to haue ordeined fyr≈øt, that Cardinals ≈øhall haue aucthoritie to cho≈øe the by≈øhop of Rome. Berengarius was al≈øo condempned againe by hym, and was compelled to reuoke that he had taught of the ≈øacrament.
Alexander the .ij. the .clix. by≈øhop of Rome ≈øucceded Nicolaus, then al≈øo was greate ≈øtrife for the delection.

Gregorius the .vij. before called Hiltebrande was the .clx. by≈øhop of Rome after Alexander. The ≈øame dyd excommunicate and per≈øued Henry the iiij. rai≈øyng al≈øo fearce warres, that he myght get & obteyne, that a by≈øhop of Rome myght be cho≈øen and confirmed wythout the Emperoures con≈øent
and confirmacion, le≈øt the Emperours ≈øhoulde clame any aucthoritie vpon the by≈øhops of Rome to rule them, whereof we ≈øhall ≈øpeake more in Henry the fourth.

div.head: Henry the .iiij. the .xvi. Germane Emperour.Henry y‚Ä¢ .iiij.
div.p: THe yeare of Chri≈øt .M. lvij. began Henry the .iiij. to reigne after that his father was deade, beynge yet a chylde, and raygned fyfty yeares. In this man dyd not onely the vertue of ≈øuche kynde of Emperours fayle, but the empyre of whole Germany began ≈øo to decaye, that afterwarde it neuer coulde nether be brought to his olde ≈øtate, nor recouer his former ≈øtrength. Hiltebrand by≈øhop of Rome was cau≈øer of this lamentableOf how great euell Hiltebrand was occa≈øion. game, who turned neare haÃÑd al Germany vp & down with warres among the princes therof.

In Henry the Emperours chyldhode, dyd Agnes his mother gouerne the empyre, not without pray≈øe: ≈øhe ≈øet Germany and Italy at peace and traÃÑ quilitie. But the by≈øhop of Colen dyd priuely leade away the chylde beyng now twelue yeares of age, and ready to be gyn to beare rule, and in the meane ≈øea≈øon he hym≈øelfe ruled afterwarde the empyre. It is ≈øaide al≈øo that he cau≈øed the Imperiall childe to be brought vp vn≈øemely.

It were longe to reher≈øe here all the cau≈øes and circum≈øtaunces: I wyll onely reher≈øe here brefely the mo≈øt worthy of remeÃÑbraunce. Henry the BlackThe con≈øtitution of Henry the blacke of choy≈øynge the by≈øhop of Rome. father to this Henry, had made a con≈øtitucion of making a by≈øhop of Rome by a mo≈øt wy≈øe adui≈øe, that y‚Ä¢ ≈øame ≈øhould not be done without the knowledge and con≈øent of the Emperoure. But now that Hiltebrand
was come into the ≈øee, he made a decre coÃÑtraryThe tyranny of HiltebraÃÑd in derogati ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the auth ‚Ä¢ ritie of Emperoure. wy≈øe, that the confirmacion of a by≈øhop ≈øhoulde not be demaunded of the Emperoure. But the Emperoure woulde, that this his fathers con≈øtitucion ≈øhould beare effect. Be≈øydes that al≈øo had the Emperoure aucthoritie to geue the by≈øhoprycks of the empyre: but Hiltebrand would not ≈øuffre that al≈øo. For it happened oft, that when one by≈øhop was dead, another was made in his ≈øtead of the Emperoure, and agayne another of the by≈øhop of Rome, whiche dyd then excommunicate the other. Finally came the game to this ende, that the Emperoure was not onely excommunicated, but it was al≈øo coÃÑ maunded, that other greate Lordes of Germany, ≈øhould make another Emperoure. And the mai≈øter of this game was the by≈øhop of Halber≈øtat in Saxony, to do the by≈øhop of Rome a plea≈øure. Wherfore fell from the Emperoure Henry the fourth Otho
‚Ä¢ ha ‚Ä¢ the ‚Ä¢ were that tell „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Henry the ‚Ä¢ ourth „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚Ä¢ i≈øhops plea≈øure. duke of Saxony, Rudolfus duke of Schwaben, to whom was maried the Emperoures ≈øy≈øter germane, and certayne by≈øhops, ≈øpecially Saxons. On the Emperours ≈øyde were the Bohemies, and the lordes Catuly, whom the Emperoure gaue Baierlande, driuyng out Otho the duke of Saxony, and ≈øome by≈øhops al≈øo, whiche di≈øalowed the by≈øhop of Romes tyranny, in derogatyng and takyng away the aucthoritie of Emperours at his plea≈øure. Wherfore they made congregacions al≈øo, and reiectyng the by≈øhop of Rome excommunicacion, excommunicated hym lykewy≈øe. Now went the Emperoure into Italy to treate and fini≈øh this controuer≈øy. In the meane ≈øea≈øon was Rudolfus duke of
Schwaben cho≈øen Emperour of y‚Ä¢ contrary partyRudolfus is made Emperoure of the bi≈øhops at Phorcen. in the town Phorcen, whych was about the yere of oure lorde .M. lxxvii. The by≈øhop of Rome ≈øente Rudolfus a crowne, wherein was wrytten thys ver≈øe. Petra dedit Petro, Petrus dyadema Rudolfo. That is: Chry≈øt the Stone gaue the crowne to Peter, Peter geueth to Rudolfe both crowne and ≈øepter.

Whereby he wolde ≈øygnyfye, that Chri≈øte gaue the Empyre to the by≈øhoppe of Rome, and that he lykewy≈øe geueth it to princes. Therfore came Henry hay≈øtely agayn into Germany. & droue Rudolfus out of Schwaben into Saxonye, and foughte ≈øome battayls wyth hym by the ryuer Vn≈øtrote, in the which were ≈ølayne the by≈øhops of Worms and Magdeburg.

The yeare .M. lxxx. was foughten the la≈øte felde agayn≈øte Rudolfe by Mer≈øburge, and in the ≈øame battayll was Rudolphus ryghte hande ≈øtryken of. Whan euerye man nowe fled into the cytye Mar≈øburge, the hande was brought to the new Emperoure, lyenge in hys bedde, where the by≈øhopsThe complaint of Rudolfus the Emperoure vpon the bi≈øhops. ≈øtoode aboute. The whyche as he ≈øawe, he ≈øayde: Lomy Lordes ye by≈øhops, thys ys the hande, wherewyth I haue promy≈øed my lord Henrye ≈øayeth and loyaltye: iudge ye your ≈øelues now howe godly ye haue coun≈øeled me to decyner from him. Thys is a very my≈øerable complaynte, whyche declareth the troubled mind of the prince to haue iudged it ≈øelf gilty of vprour. Of this wi≈øe dyed Rudolfus about the .iiij. year of his election.
Whome I praye you would it not moue (wythout he be of yron) this ≈øo dredefull example to obey hys magi≈øtrate, & to beware of vproure? Yet were not the by≈øhops in the meane tyme in re≈øte, and ≈øet the ≈øonne al≈øo again≈øt the father. Hiltebrand the by≈øhop boa≈øted to haue ≈øene a vi≈øion in his ≈ølepe, that an vnlawfull Emperoure ≈øhould dye that ≈øame yeare. But thys was Caiphas prophecye: for the puni≈øhmentHiltebrande the by≈øhop of Rome was another Cayphas. fell not vpon Henry, but on the by≈øhop of Romes adherentes.

After this victory came Henry to Rome, and takyng in the citie by force, he toke Hiltebrand the by≈øhop and put hym from his office: and in his ≈øteade was cho≈øen the by≈øhop of Rauenna, called ClemeÃÑs, and of hym was Henry the fourth crowned. As for Hiltebrand died not longe after in exile.

Sigebertus the hi≈øtory writer doth not greatlySigebertus ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ hi≈øtory wryter. pray≈øe Hiltebrande, and doth reprehende the man ‚Ä¢ dedes, that he did di≈øquiet the peaceable ≈øtate of the churche and empyre without greate cau≈øe: and writeth al≈øo, that Hiltebrande when he was dyeng ≈øhould hym≈øelfe haue complayned it, and ≈øhould haue required of Henry by emba≈ø≈øage forgeuene≈ø≈øe of hys tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe. Hiltebrande forbade the prie≈øtes ofHiltebrande did fir≈øt forbyd the Germane prie≈øtes to mary. Germany to mary, and many that were maryed, cau≈øed he to be diuorced.

The yeare of Chri≈øte .M. ciij. when Henry had vaÃÑqui≈øhed the Saxons, & the erle of Mi≈øen Erbert was ≈ølayne, whome the by≈øhops made to tru≈øte to be Emperoure after Rudolfus. Be≈øides that when al maters of Germany and Italy were ≈øet at a ≈øtay, was Henry the fyft cho≈øen Emperoure by Henry
the fourth hys father. Wherefore dyd the by≈øhoppes procure by this Henry, that he ≈øhoulde ry≈øe again≈øt his father, and driue hym out of the empyre. But this greued the good prince greatly. WhereforeHenry the .v. ≈øet to worke by ye by≈øhops be≈øyeged hys father. Henry the ≈øonne makyng a leage the yeare. M C. v. dyd fyr≈øt be≈øyege his father at Mentz: but the princes refu≈øyng to a≈ø≈øault it, Henry the ≈øonne was fayne to departe, and leauyng Mentz went with the hoo≈øt to Norinberg, and gat and ≈øpoyled it inNorinbergh is taken by Henry the, v. the ≈øpace of two monethes. The father per≈øued the ≈øonne, and on both ≈øydes were they a while in their campes by Regen≈øburg: but they came neuer to playne felde by rea≈øon the princes went alwaye betwene. But the ≈øonne warned the father to beware of hys owne ≈øeruauntes, wherefore he fled priuely to Ludich, and dyed there that ≈øame yeare. But when he had lyen vnburied fyue yeares, by rea≈øon of the excommunicacion or cour≈øe of the Romy≈øhe by≈øhop he optayned ab≈øolucion, and was buried at Spire. There are yet wrytynges at thys houre, that were ≈øent to the kynge of Fraunce by Henry the father, treatyng of the iniury of the ≈øonne, and their malice, which ≈øet the ≈øonne again≈øt the father. Reade more of this tragedy in the life of HiltebraÃÑd, prynted ≈øeuerally in Engly≈øhe.

div.head: Of the takyng in and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øyng the citie Hieru≈øalem.
div.p:
IN the tyme of this Henry the fourth began the ≈øettyng forth to warre into Iewry again≈øt the Saracens and Turkes. The fyr≈øt capitayne was Godfre of Bilion,
prince of Lothringe or Lorain. Hym accompaniedGodfre of Bilion. the be≈øt princes and lordes of Gallia.

The yere .M. xcix. Godfre wan the citie Ieru≈øaleÃÑ, and was ≈øtraight waye made kyng. But he refu≈øed to be crowned with a golden crowne there, where Chri≈øtes was crowned with a crown brayded of thornes. This happened foure hundreth thre ≈øcore and eight yeres before that Hieru≈øalem was taken out of the Per≈øes power by Heraclius. But not muche aboue thirtene yeres after became the Saracens lordes of Hieru≈øalem. Many yeares after were the Saracens dryuen out of Hieru≈øalem by the Turkes. About this tyme gat the Chri≈øtiaÃÑs Ieru≈øalem again, and ≈øubdued many cities & contreis there about. They had the realme of Ieru≈øalem. lxxxviij. yeares, vntyll the yere of Chri≈øt a thou≈øand, one hundreth & foure ≈øcore & ≈øeuen. The Souldane wanne Ieru≈øalem againe in the tyme of Frederick Barbaro≈ø≈øa.

div.head: The chaunge of many duchyes in Germany.
div.p:
HOw many mi≈øeries the inwarde warreThe „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ray≈øed in Germany ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the bi≈øhop ‚Ä¢ Rome. of Germany, whiche was ≈øturred by the by≈øhop of Rome wylene≈ø≈øe, hath brought with it, may ea≈øely be gathered thereby, that when the princes and great men were ≈ølayne, the lord ≈øhyppes and dominions were chaunged. Henry the fourth gaue to the Catuly Lordes of Schwaben the lande of Baier. After Rudolphus death gaue Henry the fourth the duchy of Schwaben to Frederick of Stauffen hys ≈øonne in lawe that had maried hys daughter. The auncetry or
kynred of the Frankes dyed in a very ≈øhorte ≈øpace. Ecbertus erle of Mi≈ønia was ≈ølayne. Gebhardus the father of that Lotharius, whiche became afterward Emperoure, was ≈ølayne al≈øo in a battaill: and to conclude, the power of Germane is wholy made feble and turned vp≈øyde downe by this debate of the princes.

Whan Hiltebrande was deade, a by≈øhop called Victor the third of that name was cho≈øen out of the citie of Rome by his companions, in ≈øpete of Clement. But when Victor was deade a litle after, by them was Vrbanus the, ij. cho≈øen by≈øhop of Rome The ≈øame returned to Ro. by their ayde that were‚ñ™ now appointed to go to Ieru≈øalem. Being re≈øtored in the ≈øee, he droue out Clemens.
Pa≈øchalis the, ij. ≈øucceded Vrbanus the .ij. Thi≈ø≈øame was fir≈øt taken by Henry the fyft. Afterward did he con≈øtrayne hym to crowne hym Emperoure.

div.head: Henry the fyft, the xvij. Germane Emperoure.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øte .M. C. vii. beganneHenry the. ‚Ä¢ . Henry the fyft to reigne after his fathers dece≈ø≈øe, and reigned .xx. yeres. Verely he was well rewarded of the by≈øhops, that folowyng their coun≈øails, he warred vpon his father the good Emperoure. Comminge to Rome, he coulde not obtayne the crowne of the by≈øhop of Rome, without he dyd fyr≈øt ordeyne that thenceforth it ≈øhoulde be alowed that both the by≈øhop of Rome and other by≈øhops ≈øhould be made without the Emperours approbating and con≈øent. Be≈øides
that al≈øo was at that tyme ≈øo great an vproure made in the citie of Rome by the by≈øhop of it, that except the Emperoure had defended his lyfe with his owne hande, he had bene lo≈øt. When the Emperour had the ouerhande, many Romanes were put to
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ mple „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ grauÃÑce death and taken pry≈øoners. The by≈øhop was taken al≈øo, and led out of the citie: And when communication was had wyth hym of the coronation & right of makyng the by≈øhop of Rome and other by≈øhops, Pa≈øchalis dyd frely graunt, that Emperours ≈øhuld take to them that prerogatiue, that no by≈øhop of Rome nor other ≈øhould be cho≈øen, without their grauÃÑt. From thence are they returned to Rome, and Henry was crowned Emperoure of Pa≈øchalis.

But after that the Emperoure was departed out of Italy, the by≈øhop turned hys mynde, and makyng an a≈ø≈øemble or coun≈øayll dyd not onely reuoke the graunted priuilege, but dyd al≈øo excoÃÑmunicate and accur≈øe the Emperoure. Whiche thyng when it was ≈øhewed Henry the fyfte, retourning ≈øtraight waye to Rome with a greate power, he droue out the by≈øhop, and ordemed another in his place. In the meane ≈øea≈øon dyd not the by≈øhops of Germany ≈øyt ≈øtyll, whiche dyd againe ≈øet the Saxons again≈øt the Emperoure, ≈øo ‚Ä¢ ore al≈øo, that Germany beynge eft≈øones ≈øtyrred with mutuall debates, dyd mete eche other with di≈øplayde banners, and in the yere M. C. xv. the .xi. daye of February was the battailThe ba „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Mansfeld by MaÃÑ≈øfelde, neare by the wood Catula ‚Ä¢ ia, wherin was ≈ølayne Hoterus Erle of Man≈øfelde.

Wherfore the Emperoure p ‚Ä¢ rceauynge, that this playe coulde not be a≈ø≈øuaged without coÃÑtinuall
battail, nether would the Romi≈øh by≈øhops leaue of, tyll they had oppre≈ø≈øed hym as they had done hys father before: the good prince had aduice to the common peace of the empyre, and renounced frely theHenry the .v. renouÃÑced hys ryght of the choy≈øynge of by≈øhops. right of his priuilege. Therfore as the peace was made betwene the by≈øhop of Rome and Emperour by this occa≈øion, and al≈øo betwene the other lordes, and was proclaymed not farre from Wormes by the Rhene, where greate armies were together on both parties: greate ioye was made in all Germany for this accorde of common peace.

This Henry warred al≈øo in Hollande and Lorayne. As for Lotharius duke of Saxony, who was made Emperour after Henry, came to Mentz in along and vile garment humbly requyryng pardon of the Emperoure. The ≈øame dyd Henry grauÃÑt hym frely of hys ≈øyngular mercy. This Henry had no manchylde, and therefore came the duchy of the Frankes to Conrade ≈øonne to Frederick of Stauffen and Henries the fyftes ≈øy≈øter.
Gela≈øius the .ij. ≈øucceded Pa≈øchalis the .ij. Thi≈ø≈øame was dryuen out of Rome by Henry the fyft, and in hys ≈øteade was Gregorius made by≈øhop. Gela≈øius died in Fraunce in exile.

When Gela≈øius the .ij. was deade, was cho≈øen in Fraunce by≈øhop of Rome Cali≈øtus the .ij. who commyng to Rome, fought ≈øome battayls wyth Gregorius the fal≈øe by≈øhop, whome Henry the fyft had made. At the la≈øt was Gregorius taken, and ≈øet ar≈øwarde vpon an a≈ø≈øe, was caried about the citie. Vnder Cali≈øtus was the peace made with the Emperoure Henry the fyft.
Honorius the .ij. ≈øucceded Cali≈øtÍù∞ the by≈øh. of Ro.

Innocentius the .ij. was made by≈øhop after Honorius. In ≈øpite of this man was Petrus Leonis cho≈øen, who called him≈øelf Anacletus. Of hym was Innocentius driuen out with force. Lotharius a≈ø≈øwaged this rumour, who was crowned Emperoure of Innocentius.

div.head: Lotharius the Saxon, the xviij. Germane Emperoure.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øte .M. cxxvii. was Lotharius
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ s ‚Ä¢ Saxon. duke of Saxony cho≈øen Emperoure by the Electors. who≈øe father Gebhardus was ≈ølayne by Henry the fourth. Lotharius reigned thyrtene yeares.

This Germane empire hath oft ben ≈øhaken with mo≈øte heuy a≈ø≈øaultes. For now agayne is ray≈øed a great and durable vproure again≈øt Lotharius al≈øo. For the Schwaben and Frankes, which had loÃÑg warred with the Saxons toke in euell worth, that the highne≈ø≈øe of the empire came to the Saxons. Be≈øydes that al≈øo were the ≈øonnes of the dukes of Schwaben borne of Henry the fyftes ≈øy≈øter: & therfore did they pretend, that the empire of right ≈øhuld be belongyng to them. Henry the .v. (as is ≈øayd before) gaue to Conradus of Schwaben his ≈øy≈øters hu≈øbande the duchy of Franken. Godfry counte of Palatine was with him, who chofe Conradus Emperoure, & to him did leane the cities of the Schwaben and Franckes.

But Catulus Henry duke of Baierland toke Lotharius parte, for he was Lotharius daughters hu≈øband, wherby al≈øo the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øioÃÑ of Saxony came
to the Baiers by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion hereditare. And tho≈øeThe princes of brun≈ø ‚Ä¢ ig came of the Ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ . al≈øo that now a daies are called princes of Brun≈øwig, are of the Baiers bloud, of Catulus Henry duke of Baier.

That Conradus might prenent Lotharius he went into Italy, and toke in Lombardy, where he was al≈øo crowned with an yron crown. In the meane tyme be≈øyeged & wan Lotharius the cities Sprre, Vlme and Nurenberg, and after that per≈øued he Conradus into Italy. For the Saxon Lotharius beyng more ≈øage and wyly, thought well, that without Germany were well a≈ø≈øured, Conradus coulde not kepe Italy. Wherfore when Conradus knew that both the cities of Germany were lo≈øt, and that no hope of ≈øuccoure was to be loked for out of Germany, to retayne Italy: leauyng Italy, he dyd make a conuencion of peace with Lotharius throughS. Bernarde made the peace betwene y‚Ä¢ Emperours Conradus & Lotharius. the entreatement of ≈øainct Bernarde, and left the empyre that he had taken vpon hym. Lotharius went twy≈øe into Italy. Fir≈øt to a≈ø≈øuage the commotions that were ray≈øed at Rome again≈øt Innocentius the by≈øhop, for choi≈øyng another by≈øhop. After that again≈øt Roger, which had inuaded Campania and Apulia. He droue hym out of Italy: but when Lotharius was deade, Roger returned.

div.head: Of the Roman lawes repared and re≈øtored.
div.p:
LOtharius is not onely pray≈øed for his notable valiauÃÑtne≈ø≈øe in warres, where with he hath ≈øet both Germany and Italy at a ≈øtaye & re≈øt: but al≈øo for his endeuoure in ye
religion and good lawes. In his tyme was in Italy by the quene Mectildis a man of great learnyngWernherus ‚Ä¢ re≈øtorer of y‚Ä¢ lawes. called Wernherus, whome Accur≈øius the lawer calleth oft Irnemerius. The ≈øame founde the bokes of the Romane lawes in the liberaries du≈øted & vnregarded, and brought them to lyght agayne: Lotharius commaunded to v≈øe them openly in ≈øcoles, and to geue ≈øentence agayne after them in iudgemeÃÑ tesThe p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y≈øe ‚Ä¢ profitable ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s of the Rom. lawes. of the empyre. And ≈øo by this meanes was that trea≈øure brought to lyght agayn, whiche none can be more profitable, nor more co≈øtly, namely whereof innumerable profites are flowen. For fir≈øt it is a certaine lawe and conformable to mans rea≈øon re≈øtored to whole Europa: by rea≈øon all nacions, and all other lawes v≈øe this Romane lawe in ≈øearchynge right as a certayne line or carpenters rule: for it is mo≈øte neare≈øt applyed to common hone≈øtie. SecoÃÑdly do thees re≈øtored Romane lawes not a lytle profyte thereto, that they gyue commaundementes of the common behaue ours of this lyfe and be≈øt maners, whiche are no where founde better: I pa≈ø≈øe ouer that the purene≈ø≈øe of the Latine tungue began to flory≈øh agayn, by re≈øtoryng of this lawe as borne again. But when this ≈øtudy of the lawe was in≈øtitute, ≈øtraightwaye were become great and many excellent lawers, whiche bu≈øied both to interprete the lawes, and to ≈øet them againe in vre. Truely, I can not maruaile ynough, that men became ≈øo well learned at that tyme, wherein the v≈øe of the Latine tunge, the hi≈øtories, finally al the auncient Romane di≈øciplines were left of for the whyle: ≈øo that it may ea≈øely be ≈øuppo≈øed, that tho≈øe fyr≈øt lawers were not
onely men of greate diligence in ≈øtudies, but al≈øo greate and wy≈øe men exercy≈øed with muche experience of common matters: For wythout exercy≈øe, had it bene impo≈ø≈øible to knowe the Roman lawes. Wherefore are the ≈øame doctors of the lawe to bee iudged no le≈ø≈øe, than tho≈øe auncient lawiers Vlpianus, Seruius and other.

Azo, whiche is euen the chefe of the expoundersAzo. of the lawe, lyued in the tyme of this Lotharius. After the ≈øame lyued Accur≈øius, the ≈øame al≈øo lyuedAccur≈øius. vntil the time of Frederick the ≈øecond. In the tyme of Henry of Lucelborowe were many and notable doctors, as Bartholus and other. Gratianus, whoBartholus. Gracianus. gathered the Decrees of the common lawe, was al≈øo in the tyme of Lotharius. But before were ≈øuche bookes al≈øo. For of this ≈øorte was a lytle booke written by a by≈øhop of Wormes, whiche at that tyme was v≈øed: we al≈øo haue ≈øene it in our daies. But when the ≈øtudies of the lawe flory≈øhed now euery where, and that the be≈øt learned embraced them,By what occa≈øion the moÃÑ kes are brought to wryte. (as it happeneth mo≈øte commonly in a new thing,) the monkes perceauyng that the knowledge of holy ≈øcripture beganne to coule and be de≈øpy≈øed, for ≈øtudieng the lawe: they al≈øo beganne a ≈øtudye of Theology or diuinitie, and ordeyned ≈øcole di≈øputations in diuine matters, as the lawers dyd in ciuyll matters. Thus beganne the diuinitie ≈øcole, wherof we ≈øhall ≈øaye more hereafter.

div.head: Cunradus a Schwabe, the .xix. Germane Emperoure.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øt .M. cxl. ≈øucceded ConradusConradus a Schwabe. borne duke of Schwaben Lotharius the Saxon in the empyre, who was made prince of the Frankes by Henry the fyft. He reigned fourten yeres. It is no where red that he was crowned of the Romy≈øh by≈øhop. This Cunradus (as we ≈øaid before) ro≈øe again≈øt Lotharius, but he was con≈øtrained to yelde him≈øelf vnder the Emperours power. But when Lotharius was deade, the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of the empire fell vpon Conradus: though Henry duke of Baier & Saxony that had marted Lotharius daughter coueted the empire, and be≈øyeged Conradus at Au≈øpurg. But Conradus the Emperoure mini≈øhed Henries power, & gaue the duchy of Baier to the Erle of Ea≈øtenrich. Howbeit this warre was not very long: for not loÃÑg after died Henry in Saxony, and was laide in Lotharius his wiues fathers graue. After that dyd a prince of Catuli warre with the duke & Emperour CoÃÑradus for the duchy of Baier, but inuain. Wherfore he was afterwarde reconciled againe with the Emperoure, through Frederick that became Emperoure afterward. Conradus with many princesConradus went to Ieru≈øalem again≈øt the Saracens and a great hoo≈øt went to Hieru≈øalem, again≈øte the Saracens Chri≈øtes enemyes, through the coun≈øail of ≈øainct Bernarde, again≈øt the whiche al≈øo toke wapen Lewis kyng of Fraunce: but many ≈øouldioursEmanuel Emperour of CoÃÑ ≈øtantinople ‚Ä¢ s di≈øloyaltie. dyed thorough the di≈øloyaltie of Emanuel Emperoure of Con≈øtantinople. Yet had our men many and great battails in A≈øia and at Hieru≈øalem in the meane ≈øea≈øon. Cunradus returned the fourth yere after into Germany & died, and was buried in
the towne Lorch by Gemund.

In the warre that Conradus had with the Catulies, he toke the ca≈øtel and town Wein≈øburg, that lyeth not farre from the riuer Necehar. Then commaundedThe vertue of noble dames in the citie Wein≈øburg. the Emperour to take al the gentlemen: but the gentle women ≈øhoulde be letten go with ≈øo great packe of goodes as they could cary. TheÃÑ the gentlewomen for≈øakyng the goodes would rather cary away their chyldren. Whiche thing when ≈øom did blame, whiche would haue the yong children be pri≈øoned, ≈øayeng: the graunt was to cary goodes, & not men. The Emperour delited ≈øo in the vertue of the noble women, that he gaue them leaue not only to cary away their childreÃÑ, but al≈øo al their goodes.
Cele≈øtinus the .ij. was by≈øhop of Rome after Innocencius the .ij.
Lucius the .ij. was by≈øhop after Cele≈øtinus.

Eugenius the third was made by≈øhop after Lucius. Again≈øt the ≈øame was another by≈øhop cho≈øen by the Romanes, of whom Eugenius was driuen out: but gatheryng a Frenche ayde, he returned, ouer came his aduer≈øary, and was re≈øtored againe.
Ana≈øta≈øius the .iiij. ≈øucceded Eugenius.

Adrianus the .iiij. was by≈øhop after Ana≈øta≈øius. Of hym was Frederick Barbaro≈ø≈øa or with theWilliam of Sicily. reade bearde crowned Emperoure: but afterward ≈øticked he to William of Sicily, which kept Naples and made the Lombardes obedient to hym, by a moo≈øt haynous coniuracion again≈øt the empyre. HeAn example of the Romi≈øh by≈øh‚ñ™ di≈øloyaltie & tyranny. did excoÃÑmunicate Frederick, & ray≈øed mo≈øt haynous warres in Italy. It is written yt he ≈øhuld haue ≈øaied not long before he died: there is no more wretched
≈øtate in earth then the by≈øhoprick of Rome: and toThe coÃÑplaint of Adrian by≈øhop of Rom. wheÃÑ he ≈øhuld dye. get that by≈øhopryck by bloude, is not to ≈øuccede Peter, but Romulus rather, who flew his owne brother, that he myght haue the monarchy and reigne alone. The≈øe wordes wytne≈ø≈øe ≈øufficiently, that it repented hym of the debate that he had begonne again≈øt the Emperoure.

After Adrianus began a greate diui≈øion. Some Cardinals cho≈øe Octauianus, who was called Victor. Some cho≈øe Alexander the .iij. Frederick Barbaro≈ø≈øa helde Octauianus for the true by≈øhop of Rome. But yet in the meane ≈øea≈øon commaunded he by a coun≈øayll to enquire who ≈øhoulde abyde by≈øhop. But Alexander refu≈øyng the aucthoritie of the coun≈øayll, kepeth hym≈øelfe in Fraunce, and accur≈øeth Frederick. At the la≈øt gat Alexander the by ≈øhopryck by the ayde of the Italians, and returned to Rome, where Frederick came then al≈øo. But Alexander beyng afrayed, fled to Venice, where at the la≈øt, peace was made. But hereof ≈øhall we ≈øpeake more in the hi≈øtory of Frederick.

div.head: Frederick the .i. called Barbaro≈ø≈øa, or wyth the red bearde the .xx. Germane Emperoure.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øte .M. C. lij. was FrederickFrederick y‚Ä¢ fyr≈øt. cho≈øen Emperour, the fyr≈øt of that name, ≈øurnamed Barbaro≈ø≈øa. He gouerned the Empyre .xxxvij. yeares. He was a borne duke of the noble hou≈øe of Schwaben, Conradus ye Emperours brothers ≈øonne, a mo≈øt renovmed prince of hardine≈ø≈øe, valiauntne≈ø≈øe and iu≈øtice.
So farre as I can perceaue by his dedes, it ≈øemeth that Frederick, as a gentle Schwabe, could not paciently beare the≈øe iniuries, that the by≈øhops of Rome dyd hym: and I thynke it came by this, that he was more harde again≈øte them.

In the begynnyng of his empyre, ≈øet he Baierlande and Ea≈øtenriche at one, and re≈øtored to Catulus Henry duke of Saxony, and Henry ≈øonne tooWhen the duchy of Ea≈øten riche began. Lotarius doughters hu≈øbande, Baierlande. He made his Co≈øin Henry Erle of Ea≈øtenryche duke, and ≈øet boundyng borders to ether duchy. Then began fir≈øt the duchy of Ea≈øtenriche. But Catulus Henry kept Baierlande not longe: for he for≈øoke Fredericke in Italy, and rai≈øed new rebellionsWho are the dukes of Baier and counties of Palatine. in Germany again≈øt hym. Wherfore Frederick driuyng away Henry afterwarde, the duchy of Baierlande was geuen to Otho of Witel≈øbach. And of this Othoes bloude are tho≈øe princes borne, which now a dayes haue Baierlande, and the counties Palatine by the Rene. The right of election on the Saxonies behalfe, gaue he to Bernarde prince of Anhalt. Henry flyenge, went into Englande wyth his wyfe and chyldren: but at the la≈øt when he returned, compo≈øition was made, that Catulus HenryLubeck. ≈øhould po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the duchy of Brun≈øwich. But theÃÑ dyd Phillippe by≈øhop of Colen take the countrey We≈øtphalen from the duchy of Saxony withforce.
Frederick be≈øyeged Lubeck, and ≈øubdued it toMilan ‚Ä¢ . the empyre. He compelled al≈øo the kyng of Dennemarck to require peace.

They of Milane rebelled, and went about to brynge the other cities of Italy vnder their ≈øubiection.
For that maner and wylfulne≈ø≈øe to haued ominion, doth la≈øt yet by the Italians: wherfore Frederick goyng into Italy, apea≈øed all rumors. But afterwarde did the by≈øhop of Rome entice the Milaners, and the other cities to a coniuracion again≈øte Frederick, and dyd excommunicate hym. For whicheFrederick was excommunicate by the by≈øhop of Rome. cau≈øe he went nowe the fourth tyme into Italy, he ≈øubdued and ≈øpoyled Milane, and a≈ø≈øayed all the meanes he coulde to alaye the debate betwene the by≈øhop of Rome and hym: but it was inuayne. For Alexander the third by≈øhop of Rome could not be brought to that poynte, that he ≈øhoulde not vexe the mo≈øte gentle prince: wherefore Frederick went to Rome, but Alexander fled to the Venecians. Then was Otho Fredericks ≈øonne ≈øent agayn≈øte the Venecians: who beyng taken in a battayll vpon the water, condicions of peace were accepted. For Frederick the Emperoure ≈øawe that the by≈øhops of Rome coulde re≈øte by no meanes. Moreouer con≈øydered he al≈øo, that be≈øyde that hys ≈øonne was taken, what was chaunged to the Emperours that were afore hym. Wherefore Frederick v≈øed ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion and mo≈øte lowly humblene≈ø≈øe. For he cameThe humilite or lowlyne≈ø≈øe of Frederick to Venice, and layed hym≈øelfe downe before the Churche dore afore the Romy≈øhe by≈øhop, and ≈øuffred hym≈øelfe to be troden with his fete: who commaunded al≈øo to be cried out: Thou ≈øhalt treade vpoÃÑ the adder and coceatrice, and then dyd he ab≈øolue hym at the la≈øt. Frederick ≈øayde contrariwy≈øe, that he dyd not ≈øhewe that lowlyne≈ø≈øe to Alexander, but to Peter. Whereto aun≈øwered Alexander: both to me and to Peter. But what is to be thought of this
dede of the by≈øhop of Rome, that do I committee the reader to iudge. The by≈øhops of Rome ray≈øe warres without any lawfull cau≈øe. For Alexander ≈øtriueth for his priuate election, nether woulde he euer admitte any coun≈øaill, nor any other condicions. And be≈øyde this iniury, dyd he v≈øe al≈øo extremeThe extreme tyranny of Alexander the thyrde by≈øh. of Ro. again≈øt y‚Ä¢ Emperour Frederick. wylfulne≈ø≈øe and pryde again≈øte the hyghe≈øt power of Chri≈øtianitie, when he dyd treade vpon the Emperoure with his fete, whome God commaundeth euen to honoure.

But when this agremeÃÑt was made, he cho≈øe HeÃÑ ry his ≈øonne to be party ruler with hym, the yere of Chri≈øt .M. C. lxxxvj. le≈øt the empyre ≈øhuld be with out a gouernoure, when he toke his yourney into A≈øia. He maried his ≈øonne to CoÃÑ≈øtantia the daughter to Rogerius, by whiche meanes the kyngdome Sicily and Naples came to the empyre & Germanes, and made the young kyng gouernoure of Italy. Not long after went he into A≈øia with a greate preparacion of warre & company of many princes, to recouer again the citie Ieru≈øalem, that was lo≈øtFrederick the fyr≈øt goynge into A≈øia what warres he had. not long before. He toke in many & mighty cities in Cilicia, & vanquy≈øhed the Saracens & Turkes. He made the Souldane ≈øo afraide for hym, that he cau≈øed many of his greate cities to ca≈øt down their walles in Syria, when he did mi≈øtru≈øt to kepe them, & he him≈øelf fled into Egypt. For the kynges of England & FrauÃÑce were already arriued into A≈øia with a great army. But what fortuned when they had gathered a greate hoo≈øt? Fortune whiche is not alwaye good, beganne to turne. Frederick when he had now takeÃÑ the coÃÑtrey Armenia, by rea≈øon of ye
heate, went into a ≈øwyft water with his hor≈øe, and the doughty prince was drowned the yeare .M.C lxxxix. Nether ought it to be maruayll, that Frederick pery≈øhed of this wy≈øe in a ryuer: for hi≈øtoriesFrederick went oft into waters. do make mencion, that he otherwhyles al≈øo went into waters. In the ≈øecond ≈øetting forth vpon Milane, the Italians pitched their tentes on the other ≈øyde of the ryuer Abdua, whiche is no le≈ø≈øe then is the Tems about Sion, and mocked Frederick the Emperoure, who was of this ≈øyde the ryuer with his hoo≈øt: thynkyng, that by rea≈øon the ryuer was betwene them both, they myght mocke the Emperoure wythout daunger. Then did the Emperour ≈øteppe into the ryuer without feare, and commaunded the hor≈øemen to folowe hym. Whiche thynge ≈øeyng the, Italians thought ≈øhoulde neuer come to pa≈ø≈øe, (for ether they laye here and there, or vnadui≈øedly went vp and downe without order,) they toke the flyght, and were ouercome of a ≈ømall company of hor≈øemen. This feate witne≈ø≈øeth that Frederick was a prince of excellent hardine≈ø≈øe‚ñ™ and al≈øo one that doubted not to put hym≈øelfe lyghtely into waters.
The prince of Boheme was made a kyng by Frederick,The prince of Bohem ‚Ä¢ is made a kyng for his ≈øundry and excellent faithfulne≈ø≈øe, that he v≈øed toward Frederick at Milane.
Lucius the .iij. was made by≈øhop of Rome after Alexander.

lg.l: Vrbanus the .iij. ≈øucceded Lucius.
Gregorius the .viij. ≈øucceded Vrbanus.
Clemens the .iij. folowed after Gregorius.
Cele≈øtinus the .iij. was after Clemens.

div.p:
Henry
the .vi. was crowned of hym.

div.head: Henry the .vi. the xxi. Germane Emperoure.
div.p: THe yeare of Chri≈øt .M.C.xC. began HenryHenrye the ≈øyxte. the vi. of that name to raigne after his fathers decea≈ø≈øe, and raygned ≈øeuen yeares. He had great warres in Apulia, and finally ≈øubdued the whole realme. In Germany had he enemyes the by≈øhop of Colen and Lutich or Liege, be≈øyd them al≈øo the Burgundions. In this vproure was the by≈øhop of Lutich ≈ølayne, and the other beynge aba≈øhed by thys my≈øhappe, left of froÃÑ theyr enterpry≈øe, and obeyed frelye. He made hys ≈øonne Frederick yet a chylde Emperour wyth the con≈øent of y‚Ä¢ electors. The election was confirmed with ≈øealed letters of the princes electors. the ≈øame was afterward called Frederick the .ii. But whanFrederick the ≈øeconde. Henry was now dyenge‚ñ™ he committed the warde≈øhyppe of the chylde, and empyres gouernaunce to his brother Philippe, who had the gouernaunce of the empyre, whan Henry was yet alyue.
Innocentius the .iii. was by≈øhop of Rome after Cele≈øtinus.

The ≈øame per≈øued Philippe the Emperour, and it is reported he ≈øhulde haue ≈øayde: He wolde takeThe Romi≈øh by≈øhops crake. awaye from Philippe the Emperours crowne, or hys thre crowned miter ≈øhulde be taken from hym. He made Emperoure Otho the Saxon. But thys frende≈øhyp was not ≈øtedfa≈øt nether: for Otho was excommunicated of the Romy≈øhe by≈øhop not longe after.

div.head: Philippe ≈øonne to Barbaro≈ø≈øa, the .xxii. Germane Emperour.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øt .M.C.xcviii. was cho≈øenPhilippe Emperour. Emperour Philippe the ≈øonne of Barbaro≈ø≈øa, duke of Schwaben, and gouernour of Italy on y‚Ä¢ Emperours behalfe, he raygned ten yeares. In hys tyme ro≈øe greate vproures in Germanye. For whan Henrye was deade, hay≈øtynge out of Italy, Philippe dyd admony≈øh the princes electors of the election had of hys yonge co≈øyn made Emperoure. And that the empyre ≈øhulde haue no alteracyon, ether they ≈øhulde coÃÑmitte to hym the admyni≈øtracyon, or make hym Emperoure, and none other prince. But whan Innocentius the By≈øh. of Rome ≈ømelled that, he dyd earne≈øtly procure by the princes electors that another Emperour ≈øhulde be cho≈øen, ≈øhewyng openly: he coulde not brouke Philippe: for he was di≈øplea≈øed wyth hym, becau≈øe that whan he was gouernoure in Italye, he had done I wote not what agayn≈øt the By≈øhop of Rome wherefore al≈øo he was excommunicated of Innocentius. But nowe had alegat ab≈øolued Philippe of the excommunication, wo al≈øo was puny≈øhed therefore of the By≈øhopp of Rome. But what nede many wordes? The by≈øhop of Ro. hated all Fredericks kinred, & intended‚ñ™ to rout it out. Wherefore was cho≈øen by the electors Emperour Bertholdus duke of zaryngeÃÑ, who be≈øyde yt he was riche, was worthy nopray≈øe in a maner.Bertholdus duke of Ze
‚Ä¢ ingen. Philipp was in the toune Mulhau≈øen, where were come al≈øo many princes, as of Bohemy, Saxony, Baier & Schwaben, of whome he was made
Emperour. But whan the duke of zeryngeÃÑ knewe that he was weaker than Phlippe of pu≈ø≈øaunce and power, he came frely to him, and yelded him≈øelfe as to his lyege lord, refu≈øing to take vpon him the naming of the Emperiall maie≈øty. But the by≈øhopp of Ro. cea≈ø≈øed nothyng the more of his forepry≈øe: but broughte to pa≈ø≈øe that the prince of Brun≈øwich Otho,Otho the fourth. the fourth of that name, ≈øonne to Henrye that fled, was made Emperoure of the by≈øh. of Colen, and county af Palatine. The ≈øame dyd Innocentius confirme and crowne, cur≈øynge and excommunicating Philippe. Wherefore went from hym to Otho not a fewe princes, the prince of Bohemye, the erle of Thuringen Herman and the by≈øhop of Argentine or Stra≈øburg. But yet dyd God in theGod pro≈øpered the bu≈øine≈ø≈øes of theÃÑ that are lawfully called. meane ≈øea≈øon pro≈øper Philips affaires, in≈øomuche that he gouerned the empyre all the tyme of hys lyfe. Fyr≈øt goynge in Al≈øace, he toke in Stra≈øburg and compelled the by≈øhop of Stra≈øburge to yelde hym≈øelfe. In the meane tyme was Otho come tyll Spyre: but he al≈øo was dryuen backe by Philippe into Saxony, and as Philippe folowed now vpon hym into Thuryngen, thether came the kynge of Bohemy, and ye erle of Thuryngen. But they refu≈øyng to geue battayl, yelded theÃÑ≈øelues to Philppe. Afterwarde be≈øyegynge the citye Colen al≈øo, he compelled the by≈øh. to yelde him≈øelfe: who though he had crowned Otho before, yet crowned he Philyppe al≈øo at Achen wyth the Emperyall crowne. Not longe after Otho ≈øtrengthened wyth the ≈øuccour≈øe of ≈øome by≈øhops, he for≈øoke the by≈øhoppe of Colen, becau≈øe he was fallen to Philippe: but than
returned Philippe to Colen, and fought ≈øome feldes wyth Otho, and gat the victory: but Otho fled into Englande.

At the la≈øte whan the princes ≈øawe that Othoes parte was weakened, and that Phylippe kept the empyre, who al≈øo made hym ≈øelfe familiar with the princes. He had to wyfe Irene, doughter to theIrene doughter to the Emperour of CoÃÑ ≈øtantinople. Emperour of Con≈øtantinople: of the which he had foure doughters, whereof he maryed the one to the kynge of Bohemes ≈øonne, another gaue he to the prince of Brabant. Than I ≈øaye, whan the princes ≈øawe all the≈øe thinges, they deui≈øed to make an accorde. To the bi≈øhop of Rome wer Legates ≈øent to make an atonement betwene him and Philippe, and al≈øo that Otho ≈øhuld be taken in fauoure. Wherefore the By≈øh. of Rome ≈øendyng emba≈ø≈øiadours into Germany, Phylippe the Emperoure was ab≈øolued of the excommunicatyon. The agrement was made al≈øo, that Otho ≈øhulde marye one of the dougdters, to the intent the bande of the concorde and familiaritye made, myght the better be kepte betwene both partees. All thys was done.

But whan this agrement and leage was made, Philip dwelt afterward at Bamberg. And vpon a day whan he was letteÃÑ bloud, and the good prince ≈øu≈øpected now no harme, and had in hys chamber no more wyth hym, than the Chaunceler and hys karuer of Walpurch, ther came in to him Otho of Witel≈øpache, who≈øe kynred Friderick the fir≈øt had made honorable & famous, by geuynge him the duchy of Baier. The ≈øame whan he ≈øawe that the Emperour was alone without any company or ayde,
he fell ≈øodenly vpon hym not thinkyng any thing,Philippe the Emperoure was ≈ølayne of Otho of Witel≈øpach and ≈øtroke a greate wounde in the Emperoures necke. The Karuer came runnynge, to helpe hys prince, but the murtherer by rea≈øon of hys ≈øwyftne≈ø≈øe e≈øcaped. Thys wouÃÑd was deadly to Philipp: and as he was deade, he was buryed, at Bamberg. But afterwarde was the bodye dygged vppe, and brought to Spyre by Fridericke the .ii. Vpon the ≈øtone that lyeth on the graue, is written Philipp of Bamberg. Nether wanted Otho of Wytel≈øpacheAn example of vengeaunce. the murtherer finally his worthy puny≈øhment: for he hym ≈øelfe was ≈ølayne al≈øo not longe after.

div.head: Of the in≈øtitution of the freres beggynge ordres.
div.p: IN the tyme of Philippe founded DominicusDominicus. Franci≈øcus. and Franci≈øcus the Orders of beggynge Freres. For the monkes or chanons that were ryche the ≈øame beynge now become mighty lordes, de≈øpi≈øing the ≈øeruice of teachynge in the Churche or congregacyon, went to warre wyth ye Emperoures and princes. Therfore beganne the≈øe two men than to preache, and toke to their companions ≈øobre and peaceable men, as men geuen to learnynge and thus beganne that thinge. After that began more orders after the example of the≈øe, as it commeth moo≈øt communely to pa≈ø≈øe, as oft as new thynges begynne to be wondered at. But as nothyng remayneth ≈øtedfa≈øt alway, and durable in his degre, in mens affayres: euen ≈øo do we ≈øe the orders of Freres and monkes to lo≈øe theyr ≈øtate and doctrines.

div.head: Otho the fourth, the .xxiii. Germane Emperoure.
div.p: THE yeare of Chri≈øt, M.CC.ix. afterOtho the fourth. that Philippe was deade, fell the maie≈øtye of the empyre to Otho prince of Brun≈øwich, who was cho≈øen Emperoure afore al≈øo agayn≈øte Philipp. He raygned after Philips decea≈øe foure yeares. But wythin the≈øe foure yeares went he fyr≈øt to Rome, and receaued the Imperiall crowne of Innocentius. In Italy v≈øed he a very kynglye and moo≈øte co≈øtly apparelynge, and ≈øhewed a notable grauitye toward all princes and cityes, in≈øomuch, that they all dyd humbly wor≈øhyp hym. After hys coronacion toke he ≈øome imperyall cityes, whyche the Romy≈øh by≈øh. dyd po≈ø≈øede: but thys was an occa≈øyon of the breche of frende≈øhyp with the by≈øh. of Rome. Wherefore Innocentius dyd accur≈øe Otho, euen whan he was yet pre≈øent in Italy: and before Otho came agayne into Germany, he ≈øent amba≈ø≈øadours to the princes, that they ≈øhould choy≈øe another Emperoure, namely Frederick the ≈øeconde, ≈øonne to Henry the vi.

It was very proudly and cruellye done of theThe pryde and cruellye of the by≈øhoppes of Rome. By≈øh. of Rome, ≈øo to excommunicate and accur≈øe the Emperoures, nether to excommunicate them only, but al≈øo to put them from the empyre, ≈øo that one can thynke no hone≈øtye in the≈øe dedes of the Romy≈øh by≈øhoppes, ≈øpecially yf ye ponder and way all the cau≈øes and rea≈øons. All the≈øe were excommunicated in a rowe, and yet were they myghtye and wy≈øe Emperoures, that haue brought to pa≈ø≈øe great and notable thinges.

lg.l: Henry the fourth a Franke.The Emperours that were excommunicated by the by≈øhops of Rome.
Henry the fyfth a Franke.

div.p:
The yeare of Chri≈øte .M.CC.xii. Otho beyng come agayne into Germany, though he knew that the princes myndes were ≈øet agayn≈øt him, yet poynted he a day of parlament at Norinberg, and admony≈øhed the princes, that they ≈øhulde not graunt the bi≈øhops of Ro. that authoritye, that they ≈øhulde put downe Emperoures at theyr plea≈øure: for the empyre pertayneth not to Romy≈øh by≈øhops, but to the Germane princes. He brought ≈øome princes to his mynd with this admonition, and fell vpon HermanHerman county of Thuringen. S. Elizabeth erle of Thuryngen the father of erle Lewys, to whome. S. Ely≈øabeth was ≈øpou≈øed. For erle Herman, to do the By≈øhoppe of Rome plea≈øure, ≈øet hym≈øelfe agayn≈øt the Emperour, as a man condemned wyth by≈øhoppe of Romes excommunicatyons and cur≈øes. But afterwarde was Otho for≈øaken of all the princes, except one erle of March in Mi≈øen. For Fryderycke the yonger, enemy to Otho, was alreadye come into Germany: be≈øyde that by the by≈øhoppe of Romes procurynge, was the Frenche kynge in armes agayn≈øte Otho. But whan tydynges came to Otho of Frideryckes commyng he prepared hym to go agayn≈øte hym into Al≈øa≈ø≈øe, and was wyth hys hoo≈øte at Bry≈øacke: howe beyte beynge de≈øtytute of all the ayde of
hys, he was con≈øtrayned to flye into Saxony. But than repayring an hoo≈øte, and beyng holpen of the kynge of Englande, he went into low Germany, agayn≈øt the Frenche kynge, of whome he was ouercome, and dyed afterwarde, the yeare .M. CC. xviij. He lyued wythout the tytles of thempyre .v. yeares.

div.head: Friderick the .ij. the .xxiiij. Germane Emperoure.
div.p: THe yeare of Chri≈øt .M. CC. xiij. was cho≈øenFriderick the ≈øecond. Emperoure Friderick the .ii. of that name, the ≈øonne of Barbaro≈ø≈øa, kinge of Naples and Cicily, and duke of Schwaben, whan Otho was put downe, and was crowned Emperoure at Achen. He raygned ≈øeuen and twenty yeares. Yet before he dyed, was he depryued fyue yeares of the Empire, by Innocentius the By≈øh. of Rome. Noman can pitye ynough the ca≈øe of thys laudable Emperoure, that he was endued wyth many and noble vertues: and yet in the mean ≈øea≈øon ≈øuffred he moo≈øt extreme and heuy per≈øuinges of Romane by≈øhops. He was verye well learned in many languages. For he knew perfectly the Latine, Greke, Germane and Saracens languages. Be≈øydes thys ≈øet he forth al≈øo the di≈øciplines of good ≈øciences. He brought to pa≈ø≈øe that the bokeThe ≈øcience of A≈øtronomye was brought to lyght agayn by Friderik the .ij. of Ptolome, called Almage≈øtuÃÑ was tran≈ølated out of the Saracens language into Latyn, and by that meanes the doctryne of A≈øtronomye, whyche noman had taughte many yeares before in Europa, was brought to lighte.
Hys fyr≈øte warre had he in Germanye agayn≈øte Otho the .iiii. by the bi≈øhop of Romes coun≈øel: but he had the ≈øame rewarde for it, that other Emperours afore him haue had.
The ≈øeconde warre had he in Brabant, agayn≈øte the duke of Brabant and Othoes adherentes, and re≈øtored Lorain againe to the Germane empyre.

The yeare of oure lorde .M. CC. xx. was Fridericke crowned of Honorius the .iii. Emperoure. Two erles in Tu≈øcia had taken in ≈øome cityes that belonged to the empire, the which whan Friderick had taken agayne, the erles that were driuen out, fled to Honorius by≈øh. of Ro. who toke them in hys defence and commaunded Friderick, to re≈øtore theÃÑ into the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the cityes, that he had taken from them.
