But whan Friderick refu≈øed that, Honorius excommunicated hym, ≈øettyng a≈øyde all the former loue.

The yeare .M. CC. xxii. came Friderick again into Germany, and holding a parlameÃÑt at Wyrtzpurg, he made Henry his yonger ≈øon felowgouernoure of the empyre, and was crowned at Achen.Henry the ≈øonne was taken by Frideryke hys father. But afterwarde was the ≈øame Henry taken by his father, becau≈øe he had made a leage with certayn cityes of Lombardy agayn≈øt the father: & while the father liued yet, died he of ye filthine≈ø≈øe of the pri≈øon.

Though the city Hieru≈øalem, was now lo≈øte, yet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the Chri≈øtians other great and mighty cytyes in Siria. But whan the power of the Turkes grewe dayly more & more, and the fortune of ye Ioannes kyng of Hie-ru≈øalem. Chri≈øtiaÃÑs went back: Ioannes came to Rome, who had yet the title of ye king of Hieru≈øaleÃÑ, and de≈øyred
ayde of Honorius the by≈øhop of Rome, and optayned by Honorius, that Friderick who was accur≈øed, was ab≈øolued. Wherefore Fridericke and the Germane princes con≈øented frelye to make an armye for the delyueraunce of the cytye Hieru≈øalem: and the kyng of Hieru≈øalem gaue Iole hys doughter in maryage to Friderick the Emperoure. WherebyWhy the kynges of Sicyly clayme the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tle of Hieru≈øalem. it commeth, that yet at this houre the kynges of Sicily a≈øcrybe to them the title of the realme of Hieru≈øalem. Fridericke the Emperour than went wyth a great army, well furny≈øhed to Hieru≈øalem and wyth hym many princes of Germany, among the which was al≈øo Lewis y‚Ä¢ landtgraue, to whomLewis the Landtgraue S. Eli≈øabeth was maried, & the ≈øame dyed in that ≈øettynge forth at Brundu≈øium.

The yeare .M. CC. xxviij. went Fridericke to Hieru≈øalem, and dyd hys bu≈øyne≈ø≈øe ≈øo, that the Souldane gaue hym frely agayne not only Hieru≈øalem, but many other cytyes there about. Friderick was crowned at Hieru≈øalem the yeare .M. C C. xxix. He cau≈øed the citye Hieru≈øalem to be made ≈øure agayn≈øte the power of the enemyes. He made treuce with the Souldane for ten yeres. All thys ≈øhewed he by a letter to the by≈øhop of Ro. and requyred ab≈øolucion of the cur≈øe: for by thys Gregorye was he accur≈øed al≈øo. I wote not for what title in the kingdome of Sicily. But it was a ≈ømall matter for the by≈øhop of Rome to deny to the Emperoure the ab≈øolution: for this gyle al≈øo or rather iniury had he done to Frederick being ab≈øent. For he ≈øet y‚Ä¢ Italian cities again≈øt him, & toke in by force ≈øome cityes in his patrimonial realme Naples. By
thys con≈øtraynt was Friderick driueÃÑ to come back agayn into Sicilye, and to re≈øcue his realme come by inheritaunce, from feare of daunger. Although the by≈øh. of Ro. had ben ≈øore di≈ø≈øoial again≈øt the Emperour in his ab≈øence, yet required he ab≈øolution ≈øo lowly, that he promy≈øed he wolde holde the kyng dome of Sicily of him by fealtye. Be≈øydes this al≈øo cau≈øed he the princes of Germanye to come into Italy, that at the lea≈øt by them myght the debate betwen hym and the Emperour be alayed. Therfore dyd Gregorius ab≈øolue the Emperour agayne the yeare of Chri≈øte .M. CC. xxx.

After yc came the Emperour Friderick the thyrd time into Italy, and warred in Ea≈øtenrich agayn≈øt the Hungarians, & toke the eyty Vienne the which that ≈øhe ≈øhuld be & remain an emperial city, he wold haue it confirmed with letters geuen there vpon.

The yeare .M. CC. xxxviij. Whan Fridericke went agayn into Italy, they of Milan ro≈øe agayn≈øt him, and many other ≈øtrong cityes. To Milan dyd Friderick great harme: for the which cau≈øe the city es makynge an aliance wyth the by≈øhop. of Ro. conFriderick y‚Ä¢ ij. is excom-municated y‚Ä¢ thyrd time. ≈øpired again≈øt Friderick the Emperour whome for this cau≈øe Gregorius the Romy≈øh by≈øhop doth excommunicate the third time, and condemneth him for an heretike, ≈øtearing al≈øo the Venecians to war vpon him. Friderick with opeÃÑ writynges dyd complain of the iniury done to hym, and in the meane tyme dyd he al≈øo humbly require ab≈øolution of the by≈øhop of Ro. Ther were many of the Cardynals, whiche alowed not the by≈øh. of Romes coun≈øels. But whan Frederick could by no meanes optayne
pardon of Gregorius, nece≈ø≈øitye compelled Frederyck to defende hym≈øelfe: he had al≈øo his faction or diui≈øion. For at that tyme was Italy diuyded in Guelphies and Gibelines, the Gibelini were for the Emperoure, and the Guelphi were wyth the By≈øhop of Ro. Ether name beynge brought vp in Germany, was tran≈ølated and brought ouer intoGuelphi. Italy. For the kynred of the Guelphi, had continuall hatred agayn≈øt Fredericks bloude. Whereof al≈øo they were called Guelphi, as alwaye hatefullGuelphi. enemyes of Fredericke. As for the ≈øpring of Fredericks kynred was of the Weiblings, whereof they are called Guiblings, which the Italians (chaunginge the name) do call Gibelini.

The by≈øh. of Ro. con≈øtrayned by great nece≈ø≈øitie dyd proclayme the cro≈ø≈øe and pardon agayn≈øt Friderick the Emperoure, as though he were manyfe≈øtly vngodly, and de≈øtroyer of the religion. Friderick toke that very euell: he be≈øyeged Rome, but drue back agayne wythout takyng it, and toke the citye Rauennas.

The yeare of Chri≈øt M. CC. xlv. Innocentius the iiij. holding a councel at Lyons in Fraunce, depo≈øedFrideryk y‚Ä¢ Emperoure ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ depo≈øed of y‚Ä¢ empyre by the byth. of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . Friderick of the empyre, v≈øynge therto the Frenchmens ayde: and by letters he ≈øhewed the princes Electors, to choy≈øe another Emperoure. But they made Emperoure Henry the Landtgraue of Thuringen. The ≈øame was ≈ølayne before the citye Vlme wyth an in≈øtrument of warre.

Friderick buylded a new citye in Italy, whiche was called Victoria. Whan he wanted ≈øyluer, heVictoria ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ yty ‚Ä¢ . cau≈øed to make a coyne of lether, y‚Ä¢ he mighte haue
where wyth to pay his men of warre: but ≈øo ≈øooneFridericke coynet ‚Ä¢ ether in tyme of nede. as he had gotten ≈øyluer, he ≈øhulde geue them good and lawful mony for the lether coyne, which thing he dyd liberally. But now whaÃÑ he could loke for no more ayde out of Germany: and that be≈øydes thys hys ≈øonne Encius was taken, who al≈øo dyed in the pre≈øon, he was ≈øore di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, and went into Apulia were he al≈øo dyed the yeare .M. CC. l. Some wryt that he was poi≈øonned. Yee ≈øurely, the moo≈øt holy fathers coulde not re≈øt, without they ≈øawe the good prince clene rydde out of the waye. The kingdome of Naples left he to hys ≈øonne & heyre Cunradus. As for Italy remayned alwaye after diuyded. For one part helde wyth the empyre, another wyth the by≈øhop of Rome, vntyl the powers of the Venecians and of them of Mylane beganne after to growe and increa≈øe.
Honorius the .iij. ≈øucceded Innocentius the .iij. of whome Friderick the .ii. was crouned, and after warde excommunicated.
Gregorius y‚Ä¢ .ix. was after Honorius, of whome was Friderick lykewy≈øe accur≈øed.
After Gregorius was Cele≈øtinus the .iiij. by≈øh. of Rome.
After Cele≈øtinus was Innocentius the .iiij. The≈øame depo≈øed Friderick from the empyre, and accur≈øed hys ≈øonne Cunradus.

div.head: Cunradus the .iiij. the xxv Germane Emperour.
div.p: THe yeare of Chri≈øt .M. CC. l. raignedC ‚Ä¢ nradus the fourth. Conradus the ≈øonne of Fridericke after hys fathers decea≈ø≈øe, but he was excommunicated by Inocentius the .iiij. Henry the Landtgraue of Thuryngen ouercame hym by Francoforde, whyle hys father Frederick was yet alyue. Some wryte that thys warre was after hys fathers death, by Wyllyam the Landtgraue. But whan Conradus perceaued that he was de≈øtitute of the Germane princes ayde he gat him into his hereditary kyngdome Naples, and there he dyed the yeare .M. CC. liij.

div.head: The ende of the dukes of Schwaben.
div.p:
CVnradus, of whome we haue now ≈øpoken, had a wyfe of the Baiers bloude, of the whiche he had a ≈øonne Conradinus who was noury≈øhed and brought vp in hys hereditary duchy of Schwaben, and after hys fathers decea≈ø≈øe wolde go to Naples hys heredytary kyngdome. But Clemens the bi≈øhop of Rome called Charles the Frenche kynges brother into the realme of Naples agayn≈øt hym. Conradynus for ≈øo muche as he was duke of Schwaben, had a greate bende and hoo≈øte of Germanes about hym, and at the begynnynge had he greate vyctoryes. But at the la≈øte were Conradinus the ≈øonne of Conradus, and Fryderyck duke of Ea≈øtenriche taken by a trayne. Be≈øydes thys were they entreated more vn≈øemelye than was pertaynynge and put to ≈øhame. At the la≈øte were they beheaded throughe the coun≈øell of the Romy≈øhe by≈øhop.
O notable crueltye. He mu≈øt be euen as harde as aThe notable cruelty of Clemens bi≈øhop of Ro. agayn≈øt CuÃÑ radinus. ≈øtone verely, whome the examples of ≈øo great cruelty dyd not moue, namelye ≈øo noble a kynge, borne of≈øo many Emperoures, to be ≈øo ≈øhamefullye put to death by Clemens the Romy≈øh by≈øhop, without any ryghte or rea≈øon. Ther are yet euen at thys houre writinges, which were written at that time, in the which the good prince complayneth of the iniury, and rehear≈øeth at length the whole matter orderly: ≈øo that it is no doute, the bi≈øhoppes of Rome haue v≈øed playne tiranny again≈øt Conradinus.

div.head: Wiliam, the, xxvi. Germane Emperour.
div.p: THe yeare of Chri≈øt M. C. C. liiij. wasWilliam Emperoure. cho≈øen Emperoure Wylyam counte of Holland. It is ≈øayde he was an hone≈øt manered prince, and of notable innocency of life: but he was ≈ølayn by the Fri≈øelanders the yerre. 1256.

div.head: Vacation of the Empyre.
div.p:
WHan thys Wiliam was dead, the empire ≈øtode with out a certayne emperoure ≈øeuentene yeares, and that not wythout great de≈øtruction of the Germane nacion. Thys mi≈øchaunge grewe by the cyuyl warres, that were ray≈øed in the empyre by the by≈øh. of Ro. Now whan the debate was ry≈øen amonge the ElectorsAlfon≈øus kynge of Spayne and a≈øtronomiaÃÑ. for the choy≈øe, ≈øome cho≈øe Alfon≈øus kyng of Spayne Emperoure, becau≈øe he was a very wy≈øe man, and endued with notable vertues. As for thys Alfon≈øus is he, who not only had hys plea≈øure in the ≈øcience of A≈øtronomye, but al≈øo augmented
and ameÃÑded the ≈øtudy thereof with many bokes wrytten. Thoughe Alfon≈øus was admony≈øhed by the by≈øhop of Rome to take vpon hym the Emperyall maie≈øtye: yet refu≈øed he it earne≈øtly, becau≈øe of the vncertayn faythfulne≈ø≈øe and vn≈øtable concord of the Romy≈øh By≈øhops wyth the Emperours. The other parte of the Electors cho≈øe Richard, the king of Englandes brother, and brought hym vntyll Ba≈øyll: but he was not accepted of the Empyre.
Alexander the .iiij. ≈øucceded after Innocentius. At thys time lyued Albertus the greate. and Thomas Aquinas.
Vrbanus the .iiij. was after Alexander.
Clemens the .iiij. ≈øucceded Vrbanus. Thy≈ø≈øame cau≈øed Conradynus Conradus ≈øonne to be beheaded.

Whan Clemens was deade, was the ≈øee voyde two yeares through the di≈ø≈øen≈øion of choy≈øynge a By≈øhop at the la≈øt was Gregorius the .x. cho≈øen. The ≈øame admony≈øhed the Electors in the begynnynge of hys by≈øhopryck, to choy≈øe agayne an Emperoure wyth egall con≈øent, le≈øte the ≈øtate of the empyre dyd wholy decaye.

div.head: Rudolfe the .xxvij. GermaneRudolf erle ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Haby≈øburge. Emperoure.
div.p:
THe yere of Chri≈øt .M. CC. lxxiij. was Rudolfe cho≈øen Emperour the erle of Habi≈øburge, and counte prouincial of Al≈øace. He raygned .xix. yeares. He was confirmed of the By≈øhopp of Ro.
For the Emperoure and by≈øhop of Rome came together at Lau≈øana euen accordyng to the ≈øaieng of the≈øe two ver≈øes of auncient men.
Twelue hundreth thre ≈øcore and thertene yere, dyd ≈øtande.
Lau≈øana, tyll the pope and the kyng came thether into that lande.

Howbeit Rudolfe went not into Italy, nether receaued he the Imperiall crowne. He was wont to reher≈øe E≈øops fable of the Foxe, which ≈øaid to the Lion ≈øicke in his denne: ≈øhe were afrayd to come in therefore, becau≈øe ≈øhe ≈øawe the foot≈øteppes of bea≈øtes that were gone in, but not of bea≈øtes that were come out. That lykewy≈øe he dyd con≈øyder, how his aunceters went oft into Italy with greate hoo≈øtes: but moo≈øte commonly returned home euell intreated. Yet in the meane ≈øea≈øon ≈øent he a Lieutenaunt into Italy, who was receiued of the be≈øtpart of the Italian cities.

The Bohemies and Baier with≈øtode Rudolfe at the fyr≈øt, but he ≈øubdued Baierlande forth with. Othacarus kyng of the Bohemies wold not obey, and be≈øydes that helde Ea≈øtenriche, (that was now without heire, & belongyng to the empyre) again≈øt ryght and rea≈øon. Wherfore Rudolphe ≈øent the Burggraue of Norenberg into Bohemy, to ≈øhewe the kyng on the Emperours behalfe, to obeye, andOthacarus hy ‚Ä¢ g of the Bohemes. to voyde out of Ea≈øtenryche: but Othacarus refu≈øed both. Wherfore after muche rea≈øonynge vpon the matter, brought Rudolphe armed ho≈øtes into Ea≈øtenryche, and toke it in. He be≈øieged the citie Vienne, & fought a great battaill by Nider≈øbrug‚ñ™
in the yeare .M. cclxxviij. In that battayll was Othacarus ≈ølayne. Of this wy≈øe was Ea≈øtenriche at the la≈øt brought vnder Rudolphes dominion, and after that made he Albert his ≈øonne duke there: ≈øo that henceforth Ea≈øtenriche by this meanes is holdenAlbert duke ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Ea≈øteÃÑrich of the empyre by fealtie or benefite. Moreouer the princes of Ea≈øtenriche haue their offpringe of this Alberte, vntyll the mo≈øte pray≈øe worthy Charles the Emperoure that now is, & his brother kyng Ferdinande.

Rudolphe the Emperoure ≈øhewed high fauour and gentlene≈ø≈øe towarde Wence≈ølaus Othacarus ≈øonne: for he left hym the kyngdome of Bohemy, and gaue hym his daughter in mariage. ThisWen ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈ølaus „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ g of Bo
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ma
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . Wence≈ølaus is canoni≈øated for a ≈øaynt, and is wor≈øhypped. Rudolphe ≈øubdued the Bourgundians al≈øo. In Al≈øace dyd he take by violence tho≈øe cities that rebelled and con≈øpyred agayn≈øt hym, and puny≈øhed them worthely: amonge tho≈øe were Hageno ‚Ä¢ , Colmar, Tzurig and Berne.
The yeare .M. cclxxxvi. dyd he inuade the Erle of Wirtenberg, and be≈øyeged the citie Studtgard: at the la≈øte was an accorde made by the by≈øhop of Mentz.

The yeare .M. ccxc. had Rudolphe a great parliament at Erfurde‚ñ™ and by the aide of the citie ErfurdeErfurde. did he ≈øpoyle & ca≈øt downe about .iij. ≈øcore holdes in Thuringe. O ‚Ä¢ this wy≈øe fynally dyd Rudolfe bryng the troubled & full of ≈øedicion e≈øtate of Germany, whyle it had no certayn Emperours to a peaceablene≈ø≈øe, and dyd in a maner ≈øet vp the decayed empyre. He dyed the yere of Chri≈øt M. ccxcii.
Innocencius the .v. ≈øucceded Gregorius the .x.
Adrianus the .v. ≈øucceded Innocencius.
Iohannes the .xxi. a phi≈øicion ≈øucceded AdrianÍù∞

When Iohannes was deade, Nicolaus the .iij. was made by≈øhop of Rome. He went about to geue his two co≈øins the two kyngdomes of Italy, that the one ≈øhould be kyng of Hetruria, the other kyng of Lombardy: For the Romy≈øh by≈øhop ≈øawe that Rudolphe had more then ynough to do in Germany, and thought he coulde not therefore come into Italy. But the imperiall cities wyth≈øtode the by≈øhop of Romes enterpry≈øes, that they could not pro≈øper, and Rudolphe ≈øent a Lieutenaunt into Italy al≈øo.

lg.l: Honorius the .iiij. was by≈øhop after Nicolaus.
Nicolaus the .iiij. was by≈øhop after Honorius.

div.head: Adolfe the .xxviii. Germane Emperoure.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øt .M. ccxcij. was AdolfeAdolfe couÃÑte of Na≈ø≈øau Emperoure. counte of Na≈ø≈øau cho≈øen Emperour. The ≈øame was before in greate e≈øtimacion by Rudolphe. Be≈øydes that was his brother by≈øhop of Mentz, and by his voyce in the election was he holpen to be made Emperoure. He raygned ≈øyxe yeares, and was depo≈øed from the empyre by the Electours: For hys ≈øub≈øtaunce was not ≈øufficient to ≈øu≈øtayne the co≈øtes of the Emperyall hyghne≈ø≈øe: Be≈øydes that was he very in fortunable in di≈øpatchynge greate thynges. The warre, worthy of remembraunce that he hath had, was that he brought an army into Thuryngen. For Albert Landtgraue of Thuringen had a
≈øtryfe wyth his ≈øonne Dieterus, and Frederick ≈øurnamed Gnawed cheke. And the ≈øame ≈øolde to Adolfe the Emperoure the prouinciall Erldome of Thuringen. He al≈øo endeuoured to make his kynreds nobilitie more renowmed, and went into Thurinvan, and dyd much harme to it. He be≈øyeged Crutzberg, Franken≈øtein and Friburg: But Frederick droue him back agayn. Howbeit to apeace ≈øundry & many perturbacions that were at that tyme in the empyre, it was requi≈øite to haue a more puy≈ø≈øaunter heade in Germane. And therefore the princes Electors makyng an a≈ø≈øembly at Mentz, they cho≈øe Albert duke of Ea≈øtenrich, ≈øonne to the Emperour
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ du ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øte ‚Ä¢ rich Rudolphe. But for a≈ømuche as Adolfe would kepe the empyre by force, duke Albert went again≈øt hym with an army, and they fought fearcely together by Worms. In that battayll was Adolfe ≈ølayne the yeare .M. ccxcviij. as the≈øe ver≈øes folowynge do witne≈ø≈øe.

lg.l: The yeare thou≈øand, thre hundreth two le≈ø≈øe.
Was through the ≈øwearde kynge Adolfes decea≈ø≈øe.

div.p: After Nicolans the .iiij. was Cele≈øtinus the .v. made by≈øhop of Rome. The ≈øame leauynge the by≈øhoprycke became an heremite.

After Cele≈øtinus became Bonifacius the .viij. By≈øhop of Rome. It is ≈øayde that Cele≈øtinus was begyled by thys man with a voyce ≈øpoken to hym through a rede or pype, as though it wer come out of heauen, that he ≈øhould for≈øake the by≈øhopricke, & ordeyne Bonifacius. He ray≈øed greate warres in Italy. He dyd excommunicate the Frenche kyng,
and gaue the tytle of the Frenche kyngdome to Alberte the Emperoure, that by this meanes at the la≈øt the Garmanes and frenchemen might come to ≈øtrokes. At the la≈øt was Bonifacius taken, and dyed in the pry≈øon. And hereby commeth that it isA feate ≈øaieng by Bonifaci ‚Ä¢ the .viij. ≈øayde of hym: He entred as a Foxe, he reygned as a Wolfe or Lion, he died as a Dogge.

div.head: Albert the .i. xxix. Germane Emperoure.
div.p: the .M .cc. xcviij. yere of Chri≈øt began AlberteAlbert Emperoure duke of E≈øtenriche. duke of Ea≈øtenriche, ≈øonne to Rudolphe the Emperoure to raygne. He ruled the empire ten yeres: he ouercame in battaill Adolfe the Emperoure. At the fir≈øt would not bonifacius confirme Albertus empyre: afterwarde did he frely coÃÑfirme it, to do the Frenche kyng a ≈øpite, and geuyng Albert the title of the kyngdome of Fraunce, he ≈øet hym agayn≈øt the Frenche kynge. But the kyng of Fraunce geuyng hys daughter to Alberts ≈øonne, he appea≈øed hym, that he ≈øhould enterpry≈øe no enimitie agayn≈øt hym. He made a ≈øettynge forth agayn≈øt Bohemy, and made his ≈øonne kyng of Bohemy. He dyd ≈øo tame Bohemy and Mentz, whiche made fyndely confederacions together that they obeyed the empyre.

At the la≈øt was he ≈ølayne of his brothers ≈øonne & ≈øome erles of Ea≈øtenryche. It was happely Gods plea≈øure ≈øo, le≈øt the man≈ølaughter that he had done again≈øt Adolfe the Emperoure ≈øhould be vnpuny≈øhed. For though he was not of lyke power: yet in the meane ≈øea≈øon ought he to haue wor≈øhipped him as his lorde, ordeyned of God. The kyllers of hym
were puny≈øhed al≈øo. For God letteth not manquellers
‚Ä¢ n example of vengeauÃÑce vnpuny≈øhed.
Benedictus the .x. was by≈øhop of Rome after Bonifacius the .viij.

div.head: The remouing of the Romy≈øh by≈øhops ≈øe from Rome into Fraunce.
div.p: WHen Benedictus the .x. was deade, Clemens the .v. was made by≈øhop of Rome. The ≈øame dwelt at Lions in Fraunce, & ab≈øolued the Frenche kyng of the excommunication. Wherfore ≈øence that tyme, which was the yeare .M. cccv. was the by≈øhop of Romes ≈øee tran≈ølated from the citie Rome, to Auinion in Prouence a contry of Fraunce .xvii. yeres.

At this tyme were the Fratri ‚Ä¢ elli, whiche were
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ricelli. euen of lyke opinion with the Anabapti≈øtes, that in oure dayes go a≈øtraye: their opinion was, that noman ≈øhould haue ought propre or of hys owne, that Chri≈øten men ≈øhould not gouerne coÃÑmon welthes, and ≈øuche lyke madde opinions had they.

div.head: Of the Turkes.
div.p: IN the tyme of Albert of Ea≈øtenriche, began the kynred of Othomanus to growOthomaÃÑnus among the Turkes in power and e≈øtimacion: of who≈øe bloude are ≈øpronge tho≈øe kynges of the Turkes that raygne at this tyme.
Henry the .vij. called of Lucelburg, the .xxx. Germane Emperoure.

THhe yere of Chri≈øt .M. cccix was cho≈øenHenry the vi ‚Ä¢
Emperoure Henry the prince of Lucelburg. He reigned .vi. yeares. For in the meane tyme that the Romi≈øh bi≈øhop was in Fraunce, the Frenche kyng de≈øyred inordinatly the dignitie of the empire, and tru≈øted to obteayne his reque≈øt. througe the con≈øent of the Romi≈øh by≈øhop. But the coÃÑcorde was not long durable betwene the by≈øhop & the Frenche kyng. Wherfore the by≈øhop aduerti≈øed the princes Electours, whiche had now long di≈øagreed for the electioÃÑ, to hay≈øte to choy≈øe an Emperoure with one con≈øent the prince of Lucelburg, who at that time was demed a mo≈øt renowmed prince, for his wy≈ødome ioyned with hygh grauitie. As he was cho≈øen, ≈øtrayght waye dyd the by≈øhop of Rome coÃÑfirme hym. And thus was the FreÃÑ che kyng di≈øapointed of his reque≈øt & endeuoure‚ñ™ to remooue the dignitie of the Romi≈øh empire to him.

Fir≈øt toke he from the duke of Wirtenberg al his goodes, becau≈øe he was a rebel to the empyre. To his ≈øonne Iohn gaue he the kyng of Bohemies daughter in mariage: & by this meanes became Iohn prince of Lucelburg, the father of Charles the iiij. kyng of Bohemy.

Afterward went he into Italy with a great army, and made Italy ≈øo afrayde of hym, as no Emperoure had done a greate whyle before hym. Some cities woulde not yelde them to hym, without they were compelled by force, namely Cremona and Brixia: the re≈øidue obeyed frely. At RomeHenry the vij was poi≈øoned of a black frier in the Sacrament. was he crowned Emperoure. He be≈øyeged Florence with a heuy and ≈øtrayght ≈øyege, at the whiche
tyme (as it is reported) a frere of y‚Ä¢ preachers order or Black freres, that was made out of the Florentines, de≈øtroied Henry with venim, whiche he ≈øtrake vpon the ≈øyngynge breade, yea and the by≈øhop of Rome hym≈øelfe al≈øo, beynge now armed with hys weapons, threatened Henry wyth the dart of excommunicacion, as he perceaued that he began to be ≈øett by in Italy.

div.head: Ludouicus or Lewis the Baier, the .xxxi. Germane emperoure. And agayn≈øt hym was cho≈øen Emperour Frederick Duke of Ea≈øtenriche.
div.p:
THe yere of Chri≈øt M. cccxiiij. were a≈ø≈øembled together at Franckforde the princes Electors the by≈øh. of Mentz‚ñ™ Trier and Colen, Ihon kyng of Bohe my, Rudolphe counte Palatine of the Rene, Rudolphe duke of Saxony & Volcmarus marques of Brandenburg. On ≈øaynct Lucies daie was cho≈øen Emperoure Lewis theLewi ‚Ä¢ the Ba
‚Ä¢ er Baier by the by≈øhops of Mentz & Trier, the kyng of Bohemy and Marques of Brandenborowe. And agayn≈øt hym was cho≈øen Friderick duke ofFrederick duke of Ea≈øten
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ che‚ñ™ Ea≈øtenriche be the by≈øhop of Colen, the cunte Palatine and duke of Saxony. Lewis was crowned Emperoure at Aken, & Frederick at Bonne. This controuer≈øye in cho≈øynge, brought an occa≈øion of greate inwarde or ciuyll warre in Germany. The duke of Ea≈øtenriche had fauourers the by≈øhop of Rome the kynges of Fraunce and Bohemy, the Schwabes, the counte of Palatine, them of Stra≈øborow
and other cities many. But God pro≈øpered Lewis, who was le≈ø≈øe of power, & de≈øtitute of mans ayde. He raygned .xxxiij. yeares.
The yeare .M. cccxxiij. dyd they ≈øtryke a felde by the floude Nechare, whereof both ≈øydes many were ≈ølayne.

The yeare .M. cccxxv. on ≈øaynt Michaels euen gaue Lewis a greate battaill to Frederick. Frederick did ayde Lupoldus hys brother, ioyned wythLupoldus. hym the Schwaben and Switcers, and a greate parte of the Hungarians. As for Lewis dyd folow the kyng of Bohemy, and the erle of Norenberg, and ≈øome other princes. Now when Lupoldes taried ≈øo long, that he could not pa≈ø≈øe the water, y‚Ä¢ ho≈øt of Ea≈øtenriche was ≈ølayne, and Friderick was takenFriderick duke of Ea≈øtenriche was taken by a Ebrarde Mo≈øbach. by a Franke, who≈øe name was Ebrarde Mo≈øbach: the ≈øame led hym to the erle of Norenberg, who ≈øent hym to Lewis. But when Lupoldus ≈øawe he coulde not helpe hys brother, he was ≈øo angry and ragious, that he had in a maner vndone hym≈øelfe, had not hys men refrayned hym: whiche al≈øo con≈øayled hym to withdrawe, nether dyd ra≈øhly ca≈øt hym≈øelfe into the daunger. Afterwarde a≈ø≈øayed Lupoldus many thynges inuayne both by the by≈øhop of Rome, and al≈øo the Frenche kyng, that he myght take his brother awaye by force: for the FreÃÑ che kyng made no greate force of a ≈øtrange matter Friderick was a pry≈øoner the ≈øpace of thre yeares in a ca≈øtel in Baierlande: at the la≈øt when the controuer≈øy was brought to a poynt, he was let lou≈øe vpon this condicion, that he ≈øhoulde renounce the empyre: whiche thing when he had frely promi≈øed
he was re≈øtored into Ea≈øtenriche by Lewis. Of this wy≈øe behaued Lewis hym≈øelfe very gently toward his enemy: Lupoldus yet in the meane tyme not cea≈ø≈øynge of ray≈øynge commocions, euen after that Frederick was deliuered.

Afterwarde dyd Iohannes the .xxij. ca≈øt hysLewis is excoÃÑmunicated thonder boltes of cour≈øyng agayn≈øt Lewis the Emperoure, becau≈øe he v≈øed the Imperyall aucthoritie and empyres gouernaunce in Italy, before hys coronacion. Thereof ro≈øe an occa≈øion of a greate diui≈øion in Germany, and that la≈øted about .xxiiij.A diui≈øion in Germany. yeares. In the meane tyme ro≈øe here and there greate ≈øedicions in the empyre and cyties, and one parte bu≈øyed to dryue out and oppre≈ø≈øe the other by con≈øpiracion. And though Lewis de≈øyred ab≈øolution not once, but often of the by≈øhop of Rome, yet could he not obtayne it wyth any prayers, ≈øo that both Benedictus that was after Iohannes, and other many and hone≈øt men dyd refu≈øe the proce≈ø≈øe. There are yet now a dayes wrytynges of the controuer≈øie, wherein the Romy≈øhe by≈øhop. Iohannes the .xxii. is not a≈øhamed to boa≈øte, thatThe boa≈øtiÃÑg of Iohannes ‚Ä¢ he .xxij. by≈øh. he hath the full power and aucthoritie to make and depo≈øe, not onely kynges, but al≈øo all Emperoures at hys plea≈øure. By thys it maye be gathered ea≈øely, that the Romy≈øhe by≈øhop v≈øed ≈øo greate hatred agayn≈øte the Emperoure, for no very weyghty cau≈øe. There were al≈øo about that tyme ≈øome learned men, whiche openly blamed the Romy≈øhe by≈øhops writynges, amonges the≈øe was Occam one‚ñ™ Ocam a re
‚Ä¢ ouer of the ‚Ä¢ om ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h bi≈øh. the princes of Germany euery one, as wel eccle≈øia≈øticall, as of the nobilitie helde with the Emperour:
at the la≈øt were ≈øome compelled by the by≈øhop of Rome to fall back, and al≈øo to choy≈øe another Emperoure.

Lewis had very greate vproures in Italy. GaleaciusGaleacius of Milan. of Milan, and the coun≈øayll of Rome longed for Lewis commyng into Italy. Wherfore he went thether with the Empere≈ø≈øe, which al≈øo was delyuered of a chylde at Rome, that was called Lewis the Romane, and was afterwarde by the Emperoure made marques of Brandenborowe. At Milan was Lewis crowned of the by≈øh. there, and at Rome of the Cardinall de Columna. He made al≈øo Peter of Corbaria by≈øhop of Rome, who was not longe after caried bounde to Auinion in Fraunce, to Iohannes the .xxii. who ca≈øt hym into pry≈øon, wherein he dyed.

But whyle allthys was adoynge, Lewis by noLewis the Romane. reque≈øtes coulde optayne to be relea≈øed of the excoÃÑ municacion by the by≈øhop of Rome. But for≈øoeth the Romy≈øh by≈øhop brought that to pa≈ø≈øe wyth his bu≈øy laboure at length, that in an a≈ø≈øembly or daye holden at Lucelburg, the by≈øhops of Mentz, Trier and Colen, the kyng of Bohemy and duke of Saxon, dyd choy≈øe another Emperour. There was cho≈øen Charles the fourth erle prouincial of Morauia, the ≈øonne of the kyng of Bohemy. The ≈øame was then confirmed by Clemens the .vi. by≈øhop of Ro. But for as muche as the cities of Aken and Colen would not knowe hym for an Emperoure, he was crowned at Bon.

div.head: Of Nicolaus Augu≈øtus, that is, Nicolas the noble, that was at Rome.
div.p: ABout this tyme happened at Rome anNicolas the noble or ful of maie≈øtie, an example of notable folye. example of a notable folye: There was at Rome one Nicolas, a towne clarke or recorder of Rome, of ≈øuche power and aucthoritie, that one would haue ≈øayde he had the rule of the whole citie: for at that tyme were the Romy≈øh By≈øhoppes yet in Fraunce. This Nicolas called hym≈øelf Tribunus Augu≈øtus, that is, the noble hygh officer: and with open ≈øcriptures wytne≈ø≈øed, that Rome is yet the true heade of the empyre: and therfore by ye citie of Romes aucthoritie, had he the hyghe≈øt power to handle maters of the empyre. And by rea≈øon of this aucthoritie called he Lewis and Charles to appeare before hym, and to coÃÑmitte their matter to his arbitremeÃÑt or iudgement. Lyke foly≈øhne≈ø≈øe v≈øed he oft agayn≈øt other cities and kynges ye ≈øpace of two yeares. At the la≈øt this pore Augu≈øtus being driueÃÑ out by the by≈øhop of Romes partie, fled to Charles the fourth. But Charles ≈øent the ra≈øh man to the by≈øhop of Rome at AuinioÃÑ, of whom he was kept in pry≈øon.

The yeare of Chri≈øt .M. cccxlv. died Lewis the Bayer. And then came Charles with a great hoo≈øt out of Bohemy to Regen≈øpurg, where he was knowen for an Emperoure. From thence was he al≈øo receaued at Norenberg: for Charles made theÃÑ beleue, he had gotten a fauourable ab≈øolution of the bi≈øhop of Rome to put out the great offences, wherwith they had offended, in that they were adherent to Lewis. When they of Ba≈øyl ≈øent out their Burgemai≈øters to Charles, that he in the name of the citie ≈øhould a≈øke ab≈øolution, he an≈øwered: he thought
they had not done ami≈ø≈øe, in that they had Lewis for an Emperoure, nether thought he that Lewis was an heritike: yet in the meane tyme if they could be ab≈øolued of their tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes, he wold be content. And thus were they ab≈øolued.

The yeare of Chri≈øt .M. cccxlviij. when Lewis was now deade, there ro≈øe yet a greater di≈øcorde: the by≈øhop of Mentz, the counte Palatine, the marques of BraÃÑdenburg, and the duke of Saxony, his ≈øonne that hath cho≈øen Charles Emperoure, a≈ø≈øembled and refu≈øyng the election of Charles, they cho≈øeEdward the iij. kynge of Englande, & Fredrick erle of Mi≈øen refu≈øe the dignitie Emperial ‚Ä¢
Edward the third, kyng Englande to take vpon hym the maie≈øtie Emperiall: but he refu≈øed it, as a thyng ful of cumbraunce. After that cho≈øe they Frederick Erle prouinciall of Mi≈øen. But he al≈øo for≈øoke that title of the empyre: for he would not fyght and warre with his neyghbours the Bohemies to vndoe his countrey.

div.head: Guntherus Erle of Swartzburg is cho≈øen Emperoure.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øte .M. cccl. was cho≈øen Emperoure at Franckforde Gunterus Erle of Schwatzburg, yet not with con≈øent of all the Electors. The≈øame accepted the gouernaunce of the empyre, and garny≈øhed with all defence to retayne the empyre, he was armed ynough again≈øte the force of Charles, who then abode at Mentz. But ≈øhortly after died Gunterus at FraÃÑckforde ≈øodenly poy≈øoned. Wherefore Charles was Emperoure alone. He came to Franckforde, and
was receiued for an Emperoure.
After Clemens the .v. became Iohannes the xxii. by≈øhop of Rome who without a iu≈øte cau≈øe dyd excommunicate the good Emperoure Lewis.

Benedictus the .xi. was made by≈øhop of RomeBenedictus the. ‚Ä¢ i. after Iohannes. The ≈øame neuer alowed the action of Iohannes again≈øt the Emperoure Lewis, and when he was made by≈øhop of Rome he had frely ab≈øolued hym, had not the kynges of Fraunce and Naples with their threatenynges with≈øtande hym. When in the relacion the orators or emba≈ø≈øadors of the kinges alledged, that Lewis had enterpry≈øed many haynous thynges again≈øt the by≈øhop of Rome. Benedictus an≈øwered: yea, we haue done again≈øt hym. He liued not long in the by≈øhopricke, & therefore dyd al the cau≈øes hang vndi≈øpatched.

Clemens the .vi. was made by≈øhop after Benedictus. The ≈øame renewined the thonder boltes ca≈øt again≈øt Lewis, and per≈øued hym mo≈øte fearcely: though in the coun≈øayll of Vienne in Fraunce were treated in the meane tyme of the condicions of peace, and that Lewis declared hym≈øelfe humble. This Clemens bought the citie Auenion of IoannaAuenion a citie p ‚Ä¢ pall. quene of Sicily, and ≈øo hath the by≈øhop of Ro. aucthoritie vpon this citie.

Moreouer at this tyme went about here & therinThe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ de
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
many & FrauÃÑ ce „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ g them≈øel ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s. in Germany and Fraunce, a great nomber of men, whiche did beate them≈øelues with roddes. Many of them came to Spire, when the day or parliameÃÑt was holden there pretending great holyne≈ø≈øe. For their holine≈ø≈øe ≈øake were they bidden to the meales of the cite≈øens. And as the deceate of the erroure
dyd not differ from the Anabapti≈øtes ≈øuper≈øticious opinion: euen ≈øo was that ≈øecte no le≈ø≈øe dauÃÑgerous in tho≈øe daies. But at the la≈øt it was condemned.
Innocentius the .vi. ≈øucceded Clemens. In his tyme was Charles the .iiij. crowned at Rome.

div.head: Charles the .iiij. the .xxxij. Germane Emperoure.
div.p: THe yere of Chri≈øt .M. cccl. began Charles y‚Ä¢ Charles y‚Ä¢ iiij iiij. to raigne, after ye death of Guntherus of Schwartzburg. He was a prince of ye bloud of Lucelburg, the ≈øonne of Ihon kyng of Bohemy: for Iohn was ye ≈øonne of Henry of Lucelburg. FroÃÑ this yere of .M. cccl. reigned Charles. xxvii ‚Ä¢ . yeres

The yeare .M. ccclv. went Charles downe into Italy, & was gently receaued of the cities. At Ro. the ≈øenate & all the be≈øt metyng Charles, did receaue hym with all reuerence. He likewy≈øe, to declare to the Romanes his gentlene≈ø≈øe, lyghted from his hor≈øe, & receaued on fote the yelding of the citie. Afterward was he crowned of the cardinal of Ho≈øtia. The cities of the by≈øh. of Rome in Italy, that were rebels, ≈øubdued he to do the Romy≈øh by≈øhop a plea≈øure, ≈øo that they repyned nomore. I fynde none other thynges that he dyd in this iourney.
They yeare .M. ccclx. he ouercame and ≈øp ‚Ä¢ yled Ebrardus erle of Wirtenberg with a great army. But at the la≈øt was the debate layde downe, by the by≈øhop of Au≈øburg, Stra≈øburg and Spire.
The yeare .M. ccclxvi. went Charles agayne in to Italy, in the whiche iourney he a≈ø≈øuaged and ≈øubdued ≈øome cities, de≈øyrous of vproure.

Charles be≈øyeged al≈øo y‚Ä¢ citie Vlme, but I reade no where for what cau≈øe. For oure Germanes not knowyng the propertie of hi≈øtories, haue not taken hede to the circum≈øtaunces and cau≈øes of thynges.Charles the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ maker of ye gold ‚Ä¢ buile

Charles hath de≈øerued greate thankes for the golden bulle that he made, wherein he hath hand≈øomly compri≈øed many thynges, that make to entertayne common peace. He did chefely endeuoure & procure the affayres of Bohemy. He ordeined the:The viuer≈øitie of Praga in Bohempe. vniuer≈øitie of Praga. Some there are that di≈øalowe, that he gaue the French kyng ryghtes in the kyngdome of Orleaunce.

The yeare .M. ccclxx. cau≈øed Charles his ≈øonne Wence≈ølaus to be made Emperoure. To his other ≈øonne Sigi≈ømundus gaue he the Erldome of the marques of BraÃÑdenburg, the which he had bought of Lewis the Romane.
The yere .M. ccclxxvii. fought Vdalricus Erle of Wirtenberg mi≈øhappely, before the citie Rutlingen.The battayll by RutlingeÃÑ In that battaill dyed many and noble men.

div.head: Switzer league.
div.p: ABout this tyme began the Switzer league,The Switzers league. and fir≈øt the citie Lucerna, then Berna, at the la≈øt Tzurich dyd ioyne them≈øelues to the Switzers: and the noble prince Lupoldus duke of Ea≈øtenriche, was ouercomeLupoldus duke of Ea≈øtenriche was ≈ølam by the Switzers. and ≈ølayne by the Switzers the yere .M. ccclxxxv.
But for as muche as there are in mans handes euery where hi≈øtories of the Switzers dedes. I reken it neoele≈ø≈øe to make longe reher≈øall of their actes in this lytle boke.
Vrbanus the v. ≈øucceded Innocentius the v ‚Ä¢ .
Gregorius the x ‚Ä¢ . was by≈øhop of Rome after Vrbanus. The ≈øame remoued y‚Ä¢ ≈øee out of Fraunce to Rome agayne, the yeare MCCCLXXVI.

div.head: A diui≈øion
div.p: AFter Gregorius the xi. ro≈øe a greate diui≈øioÃÑ A diui≈øioÃÑ after Gregory us the .xi. in the ≈øpiritualtye. The Italians made an Italian By≈øhoyp of Rome called Vrbanus the vi. and the ≈øame remayned at Rome. The Frenchmen al≈øo cho≈øe a By≈øhop of Rom. in Italy, whome they called Clemens the vii. The ≈øame gat hym to Auinion. Thus was Rome diuided, and ther were two by≈øhoppes of Rome: the one dyd accur≈øe the other. Truely Italy, Germany and Hungary dyd hange to Vrbanus the by≈øhops of the Romanes. Thys diui≈øion la≈øted vntyll the councel of Con≈øtance .xxxix. yeares.

div.head: Wence≈ølaus the .xxxiii. Germane Emperoure.
div.p: THe yeare of Chri≈øte .M. ccc. lxxviij. afterWeÃÑce≈ølaus Emperour. Charles decea≈ø≈øe, began Wence≈ølaus his ≈øonne to raygne, and raygned after hys fathers death .xxii. yeares.

At thys tyme began Ihon Hu≈ø≈øe opeÃÑly to teacheIhon Hu≈ø≈øe teacheth opeÃÑ lye agayn≈øt pardons. at Praga agayn≈øt the by≈øhop of Romes pardones: and by thys occa≈øion ro≈øe hurteful in≈øurrections in Bohemy agayn≈øt pre≈øtes and religious men.
Wence≈ølaus was at the la≈øte taken by hys brother Sigi≈ømundus, and kept at Vienne in pre≈øon. Other thinges do I not fynde of this Wence≈ølaus that I iudge worthy to be put in writynges.

div.head: Rupertus the xxxiiij. Germane Emperoure.
div.p: THe yeare of Chri≈øt .M. CCCC. was Rupertus the counte Palatine madeRupertus Emperoure. Emperour. He raigned tenne yeares. But ≈øeynge the Emperours had now ben long from Italy, the power of the kynred of Galeacyus was waxen greate at Milan and the Florentins were become ryche al≈øo, and warred agayn≈øt them of Milane. The Florentins a≈øked ayde of Rupertus the Emperoure, to repre≈ø≈øe the power of the Galacians. Wherefore Rupertus went vppe into Italy to helpe the Florentius. and toke Galeacins. Howbeit Rupertus beyng de≈øtitute of the a≈ø≈øi≈øtaunce of the duke of Ea≈øtenriche, and bi≈øhop of Colen, was to weake, than that he coulde haue brought ≈øo greate thynges to pa≈ø≈øe: and though he had a≈ø≈øayed many thinges, yet was he con≈øtrayned to returne agayne into Germanye hys bu≈ø≈øine≈ø≈øe beyng not di≈ø ‚Ä¢ p ‚Ä¢ rched.
Bonifacius the .ix. was made bi≈øhop at Rome after Vrbanus.
And again≈øt him was made bi≈øh. after Clemens ye .vii. Petrus de Luna called Benedictus the .xii.
After Bonifacius was Innocentius y‚Ä¢. vii made by≈øhop at Rome.

After InnoceÃÑtius was Gregorius the xii. made by≈øhop at Rome. The ≈øame promy≈øed y‚Ä¢ he woulde renounce the by≈øhoprycke, yf Benedictus lykewi≈øe dyd not refu≈øe to renounce al≈øo. But whaÃÑ Benedictus fled into Spayne, leauyng Auinion, Gregorius reuoked hys promi≈øe concernyng to re≈øigne the
by≈øhoprycke. Wherefore was a councell gathered at Py≈øis, whereyn bothe Gregorius and Benedictus were depo≈øed of the by≈øhoprycke, and in theyr ≈øteade was the thyrde Romy≈øh by≈øhop cho≈øen Alexander the .v. Gregorius fled to Ariminum, where he remayned vntill the coun≈øel of Con≈øtance was. Alexander the .v. dwelt at Bonony, for the Hungarians hauing than taken in Rome, v≈øed incredible tiraÃÑny, & warred with the Frenchmen for Naples.

After Alexander the .v. was Ioannes the .xxiii.The diui≈øion of thre Rom. vy≈øh. made by≈øhop of Rome at Bonony. And of this wi≈øe were a lyue, vntil the general councel of Con≈øtance thys Ioannes the .xxiii. at Bonony, Gregorius at Ariminum and Benedictus in Spayne. But they were all thre ≈øet be≈øyde y‚Ä¢ Romy≈øhe by≈øhopryck in that councel.

div.head: Of Tamerlanes the tyraunt of Tartaria.
div.p: IN the time of Rupertus the EmperourTamerlanes a tyraunt. lyued the pa≈ø≈øynge cruell tyraunte Tamerlanes the Tartarian, who by greate ≈øpoylynge, wente aboute nearehande al y‚Ä¢ Ea≈øt and A≈øia, with an armye of tenne hundreth thou≈øande men. He ≈øpoyled the Per≈øeans, Armenians and Syrians. He inuaded al≈øo the le≈ø≈øe A≈øia and toke Paia≈øetus the Turky≈øh Emperoure, and caryed hym in a cage as a byrde aboute wyth hym for a wonder and mockage.

div.head: Sigi≈ømundus the .xxxv. Germane Emperoure.
div.p: THe yeare of Chri≈øte .M.CCCC. afterSigi≈ømundus Emperoure. Rupertus the Emperours decea≈ø≈øe was Sigy≈ømundus made Emperoure. He was the ≈øonne of Charles the fourthe, marques of Brandenburg, kynge of Hungary and Bohemye. He was Emperour ≈øeuen and twentye yeares. He was a moo≈øt famous prince in wi≈øedome, learnyng and hone≈øtye: ≈øuche one of ≈øtature, as was ≈øemynge a lyke prince. His countrefaytoure very connyngly made, is to be ≈øene yet this daye, by the erle Hoier of Man≈øfelde. He had greate warres in Hungary agayn≈øt the Hungaryans of the whyche he was taken. He fought oft agayn≈øt the Turkes. But whan he was made Emperoure, he made a greate ≈øettyng forth agayn≈øt the Turkes with the ayde of all nacions, whereof we ≈øhall ≈øpeake hereafter

div.head: Of the councell of Con≈øtance.
div.p: IN the beginnynge of Sigi≈ømundus raygne he went vp into Italye, and toke coun≈øell with Ioannes the by≈øh of Ro. of callinge a generall councel for to auoyde the diui≈øion. He went al≈øo to the Frenche kynge, and compelled hym to agre to the callynge a general councell. Wherefore by the con≈øent of the by≈øhop of Ro. Ioannes, the Emperoure, and al≈øo the kynges of Fraunce, Spayne and England, was the councell of Con≈øtance begonne the yeare .M. C C C C. xiiii. to the whiche came Ioannes the By≈øhop of Rome hym≈øelfe.

The Emperoure Sigi≈ømundus came to Con≈øtance
before Chri≈øtma≈ø≈øe, and at ma≈ø≈øe ≈øonge he the go≈øpell as Deacon: Ther went oute a commaundemente from Augu≈øtus the Emperoure &c.

Afterwarde was ther treated of Ihon Hu≈ø≈øe,He that wyll knowe the whole hi≈øtory of Ihon Hu≈ø≈øe & HieroÃÑ of Pragga yt were burnt in ye councel at CoÃÑ≈øtaÃÑce, let him read Eneas ≈øiluius iÃÑ his boke of yE beginning & dedes of ye Bohemies ye .xxxv. & xxxv. chapy. and hys doctryne beyng condemneth, he was burneth wyth Hieronimus of Praga. After that treated they to a peace the diui≈øyon, and depo≈øyng the by≈øhoppes of Rome. Ioannes the .xxiij. Gregorius and Benedictus, was cho≈øen in the ≈øee Othode Columna, who was called Martynus the fyfte.

But whan it repented Ioannes the .xxiii. that he had con≈øented frelye to the renouncynge of the By≈øhoprycke of Rome, he wente aboute to flye pryuelye, wyth the ayde of Frederyck duke of Ea≈øtenryche. But in the flyghte Ioannes was had backe agayne, by the Emperoures men. And the duke of Ea≈øtenryche was banny≈øhed by the Emperoure, and ≈øome of hys townes taken in hys duchye. At the la≈øt was the debate layed downe of thys wy≈øe: It was couÃÑ≈øelled Frederyck, that he frely yeldyng to the Emperoure all hys landes, ≈øhulde humblye requyre forgeuene≈ø≈øe of hys offence. Wherefore by the Emperoures gentlene≈ø≈øe and fauoure he was re≈øtored in the duchy of Ea≈øtenryche.

But Ioannes the by≈øhoppe of Rome, was delyuered to the counte Palatyne to be kepte. The≈øame caried him int ye ca≈øtel MaÃÑheym, not farre froÃÑ the citye Heidelberg: there was he kepte the ≈øpace of thre yeare. After yt was he receaued to grace by
Martinus the Romi≈øh bi≈øh. and made a Cardinal. Whan of this wi≈øe that hurteful diui≈øion that was betwene the bi≈øhops of Rome was anoyded, peace and re≈øte was re≈øtored to the churche, and that by the endeuoure and procurement of Sigi≈ømundus the Emperoure, who therefore de≈øerued greate pray≈øes.
The re≈øidue that were done in that a≈ø≈øemble or councel, is no nede to rehear≈øe: for whole bokes are wrytten thereof.

div.head: Of the prouincial erles of the marque≈øhip of Brandenburg.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øt .M. C C C C. xvii. the fyr≈øte ≈øondaye after Ea≈øter, dyd Sigy≈ømundus the Emperour in the councell geue to the moo≈øte pray≈øe worthy prince Fridericke Burgraue of Norinberg, the ryghte of Imperyall election, and the prouincyall marque≈øhyp of Branbenburge: and that for hys excellent vertues, and greate tru≈øte, that he had ≈øhewed in di≈øpatchinge great cau≈øes of the empyre. But truely it were long to rechear≈øe here how noble princes haue ben both before thys dignitye was gotten, & al≈øo afterward in this progeny of Burgraues: yee and before hath oft ben made meÃÑcion of them. But after that they were made Electors, they were diligente euer in treatynge the greate≈øte and moo≈øte weightye≈øt matters of the empyre, for the whyche thynges ≈øake ≈øhalbe oft made meÃÑcion of theÃÑ hereafter. Wherfore in the hi≈øtories of our time, is Albertus the Marques prai≈øed before al other, who for
his vertues ≈øake is ≈øurnamed y‚Ä¢ germane Achilles.

It is al≈øo not vnknowen in oure dayes, y‚Ä¢ Marques Ioachim of Brandenburg Elector, my moo≈øt gentle lorde, and his brother Albert Cardinal and Elector, Archeby≈øhoppe of Mentz and Magdenburge &c. are garny≈øhed with hygh wy≈øedome, and all princely vertues: and that therfore theyr coun≈øel & ayde is requyred before other in hyghe and harde matters, not only concernynge the empyre, but al≈øo to y‚Ä¢ whole Chri≈øtiantie. Nother caÃÑ it other wy≈øe be in gouernaunces and dominions, y‚Ä¢ whych ≈øo longe as they haue theyr beynge, mu≈øt be de≈øerued and maynteyned by the wy≈øedome of men of greate authoritye, whiche thynge the Wy≈øedome her ≈øelfe wytne≈ø≈øeth in holye ≈øcriptures, ≈øayenge: By me kynges do raygne.

Whan the councell was broke vp, many ≈øettyng forth were appoynted agayn≈øt the ≈øeditions and euell di≈øpo≈øed men, whiche ≈øpoyled and robbed both churches & mona≈øteryes after Ihon Hu≈ø≈øes deathZi≈øcha captayn of the Hu≈ø≈øites ≈øect. Theyr captayn was called zy≈øcha. Greate man≈ølaughter was of both ≈øydes, of the Bohemes and Germanes, which went again≈øt them: yet was notThe ≈øettyn ‚Ä¢ forth of Sygi≈ømundus agayn≈øte th ‚Ä¢ Turkes. that brunt of vproure ≈øo quenched. Sigi≈ømundus (as we ≈øayd before) had prepared & brought vntill Adrianopolis a verye greate army of Germanes, FrenchmeÃÑ, Italians & Hungarians again≈øt y‚Ä¢ Turkes. In this ≈øetting forth were mo≈øt greate≈øt princes y‚Ä¢ Emperour Sigi≈ømundus & Philippe duke of Burgundion. But by rea≈øon the Frenchemen ≈øtroue, ≈øayenge they mu≈øt haue the foreward in the army, y‚Ä¢ orders were broken, not without an incredible
lo≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øten men: for theyr enemyes vanquy≈øhed them, and the duke of Burgundy was taken. Sigi≈ømundus the Emperour fled to Con≈øtan tinople. After longe ≈øea≈øon after, was the duke of Burgundy delyuered.

A mery ≈øtory is recited of Sigi≈ømundus. HeThe hi≈øtory of Sigi≈øinuÃÑ dus with his seruauÃÑt. had a ≈øeruaunt y‚Ä¢ was many yeares familiar wyth him, whom he had not greatly rewarded, (though in the meane ≈øea≈øon he was a liberal & free prince,) which thing Leonardus Aretinus al≈øo doth write who ≈øawe Sigi≈øinuÃÑdus the Emperour, & had done many me≈ø≈øages to him, on the by≈øh. of Ro. behalfe. It fortuned that whaÃÑ he was ridden into a water, hys hor≈øe dyd ≈øtalle. Whyche thinge whan the ≈øeruaunt, that went ≈øtrayght before the Emperoure did ≈øee, he ≈øayd in ≈øporte: The hor≈øe was of lyke nature that hys lorde was. The Emperour hearyng it by chaunce, maruayled, & commaunded to ≈øhewe him what he ≈øaide. The ≈øeruaunt aun≈øwered. The hor≈øe pourech out water into the ryuer, where as is water ynough alredy. Euen ≈øo is the Emperour lyberall to tho≈øe, whych haue ryches plenty, & nede them not greatly. Sigi≈ømundus the Emperoure perceaued that he was adui≈øedly touched or taunted, that he had not rewarded hys olde ≈øeruaunt with ≈øome peculyar or greate rewarde, and ≈øayd: He neuer wanted the wyll to recompen≈øe, but that princes gyftes are not properlye theyrs, that de≈øerue them: but theyrs that they are appoynted by Goddes prouydence and dy≈øpo≈øycyon. The ≈øame ≈øayde he that he woulde proue wyth the dede, ≈øo ≈øoone as he ≈øhulde be at lea≈øure and re≈øte. Afterwarde
whan the Emperour had gotten lea≈øure he cau≈øed to make two boxes of one bygne≈ø≈øe and fa≈øhion. In the one he put golde, in the other leade of lyke weyght, and callyng the ≈øeruaunt, he bad hym take one of the boxes. The ≈øeruaunt being aba≈øhed weyed now the one boxe, than the other douting y‚Ä¢ whiche he myghte rather take: at the la≈øte he toke y‚Ä¢ boxe, wherein the leade was. Which whan he had opened, the Emperour ≈øayde: It may be ≈øene openly, that hys wyli was not in the faute, why he was not rewarded hetherto, but hys mi≈øfortune. This dede wythne≈ø≈øeth verely, that the Emperoure dyd wy≈øely con≈øyder, that the fortunable pro≈øperity ofThe pro≈øperity coÃÑmeth of God. Albert duke of Ea≈øteÃÑrich. thynges commeth of God.
Sigi≈ømuÃÑdus the Emperour had no heyre mankynne, he gaue hys only doughter to Albert duke of Ea≈øtenryche, who became kyng of Hungary and Bohemy by that meanes.

The yere .M. CCCC. xxxiiii. whyle Sigi≈ømundus was yet alyue, began the councel of Ba≈øil. ForThe co≈øicel Ba≈øil. it was ordeyned in y‚Ä¢ councel of Con≈øtance, that of a newe couÃÑcel ≈øhulde be gathered after twelue yeares. But after that Sigi≈ømundus was deade, the by≈øh. of Ro. holdinge a councell fyr≈øte at Ferraria, and from thence at Florence, letted y‚Ä¢ furtherauÃÑce of the councel of Ba≈øill: and that had he ≈øo muche the more ea≈øy a do, becau≈øe ther was no monarche or noble prince that defended the decree: of y‚Ä¢ councel of Ba≈øill.
After that Martinus was deade, Eugenius the iiii. was made by≈øh. of Ro. The ≈øame crowned Sigi≈ømundus Emperour at Rome.

div.head: Albert the .ii. of that name, the .xxxvi. Germane Emperour.
div.p: THe yeare of Chri≈øte .M. cccc. xxxviii. afterAlbert the .ii. the death of Sigi≈ømundus, was Alberte, a prince of the bloude of Ea≈øtenryche, kyng of Hungarye & Bohemye, made Emperoure. He dyed in the ≈øeconde yeare of hys raygne.

Parte of Bohemy dyd cleue to the kyng of Polen, & endeuoured to drawe y‚Ä¢ kyngdome of Bohemy to Polony. The Poles brought a great army into Bohemy, & drew into their faction the vproury≈øh kynde of men called Thaborites. Agayn≈øt theÃÑ ≈øent Albert y‚Ä¢ Emperour Albert marques of Bran denburg. The ≈øame brought to pa≈ø≈øe wyth manye battayls, that the matter was agreed betwene the Emperoure and the Poles.

Albert the Emperoure came wyth a greate army into Hungary, agayn≈øt Amurates the Turke, who at that tyme was fallen into Hungary. Whan Albert the Emperoure came he fled backe, and be≈øye gynge the cytye Sinderouien, he returned into Grece, and wann the city The≈ø≈øalonica. In this ≈øettynge forth fell Albert into a ≈øyckne≈ø≈øe, and beynge broughte agayne to Uyenna, dyed wythyn few dayes.

div.head: Friderick the .iii. the .xxxviij. Germane Emperoure.
div.p:
THe yere of Chri≈øt .M. CCCC. xl. afterFrederick y‚Ä¢ third. Albertus deathe, was Fridericke the thyrd duke of E≈øtenrich, made Emperoure. He raygned .liii. yeares.
The doughter of Sigi≈ømundus, wyfe to Albert the Emperoure was now bygge wyth chylde: but ≈øome of the Hungaryans de≈øpayrynge of an heyreIoannes Huniades. of the realme, cho≈øe Vladi≈ølaus the yonger kynge of Polen for a kyng. The kings gouernour in Hungary was IoaÃÑnes Huniades, father to Mathias. The ≈øame had weakened the power of the Turkes wyth a great battail, and compelled Amurates toVladi≈ølaus. demande peace. But ≈øo ≈øoone as Vladi≈ølaus was come into the realme, the HungariaÃÑs tru≈øted, that yf they & the Poles powers were ioyned together, they ≈øhuld ea≈øely gett great pray≈øe yf they inuaded the Turke. And happely had the yonge kyng Vladi≈ølaus plea≈øure in thys pray≈øe. Wherfore IulianusIulianus the Cardinal. the Cardinall brake the treuce made wyth the Turke, vnder thys pretence and coloure: that it were not lawfull to make peace wyth the Turkes, wythout the Bi≈øh. of Romes con≈øente, ≈øeyng y‚Ä¢ ca≈øe is belonging to whole Chri≈øtendome. Thus Vladi≈ølaus gathering an hoo≈øt went again≈øt Amurates vntill Varnam, which is not farr from CoÃÑ≈øtantinople: though Ioannes Humades in y‚Ä¢ mean ≈øea≈øon di≈ø≈øuaded to take warre, becau≈øe that he knew well the weakene≈ø≈øe of his men, & the power of the Turkes, & al≈øo had he made peace with the Turke, not without nece≈ø≈øitie. It is al≈øo ≈øayd that Vladi≈ølaus de≈øyred ayde of Dracoles y‚Ä¢ Malache, but heDracoles y‚Ä¢ Wlache al≈øo dyd coun≈øell to leaue y‚Ä¢ ≈øetting forth to warre. Yet dyd he ≈øend his ≈øonn with him to aide king Vladi≈ølaus with two thou≈øand hor≈øemen, to whom he ≈øhuld haue ≈øaid: He gaue hym a couragious andDracoles gaue Vladi≈ølaus a hor≈øe. ≈øwyft hor≈øe, ≈øuche one as he wold geue to his ≈øonn
al≈øo for his mynd gaue that they ≈øhuld lo≈øe the feld, and therefore ≈øhuld they haue the≈øe hor≈øes at hand that as nede ≈øhulde requyre, the myghte troughe theyr ≈øwyftne≈ø≈øe e≈øcape the daunger. As for the Turkes dyd for≈øe them≈øelues wyth nole≈ø≈øe carfulne≈ø≈øe, than wy≈øedome, and were euery where appoynted in a readyne≈ø≈øe, before the Hungaryans were ≈øet in an order. Wherefore thoughe the HungariaÃÑsThe battayl by Wardam. fought fearcely for ye glory of Chri≈øtes name and ouerthrwe verye great hoo≈øtes of the enemyes: yet dyd the Turkes at the la≈øt ouercome wyth the multitude, ≈øtayeng Vladi≈ølaus the yong kinge, and afterward was Iulianus the Cardinal ≈ølayen al≈øo in the flyght. Humades as he was a ware ≈øoul dioure, toke hede to hym≈øelfe by tymes, and e≈øcaped. This felde was the yeare .M. CCCC. xliiii.Amurates be ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ me ‚Ä¢ moÃÑke „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ rp man. the tenth daye of Nouember. Amurates became a Mahomety≈øhe monke after thys vyctorye, ≈øuppo≈øynge to haue accomply≈øhed hys duetye in the empyre, after ≈øo greate pro≈øperitye in vanquy≈øhynge hys enemyes, le≈øte he ra≈øhely tru≈øtynge ≈ømylynge fortune farther, dyd ≈øtayne hys glorye wyth ≈øome euell. But Hunyades dyd inuade and fell vponHuniades hurteth the Turkes greueou≈øly. the Turkes agayn, and dyd hurt them ≈øo ≈øore, that they called Amurates agayn to the realme, to re≈øi≈øt Hunyades their enemy, and ≈øhuld driue him out of HuÃÑgary. Afterward whaÃÑ CoÃÑ≈øtantinople was lo≈øt, Huniades ouercame Mahomet ye Turki≈øhe Emperour bringing into HuÃÑgari an hurtful army with a great di≈øcoÃÑfitur, & deliuered whole Europa from ye fear of dauÃÑger. For yf that ≈øetting forth had lucked Mahomet ye Turki≈øh Emperour, he had now takeÃÑ
in not only Italy, but other contryes al≈øo.

Whan Vladi≈ølaus was deade, the Hungarians receaued the chylde Ladi≈ølaus, the heyre of the realme, borne of Sigi≈ømundus doughter, for theyr kyng. Thys Ladi≈ølaus whan he was ful growen, dyed at Praga the haed citye of Bohemy.

The yeare .M. CCCC. xliiij. broughte the DolphinThe Dolphin and Armeniakes go into Germany. with the Armeniakes an army into El≈øace, vntyll Ba≈øil, not wythout a greate and horible man≈ølaughter of the Germanes. Some thynke that Eugenius the by≈øh. of Ro. ≈øent hym into Germany to trouble the councel of Ba≈øil. The Dolphyn had aboute fyue and twenty thou≈øand men. The SwitzersThe power of the Switzers agayn≈øte the Dolphin. ≈øent foure thou≈øand men again≈øt them, to re≈øcue the citye Ba≈øel out of theyr handes. They ≈øett vpon the enemyes wyth ≈øo greate ≈øtrengthe and corage, that none of them gaue backe: and thoughe they coulde not ouercome them, by rea≈øon of the multitude of theÃÑ, yet left they theyr enemies a bloudy & dolefull victorye. For the Dolphin lo≈øt in that battayl about ten thou≈øand men, and was fayne to flye out of Germany, with the re≈øidue y‚Ä¢ remayned

The yeare .M. CCCC. xlix. dyd Albert marques af Brandenburg warre agayn≈øt imperial cityes Norinberg and ≈øome other. Thys was calledWarre of ye cityes. the warre of the cityes. Many princes dyd ioyne them≈øelues to ether ≈øyde, and thys warre la≈øted. ii. yeares. Albert the marques ouerthrue them of Norinberg wyth .viii. battayls.

The yeare .M. cccc. lii. went Friderick into Italy, and was receaued of euery man wyth ≈øea≈øtly honoure. In the citye Sena dyd he acomply≈øhe hys
weddynge wyth Leonora hys ≈øpou≈øe, doughter to the kynge of Portingale. Commynge to Rome he was crowned of Nicolaus the fyfte wyth hys quene the .xviij. daye of Marche. Returnyng from Rome at Ferraria made he Bor≈øius of E≈øta duke. From thence ≈øhipped he ouer to Venice, and abode there ten dayes. I haue herde of a man of greate renowme, that it was tolde him of the prince of Venice, who beynge Senator, ≈øerued the Emperour Fridericke and the prince of Venice at the table, that Frederick ≈øhulde haue ≈øayd at the meale: that he truely wold be a frende to the Venecians continually, but they ≈øhulde haue muche trouble and daÃÑ mage of hys ≈øucce≈ø≈øours.

div.head: Of Con≈øtantinople Wonne by the Turkes.
div.p:
THe yeare of Chri≈øte .M. CCCC. liiii ye xxix daye of Maye after longe ≈øyeggat Mahometes the Turky≈øh Emperoure the citye Con≈øtaÃÑtinople at ye la≈øte with a very ≈øtrong a≈ø≈øaulte: and v≈øed thereyn ≈øo muche cruelne≈ø≈øe, that it can not be expre≈ø≈øed wyth no wordes. Con≈øtantinusCon≈øtaÃÑtinus Emperoure of Con≈øtantinople. the Emperoure was ≈ølayne by the gate of the cytye, in the flyghte, who≈øe heade cau≈øed the Turke to be ≈ømytten of, & ≈øtycked vpon a pole to be caryed thorow out the citye. He commaunded al≈øo
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ table „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of ye
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ whaÃÑ
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ nn „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ino pl ‚Ä¢ . to ≈øet vp an image of the crucyfyed Chri≈øte in the citye, and towrytte vpon it: The ≈øame is the God of the Chri≈øtians. But he commaunded to moke it, and ca≈øte fylthe vpon it, and all to defyle it. The
Emperours wyfe and doughters wyth other hone≈øt matrones were drawen to a banket, and there were they fyr≈øt mi≈øu≈øed, after that hewed to peces The≈øe examples, and other moo≈øte cruel dedes of ye Turkes, ought duely to ray≈øe and ≈øtyrre our mindes, that we ≈øhulde earne≈øtly fight agayn≈øt tho≈øe enemyes,The Turkes are bea≈øtes & not tirauntes whyche one nede not to call tyrauntes, but rather cruel bea≈øtes.

The yeare .M. CCCC. lxi. dyd the by≈øh. of Ro. depo≈øe Dietericke of I≈øenburge from hys by≈øhoprycke, and in hys ≈øteade was made Adolphe of Na≈ø≈øau. This chaunce gaue an occa≈øion of greate warres in the Empyre. Friderick the counte Palatyne toke vpon hym to defende & retayn by≈øhop Dieterych. Agayn≈øte the ≈øame dyd the Emperour ≈øturre the erles of Wyrtenberg and Baden, and the by≈øh. of Mentz. Whan the≈øe ≈øpoyled ye contry of ye count Palatine, they were taken by Frideryck count Palatine about the yeare .M. CCCC. lxii.
The ≈øame yeare dyd contrarye wy≈øe Adolfe the by≈øhop take in the citye Mentz.

The yeare .M. CCCC. lxiij. was Friderick the Emperoure ≈øtrongly be≈øieged in the ca≈øtel at Vienna, by hys citye≈øins, and the doer of thys was Albert, the Emperours brother: but George kyng of the Bohemes delyuered the Emperoure, driuing awaye the citye≈øins.

The yere .M. CCCC. lxxiiii. dyd Charles prince of the Burgundyons be≈øyege the towne Nuce a whole yeare, and that becau≈øe the chapiter chanoÃÑs of Colen had dryeuen out Rupert by≈øhoppe of Colen, whome Charles wold haue re≈øtored agayne.
But whan he went about to, turne the by≈øhopryck of Colen from the empyre &, haue gotten it to him, the Emperour appoynteth an army agayn≈øt hym.

The captayne of the hoo≈øt was Albert marques of Brandenburg, and the empyres ≈øtandardebearer Albert duke of Saxony. At the la≈øt whan diuer≈øly was treated of alayenge the debate, Charles gaue place: and it is ≈øayde, that at y‚Ä¢ tyme was fyr≈øt treated of geuyng Maximilian the doughter of Charles of Burgundy.

The yeare .M. CCCC. lxxvii. was the duke of Burgundy vanqui≈øhed by Nan≈øen, by them of Lotayn and the Switzers, and ≈ølayne. For Charles had taken from them of Lorain Nan≈øen: & in SwitzerlandNan≈øen‚ñ™ Gran≈øen. had he taken in Gran≈øen, and other ≈ømall townes: be≈øides that al≈øo, cau≈øed he in the towne of Gran≈øen, to be hanged .v. C. and .xii. Germanes.

Whan Charles was deade, the Frenchemen enterpri≈øed to ioyne Flaunders and Brabant to theyr kingdom, & this de≈øyre of the Frenchmen brought the cau≈øe of great warres. But whan the Burgundions wold not that theyr duchies ≈øhuld be ≈øtraunged or alienated from Charles doughter, they delivered to wedde Charles doughter to MaximilianMaximiliane. ≈øon to Friderick the Emperour. Wherfore Maximiliane went wel appointed into BrabaÃÑt, the yeare M. cccc. lxxvii. and wedded Mary Charles doughter: whereby it came to pa≈ø≈øe, that he augmeÃÑted not a litle the glory of the Ea≈øtenrychs name, and that MaximiliaÃÑ did many renowmed prowe≈ø≈øes, to defende tho≈øe countryes agayn≈øte the a≈ø≈øaulte of the Frenchemen.

The yeare .M. cccclxxxvi. was Maximilian made Emperoure: at Aken he was crowned the tenth daie of Apryll. When he was cho≈øen Emperoure at Franckforde, Albert marques of Brandenburg dyed there, whome the Italian hi≈øtory writers al≈øo do geue the pray≈øe of a ≈øage and wy≈øe prince, and al≈øo a doughty man of armes.

The yeare .M. cccclxxxvii. was MaximilianeMaximilian istakeÃÑ at Brudgis. taken of his ≈øubiectes at Brudgis in FlauÃÑders, by a preuy trayne of the Frenchemen. But when Frede rick came downe into lowe Germany, furny≈øhed wyth the ayde of the whole empyre, Maximilian was letten fre of them of Brudgis.
The yeare .M. ccccxc. he a≈øked agayne and tokeFrederick dyeth. po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his hereditary landes of the duchy of Ea≈øtenriche, the whiche Mathy kyng of Hungary had taken in.

The yere M. ccccxciii. dyed Frederick the third Emperonre in the towne Lyntz, and was buried at Vienne. The ≈øame yeare dyd the Turkes fall in to Croacia: but they were dryuen backe agayne by Maximiliane, that then was in Ea≈øtenriche, ≈øurny≈øhed wyth an army of fyftenth ou ≈øaude men.

When Eugenius the .iiij. was deade, NicolausNicolaus the v. a fauourer of learnedineÃÑ the .v. was made by ≈øhop of Rome. Friderick the Emperoure was crowned of hym, and he entertayned with mo≈øte hygh liberalitie not onely learned men of Italy: but al≈øo ≈øuche as were fled from Con ≈øtantinople to Rome, namely Gaza, Trapezontius, Argyropylos, by who≈øe procurement al good ≈øciences are renewed and amended.
Cali≈øtus the .iij. was by≈øh. of Ro. after Nicolaus.

Pius the .ij. before called Eneas Syluius ≈øuccededEneas Siluius. Cali≈øtus. He was Frederick the Emperoures Chaunceller. He had gathered a greate army of all nacions again≈øt the Turkes: but while the army is demi≈ø≈øed without doynge any thyng.
Paulus the .ij. was after Pius.

Xy≈øtus the .iiii. was by ≈øhop of Rome after Paulus. In his tyme the yeare .M. cccclxxx. dyd MahometesMahometes be≈øyeged Hydruntum. the Turky≈øh Emperour be≈øyege Hydruntum in Italy, and wanne it, v≈øyng therein incredible tyranny. Italy was ≈øo a≈ørayed, that Xy≈øtus the Romy≈øh by≈øhop made hrm reade to flye into Fraunce. But Mahometes died the ≈øame time when Hydruntum was a takynge, and that by ≈øome de≈øtiny, le≈øt he ≈øhould ≈øtraie farther into Italy. MoreouerAlfon≈ø ‚Ä¢ kyng of Naples. whyle this was dayng, Alfon≈øus kyng of Naples, warred with them of Sena: but when he harde the tydyngs of Hydruntum, he hai≈øted to returne into his kyngdome, and getteth the be≈øyeged citye HydruntuÃÑ out of the Turkes handes. For whyle Mahometes was deade, and that the Turkes hay≈øted now to returne home, le≈øt any variaunce myght ry≈øe in their kyngdome, Alfon≈øus obteined the citie ea≈øely, driuyng the Turkes out of Italy.
After Xy≈øtus was InnoceÃÑtius the .viii. by. of Ro.

Alexander the the .vi. was made by≈øhop of Ro.The prince of ‚Ä¢ rbinas ≈øayenge. after Innocentius. The ≈øame had a ≈øonne duke of Valencia, whom he made prince of Vrbinas. Hys ≈øayeng it was: O Ce≈øar, o nullo. that is: Ether Emperoure, or nothyng. At the la≈øt was he nothyng. For he was ≈ølayne for his ≈øundry craftes, that were mengled with gite and deceate.

The beginning of the ≈øcience of printyng, is ≈øaydThe ≈øcience o ‚Ä¢ printyng. to haue bene vnder Frederick the thyrd: and thys ≈øcience of boke printing they ≈øaye to haue ben found fyr≈øt at Mentz, the yeare .M. cccc. xl.
The craft of the gonnes is much elder, & it is ≈øuppo≈øedThe craft of gonnes. that the ≈øame was al≈øo founde in Germany, by a frear the yeare .M. ccc. lxxx.

div.head: Maxi milianus the .xxxviii. Germane Emperoure.
div.p: THe yeare of Chri≈øte .M. ccccxciiii. beganMaximilianus the Emperoure. Maximilianus hys raygne, when his father was deade, with whome he gouerned the empyre his lyfe tyme .viii. yeres. But after hys fathers decea≈ø≈øe raygned he .xxv. yeares. Though the begynnynges of the empyre were lowe and weake: yet at the la≈øt turned they to hygh auauncement and encrea≈øe of the Germane kyngdome.

In the begynnynge of Maximilanus raygne,Charles with the bunched back the FreÃÑ che kyng. brought Charles wyth the crooked backe an army into Italy, and toke Naples. But a yeare after, when he was returned into Fraunce, gat FerdinaÃÑ dus the yonger Naples agayne with ayde of Maximilian dryuynge the Frenchemen out of Italy, whiche the Frenche kynge had left at Naples, for a garry≈øon.

Maximilian had many and great battails. Fir≈øt in low Germany. Flaunders and Brabant, in the whiche it is ≈øayd he dyd many noble actes with his owne hande, where of I haue herde ≈øome, but I know not the very truth thereof. And would God
there would once come one that is ≈øure of ≈øuch thynges, who would writh all tho≈øe hi≈øtories in a coÃÑplet boke to the pray≈øe of ≈øo greate a prince, and myght auaunce worthely, before the worlde the puy≈ø≈øaunce and vertues of ≈øo doughty an Emperoure. I my≈øelfePyrcamer. haue herde of Pyrcamer of Norenberg, that Maximiliane hym≈øelfe had written ≈øome of his dedes for certayne yeares. For he ≈øayde: He ≈øayled from Lynda to Con≈øtance with Maximilian the Emperoure: and when Maximilian was nowe at lea≈øure in ≈øaylyng, he called his Scribe to hym, and reher≈øed to hym in Latine hys dedes of one yeare, in a mo≈øte feate order, with the declaracion of all the circun≈øtaunces and occa≈øions. But when Pyrcamer thought the Scribe ≈øhould note ≈øome ≈øecrete thynge, and therefore would auoyde, the Emperoure coÃÑmaunded hym to remayne and ly≈øten. Yea and at euening he toke it to Pyrcamer that he had reher≈øed to rede, and a≈øked: whether that ≈øouldiours Latine dyd lyke hym? and ≈øhould haue ≈øayde moreouer: He were mynded to comprehende tho≈øe thynges ≈øo brefely and clerely, that afterwarde learned men might declare them ≈øo muche the more diligently by their cau≈øes and circum≈øtaunces. And Pyrcamer ≈øayde: that no Germane hi≈øtory writer had v≈øed ≈øo pure a ≈øtile, as was that of Maximilian: And that after maximilianus death he had a≈øked after this writynge, but he coulde not obteine it. But let this ≈øuffy≈øe to be ≈øpoken of low Germany.

The yeare .M. ccccxcv. was in the parliamentWhen the duchy of WirteÃÑ berg began. holden at Worms of the earldome of Wirtenberg made a duchy, and erle Ebrarde was made the
fyr≈øt duke.

The yeare .Mccccxcix. toke the Switzers warrThe ≈øwitzers warre again≈øt their neighbours them of Ea≈øtenriche. again≈øt their neyghbours them of Ea≈øtenrich, the whiche to re≈øcue, Maximiliane came hay≈øtely out of Gelderlande, where at that tyme he had to do al ≈øo. Wherefore hauing many ≈økyrmy≈øhes of both ≈øydes, it is certayn that .xx. thou≈øand meÃÑ were ≈ølayn: at the la≈øt was an agrement made.
The yeare .MDi. were euery where figures ofFigures of a cro≈ø≈øe ≈øene vpon garmeÃÑts. cro≈ø≈øes ≈øene vpon mens garmentes. But ≈øuche lyke was oft happened before al≈øo.

The yeare .MDiiij. was the warre of Baierlande,The warre of Baier. wherein the Emperoure Maximilianus defended the princes of Baier, agayn≈øt Philip count Palatine of the Rene, and duke Ruperte ≈øonne to Philippe the Palatine. For the ≈øame maryeng the daughter of George duke of Baier, woulde haue Landshut and that≈øame parte of Baier to be geueÃÑ ouer to hym by a tytle of inheritaunce. But Rupertus dyed with his ≈øpou≈øe, whyle this warre was in hand, & the count Palatine was put be≈øyde a great parte of his lorde≈øhyppe by the Emperoures men and them of Wirtenberg. Yea and a great army of the Bohemyes that came to helpe the count Palatine, were ouerthrowen of the Emperoure. At the la≈øt neuerthele≈ø≈øe Maximilian v≈øyng no le≈ø≈øe wy≈ødoÃÑ than fauoure, toke the count Palatine to mercy, le≈øt any perturbacion myght be ray≈øed in the ryght of the election in the empyre, that long ≈øence was alowed and approued.

The yeare .MDv. be≈øyeged the army of the Emperoure the duke of Gelders in the citie Arnheym,
and con≈øtrayned hym to yelde hym≈øelfe.

The yeare .MDvi. died Philippe ≈øonne to Maximilian,Philip ≈øonne to Maximilian d „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ th Maximilian warreth again≈øt the Venecians. Lewis kyng of Fraunce. kyng of Spayne and duke of bourgundy, beyng of age .xxviii. yeares.

The yeare .MDvii. beganne Maximiliane the warre again≈øte the Venecians, no le≈ø≈øe greate then durable: in the whiche befell both many bloudy battails, and wonderfull mutacions. Lewis kynge of Fraunce was fir≈øt with the Venecians, afterwarde fell he from them to the Emperour. Contrary wy≈øe the by≈øhop of Rome Iulius, was fir≈øt of the Emperoures ≈øyde, afterwarde toke he parte with the Venecians. The Venecians lo≈øt in this warretheir be≈øt cities. Verona, Pauy, Teruas & other many. Howbeit when the Romy≈øh by≈øhop deciuered and fell to the Venecians, the Frenche kyng began to warre vpon hym al≈øo, ≈øeyng he had yet the Emperours ≈øouldiours in Italy. Now feared the Emperoure, le≈øt if he had the victory, he ≈øhuld fall into Naples al≈øo, and do al≈øo ≈øome euell at Rome, to the empyres de≈øtruction. Wherfore he ≈øent the Cardinall Matheus Langius bi≈øhop of Saltzburg one of his coun≈øaill to Iulius the by≈øhop of Ro. to demaunde peace, before the Ro. by≈øhop and the Frenche kyngIulius the by ≈øhop of Rom. was di≈øcomfited in a battaill by the citie Rauennas vpon Ea≈øter daye. had foughten a felde. Iulius, for a≈ømuch as he was very well appoynted with the ayde of Spaniardes and Italians, he thought to be ≈øure of the victory, & therfore refu≈øed he the peace. The battail was vpoÃÑ Ea≈øter daie the yeare .MDxii. by Rauennas. The by≈øhop of Romes ho≈øt lay vnder, & there were ≈ølain in that battaill ≈øyxtene thou≈øand. Nether is there red of a more greuous felde to haue ben about this
tyme, wherein men haue fought ≈øo fearcely. But after this victory lo≈øt, dyd Iulius frely demauÃÑde peace. Howbeit le≈øt the French kyng enterpri≈øedought farther in Italy, dyd Maximilian and the by≈øh. of Rome ≈øet the kyng of Englande, Germany and the Switzers again≈øt hym: and of this wy≈øe was the Frenche kyng at the la≈øt con≈øtrained to leaue Italy. The Venecians were afterwarde reconciled to to the Emperoure al≈øo.

The yere .MDxix. dyed Maximilian the Emperoure, and that≈øame yere the princes ElectorsWhat Electors cho≈øe Charles that now is Emperoure. Albert Cardinall by≈øhop of Mentz. Herman by≈øhop of Colen erle of Wida. Richarde by≈øhop of Trierlorde of Grieffenklau, the deputie of Lewis kyng of Bohemy. Lewis couÃÑt Palatine of the Rene. Frederick duke of Saxony. Ioachim marques of Brandenburg, did cho≈øe lawfull and with great wi≈ødom at FraÃÑckford Charles duke of Ea≈øteÃÑ ryche and Bourgundy, and kyng of Spayne, the xxviii. daye of Iune.
Pius the iij. was by≈øh. of Ro. after alexander the vi. The ≈øame died ≈øhortely after.

Iulius the .ij. ≈øucceded Pius. Again≈øt him wrote BernardinÍù∞ the Cardinal in the tyme of the Venecian warre of kepyng a coun≈øail. The matter ≈øhuld haue geuen an occa≈øion of a diui≈øion, had not Maximilian preuented it by his ≈øyngulare wi≈øedome.
Leo the .x. ≈øonne to Laurence Medices was made by≈øhop of Rome. after Iulius.

In the tyme of this Leo y‚Ä¢ yere .MDxvii. wroteMartine Luther‚ñ™ Martin Luther fyr≈øt again≈øt the Romy≈øh by≈øhops pardons, & from thence ro≈øe many di≈øputacioÃÑs after ward, whiche thynge cau≈øed no ≈ømall alteracionin
the churche by the Germanes.

div.head: Charles the .v. the .xxxix. Germane Emperoure.
div.p: ‚Ä¢ He yeare .MD. xix. was Charles the .v.Charles y‚Ä¢. cho≈øen Emperoure the nepheu to Maximilians, kynge of Spayne, prince of Ea≈øtenryche and Burgundy. The Electors ≈øent into Spayne to ≈øhewe Charles of this election Friderick count Palatine. Wherfore the next yeare after he came into Germany, and was crowned Emperoure at Aken.

The yeare .MDxxv. was Frances the FrencheFrances the French king taken. kyng taken by Pauy in Lombardy, by the Emperoures ≈øouldiours in a felde, and afterwarde brought into Spayne. Charles v≈øed a very incredible gentlene≈ø≈øe & moderacion of mynde in ≈øo great pro≈øperitie of victory. For he dyd not onely let fre the Frenche kyng, re≈øtoryng hym to his kyngdom: but al≈øo bounde hym with affinitie to hym, geuing hym his ≈øy≈øter Leonora to wyfe. The capitaines of the battail, whereof we ≈øaied euen now, were Nicolas couÃÑt of Salma, George of FruÃÑ≈øberg knight, Mark Sittich, duke Burbon, & the marques Pi≈økerame.

The ≈øame yeare were ray≈øed in Germany horribleThe commotion of vplan
‚Ä¢ y ‚Ä¢ h m ‚Ä¢ n. and neuer afore herde comotions, by vplandi≈øhe men in El≈øace, Schwaben, FrankenlaÃÑd, ThuringeÃÑ, and in tho≈øe contreis that lye by the Rhene. This commotion was alayed by the great force & armes of the princes, ≈øo that within the ≈øpace of thre monethes nere hande, were ≈ølame in battaill aboue hundreth thou≈øand vplaÃÑdy≈øh men, none other wy≈øe theÃÑ
as bea≈øtes. Moreouer one called Schapler, wroteSchapler. Twelue articles of the ≈øedicious ru≈øtikes. xii. artickes of the Chri≈øteÃÑ libertie, among the whiche this was euen the chefe≈øt: Tribute ought not to be geuen to the magi≈øtrate or ≈øuperioritie. By thys doctrine, vpon hope to get libertie, the grete≈øt part of the ru≈øtikes beyng enflamed, it is ≈øaide to haue taken weapons agayn≈øt their lawfull magi≈øtrate. In the towne of Thuringen, called Mulhau≈øen, was aThomas Mynter. preacher, called Thomas Mynter. The ≈øame preached openly, that he ≈øhoulde re≈øtore the decayed ≈øtate of the churche: and dyd boi≈øte, that reuelacions were priuely ≈øhewed him: and that Gedeons ≈øword was geuen hym, to roote out the tyranny of the vngodly. He led forth by heapes the vplandi≈øh men, and commaunded the hou≈øes of gentlemen to bee ≈øpoyled, and the goodes of mona≈øteries to be polled and wai≈øted. But when the ru≈øtical armies ≈øpoiled euery where without order, the prince of Saxony and Landgraue of He≈ø≈øe de≈øtroied them. Thomas Mynter and ≈øome of his felowes were takeÃÑ and beheaded, and were puny≈øhed for their enterpry≈øe. This Mynter was the fir≈øt begynner of the madde erroure of the Anabapti≈øtes, which yet cau≈øeth muche ado in Germany.

The yere .MDxxv. dyd Iohn OecolampadiusIohn Ocal ‚Ä¢
padius & Huldrich Zwinglius renew the doctrine of Berengarius ‚Ä¢ ndreas ‚Ä¢ arole≈øtadius. at Ba≈øel, and Huldrich zwinglius in zwizerlande fyr≈øt of all with there writing renewed the doctrine of Berengarius that in the bread and wyne was not really pre≈øent the body and bloude of Chri≈øte, though the yeare before the learned man Andrew Carolo≈øtadius had propo≈øed the ≈øame argument.

The yeare .MDxxvi. was Lewis kyng of HuÃÑ gary
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ayne by Solyman the Turky≈øh Emperour.

The yere .MDxxvij. dyd duke Burbon bryngeRome taken by Burbon. the Emperoures hoo≈øt to Rome, the citie was be≈øieged and taken, and al≈øo ≈øpoyled. The by≈øhop of Ro. con≈øtrayned by nece≈ø≈øitie into the Ca≈øtell angel, yelded hym≈øelfe to the Emperoures men: but the Emperoure of his gentlene≈ø≈øe let hym fre agayne, and re≈øtored hym to hys former dignitie, that the common peace of Chri≈øtendome were nothyndered.
The yere .MDxxix. went Charles into Italy, & was receaued of all princes and cities, with mo≈øte hygh honoures.

The ≈øame yeare in the moneth of October theWith what an ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ o≈øt Sol „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ yd be
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ge ‚Ä¢ ieÃÑn ‚Ä¢ . Turky≈øh Emperoure Solyman brought about a hundreth and fourty thou≈øand men into Germany whiche nomber they ≈øhoulde afterward haue boa≈øted them≈øelues in the citie Cracowe in Polen: and be≈øieged the citie Vienne certayn wekes and a≈ø≈øaulted it greueou≈øly. But Friderick count Palatine, apointed by the empire captaine of the ≈øouldiours, gatheryng an army with all ≈øpede, ≈øent it to VieÃÑne, thre dayes before the Turke be≈øieged it. Philippe counte Palatine was with them in the citie VieÃÑne. Wherfore by the gracious fauoure of God was the citie Vienne ≈øo ≈øtrongly defended, that the Turki≈øh tyrauÃÑt was fayne to turne backe agayn with great ≈øhame, and lo≈ø≈øe of hys ho≈øt. The me≈ø≈øaunger of the Poles is reported to haue ≈øayde: that in the a≈ø≈øault of Vienne, were ≈ølayne about foure ≈øcore Turkes, and partely to haue dyed by the waye, for lacke of ‚Ä¢ itayls, and fearcene≈ø≈øe of the colde.

The yeare .MDxxx. the .xxij. daye of February,
was Charles crowned Emperoure at Bonony byCharles is crowned Emperour at Bonony by the by≈øh. of Ro. Clemens the by≈øhop of Rome with a great ≈øolemnitie and co≈øte.

After that went he agayne into Germany, and came on Corpus Chi≈øt euen at Au≈øborow, wherthe parliament was adiourned. The chefe princes of Germany came thether, of whom Charles the Emperoure was receaued with high honour. ThoughThe parliament of ‚Ä¢ u≈øborow. the Emperour a≈ø≈øaied many waies to appeace y‚Ä¢ debates in the religion, & to re≈øtore them into a quietne≈ø≈øe, yet could no certayne thynge be brought to pa≈ø≈øe or ordeined, in ≈øo great diuer≈øitie of myndes. At the la≈øt commaunded he by an open commaundement to retaine and kepe the acco≈øtumed maners of ceremonies, and the doctrine afore v≈øed.

The ≈øame yeare. the eight daye of October, wasAn ouerflowyng at Ro. an ouerflowynge at Rome ≈øo greate, as no man coulde remembre to haue bene ≈øene, and the ≈øame la≈øted about foure and twenty houres: and when thys ouerflowynge ≈øtode ≈øtyll in the place called Campo Flore, the hyght of a longe mory≈øhpycke, many buildynges, walles, hou≈øes and goodes were de≈øtroyed.
When Leo was deade, Adrianus alowe Germane, borne at Vtrecht was made by≈øhop of Rome.

After Adrianus was Clemens the .vij. cho≈øenClemens the vij. is taken. by. of Ro. The ≈øame was taken by the Emperours hoo≈øt at Rome, for makyng a confederacy with the Frenche kynge, whome al≈øo he ≈øent ayde agayn≈øte the Emperor. But the ≈øame iniury dyd y‚Ä¢ very good Emperoure di≈ø≈øemble with hygh ≈øoftne≈ø≈øe: and le≈øt any occa≈øion myght ry≈øe of a greueous debate
in Chri≈øtendom, he ≈øet the by≈øhop of Rome ClemeÃÑs the .vij. at libertie, of whome he was afterwarde crowned at Bonony.

div.head: Ferdinande the .xl. Germane Emperoure.
div.p: THe yeare .MDxxx. was FerdinaÃÑde kingFerdinande kyng of Hungary. of Hungary and Bohemy, Archeduke of Ea≈øtenriche &c. brother to Charles the Emperoure, made kyng of the Romanes: and that after the example of the auÃÑcient Emperours, which were wont to take to them other, that the empyre myght haue a ≈øucce≈ø≈øor, and that when the other were deade, no debate or occa≈øion of warre myght ry≈øe amonge the princes of the empyre. This election was at Colen the yeare .MDxxx.
The yeare .MDxxxi. was Ferdinande after the election crowned at Aken in Ianuary.

The ≈øame yeare was a Comete ≈øene in Germany,A Comete ≈øene. Italy Fraunce and Englande, about the ≈øyxte daye of Augu≈øte, and fyr≈øt appeared it certayne dayes in the morning before Sunne ri≈øing, after that folowed it the Sunne, and was ≈øene the ≈øpace of. iij wekes about the euenyng, after Sunne ≈øett, vntyll the thyrd daye of September. Hys cour≈øe was through the cele≈øtiall or heauenly ≈øygnes Cancer. Leo, Virgo and Libra, where it was ≈øene nomore nether appeared any more after that.

Not long after in October ro≈øe a warre in SwitzerThe Switzer warre within them≈øelues. lande. For to they of Tzurich ≈øtopped the pa≈ø≈øages, that to their neghburs of zugia, Vria. Suicia.
