Siluia and Lucerne, noman coulde bryng corne, ≈øalte and other victuals. Wherfore they armed theÃÑ again≈øt tho≈øe of Tzurich. They met eche other wt di≈øplaied banners, & they of Tzurich beyng vanqui≈øhed with thre fieldes, had the wor≈øt. In the fyr≈øt battayll was ≈ølayne the preacher of Tzurich, Huldrich zwinglius. In the meane tyme endeuoured they of Stralborow and Con≈øtance their neighbours, to make an accorde among the coÃÑfederated. And thus after .viij. monethes and .vi. wekes was the vproure alayed. Of theÃÑ of Tzurich died about fyue thou≈øande, of the other ≈øyde a fewe.

The yeare M D. xxxii. came Charles the Emperoure againe out of Brabant into Germany, and came in Marche with his brother kyng Ferdinand to Regen≈øpurg to kepe a parliament. ThithercameThe parliament holden at RegeÃÑ≈øpurg the deputies ≈øent froÃÑ the Imperial cities. There came al≈øo many princes, or at the lea≈øte, their Amba≈ø≈øadours.

Not very long before that Con≈øtantinople was taken by the Turkes, I reade there was a ≈øolitary man, not farre from the citie Con≈øtantinople, and he ≈øhuld haue prophecied: that the Turkes in dedeProphecies of recouering Con≈øtantinople, and of roting the Turkes out of Europa. ≈øhould winne Con≈øtantinople, and ≈øhould roote out the kyngdom of the Grekes: but anone after foure ≈øcore yeres, ≈øhould they lo≈øe Con≈øtantinople agayn, and that the Turkes ≈øhould be rooted out of Europa. But that tyme ≈øence CoÃÑ≈øtantinople was wonne, is expired the la≈øt yeare.

A mo≈øt connyng A≈øtronomer al≈øo at Naples, calledLaurentius Miniaten≈øis an A≈øtronomer. LaureÃÑtius Miniaten≈øis, ≈øcholemai≈øter to Pontanus, wrote the≈øe ver≈øes in his boke .lx. yeres ago,
concernyng the coniunction of Iupiter and Saturnus in the ≈øygne Cancer, the whiche he ≈øayeth ≈øhall be, and was in the yeare thou≈øande, fyue hundreth and foure la≈øt pa≈øt.

lg.l: That age ≈øuccedyng oures vpon the heles.
Shalbe better, and more pray≈øe worthy,
Lytle of oure lawe ≈øhall it di≈øanull ≈øcarcely:
But the greueous and harde to ≈øuffer thynges.
In holy matters, ≈øhall it auoyde doubtle≈ø≈øe.
All kynd of wickedne≈ø≈øe, and al≈øo holy pryde.
A kyng al≈øo ≈øhall it geue vs harmele≈ø≈øe,
Who ≈øhall the worlde ende, and peoples repre≈ø≈øe:
Rebellyng nacioÃÑs ≈øhall he ≈øubdue to the empyre.
And the whole worldes dominioÃÑ ≈øhall he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe.

div.p: The≈øe ver≈øes are mo≈øte worthy to be marked: and I woulde not pa≈ø≈øe them ouer, becau≈øe of the renowme of the mo≈øte famous Emperour. For what hygher pray≈øe can be in the Emperour, then that he calleth hym a Harmele≈ø≈øe kyng, euen as Iohn Lichteberg ≈øayde of hym: The ≈øhamefa≈øt of vi≈øage ≈øhall raygne euery where.

At Magdeburg is founde .C. yere ago a Latine cronicle, wherin are the≈øe wordes: Of the bloude of Charles the Emperour, and the kynges of FrauÃÑce, ≈øhalbe borne an Emperoure, called Charles: the≈øame ≈øhal haue dominion in all Europa, by whom al≈øo the decayed e≈øtate of the church, ≈øhalbe repared, and the auncient glory of the empyre ≈øhalbe re≈øtored. For there ≈øhall come a people, that ≈øhalbe called: people without heade, and than we to the prie≈øtes: Peters lytle ≈øhyppe ≈øhall ≈øuffre greate force, but the waues ≈øhall cra≈ø≈øe at the la≈øt, and it ≈øhall haue victory.
Greate and dredefull mutacions of al kyngdomes, are at hande, and the ≈øettyng ≈øtore by monkes, ≈øhall pery≈øhe. The Bea≈øte of the We≈øt, and the Lion of the Ea≈øte ≈øhall haue dominion of the whole worlde, and the Chri≈øtians ≈øhallwander through A≈øia in ≈øauegarde fyftene yeares: but after that ≈øhal dredeful thynges be herde of Antichri≈øte.
Abbas Ioachim ≈øaieth in the ende of Ieremye: A great Egle ≈øhall come, whiche ≈øhall ouercome euery man ≈øaue one, who at the la≈øt beynge de≈øpy≈øed, ≈øhalbe for ≈øaken of the people.

I fynde al≈øo another prophecie, whiche is renowmed: The Emperoure ≈øhalbe awaked, as a man fallen into a ≈øwete ≈ølepe. The ≈øame ≈øhalbe counted of men as deade, and ≈øhall go vp vpon the greate ≈øea, and inuade the Turkes, and ≈øhall ouercome them: he ≈øhall leade their wyues and Chyldren captiues. Greate feare and drede ≈øhall ouerwhelme the Turkes, their wyues and chyldren ≈øhall wepe and lamente: all the Turkes landes ≈øhalbe geuen ouer in to the Emperours handes of Rome.

I haue herde a Portingale ≈øaye, that an A≈øtronomer ≈øhould haue ≈øayde to Ferdinandus oure Emperoures greate graundefather: that the Turky≈øh empyre ≈øhoulde be ≈øubdued and ouerthrowen by a kyng of Spayne, and that the ≈øame ≈øhould haue interpretated the kyng to be Ferdinande. But Ferdinande ≈øhould haue an≈øwered: That he ≈øhoulde not do it, but hys heyres that ≈øhould ≈øuccede hym.

Other emdences more that are yet re≈øtyng, wyl I at this tyme pa≈ø≈øe ouer. God the father of mercy, geue and graunte Chri≈øtendom victory and grace,
for the glories ≈øake of his godly name. Amen.

Moreouer the thinges that ≈øhal yet happen, ≈øhal doutle≈ø≈øe marke greate and wy≈øe men, whiche are now in this ≈øettyng forth of warre. As for me, I haue onely reher≈øed ≈øuche thynges of this preparacion of the ≈øettynge forth to warre, as I was ≈øure of, and therefore do I now make an ende of wrytynge.

In the moneth of September this yeare, wasA Comete ≈øene. a Comete ≈øene agayne certayn wekes, two houres before Sunne ry≈øyng, and toward the Ea≈øte. WheÃÑ I ≈øawe it, it was in Virgo to my iudgemen, & ≈øtretched his brandy≈øhynge tayll betwene the South & We≈øt. But by rea≈øon of the gloumynge and cloudy ayer in the≈øe contreis, coulde it not be ≈øene here. Howbeit, who wil not iudge it to be a fearfullthing, that two Cometes haue bene ≈øene in the ≈øpace nerehande of twelue monethes? and ≈øeyng the Comete of the la≈øt yere, namely of the yere M D. xxxi. dyd not appeare without the hurte of Ea≈øte and North: for it ≈øemed to threaten tho≈øe partes. For the tyranny≈øhe Turke fell into Hungary and Ea≈øtenryche kyng Chri≈øtiernus goyng into Dennemarck with a greate nauy, to demaunde againe his kyngdome, yelded hym≈øelfe into Frederick hys fathers brothers the kyng of Denmarck handes. Chri≈øtiernus al≈øo his ≈øonne, that was brought vp in the Emperours court, dyed. Veryly it is to be feared al≈øo, that the Comete of this yeare of. M D. xxxij. do ≈øignifye greate euell to the partes of Italy and the Rene.
The ende of the Cronicle.
The coÃÑclu≈øion of this Cronicle of Iohn Carion.

A boke of Chronicles ought to coÃÑprehende mo≈øte greate≈øt thynges in a feate order, ≈øo that the rekenyng of the yeares, and the chefe alteracions, that befall into the religion and other greate thynges may be ryght ob≈øerued and knowen. For it can not be that all thynges that are done in one realme, can be written in one boke, though it were great, by rea≈øon of the ≈øundry circum≈øtaunces and occa≈øions of y‚Ä¢ bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, the whiche mu≈øt chefely be con≈øydered. Of this wy≈øe truely wrote Herodotus, Theucydi des, Xenophon & TitÍù∞ Liuius hi≈øtories. The otherWriters of Hi≈øtories. Cronicles. are onely to be called Cronicle writers, whiche al≈øo ought not to take vpon them the name of Hi≈øtory wryters: For they do brefely ≈øhewe thynges done, and ≈øettyng the order of the tyme before, ≈øeme onely to aduerty≈øe the wy≈øe reader, to marke ≈øome of the notable≈øt thynges. Whiche thinge we haue done al≈øo in this Cronicle: we haue only drawen tho≈øe thinges as it were in a pathwaye, whiche ≈øemed mo≈øte be≈øt, and haue other whyles ≈øhewed their occa≈øions, to the intent we maye learne to marke and for≈øe ≈øo much thenarower ≈øuche lyke thynges, in like chauÃÑ ces, Howbeit what profites otherwi≈øe be≈øides this do Cronicles bryng, that ≈øame haue we declared before in the preface.

Truely I mu≈øte before the ende of this wryting put the reader agayne in remembraunce of the ≈øayeng of Elias, the whiche we haue ≈øet in the begynnyng of this treaty≈øe, that he may ≈øo much the more ea≈øyer marke both the order of the tyme, and al≈øo the dedes of the hi≈øtories. Item that he thinke that
al≈øo, that the ende of mens affaires is at hande, accordynge to the ≈øayeng of Elias, that the worldes age conteyneth .vi. M. yeares, and that the ≈øame ≈øpace ≈øhall not he fully expyred: for God ≈øhall preueÃÑt it becau≈øe of the worldes corrupte maners. Now ≈øeyeng there are expyred .v. M. and .v. C. yeares ≈øence the worlde beganne, as may clerely be gathered out of the table folowing: it is no doute but that the worldes age is nerehand come to the ende, that Chri≈øte our lorde do ray≈øe vp the death by his commyng, and iudge the whole worlde, and that more is al≈øo appoynt the deuels and wicked men euerla≈øtynge fyre, but take the very godly out of al ≈øorow, and ≈øet them into the euerla≈øting fruition of God & ble≈ø≈øe. Be≈øydes this do the wonderfull mutacions and chaunges of all kyngdomes nearehande wytne≈ø≈øe that the worlds ende is not farre of. For withWhat the mutacions of kyngdomes de ≈øignifye. in fewe yeares euen by our remembraunce we haue perceaued the hyghne≈ø≈øe of the Romi≈øh by≈øhop, Fraunce, Hungary and Dennemarckes kingdoms to haue greucou≈øly fallen, and lyke chauÃÑce are ≈øhortly to be loked for in other kyngdomes al≈øo. Daniel witne≈ø≈øeth that ≈øhortely after that the Turkes powers be miny≈øhed, ≈øhall the ende of all thynges of the worlde be at hande. But the Turky≈øh kyngdoÃÑs decaye ≈øhall doutle≈ø≈øe be ≈øene wythin few yeares (if Goddes wyll be ≈øo,) and after that our Emperoure Charles ≈øhalbe decea≈ø≈øed, it can not be, but that the empire al≈øo ≈øhalbe mi≈øerably toren of the Germans them≈øelues. For I feare me two wyll then greatly ≈øtryue for the monarchye. Almighty God of his infinitie mercy, ≈øwage ≈øo horrible commotions & turne the
princes hartes, to concorde and peace.

The toren tranquillitie and ≈øpoiled peace in the churche, maye al≈øo be a ≈øigne and token, and it is to be feared, le≈øt the ≈øame do al≈øo growe and ≈øprede farther by warres and negligence of Romi≈øh by ≈øhops.

But ≈øeyeng Chri≈øte hym≈øelfe aduerti≈øeth vs in the Go≈øpel of the perils, that ≈øhalbe at hande in the latter dayes, not only in tho≈øe thinges that pertayn to the body, but al≈øo tho≈øe that belong to the ≈øprete, yea the heauen it≈øelfe al≈øo threateneth with horryble darkeninges and coniunctions: I wil pa≈ø≈øe ouer to ≈øpeake of tho≈øe tokeÃÑs, that be reher≈øed in the ≈øcripture coÃÑcernyng the latter dayes, ≈øo that at the la≈øt we maye learne to beware & take hede to our ≈øelues and doute not to demaunde and loke for ayde and comfort of God onely in ≈øo greate mi≈øere of al thinges. Wherefore I willed the reader to be admony≈øhed in this place, to call to remembraunce, that tho≈øe tymes full of peryls & wretchedne≈ø≈øe, are at hand, and that the ≈øame peryls ought not to be de≈øpi≈øed with a rechele≈ø≈øe mynde. For it is no lyght thynge, and ≈øuche one as all maner of men do proue wyth their harme and damage, that realmes are chaunged, empires pulled out of their frames, and concorde of religion is ≈øpoyled. The buyldynge or fabrike of the worlde ≈øemeth to repre≈øente a greate and mo≈øte olde buyldynge, whyche oftentymes is more and more ready to fall, when nowe doth one wall fall downe, then the other. Likewi≈øe doth the world ≈øeme to be ready to fal at this time, & doth by litle and litle bryng a more greuous fal with it, one and other kyngdomes falling down and decayeng.
Nether let any man thynke that ≈øo greate a buyldyng ≈øhall fall without a mo≈øte excedynge commotion. God lyghten oure myndes, that we beyng admony≈øhed with the earne≈øt threatenynges of the Go≈øpell, maye ≈øeke at onely Chri≈øte con≈øolation and refre≈øhynge: and that greate princes maye v≈øe no le≈ø≈øe wy≈øedome in the feare of God, then mekene≈ø≈øe, to a≈ø≈øuage the occa≈øions of all euels. For thereto are they ordeined of God, that with their care and wi≈øedom, they maye gouerne and defende mankynd that is weake & wretched. And yf they do their duetye in the feare of God. God ≈øhall lykewy≈øe be with them, and pro≈øper their enterpry≈øes.

div.head: A Table of the worldes yeares, out of the Bible and Philo.

div.p: This pre≈øent yeare .MDxxxii. are accompli≈øhed ≈øence the worlde was made .v. M. CCCC. lxxvi. yeares.

The citie Rome (as witne≈ø≈øeth Eutropius) ≈øtode before Chri≈øte was borne .vij. C. liij. yeares: and yf the yeares ≈øhoulde be counted a ryght, it can in a maner be no better rekened by true hi≈øtories.

This pre≈øent yere of oure lorde .MDxxxij. are pa≈øt ≈øence the citie Rome was builded. ii M. CClxx xv. yeres. Babylon was not ≈øo olde before Alexander. For from Abraham vntyll Alexanders tyme are .M. vi. C. lxxxvi. yeares. But now ≈øeyeng Rome is elder then Babylon, it is no doubte but that her ende ≈øhalbe ≈øhortely al≈øo, after the twoo Monarchies.

Nether doth the nomber of the yeares that is in the Bible greately di≈øagre from the order of the Monarchies that is in the chefe aucthors of the Greke hi≈øtories. Herodotus wryteth that the A≈ø≈øyrians kept the Monarchie .Dxx. yeares, and ≈øence that tyme to haue bene no certayne Monarchye, vntyll the tyme of the Medes. He rekeneth the Medes to haue ruled vntyll Cyrus tyme C. xxx. yeares. And the ≈øame, as it can not ≈øeme fal≈øe, euen ≈øo do I greatly alowe it: for yf any man do waye it aryght, the ≈øame ≈øhall ea≈øely perceaue that it doth not di≈øagre wyth the Bible. That he ≈øayeth the monarchy of the A≈ø≈øyrians to haue ≈øtand .Dxx. yeares, that wyll he doubtle≈ø≈øe haue referred to that tyme, when the kyngdome of Babilon and Niniue the citie were not yet diuided, euen when the A≈ø≈øyrians reygned only at Babylon.

Agathias wryteth in the ≈øeconde booke of theAgathias. Gothian warre, that Cte≈øias ≈øet the nomber of the yeares, and the order of the Monarchies of thys wy≈øe. As for Cte≈øias was a Grecian, who whenCte≈øias. Artaxerxes Mnemon and Cyrus the yonger warred with eche other, he was al≈øo in the army, and was a Phi≈øician. Beynge taken in warre, he was at the la≈øt caried to Babylon, where he was hone≈øtly entreated, and then readynge the hy≈øtoryes of Babylon, he ≈øet the nomber of that kyngdome in an order of this wy≈øe.

From Ninus vntyll the begynnyng of the Medes kyngdome, wiche did deciuer from the A≈ø≈øyryans the fyr≈øte, are .M. CCC. lx. yeares, and this order do all tho≈øe ob≈øerue, that wrote afterwarde, Diodorus Siculus and Iu≈øtinus. Diodorus Siculus wrote of this wy≈øe in his thyrde booke: Lyke wy≈øe al≈øo the re≈øydue of the kynges thyrty in nomber, helde the kyngdome, vntyll Sardanapulus, by who≈øe tyme, the kyngdome of the A≈ø≈øyrians, which had la≈øted .M. CCC. lx. yeares, (as wryteth Cte≈øias in the ≈øeconde booke,) fell to the Medes. Iu≈øtinus ≈øayeth of this wy≈øe: The a≈ø≈øyrians, who afterwarde were called Syria, had the gouernaunce M. CCC. yeres. Herodotus doth pa≈ø≈øe ouer ≈øomthynge, in the meane tyme that the decayeng kyng dome of the A≈ø≈øyrians came to the Medes. I thynke this al≈øo, that the≈øe yeares of Cte≈øias concernyng the begynnyng of Babylon, to be vnder≈øtand from the tyme of Nembroth, not Ninus.

The Medes reigned after the fallyng from the A≈ø≈øyrians vntil Cyrus, about thre hundreth yeres,
as Agathias gathereth out of Cte≈øias.
The kyngdome of the Per≈øes vntill Alexander, dyd la≈øt .CCxxviij. yeres, as witne≈ø≈øeth Agathias and ≈øome Grecian wryters.

Alexander and his po≈øteritie kept Babylon vntyll the tyme, that the power of the Parthians beganne to grow: and Agathias ≈øetteth CCC. yeres ≈øeuen le≈ø≈øe, and that is from Alexander vntyll Augu≈øtus tyme.

Afterward raigned the Parthians in the Ea≈øte hundreth yeares, vntil the tyme of Alexander Seuerus the Emperoures, and then dyd Artaxerxes the Per≈øian ≈øtick through and ≈ølaye Artabanus the la≈øt kyng of the Parthians. And of this wy≈øe came the Ea≈øt kyngdom agayne to the Per≈øes, which were myghty vntyll Mahomets tyme. For the ≈øucce≈ø≈øors of Mahomet inuaded the Per≈øes, and teke in the empire of whole Arabia. But the Turkes toke from them afterwarde Syria and A≈øia the le≈ø≈øe. And thus were the kyngdomes of the Ea≈øte to≈ø≈øed finally with diuer≈øe mutacioÃÑs, the one people was oftymes remoued to the other. It is greatly nece≈ø≈øary to ouerlaye all the≈øe thynges, and often to con≈øyder them, that the order of all tymes and hi≈øtories may be knowen aryght.

div.head: An addition vnto the Cronicle of Iohn Carion contaygnyng the actes and hi≈øtories come to pa≈ø≈øe in dyuers and ≈øundry partes of the worlde from the yere of our lorde .MDxxxij. vnto the yeare of our lorde .MD. L. excerpted and gathered out of the be≈øt hi≈øtoriographers by Iohn Funke of Nourenborough. And cau≈øed to be tran≈ølated by Gwalter Lynne.
div.p:
AT the entraunce or beginning of the conuocationThe conuocation or coun≈øaill holden at Ram≈øburgh. holden at Rati≈øbone or Rayne≈øborough in the yere of our lorde .MD. xxxij. in lent, ther lay at Nurrenborough certayn princes electours, with many other nobles of the empire, among whom were as principall Albert Archeby≈øhop of Mogunce or Mence, Lodowike Palatine of the Rhyne, Iohn Frederike duke of Saxon and electour imperiall, whiche princes & nobles did there treate and con≈øulte vpon mattersThe duke of Saxon agreeth not to the election of ye kyng of the Romaines. of religion, and about the e≈øtabli≈øhing of kyng Ferdinandus (to who≈øe election as to be king of the Romains, the ≈øaid Iohn duke of SaxoÃÑ & electour imperiall would not accorde nor con≈øent) and after much intreataunce they obtayned of themperours maie≈øtie a graunt and promes of a ≈øure and ≈øtedfa≈øt peace vntil the next general couÃÑ≈øail that was to come, yea and is to come yet, euen at this day. Other notable actes coÃÑcerning matters of religioÃÑ was there none
concluded in that conuocation. For Soliman EmperoureThe ≈øeconde breakyng in of Soliman into Germany. of the Turkes was vp with all his power and inuaded the lande of Hungary, wherefore the Chri≈øtian princes were con≈øtrained with all ≈øpede and ≈øtrenght po≈ø≈øible to prepare them≈øelues to re≈øi≈øt the ≈øaid aduer≈øary. In≈øomuche that there was prepared ≈øuche an armie and hoo≈øt of men of diuers nacions as neuer was ≈øene before in all Germany, y‚Ä¢ beginnyng wherof was about the fea≈øt of S. Iohn the bapti≈øt, the warriours of the towne of Nurenburgh beinge the fir≈øte that arryued at Weene in Au≈øtriche, for there was all the whole hoo≈øt appointed to a≈ø≈øemble and come together: & the ≈øame a≈ø≈øembling continued vntil the fea≈øt of ≈øaint Bartholome we next en≈øuyng. The nombere of Duche pietons or footemen was about foure ≈øcore thou≈øande ≈øtoute and valiaunt fyghting men. And of the hor≈øe men there was about .xxiiij. thou≈øand. The Bohemes were in the nomber aboue twenty thou≈øande. All the≈øe lay about Wyene by the ryuer called the Danube a lycle myle froÃÑ the towne, Their chefe capitaine was the right noble and mighty prince, lord Frederick Palatine of the Rene &c. nowe being electour imperiall. About the ≈øaid towne laye al≈øo vpon a fifty thou≈øand Spanyardes, whiche in the≈øe affayres v≈øed but ≈ømall kyndne≈ø≈øe towardes the germaynes. For in their pa≈ø≈øage from the Countie of Tyroll ouer the Eye and the Danube into Au≈øtrich they burned certayn ≈øtrong holdes and townes well inhabited, and ≈øome they pylled, and with women and maydens they wrought ≈øuche vylanye and enormitie (whiche is horrible to be ≈øpoken) that
many of them dyed thorough their ≈øaid outtragiou≈ønes. The goodly and ple≈øauÃÑt Citie of Krembes was vtterly by theÃÑ ≈øubuerted and brent vp except fourtenne hou≈øes wyth certayne walles. After this when they lacked vitualles in their campe for the ≈øpace of one daye, they ru≈ø≈øhed with violence before the Cytie of Wyene, wherein the Emperoure and the kyng had theyr beyng, wyth a great nombre of other greate men of armes and warriours whiche were come thether wyth them, and would haue a≈ø≈øaulted and ouerrunne the ≈øame towne if the Germaynes had not the ≈øooner re≈øy≈øted them, and letted their enterpry≈øe.

In the meane ≈øea≈øon the Turke layde ≈øyege to aGuns a≈ø≈øaulted of the Turke by the ≈øpace of .xij. daies certayne lytle Towne called Guns, whiche lyeth about twelue or thirtene myles from Wyene, in the coa≈øtes of Hungary, and a≈ø≈øaulted the ≈øame mo≈øt fiercely by the ≈øpace of twelue dayes, during the which tyme he ≈øought all meanes po≈ø≈øyble to ≈øubuerte and ouerthrowe the ≈øame. But the right noble and wor≈øhypfull Syr Nicolas Iuri≈øthi knight and Ruler of the ≈øayed towne dyd ≈øo manfully and valiauntly behaue hym≈øelfe in tho≈øe affayres wyth hys cyte≈øens or bourgeou≈øes beyng in nombre about eight hundreth men, and one hundred ≈øouldiours whiche were layde there in garni≈øon for the ≈øauegarde of the ≈øame towne that the Turke maruayled not a lyttell of it. Wherefore he promi≈øed vnto the ≈øayed Ruler fre pa≈ø≈øage and ≈øaulf conduct, and hauing per≈øonally him≈øelf talked wt him, did highly pray≈øe him for his con≈øtauncy & faithfulnes which he had v≈øed towards his prince, in y‚Ä¢ he had ≈øo coÃÑ≈øtantly re≈øi≈øted
and repelled his aduer≈øary: and after that he had endued hym with great giftes, he ≈øent hym againe to his owne.

A≈ø≈øone nowe as the Turke with his armie was departed from the ≈øaied towne, and had geuen ouer the ≈øayed ≈øyege, the wall of the ≈øayed Towne fellThe wall of „Äà‚óä„Äâ falleth „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ e by it ‚Ä¢ elfe. downe to the grounde by it ≈øelfe. whereby it may appeare that the ≈øame was afore pre≈øerued and defended from that violent power of the Turke by the myghty hande and a≈ø≈øi≈øtence of God.

Nowe when the Turke perceiued ≈øuche a great power of the germayne nation commynge agayn≈øt hym‚ñ™ he retyred backwarde againe with his power whiche all ready entred into Stewermarke as farre forth as Graytes, and made his arryr to marche and pa≈ø≈øe alonge by the ≈øayed Towne of Graytes euen from the dawnyng in the mornyng vntyll the next morowe folowyng, whereof it maye ea≈øely be gathered with what power he was come thether. But yet to thyntent he myght not ≈øeme to haue be≈øtowed all his laboure in vayne, and to haue ‚Ä¢ led without any harme done to the Germayne nation he left behynde hym not farre from the newe towne in Au≈øtriche, about. xi ‚Ä¢ . thou≈øande‚ñ™ ≈øome ≈øay xvi. thou≈øand men, to de≈øtroie the borders of Steyerm ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and Au≈øtrych as ≈øone as the Germayne warriours ≈øhoulde haue remoued. Howbeit after muche ≈øearchyng the≈øaied nomber of men was e≈øpyed and theyr‚ñ™ enterpry≈øe brought to lyght. For thys cau≈øe Duke Frederike chief Capitayne
toke vnto hym a certain nomber of launce knightes or Pietons, and a certayn nomber of heauy hor≈øemen with whome he vndertoke and attempted to ≈ømite the ≈øaid multitude of Turkes, and compa≈ø≈øed them on euery ≈øyde, be≈øydes the montaynes by a great caw≈ø≈øy and cau≈øed certain dubble ≈øouldiours well armed to folowe them at their hyles & to barre them in, for turnyng backwarde agayne of the whiche dubble ≈øouldiours was Capitayne one Seba≈øtiane Skartell of Au≈øborongh, in≈øomuch that the ≈øaied Turkes were fir≈øt a≈ø≈øayled with two heapes, again≈øt whom they defended them ≈øelues ≈øtoutely, but yet they lo≈øt ther about a thou≈øand of their own men, whereupon eft≈øones they toke their flyght, but as they would haue fled out of the mountaines the other heapes of our men were in their neckes, by whom al≈øo they were all di≈øcomfited and ≈ølaine, ≈øo that no Turke might e≈øcape. Some of them they founde afterwarde on the mountaynes and in wodes, and ≈øome vpon trees, where they were fled to ≈øaue their lyues, amonge whome ≈øome were ≈øhotdown with gonnes lyke byrdes or wyldefoule, and ≈øome were taken and deliuered to the Tro≈ø≈øe to cut and mangle them at their plea≈øures, whiche were very pyteou≈øly chopped and carued of the younger ≈øorte of people.

After that this alarme was cea≈ø≈øed and qualified the Emperoure and the kyng roade forth into the campe of the Germaines, and the Emperoures maie≈øtie beholdyng the people as they ≈øtode in aray maruayled excidyngly coÃÑcernyng the nombre and multitude of them, in≈øomuche it was reported that
he ≈øhould a≈øke of duke Frederick the vpper capitain whether ≈øuche an other multititude of men might be founde and a≈ø≈øembled thoroughout all Duchelande, whereunto the≈øaide Duke made aun≈øwere, that it was ≈øcant perceyued in the townes of Ducheland that any man there was mi≈ø≈øing or lackyng after this (as ≈øome do affyrme) there ≈øhould be takeÃÑ a certayne truce and agrement with the Turke for a certayne tyme, but how, after what ≈øorte and maner, or on what condition, this hangeth yet within the penne‚ñ™ and is lyke al≈øo there to remayne yet a whyle. Some are of this opinioÃÑ, that the cau≈øe why the Emperoures maie≈øtie made no ha≈øte to pur≈øue after the Turke was this, that winter was at haÃÑd, and that therefore the warriours were di≈ømi≈ø≈øed and ≈øent away, ≈øo that with the ≈øaied innumerable multitude of warriours littel good was done≈øauig that muche money was vnprofytably wa≈øted and expended. Wherfore I ≈øuppo≈øe after myne owne iudgement that in ca≈øe the Emperours and the kinges maie≈øtie had proceded and gone forward with that armye or multytude whiche was there at that tyme a≈ø≈øembled and gathered together and had made ≈øure certayne townes in Hungary which would gladly haue rendred and yelded them≈øelues again, while the Turkes fled, and had at the going out of winter be gonne agayne to ≈øeke the Turke at home in his owne lande, the Turky≈øh tyraunt woulde no more ≈øo ≈øpitefully plage vs in our coÃÑtreis. But thus wold God puny≈øh vs yet loÃÑger for our wickednes, for the whiche cau≈øe al≈øo God did ≈øuffre the be≈øt couÃÑ ≈øail to be hindred by one man only: for it is thought, that the Emperours maie≈øtie was by the only coun
≈øayll of Anthony de Leua turned from the≈øaid purAnthony de Leua. ≈øewte, ≈øo that the Turke had a free and ≈øure pa≈ø≈øage home agayne into his owne dominions, and remained vnharmed in Hungary for ≈øomuche as he was not there put to any lo≈ø≈øe or hynderaunce by our men, or on our behalf.

The≈øe thyngs were written out of the Lande of Pooles, and afterward ≈øet furth in printe openly, but the interpretacion thereof wyll I committe to the iudgement of other.

The re≈øt of the Sommer of this yere was very propice and warme, the frutes of the earthe were competent, and the wynes had good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe and chaunced very good, ≈øo that they cau≈øed muche di≈ø≈øentioÃÑ and debate, and al≈øo man≈ølaughter betwene ≈øuche as abu≈øed them.

This yere in the lande of Bullenois there camped in Iannuary on the We≈øt ≈øyde of Bullyn beyoÃÑd the hauen an army of Frenchemen to the nombre of. 18000. & lay there the ≈øpace of .x. dayes, & the .vi. day of Febru. they were all put to flight by the erle of Harforde & the lorde Admirall, with a ≈ømall company of men and without any bloud≈øhedyng on the Engly≈øhe ≈øyde, but diuers of the other were ≈ølayne, they left al their ordinaunce with bagge and baggage behynde them.
This yere about the .xx. day of Iuly the FrenchmeÃÑ with a greate nauy of ≈øhyppes muaded the Ile of wight in England, where as they were driuen back and a great nomber ≈ølayne.

In the yere of our Lorde. 1546. euen in the beginning
of the yere was a conuocation of the EuangelicallA conuocatioÃÑ at Franke forth. confederation kept at Francke ≈øorde on the mayne, & the di≈øputacion to be kept at Rayn≈øburgh was al≈øo begonne. &c.

This yere was doctor Martyn Luter and doctorThe death of Ma ‚Ä¢ ten Luter. Iu≈øtus Ionas called too I≈øleven of the Erle of Man≈øfelde, to ca≈øte of and accorde certayne debates and di≈ø≈øentions that were happened betwene them. Where doctor Martyn Luter was ouercome with the olde impedimentes and di≈øea≈øes of his body, whiche renewed vpon hym whereby he felt and perceiued his ende to be at hande. Wherfore he called hartely vpon the name of our Lorde Ie≈øus Chri≈øte, and with open confe≈ø≈øion commended his ≈øoule into the handes of God oure heauenly father. In ≈øo muche that the eighten daye of February he departed out of this mi≈øerable worlde into the handes of God with Chri≈øt whome he had boldely confe≈ø≈øed before the worlde all mo≈øte thyrty yeares a≈øwell by his paynfull preachyng and teachyng as by continuall wrytyng.

Hys body was at the commaundement of the Princely Electour caried from I≈øleven, by the Erle of Man≈øfelde accompanied with fyfty hor≈øes to Wittenburgh, and of all e≈øtates of the Princely Electours Court bothe of high and lowe degrees, &The buriall of doctor Martine Luter. of the vniuer≈øitie of the citie he was ≈øorowfully but yet honorably brought into the Ca≈øtell, and reuerently buried be≈øydes the burials of the Electours of Saxon the .xxii. day of February. the .lxij. yere of his age.

This man ≈øo highly endued with knowledge
from God, was apointed and ordeined of our heauenly father to be a mini≈øter and teacher of his churche and a preacher of his Go≈øpell, euen as in al ages he hath rai≈øed and ordeined ≈øome to be Prophetes, ≈øome to be Apo≈øtles, and ≈øome to be teachers of hys congregacion. For he opened and declared vnto the worlde (by Gods grace) the nece≈ø≈øary and hol≈øome doctrine of the Go≈øpell, and taught the true repentaunce and comfort of the harte, whiche is feared with the knowledge of Goddes wrath. He hath godly ≈øet furth the doctrine of Paule, whiche ≈øaith: That a man is iu≈øtified and made ryghteous by the faith in Chri≈øte. He hath al≈øo declared the difference betwene the Lawe and the Go≈øpel, betwene the rightou≈ønes of y‚Ä¢ ≈øpirite, & of the outward workes. He brought to light agayne the true wor≈øhypping of God, whiche had bene vnknowen to the moo≈øt parte of the worlde by the ≈øpace of a thou≈øand yeres. And brought the vniuer≈øall Church from that fonde opinion, whiche imagineth, that God is wor≈øhypped although y‚Ä¢ minde of man being ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed with perpetual doubting, abhorreth to come to god

He taught al≈øo howe we ought to pray in faith & with a good concience, and ledevs to the only mediatour Chri≈øt the ≈øonne of God‚ñ™ whiche ≈øytteth at the right hand of the father euerla≈øtyng, and maketh interce≈ø≈øion for vs: And not to the ≈øoules of dead men as the vngodly Papi≈øtes haue taught with fyre and fagot. He declared al≈øo what good workes were acceptable to God. He hath ≈øo garni≈ø≈øhed and e≈øtably≈øhed the temporal lawes and gouernauÃÑce, that ≈øence the Apo≈øtles tyme it was neuer ≈øo confirmed by Scriptures. He dyd al≈øo aboly≈øh the
chyldy≈øh cu≈øtome and ceremonies of mans tradicion, whiche hyndered true prayer, and ≈øeperated them from the nece≈ø≈øary workes. To thyntent al≈øo that the heauenly doctrine ≈øhould extende to hys po≈øteritie, and that the people whiche ≈øhall come after myght haue knowledge, he tran≈ølated the Propheticall and Apo≈øtolicall Scriptures into Dutch with ≈øuche lyght and clarite, that the reder maye haue more knowledge thereby, then by ≈øome mens expo≈øitions.

He made al≈øo many expo≈øitions, whiche do farre excell many other, as Era≈ømus of Roterdame witne≈ø≈øeth in his writynges. And as it is writen of them whiche repayred Ieru≈øalem, that they buylded wyth one hande and helde the ≈øwoorde in the other: Euen ≈øo warred Doctor Martine Luter with the enemies of the true doctrine and buylded neuertheles the heauenly doctrine. Be≈øydes thys he dyd helpe many mens conciences, with good couÃÑ ≈øayll. And whyle≈øt a greate parte of his doctrine is aboue mans rea≈øon, (as the doctrine of remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øynnes, and of faith) it mu≈øt nedes be graunted that he was taught of God. In prayer for the vniuer≈øall Churche of Chri≈øte was he very earne≈øt and dilygent. He dyd al≈øo eueryday cho≈øe a certaine houre to recite certayne P≈øalmes, wherin al≈øo he mixed his prayer with great deuotion. He taught al≈øo that it is not ynough to praye only with the minde and with ≈øighing, but that the maner & fourme of prayeng is pre≈øcribed vnto vs by the Coun≈øaill of God, that the hartes by the reding may be ≈øtirred, and moued, yea that the voyce al≈øo may knowledge
and confe≈ø≈øe what God we wor≈øhyppe.

He was al≈øo in the a≈ø≈øault and re≈øi≈øtauÃÑce of the enemies of Gods truthe of a con≈øtant mynde and of a bolde courage, neyther was he aba≈ø≈øhed for their threatenynges. He was al≈øo in difycult matters of a ≈øharpe and hygh wytte, and well ≈øpoken, as his famous do ≈øufficiently declare.

For a≈ømuche therefore as this man was garny≈øhed with ≈øuche a great witte and other godly vertues, and was ≈øpecially ordeyned of God to repayre his temple agayn, wherin he hath not bene negligent, we ought not to ≈øuffre his vertues and benefites to pery≈øhe among vs, and whyle≈øt he was an in≈øtrument of God, we ought gladly to folowe hys Doctrine, and therein to learne the vertues nece≈ø≈øary for vs, as the feare of God, fayth and feruentnes in prayer, diligence in the office of the worde, Cha≈øtite, ab≈øtinence and abhorryng from ≈øedition or tumulte, diligence and de≈øyrous to ≈øtudy. &c. whiche God graunt vnto vs all. Amen.

In the moneth of Marche anone after that the conuocatioÃÑ at Rayne≈øburgh was ended, there was an horrible act committed at Neweburgh be≈øides the Danube, in the iuri≈ødiction of the Palatine, betwene two brethren being Spanyardes, of whom the one was called Iohn Dia≈øy, well learned in the Lar ‚Ä¢ e, Greke and Hebrue tonges, a man that feared God, and loued the ≈øincere doctrine of Chri≈øte and his holy Go≈øpell, and was at that ≈øea≈øon ≈øent from Rayne≈øbourgh by the Dy≈øputers of the Go≈øpell, wyth whome he had greate acquayntaunce,
towards Newburgh, to correcte and fyny≈øhe certayne bookes to be imprinted.

But when his brother Alphon≈øe Dia≈øy, a DoctourAlphon≈øe dia ≈øi a trayterousmurther of the lawe and at Rome in hygh office, a ≈øeruaunt of the Pope, and an enemy to the Go≈øpell of Chri≈øte, was come from Rome to Rayne≈øburgh, & there had knowledge, that hys brother Iohn was at Newburgh, he ha≈øted hym ≈øelfe thyther with all ≈øpede, to ≈øee his brother, where he attempted in certayne dayes with many di≈øputacions to drawe and turne hys brother from the pure doctrine of the Go≈øpell to the wicked doctrine of the Pope wyth many checkes.

p.q: But Iohn remayned con≈øtaunt in the doctrine whiche he had learned and ≈øearched to the bottom, and in≈øtructed his brother wyth inuincible argumeÃÑ tes and te≈øtymonyes of the doctrine out of the Prophetes and Apo≈øtles, in all the Articles of the Chri≈øten fayth, endeuouryng hym ≈øelfe wyth all diligeÃÑce to conuerte hys brother to the ≈øincere doctrine of Chri≈øte.

When Alphon≈øe ≈øawe the con≈øtauncy and per≈øeueraunce of hys brother, and that he could not re≈øi≈øt nor confute his doctrine, nor yet bryng hym to the Popes way, he di≈ø≈øembled & behaued hym ≈øelfe as thoug he had gladly and earne≈øtly embraced the Euangelicall doctrine, and gentely ≈øuffered hys brothers charitable and Godly in≈øtructions and exhortacions, abiding wyth hym almo≈øte thre dayes. In ≈øo muche that he ≈øayd vnto hym: whyle he ≈øawe and perceiued that hys doctrine of the Go≈øpel was the very ≈øounde and true doctrine of God, and
knewe that there were many hone≈øt men at Rome, and al≈øo in other cities and townes of tho≈øe parties whiche were very dy≈øyrous to be in≈øtructed in the true and ≈øincere doctrine of Chri≈øt ≈øo that they lacked nothyng but men of good learnyng, that were expert in ≈øettyng forth of the ≈øame doctrine accordyngly: wherfore he be≈øought hym of Brotherly loue, to goo with hym to Rome, where he myght by his godly doctrine do muche good, and a dede acceptable to Chri≈øte.

But what happened? This good maÃÑ Iohn Dia≈øy, being ≈øymple and ≈øu≈øpecting no gyle, ≈øuffered his brothers per≈øwa≈øion to take place, & graunted hym his reque≈øt, howbeit he wrote back vnto the Di≈øputers and Auditours of the Euangelicall doctrine, de≈øyrynge to haue their coun≈øayll in this matter: who perceyuyng the crafte and papi≈øticall murdery≈øh harte of his brother, gaue hym coun≈øayl not to go to Rome with his brother.

Nowe when Iohn Dia≈øius folewed their coun≈øayll, and gaue hys brother an aun≈øwere that he could not at that tyme go with hym to Rome, the ≈øayde Alphon≈øe behaued him≈øelfe frendely towardes hym, and gaue hym certayne crownes and ducates for his farewell, takyng hys leaue and departure of his brother very louyngly and frendely, as though he would haue gone ≈øtrayghtwaye towardes Rome.

div.p:
But within fewe dayes after, he came to Newe burgh agayne from Au≈øburgh, where he had prepared good po≈øt hor≈øes to be in a readynes to flee
when he ≈øhould ≈øe cau≈øe. And when he came to the ≈øayde towne of Newburgh early in the mornyng at the openyng of the gates, he taryed hym≈øelfe before the gate with the hor≈øes, and ≈øent his ≈øeruaunt (beyng a murtherer, whome he had hyred at Rome for ≈øuche affayres, and brought hym forth with hym) into the towne with a lettre, who whan he came to the ≈øayde Iohn, delyuered hym the ≈øayde lettre, and whyle he red the ≈øame, the MurthererThe good doctor Iohn Dia≈øy murthered. ≈ømote hym with a greate ≈øharpe halbarde and cleft his hed in twayne, that he fell downe dead, but the Murtherer ranne out of the towne, to hys Mai≈øter, ≈øo that both the Murtherers gate them≈øelues awaye.

p.q: Whan thys horrible acte was knowen in the towne, ≈øouldiours were prepared and appoynted out of hande to pur≈øue them, whyche at la≈øt caught and apprehended bothe the ≈øayde Murtherers at I≈øebredge, where they were brought to pry≈øon.

And although there was muche ≈øuet made to the Iudges ordeyned and appointed by kyng Ferdinando and the officers there, for due puni≈øhment, by the ≈øubiectes of the Palatine, whiche had ≈øpent about the ≈øame aboue foure hundreth guidens, yet coulde they obtayne no iu≈øtice agayn≈øt the ≈øayde Murtherers. But manye exceptions were made and propounded, namely that whyle the Brother was a Spanyarde, the matter ought not too bee pleated in Dutche language,
but in Spany≈øh, and before Spany≈øhe Iudges. Yea when the Emperoure came to Rayne≈øburgh he was al≈øo mo≈øte humbly de≈øyred and be≈øought to ≈øe iu≈øtice mini≈øtred concernyng the ≈øayde matter. But an≈øwere was made, that whyle the offenders were taken within the Iuri≈ødiction of the kynges maie≈øtie the Emperours maie≈øtie had nothyng to do with the matter.

But in conclu≈øion thys was the la≈øt ≈øentence & Iudgement geuen, that for ≈øo muche as the ≈øayde Iohn was an heretike, he had de≈øerued death: And for≈øomuche as his brother Alphon≈øus was con≈øecrated, and a ≈øpirituall per≈øone, the temporall lawe had nothyng to do wyth hym, wherfore they were letten go free, and ≈øet at libertie.

div.p:
This horryble murther of Cayn was doubteles a forgaine of the dete≈øtable warres whiche the Pope & hys Churche of Cayn hath moued again≈øt Abell and the fauorers & teachers of the holy Go≈øpell in Germany, where ≈øo muche innocent & Chri≈øten bloude hath bene≈øhed, all the whiche thynges the Lorde God wyll puny≈øh in tyme conuenient, ≈øeyng there is no more iudgement in earth.The Emp

In the moneth of Aprill came the Emperoures maie≈øtie to Rayne≈øburgh on Saturday after mydlent Sonday: where he founde but fewe princes of the Empyre, be≈øydes a ≈ømall nombre of certaine by≈øhoppes.

Con≈øequentely after Ea≈øter when certayn princes,The „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ion beg „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ at Rain≈øburgh. and Amba≈ø≈øadours, or Legates of other were come thither, the conuocation was begonne, and the propo≈øitions were of the agreement of the Articles
in controuer≈øy in religion, of the ordre and e≈øtably≈øhment of the chamber court and of the Coyne, Item howe the Turke myght be re≈øi≈øted.

But in the meane ≈øea≈øon, when there was great proui≈øion and preparation made to take vp men &The begynnyng of the emperours warres agayn≈øt the Germanes. warriours in the name of themperours Maie≈øtie thoroughout all Duchelande, the Electours princes and e≈øtates of the confe≈ø≈øion of Au≈øbourgh de≈øyred mo≈øte humbly at Whit≈øontyde to knowe of the Emperours Maie≈øtie, again≈øt whome ≈øuche preparation of warre was intended, whereupon they receiued this darke aun≈øwere, that the Emperoures Maie≈øtie woulde puni≈øhe certayne rebelles of the Empire.

p.q: After this darke aun≈øwere when many thyngs were feared, and the ≈øayde warriours were in a redynes, the conuocacion toke an ende, and another was in≈øtituted and appointed again≈øt the next yere to begynne the fyr≈øt day of February.

Fora≈ømuche therfore as Duke Iohn Frederike Electour in Saxon, and Lorde Phylyppe Landgraue of He≈ø≈øen with the other Princes, Lordes, e≈øtates and townes of the confe≈ø≈øion and confederation of Au≈øburgh perceiued that the ≈øaide great preparacion of warres was enterpri≈øed and intended again≈øt no man, but again≈øt them, they prepared al≈øo an ho≈øte of men for their nece≈ø≈øary defence, for the mayntenaunce and pre≈øeruacion of the pure and ≈øincere doctrine of the Go≈øpell, for the defence al≈øo of their Landes, dominions and ≈øubiectes, and for the continuacion of the liberties and priuiledges of the Germaine nacion, and went furth in the moneth of Iune

div.p: Fyftely, the Po≈øtmay≈øters hou≈øe, where themperour was wont to haue hys po≈øthor≈øes, when he had nede of them, wyth the ≈øtables and the hor≈øes in the ≈øame at that tyme, was quyte ≈øtryken awaye by the thonder, and burned vp.

p.q: Syxtely, Saynt Barnardes place, wherin the Abbot of S. Barnarde had hys lodgyng when he came to Meghlyne, was vtterly de≈øtroyed by the thonder, and the cloy≈øter of the Augu≈øtyne freers was a great parte ouerthrowen and de≈øtroyed.
Seuently, The Voog≈øtrete, which was a fayre large ≈øtrete was al≈øo in lyke maner ouerthrowen, that there remayned neuer a hou≈øe ≈øtandyng, nor yet, as they ≈øayd, block nor ≈øtone.

div.p:
Eightely, The Palace of Hygh≈øtrete, whyche was an excedyng fayre and ≈øtrong buyldynge, belongyng to a certayn great lorde, was quyte and clene ouerthrowen and de≈øtroyed: And as the inhabitauntes of the ≈øayd towne of Meghlyne do affyrme, yf the ≈øayd Palayce of Hygh≈øtrete wyth other places and greate buyldynges had not bene there ≈øtandynd, The hole towne of Meghlyn mu≈øt nedes haue ben vtterly ouerthrowen and de≈øtroyed, ≈øo that nether hou≈øe, ≈øtycke nor ≈øtone ≈øhuld haue remayned in the ≈øame: For the ≈øayd hygh and ≈øtrong buyldynges were a greate defence to the towne: Be≈øydes thys there were al≈øo other places and great buyldinges, who≈øe names (to auoyd prolyxite) are not here rehear≈øed, whych were in lyke maner ouerthrowen & de≈øtroyed of the thonder as the other together with ≈øeuen hundred hou≈øes.
In≈øumme, almoo≈øt all the hou≈øes of the towne were endamaged, fewe or none excepte that hadde not ≈øome hurte done by the thonder.

p.q: Nyntly, the nexte daye after, when the ≈øayde piteous calamite was done, whiche was the. 8. day of Augu≈øt, when they beganne to make rowme, there were founde about thre hundred per≈øons men, women, and children which were ≈ølaine by the meanes of the thondre, whome they loded in wagens & cartes and buryed them in great holes that were digged for the ≈øame purpo≈øe. There were al≈øo founde aboue, 150. per≈øons ≈øore wounded and harmed.

And there happened one thing in the ≈øayd toune ≈øpecyally to be meruayled at, which is, that certayn ge≈øtes ≈øate in theyr ho≈øtes hous drynkynge to gether and plaieng at the cardes, and while they called for drynke, and theyr ho≈øte≈ø≈øe went doune into the ≈øeller to drawe them a pot of byre, in the meane ≈øea≈øon was the hou≈øe ≈øtryken awaye by the thonder, and the players found dead wyth the cardes in theyr handes, as though they had ben ≈øtyll playeng, but the ho≈øte≈ø≈øe ≈øaued her lyfe by the meanes, y‚Ä¢ ≈øhe was in the ≈øeller whan the ≈øayd hurt was done.
Tenthly, There was al≈øo a man founde in a corner the thyrd daye after that the ≈øayde hurte was done, hauyng no harme whych a≈øked whether the world were yet ≈øtandyng or not.
There was al≈øo a woman founde dead, beynge great wyth chylde, whych was afterwarde cut opeÃÑ and the chylde taken out of her belly, was bapti≈øed

Muche harme was there done be≈øydes, not onely within the towne of Meghline, but al≈øo without
the towne, as in the townes, villages, ca≈øtels, and boroughes lyeng there about, where the≈øaide wether hath done much harme, and there were many, innumerable, fearfull and wonderful ≈øygnes and to kens ≈øene, ≈øo that bothe the Emperoure and the lady Mary had nede to remembre them ≈øelues, for it is to be feared that God will beginne to reuenge the innocent bloude, whiche is very piteou≈øly ≈øhed in the lower partes of Duchelande, for the Go≈øpels ≈øake, for it crieth into heauen and ≈øo fylleth the bo≈øo me of Gods high mate≈øtie that he can ≈øuffre it no loÃÑ ger, yea he wyll laye on yet greater loades, oneles they repente and amende in tyme, for he hath ≈øuffered them long ynough.

div.p: When this warre betwene themperour, & the electour of Saxon, & the Landgraue of He≈ø≈øen had continued into the fir≈øt moneth, & themperour had declared hym≈øelf an open enemy both to the for≈øaid princes, onely of his owne mynde, without either right, rea≈øon, or warnyng, and without the knowledge & con≈øent of the e≈øtates & membres of thempire:Duke Maurice prepareth „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . In the meane ≈øea≈øoÃÑ did Maurice duke of Sax on with great feruentnes prepare a great noÃÑbre of hor≈øemen & pietons, wherefore al men ≈øtode in great feare, not knowing again≈øt whom he made the ≈øame preparation.

p.q:
And fora≈ømuche as the electour of Saxon was out of his lande, & duke Maurice was next of hys bloude, and his nere ki≈øman bothe on the fathers & the mothers ≈øyde, & was al≈øo by bym brought vp, & had receiued many benefites at his hand, many were of this hope & iudgemeÃÑt, that the≈øaid preparatioÃÑ
was made for the defence & ≈øuccour of the landes & ≈øubiectes of the electour, ≈øo that fewe or none ≈øu≈øpected any gyle in duke Maurice.

In the meane ≈øea≈øon did kyng Ferdinando al≈øo endenour hym≈øelfe to ≈øtirre vp the Lu≈øenitianes & Bohemianes again≈øt the lande of the Electour of Saxon, but with hone≈øt & vertuous men coulde he litle preuayle, notwith≈øtaÃÑding by the meanes of his importunate labour and in≈øtaunt intreatauÃÑce he a≈ø≈øembled a ≈øorte of Pietons in Boheme being in noÃÑ bre about eyght thou≈øand men, & in Hungary aboue a thou≈øand hu≈øbandmen, a wicked & raueni≈øh generation, to de≈øtory & wa≈øte the landes & dominioÃÑs of the≈øaid Electour, which meÃÑ did fir≈øt inuade Voyt land, & there toke the townes vilages and liberties pertaining tothe Electour, piteou≈øly ≈øpoyling, roauingburning & de≈øtroieng many men young & olde.

And ≈øpecially therwas an execrable madnes & murther coÃÑmitted vpoÃÑ an hone≈øt Curate & mini≈øter that feared God at Newechurche, whom when the≈øaid hu≈øbaÃÑd meÃÑ had mo≈øtcruelly martyred & murthered and ≈øawe that he was fatte, they cut him in peces after the maner of a fatte Swyne, ca≈øting the peces from one to another and ≈øayeng, Lo brother, there ha≈øt thou a good roa≈øtyng pece of an hogge.
Of whiche innocent bloud are gilty all they that do helpe or con≈øent to the ≈øayde murthery≈øhe and inte≈øtine warres, whereof doutles God wyll take vengeaunce in tyme conuenient.

Nowe when the matter as it was fyr≈øt begonne and purpo≈øed again≈øt the Electour & his dominioÃÑs (for Duke Maurice had bene fir≈øt with the kynge
in. Bohemy) toke effect, and apeared euidently as though the kyng woulde ouercome and take in, all the Landes and dominions of the Electour, Duke
Maurice exalted hym≈øelfe with his army, and fir≈øt toke the townes lyeng to warde the mountaynes, and then he went with the≈øayde Bohemians and hu≈øband men to be≈øege the towne of Zwickowe.

div.p:
But lea≈øt I be demed to ≈øtande to muche in myne owne conceite, and to take vpon me to Iudge other wi≈øe than it becometh me in this matter. I will ≈øet hereafter the true Copye of his lettres whereby he required and admony≈øhed the towne of the Electour to yelde them ≈øelues vnto hym, by the coÃÑ ≈øentes whereof men of hone≈øtie and vnder≈øtanding may ea≈øely perceyue what good grounde and ≈øure foundacion he pretended in the≈øe affaires.
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ .

By the grace of God we Maurice duke of SaxoÃÑ Land graue of During, and Marquis of My≈ø≈øene, aduerty≈øe you our welbeloued and tru≈øty coun≈øayl and commons of Saron. &c. That fora≈ømuche as the myghty Prince our Co≈øyn Duke Iohn Frederike the Elder, hath ben founde negligent in doing of hys dutie and it is manife≈øt that men are about to bryng you from the hou≈øe of Saxon, into the power of ≈øtraungers, and we beyng a borne prince of Saxon hauing al≈øo parte in the lande wyth our for ≈øayd Co≈øyn, and be charged by earne≈øt commaundement of the Emperoures Maie≈øtie our mo≈øte gracious lorde, for the auoydyng of greuous penalties and corrections, and al≈øo by the lo≈ø≈øe of our Regaltie and preemineÃÑce, our ≈øeiues to take the ≈øame land in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, or elles to permitte and ≈øuffre other to
do the ≈øame, whereby oure owne Landes and dominions mu≈øt nedes come in daunger and de≈øtruction. Wherfore we require you to ≈øutmitte your ≈øelues vnto vs as Prince of Saxon, and to receyue vs accordingly with due ≈øolempui≈øation.

p.q: And we are prone & graciou≈øly inclined to de≈øen de you in the Chri≈øten religion wherein ye bee, and lyke mayer your bodyes, goodes and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, and to leaue you by youre olde liberties and priuiledges. And when the matter or controuer≈øy betwene the Emperoures Maie≈øtie, the Romy≈øhe kynges Maie≈øtie, and our for≈øayde Co≈øyn ≈øhall come to an agreement, we ≈øhalbe ready, as touchynge the landes whiche we ≈øhall haue taken in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of hys, by the knowledge and wyll of their Maie≈øties, and as muche as maye be done without their preiudice, thorough our owne dominions to be intreated & ordered accordyng to ryght and rea≈øon.

But yf ye ≈øhould refu≈øe ≈øo to do, it ≈øhould apeare vnto vs, as though ye would wylfully be put from the hou≈øe of Saxon, whiche may not be ≈øuffered of vs. Wherefore we require herein your directe aun≈øwere by the bearer of the letter in ha≈øt, whyle oure enemy is at hande, that we may auoyde the daunger. Geuen in our Towne of zwickowe the ≈øyxt daye of NoueÃÑber. Anno a thou≈øand fyue hundreth fourty and ≈øyxe. Duke Maurice, of Saxon. Manu propria.
When zwickowe had yelded vnto him, the ≈øyxt day of Nouember, he toke al≈øo the townes lyeng there about, and con≈øequeÃÑtly, Aldenbourgh, Ilenbourgh, Grymme, Torgawe. &c.

the .xvi. day of Nouember duke Maurice ≈øent a Trompetter with two lettres, the one to the Deputie, and the other to the Communaltie of Witten bourgh directed, betwene thre & foure of the clocke at after none, before the Elue gate, but before the lettres were receyued, the ≈øuburbes were ≈øet on fyre whereby was ≈øygnifyed that they intended to ≈øtande to their defence.

The ≈øame daye dyd he al≈øo aduerti≈øe thinhabitauntes of Torgawe whiche lay in gare≈øon for the defence of Wittenburgh, that oneles they woulde come home by the next daye before Sunne ≈øet, he would ≈øende their wyues and chyldren after them, and be≈øydes that depriue them of all their goodes.

div.trailer: The ende of the Appendix or addition compyled by Mai≈øter Iohn Funke.

div.head: Brefe Annotations added vnto the premi≈ø≈øes gathered out of dyuers hi≈øtoriographers.
div.p: IN the ≈øayd yere of our lorde .MD. xlvi. apeace was concluded betwene EnglaÃÑdA peace betwene Englande and Fraunce. and Fraunce, whiche on Whit≈øondaye was proclaimed. For conclu≈øion whereof the Vi≈øcount Li≈ø≈øe high Admiral of England with the By≈øhop of Dure≈øine and a goodly company of Gentylmen went out of Englande into Fraunce, after who≈øe retourne Mon≈øure Denball high Admirall of Fraunce, the By≈øhop of Eureux and two Erles came into Englande with the Sacre of Depe, and .xij. galleyes, and were honorably receiued.
The ≈øaide yere al≈øo in lent before, was the StewesThe ≈øtewes put downe in London. ‚òù ‚òù Anne A≈økewe Iohn La≈ø≈øels burned. at London put downe and aboly≈ø≈øhed by the kynges commaundement.

the .ix. daye of Iuly was burned at London in ≈ømithfielde. Anne A≈økew a gentill woman, Iohn la≈ø≈øels, of the kynges preuy chambre, Iohn Adlam tayler of Suffolke, and Nicolas Belenyam prie≈øt, for opinions con≈øonaunt to the trueth, and contrary to the acte of the ≈øyx Articles: At whiche tyme alShaxton recanted. ≈øo Doctour Nicolas Schaxton ≈øomtime By≈øhop of Sali≈øbury recanted and denied the trueth whiche before he had profe≈ø≈øed. Whiche thing al≈øo one Doctour Crome (whiche had bene a great and famous preacher) had done at Paules Cro≈ø≈øe the xxvij. daye of Iune before, affirming openly that he had bene ≈øeduced by noughty bookes. &c.

In England, al≈øo in Nouember was the duke ofThomas duke of Northfolke & Henry his ≈øodne attainted. Northfolke and his ≈øonne the Erle of Surrey, attaincted of trea≈øon, for the which his ≈øonne was put to execution in Ianuary after, and hym ≈øelfe coÃÑmitted to the Towre, where he doeth yet remayne.

IN the yere of our lord God .MD. xlvij. there were in Germany dyuers and wonderfull innouacions of thinges chauÃÑces of warres chauÃÑ ges of fortune, yeldynges of Princes, ouerthrowinges and ≈øubuer≈øions of townes and ca≈øtelles, fallinges of great men, & conuocatioÃÑs of Synodes, and coun≈øayles, which I do here omitte partely to auoyde prolixite, and partely for that the certaintie of ≈øuche thinges taken by heare ≈øay onely is oftentimes deceiuable. Tru≈øting to haue occca≈øion and oportunitie hereafter to declare and ≈øet furth the ≈øame matter at large.

The inhabitauntes of the countie of Tiroll and I≈øebredge were this yere ≈øore plaghed with wonderfullA plague of locu≈øtes and gra≈øhoppers locu≈øtes and gra≈øhoppers both creping and flyeng, whiche were there in ≈øuche aboundaunce that the creping ≈øorte couered all their lande, & the flyeng ≈øorte couered that lyght of the Sune, in ≈øo muche that thinhabiters of the lande were coÃÑmaunded to go furth and to take & gather theÃÑ that crept on the grounde which they did continually during the ≈øpace of thre wekes, gatheringe euery daye about. 2400. quarters, in a quarter of a myle, for in euery quarter of a myle were appointed thre hundreth per≈øons, men and womeÃÑ, and euery hundreth per≈øons gathered euery day 800 quarters. during the ≈øpace of. 3. wekes. And they came into I≈øebredge ouer the brydge with ≈øuch a power as though they had ben an ho≈øte of warriours that woulde haue entred into the towne In ≈øo much that the Mage≈øtrates commanded the inhabitauntes of the ≈øame towne to make re≈øi≈øtaunce agayn≈øt them before the gate with be≈øomes and bromes and to ≈øwype them into the water as they came whiche they ded in ≈øuche ≈øorte as they couered all the water with gra≈øherppers that no water coulde be ≈øene: Thus did they re≈øi≈øte them & kept them al≈øo from the brydge by the ≈øpace of .iii. wekes after this the ≈øaid locu≈øtes or gra≈øhoppers turned into. the fieldes and there de≈øtroyed and wa≈øted the corne and the gra≈ø≈øe, vndoynge in a maner all the people of the lande: ≈øo that after thys the peopel re≈øy≈øted them no moore, butt onelye tru≈øted to the mercy of god with in≈øtaunt & ferueÃÑt prayer.
The ≈øayde Locu≈øtes or gra≈øhoppers were littell at the begynnyng and krepyng, but afterwarde they grewe and began to flye, doyng great hurte throughout the ≈øayde lande.

In the meane ≈øea≈øon the Emperoures maie≈øtie,A godly commaundement and the kyng of the Romaynes ≈øet furth a commauÃÑ dement that noman ≈øhuld be founde in dronkenes, horedome, aduoutery, v≈øury, and bla≈øphemy but he ≈øhould be puny≈øhed by death, and forfayte all hys goodes.

In a littell towne called Albers lyeng be≈øydes Lyndawe in the Dukedome of Zweyburgh wasA prodigious grape. this yere founde two clu≈øters of grapes growynge vpon one braunce hauyng a long read bearde, whiche was a wonderfull ≈øyght.

The ≈øame yere in flaunders and the countreesA wonderful miracle. there about was a great ≈øcacitie of corne, ≈øo that there was a great dearth in the lande. And there dwelled be≈øydes Beke aboue Gand a certayne farmer well prouided and ≈øtored with corne, vnto whome his neyghbours came lamentyng and intreatyng hym to ≈øel them ≈øome of his corne, who refu≈øed ≈øo to do, neuertheles he ≈øent none away comfortles that had nede: for he lent and delyuered vnto euery man accordyng to their nece≈ø≈øite on this condicion that they ≈øhould rendre and repaye hym agayne at the next harue≈øt, on this condicion did he lende corne to dyuers nedy per≈øons. After whiche tyme it chaunced that his corned fyelde beyng ≈øowed was by Gods grace ≈øo multiplied and increa≈ø≈øed that on euery ≈øtalke grewe an exceding nombre of eares laden with corne, ≈øo that thorough the ble≈ø≈øyng of
God he was well rewarded. By this may we ≈øee that the ≈øayeng of Salomon is an vndoubted verite, namely, he that taketh pitie on the pore lendeth vnto the Lorde vpon v≈øury, and loke what≈øoeuer he layeth out it ≈øhalbe payd hym agayne.

There was al≈øo this yere a wonderfull vi≈øion ≈øeneA wonderful ‚Ä¢ i≈øion. and heard of many within the towne of Wittenbourgh, in the Lande of Saron the .xviii. daye of September early in the mornyng betwene foure & fyue of y‚Ä¢ clocke. For there appeareth in the ayre a figure and lykenes of a dead cor≈øe or beere couered ouer with blacke cloth, and a read ribband auer the ≈øame, and there went before the coar≈øe ≈øix men with trompettes, and a greate multitude of people folowed with croked in≈øtrumentes and trompettes blowyng, whyche made a greate noy≈øe in the ayre, in≈øomuche that many in the towne whiche laye yet in their beddes were thereby awaked out of theyr ≈ølepe, thynkyng that the ≈øayde trimblyng had bene in the towne. After this the black cloth vany≈øhed awaye from the boere, whiche then was couered ouer with awhyte cloth, then appeared be≈øydes the beare a man armed in harnas ≈øhewyng hym ≈øelfe very angry, and pullyng the whyte clothe from the beere, he rent it in twaine, wynding the one half about hys arme and ≈øo pre≈ø≈øyng it harde to hys body: Wyth this the coar≈øe vany≈øhed away. The man armed dyd al≈øo apeare a lyttell whyle after & ≈øo in lyke maner bani≈øhed away. After this were althynges quiet as before. God graunte euery Chri≈øten man to remembre thys wonderfull ≈øygne with feare, for it is to be feared that it is a fearefull warnyng
≈øent vs of God.
In Englande the nyntene day of Ianuary wasThe Erle of Surrey beheaded. the Erle of Surrey beheaded, as was mencioned the yere before.

The ≈øeuen and twenty daye of the ≈øame monethThe death of kyng Henry the eight of England‚ñ™ &c. Edward the ≈øyxt byng of England. Henry the eyght kyng of Englande &c. ended hys lyfe, and was buried at Wind≈øore.
Edwarde the ≈øyxt kyng of Englande &c. ≈øucceded his father in the gouernaunce of his royalmes and dominions, and was crowned the nintene day of February, in the nyneth yere of hys age.

Vnder the ≈øayde kyng in the tyme of his minorite his vncle Edwarde Duke of Somer≈øet was made lorde Protectour of all hys Royaulmes dominions and ≈øubiectes, and Gouernour of his maie≈øties per≈øone, who with the re≈øidue of his maie≈øties Coun≈øayll gouerned the realme with great mercy and gentilne≈ø≈øe, by whome to the ≈øurtheraunce of goddes worde and true religion, coÃÑmi≈ø≈øioners were ≈øent into al partes of the Realme, with commauÃÑ dementImages and beades put downe & aboly≈ø≈øhed in England. to cau≈øe all Images to be taken out of churches, for auoydyng of Idolatry, and to wyll men & women to leaue the v≈øe of beades, hauyng with theÃÑ al≈øo godly and learned preachers a≈ø≈øigned, whiche do exorted them to geue them ≈øelf to true and vnfained wor≈øhippyng of God in the hart and minde, with due obedience to their prince.

Richard Smith a doctour of diuinite recaÃÑted opeÃÑ lyA recantacioÃÑ of Doctor Smith. at Paules cro≈ø≈øe within ye citie of LoÃÑdon diuers articles coÃÑtained in two bokes which he had made,
one for the defence of the ≈øacrifice of the Ma≈ø≈øe: an other to proue vnwritten verities to be beleued vnder payne of damnacion.
This yere al≈øo in Enland commaundement wasProce≈ø≈øions l ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t in Englande. An hoo≈øt of men ≈øent out of Englande into ScotlaÃÑd geuen that proce≈ø≈øions ≈øhould be no more v≈øed.

This yere al≈øo in England the duke of Somer≈øet then Lorde Protectour and the Erle of Warwyke went into Scotlande with a ≈øtrong army, requiring the Scottes to fulfyll their promy≈øe, made before to kyng Henry, concernyng the mariage of their younge Quene with the younge kynge of Englande, but the Scottes ≈øtubbournely came agayn≈øt them, with great pui≈ø≈øaunce. And not longe after the two armyes encountred in the fieldes of Mu≈øcleborough, at a place called Pinker ≈ølough. The Engly≈øhe part not thynkyng as than to haue battayle, at whiche tyme becau≈øe the front of the Scotty≈øhe armie was ≈øo terrybly ≈øet wyth pykes, the Engly≈øhe hor≈øemen (which gaue the fyr≈øt on≈øet) were fayne to recule backe, with lo≈ø≈øe of certayn geÃÑ tylmen: whiche reculing much aba≈ø≈øhed the Engli≈øh footemen: but yet by the great wy≈øedome and dilygence of the Lord Protectours grace, and the valiaunt hart and courage of the Earle of Warwike they gaue a newe on≈øet, and without any notable fyght di≈øcomfited the Scottes, and obtayned the victory. At this tyme were ≈ølayne of the Scottes betwene thirtene and fourtene thou≈øand, and not pa≈ø≈øyng an hundred Engly≈øhemen.Chaunteries geuen to the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ng of England.

After Mich ‚Ä¢ lmas a Parliament was holden in England wherein chaunteries were geuen into the kynges handes, to be altered and di≈øpo≈øed at
hys plea≈øure.

It was al≈øo ordeined that the ≈øacrament or communionThe CoÃÑmumoÃÑ ordeined to be receiued in both kindes. Latimer ≈øet at libertie. ≈øhould be receiued of all men vnder bothe kyndes of breade and wyne.

This yere al≈øo anone after the kynges coronatioÃÑ Mai≈øter Hughe Latimer a famous preacher, who had bene long detayned in mi≈øerable captiuite for ye Go≈øpels ≈øake by the procurement of the Popi≈øhe by ≈øhoppes, was deliuered and ≈øet at lybertie.

In this yere the la≈øt day of Marche FrauÃÑcis theThe death of the ‚Ä¢ renche King. Frenche kyng ended his lyfe in the .xxxiii. yeare of his reigne, after that he had admony≈øhed his onely ≈øonne Henry of the thynges pertaining to his kingdome and commended hym to true officers and ≈øeruauntes. After whome ≈øucceded the ≈øame Henry being the ≈øeconde of that name. His body was caried after .x. dayes to the brydge of S. Clodoalde, and from thence to the ≈øuburbes of Paris, into the Churche called the virgine of the fieldes: where by the commaundement of the kyng were brough the bodyes, of Frauncis the Dolphyne Duke of Britaigne, who dyed in the yere of. 1536. before, in the moneth of Augu≈øt: And of Charles his brother, Duke of Orleans, whiche dyed in the yere of our lorde. 15 45. in the moneth of September, that they myght accompany the body of their father to his buriall: And ≈øo were the ≈øayde thre bodyes brought with great pompe and ≈øolempnitie into the Churche of the ble≈ø≈øed virgin at Parys, and from thence to S. Denis, where they were buried, the body of the father being layde betwene his ≈øonnes.

This Frauncis the Frenche kyng was hyghly
commended for diuers ≈øingular giftes bothe of the mynde and of the body wherewith he was endued, but chiefly for his humanite and clemencie whiche he v≈øed towardes all men. He was beneficiall to meÃÑ endued with vertue, and liberall to men of lernyng. For by his benefite were the Latine, Greke and He brue tonges re≈øtored agayn to their puritie in FrauÃÑ ce, whereof he entertained & nori≈øhed publike profe≈ø≈øours, ordeining for them mo≈øt ample ≈øtipendes‚ñ™ his other actes are here omitted to auoide prolix ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e

In the moneth of December at Paris was S. Michaels bridge broken by the great power & violence of the waters ≈øo that the Ea≈øt part thereof fel downe quite, & the hou≈øes which were built theron were ouer throwen with a great parte of them that were annexed vnto them.

IN the yere of our Lorde. 1548. in the moneth
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚ñ™ of Iuly themperour ≈øent an army of Spanyardes priuely to inuade the citie of Conitaunce‚ñ™ while the legates of Con≈øtaunce that were ≈øent to Augu≈øt vnto themperour to intreate for peace were not yet retourned homewarde. For he intended quite to extingui≈øh the citie becau≈øe they profe≈ø≈øed y‚Ä¢ Go≈øpell. Wherfore the ≈øixt day of Augu≈øt early in y‚Ä¢ mornyng the ≈øaid army inuaded y‚Ä¢ citie, & ouercame the ba≈ø≈øe towne which ioyneth to y‚Ä¢ great bredge coÃÑ monly called Peter hou≈øen. When this was obtayned, and ouercome at their fir≈øt a≈ø≈øaulte, ≈øome fell to ≈øpoiling and rouing, ≈øome to deflouring of virgin ‚Ä¢ s and hone≈øt matrones, & ≈øome gat theÃÑ to the bridge, and there made a bartaill with the cite≈øens, whiche were con≈øtrained to re ‚Ä¢ ule back into the citie being
ouerpre≈ø≈øed with the multitude of their enemies vnto whoÃÑ they barred y‚Ä¢ gates of the bredge. The bridge was ful of Spani≈øh warriours, again≈øt whoÃÑ the cite≈øens could nothing preuayle vntil many peces of artillery whiche kept the bridge being lo≈øed by chaunce, but yet not without the will of God per ≈øed the gate & ouerthrewe the enemies, & put theÃÑ in ≈øuch feare yt they fled euerychone, ≈øetting the bridge on fyre & al≈øo Peterhou≈øen, lea≈øt the cite≈øens ≈øhould haue folowed & pur≈øued after them. So that Con≈øtaunce ≈øawe in one daye y‚Ä¢ iu≈øte puni≈øhmeÃÑt of pride, & the ≈øingular benefite of God towardes his electe, would to God they had not vnthankefully forgotten this great benefite.

Themperour after that he had in Germany ≈øetThe Emperour retourneth out of Germany into FlauÃÑders The Duke of Saxon captiue. Leonora retourned to themperoure The ≈øonne of Ferdinando marieth them perours daughter. all thinges in ordre, & propounded a certain fourme in religion after the pre≈øcripte whereof they ≈øhould liue while a coun≈øaille were decreed, & hauing committed the Landgraue of He≈ø≈øen in ≈øafe cu≈øtody, re retourned into Flaunders bringing with hym the Duke of Saxon captiue.
Thither came Leonora Themperours ≈øi≈øter & late Quene to the Frenche king departed.

This yere Maximiliane the fir≈øt ≈øonne of Ferdinandus king of the Romaines toke to wife themperours daughter. This yere al≈øo y‚Ä¢ king of Spayne leauing his brother Maximiliane as gouernour in his ab≈øence, departed out of Spayn into Italy, & went froÃÑ thence to Trident & into Germany, & ≈øoThe elde≈øt ≈øonne of the Turke „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
keth in≈øurr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
tion ag ‚Ä¢ yn≈øt his father. at y‚Ä¢ la≈øt came into FlauÃÑders to his father theÃÑperour

The ≈øame yere towardes the ≈øpring time the fir≈øt begotteÃÑ ≈øonne of y‚Ä¢ Turke, which was gone ouer to y‚Ä¢ king of y‚Ä¢ Per≈øiaÃÑs, becau≈øe he thought his brother
≈øhould be by his father promoted before hym to the Empyre, a≈ø≈øembled an army of Per≈øianes, and made in≈øurrection again≈øt his father, and inuaded the borders of Turkie nere vnto the lande of Per≈øia, and had ouercome many places, vntyll his father beyng armed with fyue hundred thou≈øande ≈øouldiours came thither and cau≈øed the Per≈øianes, being ≈øtriken with feare, to recule. But they hauyng ≈øet on fyre all the townes and villages by the whiche they fled the ≈øpace of fyue dayes, brought their enemy whiche folowed and pur≈øued after them, too greate pennury, in ≈øo muche that an hundred thou≈øande of his men being dead thorough pouertie famine and pe≈øtilence, he was con≈øtrained of nece≈ø≈øitie to returne thither agayne from whence he came‚ñ™

A certayne king in Aphrica toke Argieres andArgiers takeÃÑ
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
the other places there about, with certayne ca≈øtels and ≈øtrong holdes whiche themperoure v≈øed for the defence of Spayne: and al≈øo certaine ≈øtrong holdes in the coa≈øtes of Portingall towardes the ≈øea occeane.

‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cor ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ all. The ma≈ø≈øe & Images put downe in Englande. of ru≈øtikes in Cornuall, by p ‚Ä¢ py≈øh prie≈øtes.
There was al≈øo great di≈øputation in the ParliameÃÑt that yere for putting downe of the ma≈ø≈øe. And Images were put downe in al churches thorough out Englande to auoyde Idolatry.

This yere the la≈øt daye of Iuly Stephen GardinerThe by≈øhop of Winche≈øter committed to thei our of ‚Ä¢ o „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . by≈øhop of Winche≈øter in Englande, was committed to the Towre of London for papi≈øme, and this ≈øedicious opinion, that the kynges maie≈øtie in his minoritie or none age coulde not make or ordeine
any lawes in his Realme, as did Io≈øias & other godly & vertues princes, and gouernours in their dominions.

This yere the mariage of prie≈øtes was grauntedThe mariage of prie≈øtes graunted lawfull. An in≈øurrection at Norwiche. lawfull in England by the Lawes of God, to the vtter aboly≈øhement of all Papi≈øticall ≈øodomitry.

This yere in augu≈øt was a great in≈øurrection of ru≈øtikes at Norwiche, one kite (a ru≈øtike) beyng their Capitayne‚ñ™ and the .xxvij. daye of Augu≈øt it was ended, foure thou≈øand beyng ≈ølayne, the victory geuen (through goddes grace) by the handes of Iohn the noble Erle of Warwyke.

The duke of Somer≈øet coÃÑ mitted to the tour of LoÃÑdoÃÑ. The death of the Pope. A wonderful vi≈øion ≈øene be≈øydes Brun≈øwyke. men were ouercome, and very many of them ≈ølayn, be≈øydes many of their gentilmen taken.

This yere al≈øo Bonner by≈øhop of London was put from his by≈øhoprike for his ≈øtubborne Popy≈øhnes the fir≈øt day of October, and for certainte ob≈øtinate articles coÃÑmitted to the Mar≈øhal≈øee, the people muche reioy≈øyng at it.
In this moneth the Duke of Somer≈øet was coÃÑ mitted to the toure, to the great lamentacion of very many.
In this moneth al≈øo died the Pope of Rome called Paule the thyrde.

This yere the weke before Whit≈øontide, thre hone≈øt marchauntes and a younge lad, beinge hone≈øt mens ≈øonnes of Brun≈øwyke yourneyed from Andwarpe to Brun≈øwyke, there to heare at that fea≈øt goddes word preached. And as they rode on Whit≈øon euen after midnight halfway betwene Celle & Brun≈øwyke on a heath ouer gain≈øt a certayn farme, they „Äà2 pages missing„Äâ
nor yet Chri≈øt hym≈øelfe dyd knowe, namely, howe a man can ≈øerue twoo mai≈øters at ones, God and the wicked worlde. Item howe we can be good Chri≈øtianes & yet knowledge not Chri≈øt, nor helpe hym to beare his cro≈ø≈øe, yea rather per≈øecute hys poore membres, God geue vs grace to knowledge his ≈øon ne a ryght, ≈øuffre paciently all miuries and endure to the ende, that he may al≈øo at the great and fearefull day of the lorde knowledge vs before hys heauenly father, and hys vniuer≈øal churche, and before all hys aungels. Amen.

IN the yere of oure Lorde. 1550. the xix. dayeCapitayne Gambold ≈ølayne. of Ianuary Capitayne Gambolde, who was Capitayne of the Spanyardes that ≈øerued the kyng of Englande in his warres, and an other Capitaine was ≈ølayne without Newe gate in an euenyng, by a Spanyarde, whiche was taken and hanged the. xxiii ‚Ä¢ . daye of Ianuary, and thre more with hym.

the .xxviij. day of the ≈øame moneth was Humfrey arundell and Bury with two other mo drawne hanged and quartered, for becau≈øe they were the the≈øe capitaynes and mayntayners of the rebellion among the Corny≈øhe and Deuon≈øhyre men.The duke of Somer≈øet delyuered out of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ A generall p „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚Ä¢ etmene Englande ‚Ä¢ Frannce.
The ≈øixt day of February came the Duke of Somer≈øet out of the Tower, with greate reioyiyng of muche people.

In the ≈øame moneth went out of Englande certayne lordes of the coun≈øaill to Buileine, where certayne of the Frenche coun≈øayll met with them and after long con≈øultacion had and dyuers metynges betwene them, there was a generall peace conciuded,
whiche peace was proclaimed the .xxix. daye of Marche folowyng.
Al≈øo about the .xxv. day of Apryll folowyng theBullayne delyuered. towne of Bullayne with the fortre≈ø≈øes thereto belongyng was delyuered by the Engly≈øhemen, into the Frenchemens handes.

The ≈øecond daye of May was brent at London30 one Boocher in ≈ømythfielde a certayne woman called Ione Boocher otherwy≈øe called Ione of Barkyng for the horrible here≈øy of the Apellites, Cerdonians, proclianites, Valentinians, Manichees, Timotheans, Apolinarianes, Ne≈øtorianes, & ≈øedicious Anabapti≈øtes of our tyme, whiche ≈øhe helth commen with all them, of a ≈øet wilfulne≈ø≈øe, for all tho≈øe hereticall patriarkes was ≈øhe ≈øure to haue as mai≈øters and doctours of her pernicious errour, that Chri≈øt toke no fle≈øhe of the virgine, as largely apeareth in the cronicles.
About this tyme there were certayne lyght per≈øones pretendyng a newe commotion in Kent, but they were appreheÃÑded and dyuers of them for that tre≈øpas hanged.

It is ≈øayde that this yere the .xxi. daye of MarcheA wonderful miracle oftor ue fallyng downe from the element. in the countie of Carinte be≈øydes the Lande of Bauariam Au≈øtryche by and aboute a lyttel towne called Claghenforth, it rayned corne out of the element by the ≈øpace of two houres, which rayne ≈øtretched in lenght .vi. Germayn myles, and in breedth halfe a Germayne myle in ≈øome places: ≈øo that the ≈øayd corne beyng ≈øome white and ≈øome browne lay in ≈øome places the thickenes of an hand broade vpoÃÑ the grouÃÑde. WhereupoÃÑ the people of the lande came
and gathered of the ≈øayde corne, and brought it to the mylles, and baked thereof good & ≈øauery bread. the ≈øignificacion of whiche mi≈øtery is re≈øerued to God alone, to whome be honoure glory and pray≈øe in all thynges for euer and euer. Amen.
This yere the kyng of Spayne went home agayne out of Flaunders.

This yere al≈øo there was a cruel proclamatioÃÑ ≈øetA mo≈øte ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nnicall per≈øecution. furth by the vniuer≈øitie of Louayne in the name of the Emperoures Maie≈øtie, for the per≈øecution of the faithfull Chri≈øtianes, condempning al maner of ≈øcripture bookes as well Bibles as other in what tonge ≈øo euer they were written or tran≈ølated that had bene printed within the ≈øpace of .xxx. yeres before, with mo≈øte extreme death pro≈øecutinge all the fauourours of the doctrine ≈øet furth by Martine Luther. Iohn Ecolampadius, Hulderike zwinglius, Iohn Caluine, or their ad herentes and condempning them for heretikes and their doctrine for mo≈øte pernicious and pe≈øtilent here≈øy without any probable argumentes or good rea≈øons.

p.hi: After this themperoure went vp agayne into Germany.

div.head: The conclu≈øion,
div.p:
THus haue I, Chri≈øten reader, brefe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ comprehended the principall Storie ‚Ä¢ whiche I haue founde and thought nece≈ø≈øary, as they haue bene done here & there thoroughout Chri≈øtendom the≈øe. xviij yeres la≈øt pa≈øt. Howe be it if ought ≈øeme to be omitted and left out (whiche is a thyng that may lyghtely chaunce to any man) I be≈øeche you that it be not interpretated in the wor≈øt parte, coÃÑ≈øideryng that I haue done my diligence to ≈øet furth y‚Ä¢ truthe. Wherfore yf I haue bene truely infourmed it is wel. Al≈øo if it fortuned y‚Ä¢ in the ≈øayd Story were made meÃÑcion of any man, vnto whoÃÑ it might apeare, that iniury were done vnto hym, in that he is not ≈øo muche coÃÑmended as ≈øome other, & woulde therefore be angry, let hym remembre i ‚Ä¢ , at the faulte is not in me but in hym≈øelfe. For it becometh an hi≈øtoriographer or Story writer to declare the truthe in all thynges. Wherfore if men v≈øe hone≈øtie, their pray≈øe ≈øhalbe the more, but if they walke inordinately, they de≈øerue no pray≈øe at all. For the actes and hi≈øtories that are written ought to edifye and profyte them that come after, that they maye thereby learne what ought to bee e≈øchued, and what to be folowed, whiche thynge without ≈øure and certayne declaracion of the truth can not be done. Therefore let ≈øuche men be angry wyth them ≈øelues, yf they bee greued at the matter, con≈øideryng that they haue done nothyng
and ‚Ä¢ thy of commendacion: And let them from henthe ‚Ä¢ rth endeuoure them ≈øelues by hone≈øt conuer≈øathe ≈øi ‚Ä¢ and Chri≈øten behaueour to couer their ≈øhame. God ‚Ä¢ then ≈øhall all thynges be counted vnto them coÃÑ u ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ endable, for ≈øomuche as euery thynge that is pa≈øt, is rather imputed to the tyme and to fortune, then to the will of the per≈øon, when the ≈øame is perceiued and knowen to haue for≈øaken the euyll whiche heA mo≈øte T ‚Ä¢ annicall per≈øecution. v≈øed in tymes pa≈øt and to folowe hone≈øtie and goodnes. And although I haue ab≈øtayned from all that myght be tedious and bitter, as muche as the truth myght ≈øuffre, yet hath the common cour≈øe of the worlde moued me to make he re this exceptioÃÑ: For y‚Ä¢ Deuil alwayes wil be prai≈øed in his wicked dedes, but the di≈øcrete Chri≈øtianes nede no ≈øuche commendations. Wherfore al≈øo I commende me ≈øelfe next vnder God to the defence and prayer of all the fauourers of the truthe byndyng me ≈øelfe to do the lyke for them to my power. Dated the twenty day of Augu≈øt. 1550. ‚∏´

BReuely to clo≈øe vp this pre≈øent chronicle. This yere is the ful .xxxi. Iubilie from chri≈øtes incarnacion, declaring vnto vs chri≈øtianes here in Englande, by many mo≈øt graciou≈øe and godly argumeÃÑtes, the glad iubilie of the lord, what though not to the pagane Papi≈øtes, arrogauÃÑt Ana bapti≈øtes, licenciou≈øe lybertines, cruell coueters, excedyng extorcioners, fre wyll men, new Iu≈øticiaries, and ≈øprete ≈øpeakers, with other ≈øediciou≈øe ≈øectaries, all ≈øekyng to take the glory from Chri≈øt and to deminy≈øh the frutes of his helthful ≈øufferinges. To make this to you more familiar, the kynges mo≈øte excellent maie≈øtie, by a≈ø≈øent of his noble coun≈øel, and fre vtteraunce of faithful mini≈øters by them apointed, haue this yeare proclaymed a godly chri≈øten fredome to the longe captiued con≈øciences of his natural and obedient ≈øubiectes (I ≈øpeake nothing of the forenamed ob≈øtinates) none otherwi≈øe than dyd Moy≈øes to the children of I≈øraell, Leuit. 25. and noble kyng Io≈øias to their po≈øteritie vnder hym. 2. Paralip. 34. the temples and aulters in ≈øundry places de≈øtroied, and the true chri≈øtiante in many pointes re≈øtored. Con≈øidre the lent preachynges that were this yeare afore the kyng, the delyueraunce of the duke of Somer≈øet, the change in London dyoce≈øe, the nece≈ø≈øary ≈øeque≈øtracion of Gardyner, Bonner, Hethe, and other proude popi≈øh Babylonians, the godly di≈øcour≈øe of Peter Martir the inexpugnable defence of the Archeby≈øhop of Caunterbury for ye full ouerthrowe of Idolatry, with other good chaunces more whiche are apparaunt though they be not named, are manife≈øt tokens of the premy≈ø≈øes,
and ≈øpeciall good argumentes of this Iubylie of grace. Let vs therefore with our noble yonge Io≈øias be thankefull vnto God in the latter parte of this yeare holdyng holy in ≈øoule the perfyght pa≈ø≈øeouer of the lorde. And let vs ≈øtyll valiauntly fight with the two edged ≈øworde again≈øt the maliciou≈øe kyng of Egypte or bla≈øphemou≈øe By≈øhop of Rome and all his trayterou≈øe trayne, after the Godly example of the fir≈øt Io≈øias. 2. Paralip. 35. So be it.
